webTitle: United fans on a yellow card at Boro

fields.headline: United fans on a yellow card at Boro
fields.trailText: The fall-out from Monday's impassioned seven-goal thriller at the Riverside stadium yesterday saw the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson springing to the defence of Manchester United's Roy Keane - booed from the pitch when taken off after receiving a late yellow card - whereas Boro ground officials hinted that misbehaving United fans faced further restrictions in future.
fields.body:
The fall-out from Monday's impassioned seven-goal thriller at the Riverside stadium yesterday saw the Middlesbrough manager Bryan Robson springing to the defence of Manchester United's Roy Keane - booed from the pitch when taken off after receiving a late yellow card - whereas Boro ground officials hinted that misbehaving United fans faced further restrictions in future.

United's ticket allocation had been cut to below 50% for the game, after trouble last season, with the stadium's safety advisory group worried about potential trouble.

In the event about a dozen United fans were ejected by stewards during an often bad-tempered match and yesterday a Boro spokesman, Dave Allan, said: "About 60% of Manchester United fans remained seated during the game but there was a hard core who gave the stewards a torrent of abuse and refused to sit down.

"The issue will be considered at the next meeting of the safety group."

But Robson, himself a former United captain, refused to join in the criticism of the current wearer of the Old Trafford armband, Keane, who enraged the home crowd by clashing with Mark Summerbell, Hamilton Ricard and Christian Ziege in quick succession before being pulled off.

"Keane is a committed player," he said. "He's a winner and that's why he reacts sometimes the way he reacts. I have no complaints about the tackles or anything."

Meanwhile Everton have asked Leicester for closed-circuit video footage from Saturday's 1-1 draw at Filbert Street in an attempt to identify travelling supporters who hurled racist abuse at Leicester's Muzzy Izzet in the wake of the stabbing of two Leeds supporters in Istanbul.

Everton plan to ban for life any fans they can identify who taunted the London-born midfielder, who has opted to play for his father's native Turkey in Euro 2000.

The incident made front-page news in two Istanbul papers this week and the Goodison club are upset that it is being used as evidence of intolerance towards Turkey and players with Turkish links.

The club chairman Sir Philip Carter, who has already written letters of apology to both Leicester and Izzet, said: "We are more than anxious to obtain any information we can because we have [an anti-racism] 'No entry to Goodison' campaign which means if we do identify individuals then we will kick them out."

fields.headline: Tribal warfare
fields.standfirst:
The Force of Change
Royal Court Upstairs, London
*****
fields.trailText: Gary Mitchell has done it again. Only better. Last year, in Trust, he wrote a gripping play about the destructive impact of the Northern Irish Protestant ethic on its own children. Now in this even more nail-biting work he shows how both policing and terrorism are dominated by a boys' club atmosphere and by a series of interlocking collusions.
fields.body:
Gary Mitchell has done it again. Only better. Last year, in Trust, he wrote a gripping play about the destructive impact of the Northern Irish Protestant ethic on its own children. Now in this even more nail-biting work he shows how both policing and terrorism are dominated by a boys' club atmosphere and by a series of interlocking collusions.

His setting is an RUC station and adjacent interview rooms. In one, Caroline, a married detective sergeant on the fast track to promotion, has five hours in which to nail down a UDA hard man: she is clearly not being helped by her sidekick, a resentful old sweat with 30 years in the force. Meanwhile two of her male colleagues are trying to break down a joyriding UDA messenger in the hope he will implicate the terrorist next door. The two interrogations are inter- dependent; but when Caroline's partner is left alone with the suspect, it looks as if the whole edifice may fall apart.

What Mitchell does is to show how the tribal politics of Northern Ireland create both resistance to change and a network of matching relationships. Reactionary males in the RUC close ranks against high flying women like Caroline. The dominant male ethos even leads to a curious unspoken complicity between cop and criminal. And we are reminded that loyalist extremists and IRA hardliners are mirror-images of each other. One of the tragedies of Northern Ireland, Mitchell implies, is that it is made up of equally entrenched groups all sustaining each other.

What is most striking, however, is the way it keeps subverting our moral certainties. It is not simply about a lone woman battling against a pervasive male ethos: at times the heroine's interrogation technique looks suspect. And, even though the play attacks tribal codes, Mitchell shows that the RUC's protection of its own has positive as well as negative implications. It is also chillingly well acted in Robert Delamere's bowstring-tight production. Cathy White as the pressurised heroine, Sean Caffrey as her fallible sidekick, Stuart Graham as the young rival and Stephen Kennedy as the mute UDA terrorist are all first-rate.

Until April 29, box office: 0171 565 5000. This review appeared in some editions yesterday. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: Crunch time comes for net stocks

fields.headline: Crunch time comes for net stocks
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The heavy sell-off of technology stocks continued yesterday with London's Techmark index closing down 8%.
fields.body:
The heavy sell-off of technology stocks continued yesterday with London's Techmark index closing down 8%.

Techmark's 353.06 point drop to 4008.24 exceeded the early sell-off on Nasdaq as nervous UK investors bailed out of internet and technology equities and back into old economy stocks. Only two Techmark 100 index stocks closed up. In Germany, selling wiped 6.9% off the Neuer Markt.

In early US trading the Nasdaq index fell for the second day running, losing about 6% of its value until buyers moved in during afternoon trading.

High-profile casualties in London included Geo Interactive, off 20% at £16.80, and QXL.com, 16% lower at 405p. Among old-economy winners were Tarmac, up 35%, and Debenhams, 14% higher.

Yesterday's trading extends more than a month of almost continuous selling of technology stocks. West LB Panmure says that since March 6 the European internet sector has fallen in value by €82bn to €135bn. Analysts believe the period will be a crucial test for the evolution of the European internet sector.

Miles Saltiel, technology analyst at West LB Panmure, says that while the technology bubble might not be bursting the sector is undergoing a severe correction.

He argues that the sell-off of European internet stocks, which has been going on since March 6, should be seen in the context of the cyclical character of technology markets.

Nasdaq, the world's largest and oldest technology market, has seen five full cycles of bull run and correction since 1995.

Each of those cycles was propelled by a particular investment theme, and when the frantic buying came to an end the vogue business models of the day were severely tested by heavy selling and many failed to survive the shake-out. Previous bull runs have featured access and browsers, search engines and portals.

The latest has focused on business to consumer (B2C) e-commerce and Mr Saltiel warns that history could repeat itself. "It is at this point that the losers are winnowed out as they never come back."

At this time indiscriminate selling hits quality and weak stocks, and it takes months to establish which companies have the strength to bounce back in time for the next cycle.

Leading B2C plays such as QXL and Lastminute.com have been hardest hit in recent weeks. The latter closed down a further 10p at 193.5p yesterday, compared to a first-day high of 555p almost a month ago.

Popular shares such as Interactive Investor, Gameplay.com and Infobank are among the worst five performers.

Mr Saltiel says: "We see this as a signal that unsatisfactory business models and inept practitioners may expect severe punishment. Some in this subsector may recover, but very few; we see them as underperformers."

Free internet service providers such as Freeserve, which has lost almost two-thirds of its value since early March, have also struggled. Their business model is under attack from all sides as the move to unmetered access speeds up and interconnect revenues - previously a crucial cash stream - become a thing of the past.

Pure Entertainment, an AIM-listed computer games company, is the only UK internet stock to have risen during the period, adding 12%. Mr Saltiel believes companies focused on providing tools for the web have the clearest recovery prospects.

"Derelict business models -free service ISPs, first generation B2C plays - may never get back off the floor. More robust sectors, in particular tools, will certainly do so."

Nasdaq's performance is likely to be a crucial factor in determining when Europe returns to health.

During the past five cycles on Nasdaq, technology stocks have taken two to five months to recover.

However, the most recent cycle, which began on August 10, 1998, has been unusual. It has lasted more than 50% longer than any previous run and stocks have registered far bigger gains than any before.

Analysts say the potential for the most sizeable correction yet is clear. However, what worries the City is how the relatively immature European technology market will react. It has 142 listed internet companies worth €135bn (£82bn) whereas a large portion of the 4,722 companies listed on Nasdaq with a combined worth of $6.5 trillion (£4 trillion) are internet-related plays.

Two countries, Britain and Germany, dominate the European market, accounting for more than 50% of stocks. Nearly four-fifths of companies come from just two sectors: software/tools and access. Nasdaq's stocks are more evenly spread across sectors.

For investors nursing losses from the likes of Lastminute.com and World Online, the Dutch ISP which has collapsed spectacularly since its float, the big question is where to flee to. Most internet analysts remain neutral on the sector and urge buyers to be cautious. Many fund managers are returning to old- economy stocks altogether.

Mr Saltiel is recommending clients shun traditional ISPs and first-generation e-commerce plays in favour of companies that build tools and software for the internet age.

He favours business-2-business plays and content companies which are in a position to take advantage of the introduction of broadband technology.

webTitle: Women managers still hitting the glass ceiling

fields.headline: Women managers still hitting the glass ceiling
fields.standfirst: Opportunity Now
fields.trailText: More women can be found in junior and middle management, but the number reaching the boardroom has remained static, according to a new report published by the Opportunity Now campaign.
fields.body:
More women can be found in junior and middle management, but the number reaching the boardroom has remained static, according to a new report published by the Opportunity Now campaign.

Just 8% of executive directors are women but the campaign, launched by Business in the Community in 1991 to encourage organisations to recruit and retain a balanced workforce, welcomed the rise in the number of women found in junior and middle management as a vital achievement.

Opportunity Now also found that only a handful of employers monitor the number of ethnic minority women they employ and highlighted this as one of the biggest areas for improvement.

More than 75% of the 204 organisations which responded to this year's survey regularly discuss gender issues at boardroom level, with a rise of almost 15% in the number of organisations with formal policies in place to support gender-related goals and 40% of respondents are now developing ways of measuring line managers' performance on gender issues.

Over half of the employers who took part in the survey now offer equal opportunities awareness training for staff - up more than 13% on last year.

Campaign chairman and Marks & Spencer executive director Clara Freeman said: "The growth in the number of employers treating the retention of women as a serious business issue is impressive and I would like to see it rise significantly again next year.

"Many of our member organisations are introducing formal measures to ensure that equality for all staff is not undermined by outdated attitudes about women or old-fashioned working cultures."

The survey also reveals a slight drop in the number of senior women in the education sector.

A quarter of the responses came from central and local government employers and more than 15 other industry sectors were represented.

The top performers in this year's index were the inland revenue national insurance contributions office, Littlewoods and Liverpool Hope University College.

fields.headline: Equities stand test of time
fields.standfirst: Patrick Collinson on market forces
fields.trailText: Want to be a millionaire? Simple. Put £100 into shares and wait 100 years. The market will reward you with more than £1m.
fields.body:
Want to be a millionaire? Simple. Put £100 into shares and wait 100 years. The market will reward you with more than £1m.

But put the same money into government bonds and take the annual income - and see your investment shrivel to just £1 a century later.

Yesterday Barclays Capital unveiled its annual review of investment returns and again gave succour to equity salespeople across the City.

The figures show that buying equities is almost a no-brainer: only during price deflation in the 1920s and 1930s was it a better idea to buy gilts, and even then they only marginally outperformed equities.

In the two decades of the 20th century when shares lost money - the 1910s and the 1970s - gilts lost even more.

The headline figures show £100 invested on January 1, 1900 was worth £1.28m by the end of 1999. Stripping out inflation, the £100 became £24,962.

Gilts managed a miserable £14,054, or £273 after inflation, and £1 after reinvested income is taken out of the equation.

The analysis accompanying the data promises another good 10 years for equities, with technology boosting economic efficiency and keeping inflation low.

Added to that is the increasing numbers of 35- to 55-year-olds in the US and Europe who, Barclays Capital says, are not only the mostly productive segment of the population but also save lots of money for their pensions, fuelling demand for equities.

After that it all becomes a lot murkier. Not only does the UK population start dropping (a 2.2m fall by 2050, says Barclays) but it also retires: in 2050 each UK pensioner will be supported by two workers, compared to four today.

fields.headline: Debenhams to open four portals
fields.trailText: Department store chain Debenhams yesterday detailed ambitious plans for Internet sales which will involve four portals and a series of strategic partnerships to exploit their potential.
fields.body:
Department store chain Debenhams yesterday detailed ambitious plans for Internet sales which will involve four portals and a series of strategic partnerships to exploit their potential.

The company intends to have separate wedding, gifts, family/home and fashion portals.

It is pouring £6m into developing its e-commerce operations over the next two years and says it is in talks with a "major media company" about a deal regarding its family/home portal.

The company has already linked with American wedding service WeddingChannel.com for its wedding portal, which it said should break even within three years.

The group has 1,500 fashion lines available on its transactional website and claims 1.5m page views in February.

Debenhams described its online strategy as a "quantum leap" designed to "get greater exposure for the Debenhams product through the Internet".

Chief executive Terry Green said he expected to generate £5m of sales through the web this year and £10m in 2001.

The chain also reported first-half profits down from £79.4m to £73.8m. But the shares moved up 22.5p to 178.5p because the results were better than expected. The shares are well up on the 130p they hit in March but still far below their 12-month peak of 500p.

A Debenhams spokesman said the company was not panicking about its share price, and blamed the downturn on the general malaise which has engulfed the retail sector.

"We think we are doing all we can do," the spokesman said. "Hopefully the sector, and Debenhams, will fall back into favour.

"All we can do is continue with our strategy, continue doing a good job and make sure we are top of investors' shopping lists when they want to buy retail shares again, which one day they will."

webTitle: Tesco survives price war to post record profit

fields.headline: Tesco survives price war to post record profit
fields.trailText: Supermarket group Tesco reinforced its reputation as Britain's premier retailer yesterday with record sales, better than expected profits and details of plans to set up its internet and home delivery operations as a separate company.
fields.body:
Supermarket group Tesco reinforced its reputation as Britain's premier retailer yesterday with record sales, better than expected profits and details of plans to set up its internet and home delivery operations as a separate company.

It also announced expansion plans in the UK and overseas that will create 20,000 jobs - 8,000 of them in Britain.

In a year when the grocery business has been waging aggressive price wars, Tesco's sales rose 9.8% to top £20bn for the first time, and it recorded profits ahead 10.8% at £933m. After a lengthy investigation the competition commission recently ruled that the supermarkets are not making excessive profits.

Tesco, which has 15.5% of the UK grocery market, said its prices had fallen 7.5% in the past four years and price cuts had cost it £380m last year - but it recouped that and more through increased sales and cost cutting.

"We've had to devote a substantial amount of senior management time to the competition commission inquiry. But we have kept our eye on the ball and remain focused on getting cheaper, offering even better value and providing more choice, service and convenience for our customers", said the group's deputy chairman, David Reid. "We are firing on all cylinders."

The group is targeting non-food goods for special development. It has just over £2bn of that £75bn market but aims to rake in £5bn within two years.

Yesterday, in the wake of the competition commission ruling that UK car buyers are being overcharged, Mr Reid said Tesco would consider moving into that market. "We have no current plans but it is all fair game".

Tesco Direct service is now the world's biggest online grocer and the UK's second biggest e-tailer. The average order is £75, compared to £25 in-store.

Annualised sales of £125m last year are expected to grow to £350m by the end of this year as the number of stores offering the service is expanded from 100 to 300.

It will now become part of Tesco.com, a 100% owned subsidiary of the main grocery chain.

The internet service provider, which already has 400,000 users, will be headed by its own chief executive, John Browett, and receive investment of £35m this year.

But it had no plans to float the new offshoot with a separate listing.

Many of the 8,000 new UK jobs will be linked to the growth of Tesco Direct and construction of five hypermarkets.

"We are firing on all cylinders." The group is targeting non-food goods for special development. It has just over £2bn of that £75bn market but aims to rake in £5bn within two years. Yesterday, in the wake of the competition commission ruling that UK car buyers are being overcharged, Mr Reid said Tesco would consider moving into that market. "We have no current plans but it is all fair game". Tesco Direct service is now the world's biggest online grocer and the UK's second biggest e-tailer. The average order is £75, compared to £25 in-store. Annualised sales of £125m last year are expected to grow to £350m by the end of this year as the number of stores offering the service is expanded from 100 to 300. It will now become part of Tesco.com, a 100% owned subsidiary of the main grocery chain. The internet service provider, which already has 400,000 users, will be headed by its own chief executive, John Browett, and receive investment of £35m this year. But it had no plans to float the new offshoot with a separate listing. Many of the 8,000 new UK jobs will be linked to the growth of Tesco Direct and construction of five hypermarkets.

fields.headline: Truth, New York style
fields.standfirst:
Weegee
Museum of Modern Art, Oxford
*****
fields.trailText: We have all seen photographs by Weegee of mid-20th-century New York, the crowd on Coney Island beach, the dead gangsters outside the Italian restaurants, the summer hydrant showers. But this huge retrospective, the fullest there has even been in Britain, is something else. Pictures you may have loved or just been aware of as part of New York's atmosphere, become hallucinatory, to the extent of raising a question about their authorship. It's not that the identity of the man who pointed the camera, born Usher Fellig in Poland in 1899, is in doubt. The question is who or what is working through him.
fields.body:
We have all seen photographs by Weegee of mid-20th-century New York, the crowd on Coney Island beach, the dead gangsters outside the Italian restaurants, the summer hydrant showers. But this huge retrospective, the fullest there has even been in Britain, is something else. Pictures you may have loved or just been aware of as part of New York's atmosphere, become hallucinatory, to the extent of raising a question about their authorship. It's not that the identity of the man who pointed the camera, born Usher Fellig in Poland in 1899, is in doubt. The question is who or what is working through him.

There's shot after shot of people gunned down, decapitated, drowned or burned. The decapitation photograph is terrifying as you slowly recognise the cabbage-like object in the street. It's not just the efficiency of Weegee as a photojournalist that makes these pictures uncanny but the way the people of New York share their dreams and terrors with his camera.

The power of Weegee's photographs is in their oscillation between drama and mundaneness not just from image to image - but in the texture of each shot. That's why it's great to see the original, crinkled, oily prints rather than reproductions. The iconography of his photographs is that of 40s and 50s film noir, yet Weegee's streets are grimier, cracked, littered; in one two-shot sequence he even captures a street's destruction by gas explosion. You feel you are seeing not the myth of New York but the truth, which trumps the myth by miles.

There seems to be some unconscious connection between Weegee and the collective life of Manhattan. The way people look at him in that Coney Island beach photograph, waving, sitting on each other's shoulders, probably shouting a few obscenities, gives tangible form to the idea of a "community". With all the violence and horror, it's this that shines out of Weegee's photographs. When he captures an Easter promenade in Harlem, or children dancing in a hydrant shower on a July day, you envy these people their passionate common life. Even in the pictures of murders people stare together at a corpse, weeping, laughing, or just gawping.

Weegee has himself photographed alone at the wheel of his car, cruising the city like Travis Bickle in Taxi Driver. But unlike Scorsese's anti-hero of urban alienation, Weegee makes a connection with the people he meets in the night. I Cried When I Took This Picture, he titles a shot of witnesses at a fire weeping for relatives and friends, and you know he did.

Until July 2. Details: 01865 722733. ***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

webTitle: A new look at old styles

fields.headline: A new look at old styles
fields.standfirst:
Dave O'Higgins
Pizza Express, Dean Street, London
***
fields.trailText: The late Ronnie Scott may not have opted for the kind of rigorous haircut the British saxophonist Dave O'Higgins has just exposed himself to (at least until nature left him no choice) but in some ways there's a resemblance between them.
fields.body:
The late Ronnie Scott may not have opted for the kind of rigorous haircut the British saxophonist Dave O'Higgins has just exposed himself to (at least until nature left him no choice) but in some ways there's a resemblance between them.

Like Scott, O'Higgins was a teenage sax hero, one of the quick-witted young celebrities of the British jazz upswing of the late 80s that produced Courtney Pine, Andy Sheppard, Tommy Smith and many others. Like Scott, he has a feeling for both relaxed swing and romantic lyricism, he keeps his statements succinct, and he's a natural improviser. He also makes a pretty good job of that elusive jazzers' tradition, the downbeat announcement. "This is a tune in that popular idiom, jungle bossa", O'Higgins informed Monday's audience on his CD launch for The Grinder's Monkey. In a way it was, too.

O'Higgins has redesigned his band for this project, and borrowed from the engaging organ-groove feel of the 60s soul-jazz and hard-bop movement. The revival of hard-swinging saxophones over Hammond organ chords also became the staple material of the acid-jazz movement, but O'Higgins goes much further than just the mannerisms.

He appropriately dedicated a thumping mid-tempo opener to a master of bluesy tenor- playing, Stanley Turrentine. Then he rattled out of the jungle-bossa gag into a rumbling Latin American feature with a long, snakey soprano-sax theme over Winston Clifford's sonorous drumming. But it took until the third piece, the new disc's title track, for the band to loosen, with an appropriately Grant Green-like guitar solo from the excellent Mike Outram jacking up the pressure of Clifford's output into a restless stream of jolting backbeats and showers of dense cymbal sound. O'Higgins shifted a gear from the smooth currents of shapely melody he seems to be able to play in his sleep to a more raucous sound in a furious double-time. Keyboardist Jim Watson delivered some pretty convincing soul-jazz sermons on the organ and Moog, but his McCoy Tyner-like percussive chords and torrential right hand lines on the regular piano was a standout of the fast No Two Ways. Always a mature performer, even in his National Youth Jazz Orchestra days, Dave O'Higgins continues to rediscover familiar ground in revealing ways.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: The Rake's Progress
fields.standfirst:
Barbican Hall, London
***
fields.trailText: The Rake is progressing everywhere at the moment. English Touring Opera is taking its production of Stravinsky's only full-length stage work to far-flung corners of the country, as well as bringing it to London at the end of next month, while in the summer the celebrated John Cox/David Hockney production is due back at Glyndebourne. All that made this performance, conducted by Richard Hickox, rather superfluous. The concert hall can be a useful place to revive rarities or present established works with starry casts that could never be assembled in an opera house, but neither criterion applied here.
fields.body:
The Rake is progressing everywhere at the moment. English Touring Opera is taking its production of Stravinsky's only full-length stage work to far-flung corners of the country, as well as bringing it to London at the end of next month, while in the summer the celebrated John Cox/David Hockney production is due back at Glyndebourne. All that made this performance, conducted by Richard Hickox, rather superfluous. The concert hall can be a useful place to revive rarities or present established works with starry casts that could never be assembled in an opera house, but neither criterion applied here.

Not that the evening was short of a star - it's just that Philip Langridge's Tom Rakewell, still plausibly youthful and still sung with total freedom and naturalness, is a known quantity from disc and stage. The artistry is tremendous, but it's unlikely to surprise us now. And neither Laura Claycomb as Anne nor Peter Coleman-Wright as Nick Shadow could show their potential in this rather hit-and-miss semi-staging. She was careless with her words; he was rather too suave and genteel.

The London Symphony Chorus obviously enjoyed themselves as whores, roaring boys and lunatic; the City of London Sinfonia seemed less comfortable with a score that needs to be delivered as crisply as possible. Though Hickox tried to whip up some energy and pizzazz, the opera was never funny, never perceptive and never moving, even in the normally never-fail moments.

***** Unmissable **** Recommended *** Enjoyable ** Mediocre * Terrible

fields.headline: Barclays counters clients' complaints
fields.trailText: The government will today set out tough targets for banks to eradicate financial exclusion in the face of branch closures.
fields.body:
The government will today set out tough targets for banks to eradicate financial exclusion in the face of branch closures.

Melanie Johnson, economic secretary to the Treasury, is expected to take a robust stance against the banks in the week after Barclays shut 171 branches, leaving more than 60 high streets without a bank branch at all.

At the conference organised by the New Policy Institute, Barclays will counter criticism of the closures, pointing to statistics showing that use of the counters in its branches has fallen by 30% in two years.

Martin Mosley, consumer and community affairs director, intends to show that Barclays is helping to provide bank accounts to people on low incomes by outlining plans for a "basic" account. Such accounts, already offered by some banks such as Halifax and called for in a recent government report, do not allow customers to overdraw and so do not require credit references.

Mr Mosley said that Barclays was investigating whether such accounts, expected to be loss-making, could be opened away from its branches, particularly at benefits agencies.

Barclays, whose branch closures coincided with a torrent of negative publicity about its chief executive's pay, is one of three banks which has been called before the Treasury select committee of MPs.

NatWest, recently taken over by Royal Bank of Scotland, is not attending the meeting and is said to have told its rivals that it would not appear as it considered the hearings "inappropriate". Royal Bank denied the claim, citing a simple of clash of diaries.

fields.headline: Have you been absorbed?
fields.standfirst: In the first of his fortnightly columns, Britain's leading expert on workplace trends reports on how far employers will go to keep their staff at the office
fields.trailText: In the first of his fortnightly columns, Britain's leading expert on workplace trends reports on how far employers will go to keep their staff at the office
fields.body:
Say your company offers a new perk: a car-cleaning service, or a free manicure at your desk. Chances are you'll be thrilled. But beware. Your employer may have joined a new and sinister group - the Absorbers. These firms introduce schemes to make your life easier, on just one condition - that you hand it over to them; that you work 18-hour days and at weekends, eat, exercise, play, even sleep in the office in the service of their profits.

The heartland of the Absorbers is the US. The wooded New Jersey campus of the pharmaceutical company Merck has running paths and private dining rooms for entertaining friends and family. Texas Instruments' concierges will fix your car, Sun Microsystems does your dry cleaning for you, Netscape has a dentist on site. But the virus is spreading east. British Airways has created a "café culture" at its HQ, with paths and trees. Games rooms are de rigeur at trendy ad agencies. Gyms, subsidised restaurants and "meditation" rooms are proliferating. In what must be the most extreme case of Absorptiveness recorded, one company has even paid for a dating agency for its over-stretched staff. Can company concubines be far away?

Changing attitudes towards work is one reason for the trend, but there is a more fundamental explanation. It's the economy, stupid. With unemployment in the US hitting record lows, and some areas, such as Madison in Wisconsin, recording statistically implausible unemployment rates of 1.2%, employers are having to work harder to work their people harder. Here in the UK, too, the jobless rate is at an historical low point. Once the threat of being jobless diminishes, what's to keep you at work past 5pm? Without fear, bosses are turning to favour.

And it's working. The US is "enjoying" its ninth successive year of economic expansion, the longest in the nation's history. This year Americans also overtook the Japanese as putting in the longest working hours in the world. Surely no coincidence.

The message looks clear: question the motives behind any move to make your work environment more attractive. Maybe you're being conned into working longer hours. And that's bad. On the other hand, maybe it's not. Many jobs give people a high degree of autonomy, demand intellectual input and generate a real sense of achievement. Some create space for creativity. A few are even fun. More and more of us make our friends - and meet our mates - in the office. If you are a software designer or scriptwriter or campaigner, and you have the choice between 1) working an extra hour and picking up your clean clothes on the way out or 2) going home to do your own laundry, which would you pick?

This is the problem with the debate about "work-life balance". The very phrasing suggests a clear divide between our work and our life, when for most of us the boundary is far from clear - and not just because we take our lap-tops home: but because work can provide many of the benefits that are central parts of our "life" - friends, conversation, stimulation, long lunches, even, at its best, humour. As Susie Orbach put it at a recent Industrial Society seminar, for many people "work is where life is".

And while the workplace is growing in attractiveness, for many people home, or "life", is looking a bit gloomy. For dual-earner couples with children, life outside work is one of fixed timetables (daycare), conflict (whose turn is it to leave early to pick up the kids?), low-skill work (cooking, cleaning, nappy disposal) and thankless masters and mistresses (the kids). Home life has been industrialised just as paid work has enter a post-industrial era. No wonder we work long hours - for many people, "work" is a relief from the real work at home: a masculine secret that's been rumbled by women.

None of which is to say that as a society we can simply keep working more and more hours. Even if the economics make sense and the individual rationale is clear, the social consequences of an office-bound adult population are worrying. What happens to the children? And without a hinterland, what will people do with themselves in retirement? What price will we pay in terms of our health from working at high intensity? We can't let working hours grow unchecked - but we need to admit that sometimes, some of us work long hours because we want to.

If an extra warning is required, look again across the Atlantic, where the labour secretary, Alexis Herman, sets a chilling example to her fellow Americans. The newly married Herman, who returned to work about as quickly as she could get her wedding gown unzipped, was asked recently whether she would go on honeymoon with husband Chuck. "That's a goal," she said. "Now whether it will really happen is another matter." Chuck must feel real special.

It is rare that relabelling a problem makes it go away. "Differently abled" workers would rather, given the choice, have a ramp than a rebrand. Words fill the spaces left by the absence of action. The latest example is the vogue to refer to "ageing" workers, the latest version of old, elderly, "third age", and older. People in their 50s and 60s face clear discrimination and the government's efforts in this direction have been, at best, quarter-hearted.

But the new term is especially meaningless and therefore useless. In the future, some highly skilled workers may have their genes expensively modified by their companies to halt the process of ageing. But until then we are every one of us "ageing" from the day we are born. Surely we can do better than this. We could go for "people of many years" - which echoes "people of colour". Or, given that "wrinklies" is likely to be off the agenda, how about "chronologically challenged"? Don't bet against it.

What is German for partnership? According to wags in the motor industry, the precise translation is partnerschaft.

 Richard Reeves is director of futures at the Industrial Society. You can email him at: rvreeves@indsoc.co.uk.

fields.headline: Dream on
fields.standfirst: In the 80s sleep was for slackers. Now it's the new status symbol.  Angelique Chrisafis  finds out why everyone who's anyone is getting the full eight hours
fields.trailText: In the 80s sleep was for slackers. Now it's the new status symbol. Angelique Chrisafis finds out why everyone who's anyone is getting the full eight hours
fields.body:
Jeff Bezos, 35, chief executive of Amazon.com, sleeps eight hours a night. Marc Andreesen, 27, Netscape founder and chief technology officer at America Online, gets eight-and-a-half hours. Richard Branson needs eight to function properly. Tony Blair has to catch up if he has a late night. Glenda Jackson enjoys being in bed, Diana Rigg gets 10 hours and Ruth Lea, head of policy at the Institute of Directors, needs seven hours or she feels like she's underwater.

It's no shock that the high-powered have the same basic needs as the rest of us. What's new is that they are fulfilling them and falling over themselves to boast about it.

In the 1980s sleep was for slackers. Donald Trump slept three hours a night between parties and deals. Bill Gates said of Microsoft programmers: "They don't need much sleep. They will work 24 hours round the clock." Margaret "Four Hours" Thatcher may have saved her own life by staying up to work on her speech on the night of the Brighton bombing. Company directors were reminded that Leonardo da Vinci slept 15 minutes every four hours and that Napoleon, Voltaire, Edison and Churchill barely slept at all.

Last month the Wall Street Journal called sleep the new status symbol. At a time when most people complain that they stay at work too late, it's now a sign of class to refuse to sacrifice your normal brain function to the 24-hour industrial beast. Sleep snobs are dismissing the late-nighters as daft.

"The four-hours-a-night fad was hype, lies and absolute nonsense," says Lea. "Most directors average eight hours. They get in at 9.30am, work very hard and go home. Lately I have found that directors aren't complaining about sleep. They are sensible, normal people who try to get as much as they need."

There is also the suggestion that the four-hours boast of the 1980s may have been a slight exaggeration.

"John Major reckoned Margaret Thatcher cheated and had a rest for an hour during the day," says Edwina Currie. "He used to complain people expected four hours of him when he always needed seven."

Currie, 53, used to get by on six hours. She now gets seven and her mother, who is 80, says she's a much nicer person for it.

But there is a horrible smugness about the new refreshed executive. US anthropologist Lionel Tiger says that showing off about your eight hours is classic one-upmanship. "There is an implication in the 'sleep-a-lot' boast that you are so well organised and such a neat delegator that the world can persist adequately even while you are comatose. This is a tribute to how splendid you are when you are not comatose."

Executive sleep indulgence is also fashionably health-conscious. "Sleep is the new wheat allergy," says anthropologist Kate Fox of the Social Issues Research Centre in Oxford. "Bravado is out of fashion in the higher tiers of the workplace. Of course we're talking about the chattering classes. Working mothers don't have the luxury of sleeping for prestige."

The eight-hours-a-night brag by directors would be brilliant if it were accompanied by a nicer workplace which everyone left at 5pm. But it is not. If sleep is a status symbol, a class system is emerging in which the slumber-rich snuggle down at the expense of their exhausted staff. Amazon's Jeff Bezos does not schedule morning meetings, so he can have a leisurely breakfast with his wife. It's a luxury he can afford.

Many workers are sleeping less to ensure that their bosses get eight hours. When Richard Edelman, 44, head of the US firm Edelman Public Relations Worldwide, added his name to a Washington Post list of the latest eight-hour-kipping executives, his vice-president Bob Ambrose, 51, came forward to say he got up at 3am every day to get to the office at 5.30am in order to read the the newspapers and answer emails for his boss. "Because I am here I can take some of the pressure off," he told the paper.

Simon Folkard, a specialist in shift-work fatigue, says there is evidence to suggest that British workers are sleeping less than ever. Junior doctors still regularly sleep four-hour nights. One headteacher admits to working until 3am and sleeping bolt upright in an armchair to ensure he wakes at seven. Judi James, a business consultant, has found in stress-management workshops that the average British office worker goes to bed at 11 and wakes at 3.30am worrying about work.

"The executive sleep brag is elitist behaviour," says James. "It makes me sick to think that these executives are putting their heads down on their goose-down pillows. If it's meant to make executives seem more human and caring it does the exact opposite. To claim that you can run a company and bring up a family and still be able to switch off and have a good eight hours is like saying you're superhuman. It's smug and irritating.

"Status-sleeping at a time when UK workers are chronically sleep deprived is the equivalent of a slim person walking into a room full of porky people eating a cream bun."

James claims that the tidal wave of kindness that is supposedly sweeping the workplace as a backlash to stress is a myth. "There's not a sniff of it on the ground," she says. "In fact the draconian work practices of the 1980s are only just beginning. Downsizing means that companies are working on skeleton crews. It is now acknowledged that if you beat a horse, you will get a lot of hard work out of it, but if you feed it and groom it, it will work for longer. But this is not a sign of charity. It's just because people are cracking up under pressure and payouts are expensive for companies."

The reality of the sleeping executives is also more complicated than they might like to show. Bezos regularly works a 12-hour day which - combined with his breakfast needs and eight-hour sleep requirements - leaves little time for anything else. Branson admits that although he functions best on eight hours, he is often forced to get by on four to six. Trump is still going on his three hours. Martha Lane Fox, the co-founder of Lastminute.com, has proudly told newspapers that she has four hours a night. Robert Bonnier, the chief executive of Scoot. com, can manage only six.

In his book Sleep Thieves, psychologist Stanley Coren says sleep requirement is a crucial factor in image man agement. Because of this, you can never be completely sure that anyone, especially those at the top, are honest about the hours they sleep. Coren has found evidence that da Vinci actually liked his bed and Samuel Johnson once said: "I have, all my life long, been lying [in bed] till noon; yet I tell all young men, and tell them with great sincerity, that nobody who does not rise early will ever do any good."

It will always be part of office politics to boast about being efficient with sleep, just as it is big to say you sleep a lot when no one else can afford to, Coren argues.

Sandi Mann, an occupational psychologist, explains that workers are comparing sleep hours over the photocopier because people are programmed to talk about what they don't get enough of: sleep and sex. "As the number of working parents grows, working mothers and modern fathers who see to their babies in the night are appreciating the need for what they don't have, and that's sleep."

Judi James says that because sleep is a rare commodity, competition is growing among chief executives to get it. But, sadly, it means nothing to the rest of us. "Sleep is part of a new power posture. But I've sat through enough ethical management talks to see that for mere mortals, sleep is still a campaigning issue."

fields.headline: Flemings sale brings windfalls
fields.trailText: Retention packages for key Robert Fleming bankers were being put together last night after the 125-year-old investment bank confirmed its sale to Chase Manhattan of the US for £4.8bn.
fields.body:
Retention packages for key Robert Fleming bankers were being put together last night after the 125-year-old investment bank confirmed its sale to Chase Manhattan of the US for £4.8bn.

The sale, which values each of the privately-held shares at £27.44, will bring a £500m cash and shares bonanza for many of the bank's 7,500 staff and a £1.4bn windfall for the 60-strong Fleming family, which owned 30% of the bank.

Among those expected to reap the rewards of the sale are Michael Forsyth, the former Conservative Scottish minister, who joined the bank after losing his parliamentary seat.

Investment trusts will also benefit, such as those run by Scottish investment firm Murray Johnson, which yesterday said three of its oldest investment trusts had achieved a £100m uplift as a result of the transaction.

The price fetched by one of the last of the "blue blooded" merchant banks, to which the James Bond creator Ian Fleming was connected, was twice as much as the figure first mooted when information about talks between the two sides emerged last month.

However, insiders believe that the final figure failed to match the £30 per share level demanded by some members of the Flemings family, the younger members of whom were said to be eager to crystalise their stakes in the family firm to set up their own "dotcom" companies.

Roddie Fleming, who took over as chairman of the bank just last week, emphasised that the deal was about revenue growth, not cost savings, quashing any concerns about job losses after the transaction.

He will remain with the combined entity, which is to be known as Chase Flemings, until the transaction is formally completed; he has not made any commitment about how long he intends to stay.

Simon Ball, finance director of Flemings, said that the deal was completed at a time when Flemings, which owns Jardine Fleming in Asia, was making record profits, estimated at £300m before tax.

Countering claims that Chase had paid too much for Flemings, Don Layton, the vice-chairman of the US bank, insisted that the price had met Chase's financial criteria. The bank will pay half in cash or loan notes and half in shares, with shareholders able to pick and mix to minimise tax bills.

The transaction initially includes the US joint venture asset management business Rowe Price Fleming, but this is being bought out by its American management for $870m.

Meanwhile, the Fleming family will also set up a trust to buy the £7m-worth of art which adorns the walls of the bank's offices in the City - one of the largest collections of work by Scottish artists in private hands.

webTitle: Ten years make the heart grow fonder

fields.headline: Ten years make the heart grow fonder
fields.trailText: Bobby Robson has simply waited, confident, perhaps, that sooner or later time's wingéd chariot would eventually drop him off at the stop marked "National Treasure".
fields.body:
Lenny Bruce used to say that tragedy plus time equalled comedy. A similar formula might be proposed for sport. Here a villain can be turned into a beloved elder statesman simply by the addition of a decade or two. Such at least might be the conclusion of anyone comparing last week's respectful media coverage of Bobby Robson's preparations for the FA Cup semi-final with the jeering that greeted the same man's every utterance 10 years ago when he was England manager.

In any other walk of life transforming yourself from the desert prat into a wily old fox would require some extraordinary reversal of fortune - or death.

Sport, however, is different. The Newcastle manager has simply waited, confident, perhaps, that sooner or later time's wingéd chariot (recently passed fit for racing by the FIA, incidentally, after some initial problems with the width of the aerofoil) would eventually drop him off at the stop marked "National Treasure".

Where once Robson pronouncements such as "I want Bryan Robson to be Bryan Robson because that's the only Bryan Robson I want" and "I would have given my right arm to be a concert pianist" were derided as a sign that his mental acuity was not sharp enough, now they are met with indulgent smiles.

Not that I begrudge the Newcastle manager this upturn in respect in any way, I have always liked Robson, even during the dark days of Euro 88 when the only soft spot most people had for him was a patch of quicksand on Romney Marsh. Partly this is down to regional bias, but mainly it is because of his obvious enthusiasm for football.

And then, of course, there was his celebration of David Platt's winning goal against Belgium. This saw the then England supremo execute an exuberant hip-swinging rumba while simultaneously buttoning up his blazer, a combination of actions that to my mind sums up the contradictions of modern England more completely than any amount of Britart ever could.

It is possible, I suppose, that as a coach Bobby Robson has improved markedly since England's 1-1 draw with Tunisia in June 1990 led some tabloids to call for the team to withdraw from the forthcoming World Cup to spare us further embarrassment, but it seems unlikely. Robson was a good manager then and he is a good manager now. All that has changed is his age.

Clearly it helps that the former Ipswich boss is no longer in charge of the national team, a role that would dent even the popularity of Del-Boy Trotter, but it is not exclusively that. Brian Clough never managed England. Yet passage through the veil of tears has buffed his image up a treat.

Twenty-five years ago Old Big 'Ead's appearances on our TV screens were the cue for dogs to hide under tables, flying confectionery and yells of "put a sock in it, big mouth". Nowadays, by contrast, it is a signal for married couples across the land to grin fondly and slide closer together on the sofa.

Ray Wilkins might also serve as an example. When young, vigorous and still making regular trips to Superdrug to stock up on shampoo and conditioner he was generally perceived as a negative presence whose 84 caps for England summed up everything that was wrong with the national game. Then the former Milan midfielder's hair fell out and suddenly he had metamorphosed in the public eye into a cunning playmaker whose ilk we would never see again.

When I was growing up the likes of George Best and Rodney Marsh were held aloft in conservative journals as the scruffy and loutish product of the government's foolhardy decision to abolish national service. Nowadays the same newspapers celebrate them as glorious reminders of a golden past.

It must be a consolation to current objects of disapprobation such as Paul Gascoigne and Stan Collymore to know that they have only to make it past that threshold in the life of men when trousers with elasticated waistbands suddenly seem like "not such a bad idea, actually" to become well-respected figures within the game.

Dennis Wise. Yes, he could sometimes be a bit rough and ready but he always played the game with a smile on his face. Remember: you read it here first.

webTitle: Simpson takes on the final frontier

fields.headline: Simpson takes on the final frontier
fields.standfirst: The Australian coach is keen to add success at Lancashire to his career cv
fields.trailText: One of the more interesting news items coinciding with Bobby Simpson's return to England to take up a coaching post at Lancashire was a campaign to delay the retirement age to 70.
fields.body:
One of the more interesting news items coinciding with Bobby Simpson's return to England to take up a coaching post at Lancashire was a campaign to delay the retirement age to 70.

It would be tempting to present Simpson as a natural ally to the cause, except he would take it further; like every top batsman he seems obsessed with going on to make a hundred. He is as indefatigable as ever.

Since his release by Australia after the 1996 World Cup, when a flourishing reign that had made them the best side in the world ended with vague explanations that it was "time for a change", Simpson has reinvented himself as a roving ambassador for the game, "pushing the message", as he puts it, wherever he is valued.

He accepted assignments worthy of a Rough Guide To Coaching, including a spell in Nepal, where he watched live satellite feeds of Test matches in his hotel at the foot of the Himalayas and marvelled at a sudden upsurge of interest in the game that saw the Nepalese qualify for this year's under-19 World Cup.

Then Lancashire offered him a chance to rejoin the mainstream. It appealed on sentimental grounds: he spent a year in the Lancashire League at Accrington and there will also be the chance to gaze at Old Trafford and wallow in the memory of his 311 there against England in 1964.

It also enticed him because county cricket remains one of the few areas where he has not gained immediate success. His two years at Leicestershire in the early 90s, when his methods did not meet with total approval, still rankle.

The Beatles feared that, at 64, they might miss out on Valentine cards, birthday greetings and bottles of wine. But Simpson's priority is a Lancashire championship - and the last one came 17 months before he was born.

"It is extraordinary that they haven't won a championship when they have had so much success in one-day cricket," he said. "I always felt with Australia that Test and one-day cricket were more similar than many people accepted. Both need talented players, seeking a win from the first ball, showing mental aggression as well as physical aggression. We've already talked a bit about it."

For Simpson, "talking a bit about it" entails more than it appears. He likes to jibe, even about his beloved Australia, that "there have never been more coaches and there has never been more need for coaching". He advocates nothing more than the importance of peer group advice. "Senior players are often the best coaches."

So already at Lancashire Neil Fairbrother has been invited to explain his theories about one-day batting. "We've had some fantastic meetings over dinner," said Simpson. "I often find it works better after a bottle of wine." For a county full of strong-minded senior professionals, the approach could pay huge dividends.

Lancashire, this season, is a search for fulfilment: the coach who wants acclaim, second time round, in England; the team which yearns for a championship; and the captain John Crawley, once regarded as an England leader in waiting, now dismissed on the grounds of technical frailties and a perceived weakness in not rising above the more mundane aspects of touring life.

"I had great respect for John Crawley and that has increased," said Simpson. "He's an enthusiast, like me. We've got his square cut back, too, by sorting out that big early movement which sends his feet too far apart. The initial movement is what matters in batting, not the initial commitment."

Simpson is suspicious about much of what he calls "the fads and fancies of modern coaching". He rails against heavier bats, thicker grips and wicketkeepers pointing towards mid-off rather than the bowler. He refuses on principle ever to send out a message to the captain because he thinks it can only undermine him.

He even draws sustenance from Leicestershire's two titles in the past four years. "I count my time there as a success. Certain people had a dig at me but they've gone on to better things. I told them, though, that you cannot run a county when the other clubs in the area hate you. There has to be a bond. In Lancashire they understand that here."

Simpson's priority, at Lancashire as with Allan Border's Australian side, will be to develop team unity. If he succeeds, a championship might follow; if he fails, the sound of strong wills clashing will be deafening.

"It's the coach's task to be more enthusiastic than anyone," he said. "People have said I'm too old but at the end of the day I'll be going harder than anyone in the team."

Since his release by Australia after the 1996 World Cup, when a flourishing reign that had made them the best side in the world ended with vague explanations that it was "time for a change", Simpson has reinvented himself as a roving ambassador for the game, "pushing the message", as he puts it, wherever he is valued. He accepted assignments worthy of a Rough Guide To Coaching, including a spell in Nepal, where he watched live satellite feeds of Test matches in his hotel at the foot of the Himalayas and marvelled at a sudden upsurge of interest in the game that saw the Nepalese qualify for this year's under-19 World Cup. Then Lancashire offered him a chance to rejoin the mainstream. It appealed on sentimental grounds: he spent a year in the Lancashire League at Accrington and there will also be the chance to gaze at Old Trafford and wallow in the memory of his 311 there against England in 1964. It also enticed him because county cricket remains one of the few areas where he has not gained immediate success. His two years at Leicestershire in the early 90s, when his methods did not meet with total approval, still rankle. The Beatles feared that, at 64, they might miss out on Valentine cards, birthday greetings and bottles of wine. But Simpson's priority is a Lancashire championship - and the last one came 17 months before he was born. "It is extraordinary that they haven't won a championship when they have had so much success in one-day cricket," he said. "I always felt with Australia that Test and one-day cricket were more similar than many people accepted. Both need talented players, seeking a win from the first ball, showing mental aggression as well as physical aggression. We've already talked a bit about it." For Simpson, "talking a bit about it" entails more than it appears. He likes to jibe, even about his beloved Australia, that "there have never been more coaches and there has never been more need for coaching". He advocates nothing more than the importance of peer group advice. "Senior players are often the best coaches." So already at Lancashire Neil Fairbrother has been invited to explain his theories about one-day batting. "We've had some fantastic meetings over dinner," said Simpson. "I often find it works better after a bottle of wine." For a county full of strong-minded senior professionals, the approach could pay huge dividends. Lancashire, this season, is a search for fulfilment: the coach who wants acclaim, second time round, in England; the team which yearns for a championship; and the captain John Crawley, once regarded as an England leader in waiting, now dismissed on the grounds of technical frailties and a perceived weakness in not rising above the more mundane aspects of touring life. "I had great respect for John Crawley and that has increased," said Simpson. "He's an enthusiast, like me. We've got his square cut back, too, by sorting out that big early movement which sends his feet too far apart. The initial movement is what matters in batting, not the initial commitment." Simpson is suspicious about much of what he calls "the fads and fancies of modern coaching". He rails against heavier bats, thicker grips and wicketkeepers pointing towards mid-off rather than the bowler. He refuses on principle ever to send out a message to the captain because he thinks it can only undermine him. He even draws sustenance from Leicestershire's two titles in the past four years. "I count my time there as a success. Certain people had a dig at me but they've gone on to better things. I told them, though, that you cannot run a county when the other clubs in the area hate you. There has to be a bond. In Lancashire they understand that here." Simpson's priority, at Lancashire as with Allan Border's Australian side, will be to develop team unity. If he succeeds, a championship might follow; if he fails, the sound of strong wills clashing will be deafening. "It's the coach's task to be more enthusiastic than anyone," he said. "People have said I'm too old but at the end of the day I'll be going harder than anyone in the team."

webTitle: Cronje faces pressure to answer match-fixing charges in India

fields.headline: Cronje faces pressure to answer match-fixing charges in India
fields.trailText: Pressure is growing for the South Africa captain Hansie Cronje to fly to India to face allegations of match-rigging. High-level talks in Pretoria yesterday endorsed demands by police in India for Cronje to appear in court to answer the charges.
fields.byline: Andy Capostagno in Cape Town and Luke Harding in New Delhi
fields.body:
Pressure is growing for the South Africa captain Hansie Cronje to fly to India to face allegations of match-rigging. High-level talks in Pretoria yesterday endorsed demands by police in India for Cronje to appear in court to answer the charges.

The deputy foreign minister Aziz Pahad told a news conference that South Africa would give its full co-operation in investigations. Pahad said the government did not protect any individual if there was prima facie evidence of wrongdoing.

Four South African players - Cronje, Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom - have been accused of accepting bribes from an Indian bookie to lose matches during their one-day international series in India earlier this month which the hosts won 3-2. All four say they are innocent.

Indian police say they have "clinching" evidence of links between Sanjiv Chawla, a London-based Indian bookmaker, and the South Africans following revelations that he had visited South Africa at least once during November or December of last year.

"The continued association between Chawla and Cronje began much before their contacts in New Delhi. We have more than just the tapes [of an alleged conversation between Chawla and Cronje] which are now sealed but what we have are not for discussion. Whatever evidence we have will be produced in court in due course," said the New Delhi crime branch chief Pradeep Srivastava, who also alleged that Chawla met Cronje in the southern city of Cochin, the site of the first Test, on March 8 and that the two even stayed in the same hotel. Cronje denies knowing Chawla.

The claim that Chawla visited South Africa was apparently made under interrogation by Rajesh Kalra, an alleged associate of Chawla, who has been arrested in connection with the match-fixing charges.

"Kalra has made it clear Chawla had virtually followed the South African team to each of the five cities where matches were played. He also stayed in regular touch with Hansie Cronje during the series," a police source alleged.

Detectives in New Delhi yesterday raided Chawla's luxury home on the outskirts of the city and questioned his father and two brothers.

Three teams of officers have also been dispatched to the cities of Bombay, Kochi and Bangalore to find out details of where Chawla stayed during matches, and to investigate other bookies whose names have been supplied by Kalra.

Officers from India's enforcement directorate, which is also investigating, have "unofficially" approached India's state-run television station Doordashan to obtain authentic samples of Cronje's voice.

"There was some confusion about Cronje's voice because a TV channel had used their voiceover artists to enact the transcript of the recording done by us. This, some people have assumed, was Cronje's original voice," one officer said.

The South African high commissioner to India met senior foreign ministry officials yesterday and asked them to hand over the tapes that allegedly incriminate Cronje, along with a copy of the police charges against the four South African players. Maite Nkoane-Ramashaba said he received a "positive" response.

Cronje spoke to the media for the first time on Sunday, saying, "I want to make it 100% clear that I deny ever receiving any sum of money during the one-day international series in India. The only way to clear my name is to speak to the players and to check my bank account."

The Indian police intend doing exactly that and have sought Interpol's help in getting access to the South Africans' bank accounts.

webTitle: Richard Burton's family ridicule homosexual claim

fields.headline: Richard Burton's family ridicule homosexual claim
fields.trailText: Richard Burton's family has responded angrily to claims in a new biography of the hell-raising Welsh actor that he was a closet homosexual.
fields.body:
Richard Burton's family has responded angrily to claims in a new biography of the hell-raising Welsh actor that he was a closet homosexual.

"If Rich was a homosexual, then I'm a nun," said his brother, Graham Jenkins.

Controversial author Ellis Amburn has claimed in an unauthorised biography of Burton's former wife Elizabeth Taylor that Burton had an affair with Laurence Olivier and tried to seduce Eddie Fisher, then married to Taylor, even as he was stealing his wife from him.

Jenkins, speaking to the BBC, said nobody who knew Burton would give the story any credence because his brother was "the most heterosexual man most people had ever encountered."

The book, The Most Beautiful Woman in the World is due to be published in the US next month.

webTitle: DiCaprio movie to be shot in Ceausescu's palace

fields.headline: DiCaprio movie to be shot in Ceausescu's palace
fields.trailText: Leonardo DiCaprio is to star in a film which will be partially shot in the palace of Romania's former dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu.
fields.body:
Leonardo DiCaprio is to star in a film which will be partially shot in the palace of Romania's former dictator, Nicolae Ceausescu.

Librium, a science-fiction epic set in the year 2070, will use the enormous People's House in Bucharest, which, when it was built by Ceausescu, was second in size among government buildings only to the Pentagon. It now houses Romania's parliament and other official institutions.

An earlier request by Miramax to use the building had been turned down on the grounds that it invoked "possible image prejudices". Liberal Party politician Andrei Chiliman explained that those who had voted against the project suffered from "pyschological blockages" connected with the extravagant building and the gross excesses of its former occupants, who were overthrown in the anti-communist revolution in December 1989. Chiliman said he hoped that its use in a Hollywood movie would both attract tourists to the country and diminish its painful associations for many Romanians.

Filming in and around Bucharest will begin in August.

fields.headline: The ruling against David Irving
fields.standfirst: Excerpts from High Court Judge Charles Gray's ruling in the David Irving libel suit
fields.trailText: Excerpts from High Court Judge Charles Gray's ruling in the David Irving libel suit
fields.body:
It is my conclusion that no objective, fair-minded historian would have serious cause to doubt that there were gas chambers at Auschwitz and that they were operated on a substantial scale to kill hundreds of thousands of Jews.

It appears to me to be incontrovertible that Irving qualifies as a Holocaust denier. Not only has he denied the existence of gas chambers at Auschwitz and asserted that no Jew was gassed there, he has done so on frequent occasions and sometimes in the most offensive terms. By way of examples, I cite his story of the Jew climbing into a mobile telephone box-cum-gas chamber; his claim that more people died in the back of Kennedy's car at Chappaquiddick than died in the gas chambers at Auschwitz; his dismissal of the eyewitnesses en masse as liars or suffering from a mental problem ... I reject as being untrue the claim made by Irving in his evidence that in his denial of the existence of any gas chambers at Auschwitz, he was referring solely to the gas chamber constructed by the Poles after the war for the benefit of visitors to the site or, as Irving put it, as a 'tourist attraction.'

Having grossly underestimated the number who lost their lives in the camps, Irving is prone to claim that a greater number than that were killed in Allied bombing raids on Dresden and elsewhere. He has, moreover, repeatedly claimed that the British Psychological War Executive ingeniously discovered the lies that the Nazis were killing Jews in gas chambers in order to use it as propaganda.

Irving is anti-Semitic. His words are directed against Jews, either individually or collectively, in the sense that they are by turn hostile, critical, offensive and derisory in their references to Semitic people, their characteristics and appearances ... Irving has made claims that the Jews deserve to be disliked; that they brought the Holocaust on themselves. He speaks regularly at political or quasi-political meetings in Germany, the United States, Canada and the New World. The content of his speeches and interviews often displays a distinctly pro-Nazi and anti-Jewish bias. He makes surprising and often unfounded assertions about the Nazi regime which tend to exonerate the Nazis for the appalling atrocities which they inflicted on the Jews. He is content to mix with neo-facists and appears to share many of their racist and anti-Semitic prejudices.

The charges which I have found to be substantially true include the charges that Irving has for his own ideological reasons persistently and deliberately misrepresented and manipulated historical evidence; that for the same reasons he has portrayed Hitler in an unwarrantedly favourable light, principally in relation to his attitude towards and responsibility for the treatment of the Jews; that he is an active Holocaust denier; that he is anti-Semitic and racist and that he associates with right-wing extremists who promote neo-Nazism.

fields.headline: Irving loses Holocaust libel case
fields.trailText: Historian David Irving has lost his emotive libel case against the American academic who accused him of denying the scale of the Holocaust
fields.body:
Historian David Irving has lost his emotive libel case against the American academic who accused him of denying the scale of the Holocaust.

After considering the case for almost four weeks, Judge Charles Gray ruled against Mr Irving, saying he had failed to prove his reputation had been damaged.

Mr Irving, who outraged survivors of Nazi death camps, was seeking damages over Professor Deborah Lipstadt's 1994 book, Denying the Holocaust: The Growing Assault on Truth and Memory, which he claimed had generated waves of hatred against him.

Professor Lipstadt and her publishers, Penguin Books, both denied libelling Mr Irving by branding him "a Holocaust denier" in a book which attacked revisionists alleged to have denied or played down the slaughter of 6m Jews during the second world war.

Under British law, Prof Lipstadt and her co-defendant were not able to rely solely on truth as a defence.

Both sides had been told the verdict yesterday, leaving the announcement of the result in court today somewhat muted. The historian left through the rear entrance of the law courts, accompanied by high court security staff, saying only that the judge's ruling was "perverse".

Mr Irving, who is now likely to face defence costs estimated at £2m, Irving, indicated that he would appeal against the verdict, though he refused to talk about the effect of meeting the potentially crippling costs.

"Why is everyone talking about money, I'm not interested in money. It is all about reputation," he said. But when asked if he had sufficient funds to cover the bills he answered simply: "No."

A statement issued by Professor Lipstadt said: "I never had any doubts that [the ruling] would be [in our favour] but nonetheless, I am gratified.

"I hope that this victory will save other authors from having to face such trials and tribulations.

"I see this not only as a personal victory, but also as a victory for all those who speak out against hate and prejudice. It was a struggle for truth and for memory and a fight against those who sow the seeds of racism and anti-semitism. They have pursued justice not just on my, but on many people's behalf."

Eldred Tabachnik QC, president of the Board of Deputies of British Jews, welcomed the judgment.

He said: "The board is pleased that David Irving's action against Professor Lipstadt and her publisher Penguin Books has been so clearly rejected by the British courts. The decision proves that David Irving is a falsifier of history. Irving follows the short line of Holocaust deniers who aim to resurrect Nazism by denying the planned destruction of the European Jews.

"Although the Holocaust itself was not an issue at the trial, we welcome the fact that attempts to manipulate the truth about the tragic events of that time have been shown to be baseless."

Mr Justice Gray said the charges he had found to be substantially true were that "Irving had for his own ideological reasons persistently and deliberately misrepresented and manipulated historical evidence" and that "for the same reasons, he had portrayed Hitler in an unwarrantedly favourable light, principally in relation to his attitude towards and responsibility for the treatment of the Jews".

The judge said he found that Irving was "an active Holocaust denier; that he was anti-Semitic and racist and that he associated with right-wing extremists who promoted neo-Nazism".

There were certain defamatory imputations which he had found to be defamatory of Mr Irving, but in his judgment the charges against Mr Irving which had been proved to be true were of "sufficient gravity" for it to be clear that the failure to prove the truth of other matters did not have any material effect on the historian's reputation.

The judge observed that Mr Irving's submissions appeared to him "to have a distinct air of unreality about them". In the instances he had found the defendants' criticisms to be justified, Mr Irving had "treated the historical evidence in a manner which fell far short of the standard to be expected of a conscientious historian.

"Irving in those respects misrepresented and distorted the evidence which was available to him," he added.

On the issue of Auschwitz, the judge said the central question to be determined in the case was whether or not the evidence supported the defendants' contention that the number of deaths ran into hundreds of thousands or whether Mr Irving was right when he claimed that the killing by gas was on a modest scale.

He commented: "I have to confess that, in common I suspect with most other people, I had supposed that the evidence of mass extermination of Jews in the gas chambers at Auschwitz was compelling.

"I have, however, set aside this preconception when assessing the evidence adduced by the parties in these proceedings." He said it appeared to him that the cumulative effect of the documentary evidence for the genocidal operation of gas chambers at Auschwitz was "considerable".

He concluded: "Having considered the various arguments advanced by Irving to assail the effect of the convergent evidence relied on by the defendants, it is my conclusion that no objective, fair-minded historian would have serious cause to doubt that there were gas chambers at Auschwitz and that they were operated on a substantial scale to kill hundreds of thousands of Jews.

"In the result therefore the defence of justification succeeds".

fields.headline: Unrepentant Irving blasts "perverse" judgment
fields.standfirst: Historian vows to appeal the failed libel case which branded him a Holocaust denier
fields.trailText: Historian David Irving has admitted he cannot afford to cover the bills for his disastrous libel case defeat, but has vowed to fight on.
fields.body:
Historian David Irving has admitted he cannot afford to cover the bills for his disastrous libel case defeat, but has vowed to fight on.

Speaking after Mr Justice Gray, the judge in the High Court libel action delivered a damning 333-page judgment, branding him a Holocaust denier, falsifier of history, a racist and an anti-Semite, Irving remained totally unrepentant.

Speaking from his large apartment in Mayfair, central London, the 62-year-old was highly emotional and admitted he felt "tired. Very tired."

He said he would appeal against the judgment, although it is unclear how he can afford to do so. The bill for costs is already estimated to run to more than £2m.

"I would describe the judgment in two words - firstly, indescribable, and secondly, perverse," he said.

He refused to talk about how the potentially crippling costs of losing the libel action could affect him.

"Why is everyone talking about money? I'm not interested in money. It is all about reputation."

But when asked if he had sufficient funds to cover the bills, Irving answered simply: "No." He remained unabashed: "I am not at all anti-Semitic. It is not anti-Semitic to be critical of the Jews."

"But the leaders of the Jewish communities around the world have used the most horrific methods to try and destroy me. They had bottomless pockets to afford justice and say go ahead and destroy that bastard - which they just did."

"At the end, I suppose, it is my own fault for having explained myself inadequately clearly," he said.

Irving remained ambiguous about his views on race: "My own feelings about race are precisely the same as 95% of the people of my generation. That is all I will say."

"If the British soldiers on the beaches of Normandy in 1944 could look forward to the end of the century and see what England has become, they would not have bothered to advance another 40 yards up the beach," he added.

He also claimed he was not bitter, saying: "Some people are vindictive, but that is not in my nature. I am a Christian through and through."
