It is all about reputation." But when asked if he had sufficient funds to cover the bills, Irving answered simply: "No." He remained unabashed: "I am not at all anti-Semitic. It is not anti-Semitic to be critical of the Jews." "But the leaders of the Jewish communities around the world have used the most horrific methods to try and destroy me. They had bottomless pockets to afford justice and say go ahead and destroy that bastard - which they just did." "At the end, I suppose, it is my own fault for having explained myself inadequately clearly," he said. Irving remained ambiguous about his views on race: "My own feelings about race are precisely the same as 95% of the people of my generation. That is all I will say." "If the British soldiers on the beaches of Normandy in 1944 could look forward to the end of the century and see what England has become, they would not have bothered to advance another 40 yards up the beach," he added. He also claimed he was not bitter, saying: "Some people are vindictive, but that is not in my nature. I am a Christian through and through."

webTitle: The news cricket didn't want to hear

fields.headline: The news cricket didn't want to hear
fields.trailText: The allegations of match-rigging that emerged against Hansie Cronje and caused him to be sacked in the early hours of this morning are heartbreaking. It seems inconceivable that Cronje, who seemed to have it all - acclaim, status, a winning team, a strict faith and set of principles to live his life by - would throw it all away for a few rand. And if he of all people can, then cricket is in trouble.
fields.body:
The allegations of match-rigging that emerged against Hansie Cronje and caused him to be sacked in the early hours of this morning are heartbreaking. It seems inconceivable that Cronje, who seemed to have it all - acclaim, status, a winning team, a strict faith and set of principles to live his life by - would throw it all away for a few rand. And if he of all people can, then cricket is in trouble.

Though the protracted match-fixing trial against Bruce Grobbelaar and Hans Segers (in which they were found not guilty) didn't prevent the huge football boom which occurred in the 90s, cricket is more vulnerable. Despite the widespread rumours of illegal betting and fixing in cricket, no-one, until now, had ever been brought to book. Most people just closed their eyes and hoped it wasn't true. England might have lost most matches but at least they were losing fair and square.

Now the whole horrid hornets' nest is alive and biting. A good thing, of course, if cricket cleans up once and for all, but devastating to those like the ECB trying to attract new audiences. Women are not the only ones who will be disillusioned by the allegations. Of course not. But cricket cannot afford to lose even a tiny proportion of its female audience. For all the ECB's statistics about more and more girls playing Kwik Cricket, women are only conspicuous by their absence at most grounds. And sometimes with good reason. As Sandy Warr put it in the Observer: "Most women who go to [cricket] matches on their own know there are certain areas of the ground you avoid after lunch unless you're the type who likes wandering into a pub in the middle of a stag night."

No doubt cricket will sort itself out, and women will be made just as welcome as men at places like Edgbaston. Cronje's resignation and the subsequent repercussions will be a lot harder to recover from. Desperate stuff.

 Following last week's tales of sexism at a recent Wisden dinner, I can report that the 2000 gathering, on Wednesday, passed off without incident and was a lovely evening. The Honourable Artillery Company pulled out all the stops - men in pantaloons, gongs, welsh rarebit. Hearty speeches were rattled off by Christopher Martin-Jenkins and the former cabinet minister Peter Brooke. And the top table was crowded with venerable guests, including Clive Lloyd, Graham Thorpe, WF Deedes and Bob Woolmer. Plus women were served at the bar, though in the best traditions of having your cake and eating it I couldn't tell you if drinks were expensive because I had all mine bought for me.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

webTitle: Sri Lanka win in Pakistan, South Africa triumph in India

fields.headline: Sri Lanka win in Pakistan, South Africa triumph in India
fields.standfirst: Part II of our guide to this winter's Tests. To find out how these results have affected the world order, click here for the updated Wisden World Championship table
fields.trailText: Pakistan v Sri Lanka
fields.body:
Pakistan v Sri Lanka

First Test, Rawalpindi, Feb 26-Mar 1
Sri Lanka won by two wickets
Pakistan 182 (Wickremasinghe 4-37, Muralitharan 4-45) and 390 (Saeed Anwar 84, Younis Khan 107, Wasim Akram 79, Muralitharan 4-127)
Sri Lanka 353 (de Silva 112, Vaas 53*, Waqar Younis 4-103) and 220 for 8 (Jayasuriya 56, Abdur Razzaq 4-56)
Toss Sri Lanka Debuts Younis Khan (Pakistan)

The match seemed over when Pakistan were demolished on the opening day and Aravinda de Silva, returning to the Test side after missing the home series against Australia and Zimbabwe, hit his eighth Test century against this opposition, and his 18th in all, to give Sri Lanka a first-innings lead of 171. To make matters worse, Wasim Akram had pulled a groin muscle after delivering just 13 balls in Sri Lanka's first innings and would not bowl again in the match. Pakistan then lost eight wickets while establishing a lead of just 65. Then things changed. Debutant Younis Khan, a 22-year-old right-handed batsman from Habib Bank, paired up with the wounded Wasim, batting with a runner, to add 145 for the ninth wicket (a record for Pakistan v Sri Lanka). Khan became only the fourth batsman to make a Test century on Leap Year's Day. Sri Lanka were set 220 to win in just over a day, but from 144 for 4, lost four for 33 as Pakistan sensed a remarkable comeback. Arjuna Ranatunga, however, who had earlier retired hurt with a broken finger, summoned up almost two decades of Test experience and kept wicketkeeper Romesh Kaluwitharana company to ensure Saeed Anwar got off to a losing start as Pakistan captain.
Wisden verdict Sri Lanka continue their almost unnoticed rise up the world hierarchy.

Second Test, Peshawar, Mar 5-9,
Sri Lanka won by 57 runs
Sri Lanka 268 (Atapattu 75, Shoaib Akhtar 5-75) and 224 (Arnold 99)
Pakistan 199 (Saeed Anwar 74, Inzamam-ul-Haq 58*, Muralitharan 4-77) and 236 (Yousuf Youhana 88, Muralitharan 6-71)
Toss Pakistan Debuts Atiq-uz-Zaman (Pakistan)

Sri Lanka moved third in the Wisden World Championship with another Murali-inspired win. On a wicket that increasingly suited his wristy wiles, Muttiah Muralitharan took 10-148 - his third ten-wicket bag in Tests - as Pakistan slumped to their fifth successive Test defeat and fifth place in the table. After rain had delayed the start, Sri Lanka made wary progress against a Pakistan attack lacking the injured Wasim Akram but boosted by the fire of Shoaib Akhtar, who picked up a highly legal five-for. Pakistan were going well in reply, and reached 137 for 2 before calamity struck: while Inzamam-ul-Haq watched from one end, his colleagues committed suicide at the other, and the last eight wickets fell for just 61. With a lead of 69 on a pitch beginning to take spin, Sri Lanka were in the box seat. They remained there thanks to Russel Arnold who held things together with 99. Set 294, Pakistan were given a solid 59-run platform by their openers, but when Shahid Afridi was stumped for 31, three more wickets followed quickly to leave them 103 for 4. Yousuf Youhana stroked them back into the game, and at 208 for 5, it was back in the balance. But Chaminda Vaas and Murali combined to snaffle the last five for 28 and Sri Lanka had reached their highest world ranking yet.
Wisden verdict For the first time ever, neither Pakistan nor India is the best Test team in Asia. And while Murali's still around, Sri Lanka can get better.

Third Test, Karachi, Mar 12-15
Pakistan won by 222 runs
Pakistan 256 (Shahid Afridi 74, Inzamam-ul-Haq 86, Muralitharan 4-89) and 421 (Inzamam-ul-Haq 138, Younis Khan 61, Moin Khan 70, Pushpakumara 4-66, Muralitharan 4-107)
Sri Lanka 227 and 228
Toss Sri Lanka Debuts Irfan Fazil (Pakistan)

Inzamam-ul-Haq ensured that Pakistan, captained by Moin Khan in the absence of the injured Saeed Anwar, avoided not only a sixth successive Test defeat, but their first at the National Stadium for 34 matches, and their first whitewash in a home series. And in the process of hitting his ninth Test century, Inzy became only the fifth Pakistani to reach 4000 Test runs - after Javed Miandad (8832), Salim Malik (5768), Zaheer Abbas (5062) and Mudassar Nazar (4114). It was even stevens after the first innings, and even more when Pakistan stumbled to 159 for 5 second time round. But Inzy, who had already shepherded nightwatchman Shoaib Akhtar to a 42-ball duck, and the Khans helped add 262 for the last five wickets. Sri Lanka, set 451 to win, batted with the indulgence of a side that had already won the series, and went down in a blaze of strokes, eating up just 46 overs (a session and a half) while whacking 228.
Wisden verdict Consolation victories are rarely this crucial. Pakistan must build on it for their tour of the Caribbean.

India v South Africa

First Test, Mumbai, Feb 24-26
South Africa won by four wickets
India 225 (Tendulkar 97) and 113 (Pollock 4-24)
South Africa 176 (Kirsten 50) and 164 for 6 (Kumble 4-56)
Toss India Debuts Jaffer, Kartik (India), Boje (South Africa)

A thriller on a turner. Set 163 to inflict a rare home defeat on the Indians (Cronje said 200 would have been the cut-off point), South Africa cruised to 107 for 2. But they then lost four for 21 as Anil Kumble, who moved joint-second with Bishan Bedi in India's all-time wicket-taking list on 266, exploited familiar insecurities against top-class spin. Mark Boucher, though, has nothing insecure about him, and proceeded to thump six fearless fours to steer the Proteas home as Jacques Kallis held firm at the other end. It was an unlikely victory after India had begun with the highest total of the match and Sachin Tendulkar in regal form, hitting 97 before Kallis had him caught behind down the legside. Ajit Agarkar even broke a run of five ducks with an aggressive unbeaten 41 from 42 balls. Gary Kirsten and Herschelle Gibbs then put on 90, but when all ten fell for just 86, India's thoughts turned batting South Africa out of the game But the Little Master went early, and from 73 for 3, the rest followed subserviently, Shaun Pollock picking up four cheap wickets. It was just the boost South Africa needed; India meanwhile slumped to their fourth Test defeat in a row.
Wisden verdict Is India's invincibility at home becoming a thing of the past?

Second Test, Bangalore, Mar 2-6
South Africa won by an innings and 71 runs
India 158 and 250 (Azharuddin 102, Boje 5-83)
South Africa 479 (Kirsten 79, Boje 85, Kallis 95, Cullinan 53, Klusener 97, Kumble 6-143)
Toss India Debuts Chopra, Kaif (both India)

It was Nicky Boje's match. And South Africa's series. Not since 1986-87, when Imran Khan led Pakistan to a 1-0 win, had India lost a Test series at home. Now they were outspun in their own backyard as slow left-armer Boje, playing in his second Test, returned match figures of 53-20-93-7, including 5-83 on a turning wicket in the second innings. Boje had already outstayed his welcome as nightwatchman, scoring 85 in almost four hours and adding 161 for the second wicket with Gary Kirsten to take South Africa past India's limp first-innings showing. Five of South Africa's top six passed fifty so it didn't matter that their last six wickets fell for just 44: with a lead of 321 and the pitch starting to break up, victory was a matter of time. Mohammad Azharuddin, back after more than a year on the sidelines, held South Africa up with a glorious century (his 22nd in Tests, and his first since Boxing Day, 1998), but Boje winkled out the others - and history was made. It was a dismal end to Sachin Tendulkar's reign as captain. India dropped to seventh in the Wisden World Championship, below New Zealand, while South Africa closed the gap on Australia at the top.
Wisden verdict Indian cricket may be in disarray, but South Africa still did what no-one has managed for 13 years and beat them at their own game.

New Zealand v West Indies

First Test, Hamilton, Dec 16-20
New Zealand won by nine wickets
West Indies 365 (Griffith 114, Campbell 170, Vettori 4-83) and 97 (Cairns 7-27)
New Zealand 393 (Fleming 66, McMillan 51, Cairns 72, King 4-81) and 70 for 1
Toss West Indies Debuts Powell (West Indies)

Comebacks should retire gracefully after this. Coached for the first time by Viv Richards, West Indies coasted to 276 for 0 and thoughts turned to an inngs victory. But they contrived to lose by nine wickets in one of the most sensational Tests of recent times. The unthinkable began late on the first evening when Sherwin Campbell departed for a blistering 170 to trigger an alarming collapse: all ten wickets, including Adrian Griffith for a maiden Test hundred, fell for 89. New Zealand replied with gutsy and - thanks to Chris Cairns - explosive batting to sneak a lead of 28. Cairns now exploded again, this time with the ball. He took wickets in each of his first two overs to help reduce West Indies, in a winter of disastrous starts, to 1 for 3. But that was just for starters: against batting that had ground to a halt, he added five more to humble West Indies for 93 and return Test-best figures of 7-27 from 22.5 overs. He was aided by left-arm spinner Daniel Vettori, who tightened the noose with 22-12-20-1. Chasing 70 to win, the Black Caps were never threatened, although Matt Horhe had to retire hurt after having his right index finger broken by a ball from Franklyn Rose.
Wisden verdict Will anyone dare call New Zealand uncharismatic again?

Second Test, Wellington, Dec 26-29
New Zealand won by an innings and 105 runs
New Zealand 518 for 9 declared (Sinclair 214, Fleming 67, Astle 93, King 4-96)
West Indies 179 (Griffith 67, Lara 67, Cairns 5-44) and 234 (Chanderpaul 70, Lara 75, Nash 4-38)
Toss West Indies Debuts Sinclair (New Zealand)

Mathew Sinclair became the fourth man in Test history to make a double-hundred on debut; only England's Reg Foster, who hit 287 at Sydney in 1903-04, has done better. On a placid Basin Reserve wicket, Sinclair put New Zealand on course for their highest total in home Tests against West Indies (beating 460 at Christchurch in 1979-80) - this despite a decline from 429 for 3. West Indies, a man short after Daren Ganga injured himself in the field, then collapsed to the rejuvenated Chris Cairns, losing their last four wickets in just 19 balls. Following on, they fared little better, and were skewered by Dion Nash as their final seven wickets fell for 86. Brian Lara hit two half-centuries, but the West Indian batting line-up is weaker now than it has been for years. It was the first time New Zealand had won two in a series against West Indies, and their first win over them since the controversial series in 1979-80, when Michael Holding kicked down the stumps and Colin Croft charged into the umpire in response to several unfavourable decisions. The 2-0 result overturns West Indies's 1-0 win here five years ago, and, although the Black Caps are still seventh in the Wisden World Championship, they extend their lead over eighth-placed England to 0.24. West Indies remain third, but are now just 0.01 in front of Pakistan.
Wisden verdict A result that would have been inconceivable in the 1980s. New Zealand and the Windies have traded places in the new world order.

Australia v India

First Test, Adelaide, Dec 10-14
Australia won by 285 runs
Australia 441 (Steve Waugh 150, Ponting 125, Warne 86) and 239 for 8 decl. (Blewett 88)
India 285 (Tendulkar 61, Ganguly 60, Warne 4-92) and 110 (Fleming 5-30)
Toss Australia Debuts None

After deciding to bat on a typical Adelaide belter, Australia were almost caught with their trousers down, and faltered to 52 for 4. It was the sort of crisis made for Steve Waugh, who inscrutably added 239 for the fifth wicket with Ricky Ponting, an Aussie all-wicket record against India. Waugh hit his 21st Test century to join Sachin Tendulkar at the top of the list of contemporary players, and passed 8,000 runs in the process. He also completed a full hand of hundreds against the other eight Test nations - the first man to do so. Ponting uniquely hit back-to-back Test hundreds after registering a pair (he made 197 in the third Test against Pakistan at Perth, after two ducks at Hobart). And Shane Warne equalled the career-best he had established a few weeks earlier in Brisbane. Anil Kumble took his 260th Test wicket (Michael Kasprowicz) - but his first in Australia. India began badly, recovered to 215 for 4, but then lost their last six wickets for 70. Australia had all the time in the world to ensure against defeat, and promptly used it, batting almost 90 overs to reach 239 for 8 and leave India 396 to win. It turned out to be more than enough, as India stumbled to 76 for 5 on the fourth evening. The casualties included Tendulkar, controversially given out lbw to Glenn McGrath as he ducked into a short-pitched delivery that kept low, and was hit on the shoulder. India were outraged - but the ball would probably have clipped the bails. Next day, Fleming claimed career-best figures and was a dropped catch away from becoming the fourth man to take two Test hat-tricks: Warne spilt a catch at slip off Javagal Srinath. It was the most minor of blemishes as the Aussies notched up a fifth successive win - their best sequence since winning four on the trot against West Indies in 1975-76.
Wisden verdict India are flat-track bullies who get scared when they leave their own patch - particularly when they go Down Under. Australia sorted them out again, and haven't lost a home Test against them for 19 years.

Second Test, Melbourne, Dec 26-30
Australia won by 180 runs
Australia 405 (Slater 91, Ponting 67, Gilchrist 78, Srinath 4-130) and 208 for 5 declared (Gilchrist 55, Mark Waugh 51*)
India 238 (Tendulkar 116, Lee 5-47) and 195 (Tendulkar 52)
Toss India Debuts Lee (Australia), Kanitkar (India)

India put Australia in on an untypically hard and bouncy MCG wicket, took two early wickets, but were then batted out of the game by Michael Slater's eighth Test score in the nineties (only Steve Waugh, with nine near-misses, has shown more nerves), and a rasping stand of 144 for the sixth wicket in 32 overs between Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist. Venkatesh Prasad was fined 35% of his match fee for getting carried away when he dismissed Slater. Rain had shortened the first two days, but Australia made up for lost time, as debutant Brett Lee took a wicket with his fourth ball, and later added three in six. He looked seriously quick and finished with 5-44. Only Sachin Tendulkar, egged on by a noisy Indian contingent, could find an answer. He made his 22nd Test hundred, his fifth against Australia and his first at the MCG. Australia then left India needing 376 to win. It was never a contest, especially after Shane Warne, to his obvious delight, had trapped Tendulkar leg before playing no stroke for 52.
Wisden verdict Aussies make it six Test wins in a row and unearth a ferocious new fast bowler just for good measure. Can anyone stop them?

Third Test, Sydney, Jan 2-4
Australia won by an innings and 141 runs
India150 (McGrath 5-48, Lee 4-39) and 261 (Laxman 167, McGrath 5-55)
Australia552 for 5 declared (Langer 223, Steve Waugh 57, Ponting 141*)
Toss India Debuts None

Australia made it a summer to remember with their second consecutive 3-0 series win, and their seventh Test victory in a row. After Glenn McGrath and the Brett Lee had blasted India out for next to nothing, Australia shrugged off the early loss of their openers to fly to 552 at almost a run a minute. Justin Langer, bowled by a Javagal Srinath no-ball on 46, moved to his highest score in Tests and the highest for Australia against India. Ricky Ponting's 141 took just 183 balls, and lifted his sequence to 572 runs in his last six Test innings at 143.00 after registering three consecutive ducks against Pakistan. Adam Gilchrist's 45* raised his Test average to 69.29 (485 runs). Only Vangipurappu Laxman, with 63.98% of the total, passed 25 second time round, as McGrath completed match figures of 10-103. Laxman added 121 between tea and the close on the final day: only Victor Trumper (133 for Australia v South Africa at Melbourne in 1910-11) has scored more in a Test-match session. Ajit Agarkar fell first ball in the first innings, and second in the second. It was his second pair in a row, and meant he had now been dismissed five times in six balls - an unprecedented catalogue of disaster in Tests.
Wisden Verdict Steve Waugh said after the game that he'd back his side against any team in any era. It's hard to disagree.

South Africa v England

First Test, Johannesburg, Nov 25-28
South Africa won by an innings and 21 runs
England 122 (Donald 6-53, Pollock 4-16) and 260 (Stewart 86, Donald 5-74, Pollock 4-64)
South Africa 403-9 declared (Gibbs 85, Cullinan 108, Klusener 72, Gough 5-70)
Toss South Africa Debuts Adams, Hamilton, Vaughan (all England)

On a wet pitch and in gloomy conditions, England slumped to a sensational 2-4 against Allan Donald and Shaun Pollock - and never recovered. It was the second-worst start in Test history (Fred Trueman reduced India to 0-4 at Headingley in 1952), and the most unreal beginning to a Test series ever. Michael Vaughan (33) showed composure and Andy Flintoff (38) genuine moments of class as England clawed their way back to 90-5, but another collapse soon followed, and England were in the field shortly before tea on the first day. South Africa gathered runs slowly to begin with, but Daryll Cullinan lifted the tempo with the classiest innings of the match, and Lance Klusener flogged the tiring bowlers as only he can. Hansie Cronje's declaration deprived Darren Gough the chance of a hat-trick - he will have to wait for his first ball of the second Test after dismissing Pollock and Donald with successive deliveries. Batting again, England lost Mike Atherton for his second duck of the game: it was his second pair in consecutive overseas Tests, following Melbourne last winter, and he now has 19 Test ducks, equalling Derek Underwood's England record. No other specialist batsman in history has as many. Alec Stewart mixed fortune with blazing cuts and drives, and Flintoff (36) again played attractively, before Andy Caddick (48) biffed his way to a Test-best. Gavin Hamilton became the first Englishman since Graham Gooch (against Australia at Edgbaston in 1975) to make a pair on debut. It was South Africa's biggest win against England and their 10th win on the trot at home.
Wisden verdict England undone by the pitch and the best new-ball attack of the last decade. Winning the toss would only have lessened the margin of defeat.

Second Test, Port Elizabeth, Dec 9-13
Drawn
South Africa 450 (Cullinan 58, Rhodes 50, Klusener 174, Tufnell 4-124) and 224 for 4 decl. (Kallis 85*, Rhodes 57*)
England 373 (Atherton 108, Hussain 82, Hayward 4-75) and 153 for 6 (Hussain 70*)
Toss England Debuts Hayward (South Africa)

England were left clinging on to a draw on a slow wicket that became more uneven as the game developed. It was the first time in ten home Tests that South Africa had failed to win - although home umpire Rudi Koertzen at times appeared to be doing his best to make it 11 victories in a row. Six disputed decisions - all to the detriment of England - almost brought South Africa a victory which the ultra-defensive captaincy of Hansie Cronje scarcely deserved. On the first day, South Africa were helped out of a hole (146 for 5) by an innings of unconfined violence from Lance Klusener, who once and for all made the transition from one-day biffer to Test-match destroyer. England replied with their best first-innings total since Brisbane, over a year ago, and Mike Atherton, on the back of four consecutive overseas ducks, hit their first Test hundred since Alec Stewart at Melbourne last Christmas. He added 155 for the second wicket with the vibrant Nasser Hussain, and took on the frightening pace of debutant Nantie Hayward with the gusto of old. South Africa were soon in trouble at 50 for 3 (it could have been 4 if the cameras had picked up Chris Adams's excellent reflex catch to dismiss Jacques Kallis), and opted for safety, dawdling 92.5 overs for 224 runs. Eventually, England were left 79 overs to survive (Cronje thus bizarrely denying himself the use of a second new ball), and got off to a poor start. But from 5 for 2, Hussain and Vaughan dug in. And by the time wickets started to fall near the close, it was too late for South Africa.
Wisden verdict South Africa paid the price for going on the defensive too soon. England are beginning to make a habit of irritating them with rearguards - when will Cronje learn?

Third Test, Durban, Dec 26-30
Drawn
England 366 for 9 decl. (Hussain 146*, Stewart 95)
South Africa 156 (Pollock 64, Caddick 7-46) and 572 for 7 (Kirsten 275, Kallis 69, Boucher 108)
Toss England Debuts None

A game that entered the final day with the possibility of an England win ended in a bore draw as Gary Kirsten equalled the South African individual Test record with an innings that lasted 22 minutes shy of 15 hours. It was the second-longest in Tests, after Hanif Mohammad's 970-minute epic for Pakistan v West Indies at Bridgetown in 1957-58 (Hanif himself claims it was 999). Kirsten added 192 for the fifth wicket with nightwatchman Mark Boucher to snuff out England's hopes of levelling the series. Nasser Hussain and Alec Stewart had earlier put on 158 for the fourth wicket - more than any England pair had added all year - before Andy Caddick, extracting bounce and movement where the South Africans had found none, recorded Test-best figures of 7-46, passing 100 wickets in the process. It gave England their first first-innings lead for 17 Tests, and allowed them to enforce their first follow-on since New Zealand at Old Trafford in 1994. But they got little change from a bone-dry pitch second time round, and were left to regret a Phil Tufnell no-ball, which would have trapped Kirsten plumb in front when he had 40.
Wisden verdict England still unable to dominate for an entire Test.

Fourth Test, Cape Town, Jan 2-5
South Africa won by an innings and 37 runs
England 258 (Atherton 71, Donald 5-47) and 126
South Africa 421 (Kirsten 80, Kallis 105, Cullinan 120, Silverwood 5-91)
Toss England Debuts None

At 213 for 3 with half an hour to go on the first day, England were on top of the world. But things quickly went downhill. Allan Donald won a battle of wits with Alec Stewart, the rest followed meekly - even Lance Klusener got a wicket, his first of the series - and South Africa reached 200 for 1 by the second-day close. A mini fightback next day, led by the persevering Chris Silverwood, limited the deficit to 163 (as Cullinan reached his third century in consecutive Tests at Newlands), but England, batting a man short after Andy Flintoff broke his foot while bowling, performed like a team that believed they had already lost. All out for 126 - and another overseas series had gone begging. South Africa, led for the 50th time by Hansie Cronje, had never beaten England by so much. Donald's six wickets in the match took him to 86 in Tests - three more than SF Barnes's previous record for South Africa-England Tests. Mark Boucher simultaneously held his 100th Test catch and 200th first-class dismissal when he caught Nasser Hussain in the first innings, while Hussain became the first man to bat for more than 1000 minutes in Tests between dismissals.
Wisden verdict England regress to dark old days.

Fifth Test, Centurion, Jan 14-18
England won by 2 wickets
South Africa 248 for 8 decl. (Klusener 61*) and second innings forfeited
England 0-0 decl. and 251 for 8 (Stewart 73, Vaughan 69)
Toss England Debuts Strydom (South Africa)

The purists cried foul: for the first time in 1483 Tests, an innings was forfeited (two, in fact, although England later amended their forfeiture to 0-0 declared, so getting round Law 14, which makes no provision for a first-innings forfeiture). But England weren't complaining and duly scraped home with five balls and two wickets to spare after heavy rain had washed out the second, third and fourth days. They were grateful to two factors: the generosity of Hansie Cronje, whose target of 249 in 76 overs on a pitch that was flattening out was about as generous as he can ever have been; and a fifth-wicket stand of 126 between Alec Stewart and Michael Vaughan, who became the first man outside the big three of Stewart, Mike Atherton and Nasser Hussain to pass 50 in this series for England. At 228 for 4, England were walking it. But, true to form, they stumbled, losing four wickets for 12 as the pendulum swung South Africa's way. Then Chris Silverwood and Darren Gough hit a boundary each and England had limited the series damage to a slightly flattering 2-1.
Wisden verdict Ignore the purists: this was a victory for commonsense in a game that could do with more of it.
fields.bodyText: Pakistan v Sri Lanka First Test, Rawalpindi, Feb 26-Mar 1 Sri Lanka won by two wickets Pakistan 182 (Wickremasinghe 4-37, Muralitharan 4-45) and 390 (Saeed Anwar 84, Younis Khan 107, Wasim Akram 79, Muralitharan 4-127) Sri Lanka 353 (de Silva 112, Vaas 53*, Waqar Younis 4-103) and 220 for 8 (Jayasuriya 56, Abdur Razzaq 4-56) Toss Sri Lanka Debuts Younis Khan (Pakistan) The match seemed over when Pakistan were demolished on the opening day and Aravinda de Silva, returning to the Test side after missing the home series against Australia and Zimbabwe, hit his eighth Test century against this opposition, and his 18th in all, to give Sri Lanka a first-innings lead of 171. To make matters worse, Wasim Akram had pulled a groin muscle after delivering just 13 balls in Sri Lanka's first innings and would not bowl again in the match. Pakistan then lost eight wickets while establishing a lead of just 65. Then things changed. Debutant Younis Khan, a 22-year-old right-handed batsman from Habib Bank, paired up with the wounded Wasim, batting with a runner, to add 145 for the ninth wicket (a record for Pakistan v Sri Lanka). Khan became only the fourth batsman to make a Test century on Leap Year's Day. Sri Lanka were set 220 to win in just over a day, but from 144 for 4, lost four for 33 as Pakistan sensed a remarkable comeback. Arjuna Ranatunga, however, who had earlier retired hurt with a broken finger, summoned up almost two decades of Test experience and kept wicketkeeper Romesh Kaluwitharana company to ensure Saeed Anwar got off to a losing start as Pakistan captain. Wisden verdict Sri Lanka continue their almost unnoticed rise up the world hierarchy. Second Test, Peshawar, Mar 5-9, Sri Lanka won by 57 runs Sri Lanka 268 (Atapattu 75, Shoaib Akhtar 5-75) and 224 (Arnold 99) Pakistan 199 (Saeed Anwar 74, Inzamam-ul-Haq 58*, Muralitharan 4-77) and 236 (Yousuf Youhana 88, Muralitharan 6-71) Toss Pakistan Debuts Atiq-uz-Zaman (Pakistan) Sri Lanka moved third in the Wisden World Championship with another Murali-inspired win. On a wicket that increasingly suited his wristy wiles, Muttiah Muralitharan took 10-148 - his third ten-wicket bag in Tests - as Pakistan slumped to their fifth successive Test defeat and fifth place in the table. After rain had delayed the start, Sri Lanka made wary progress against a Pakistan attack lacking the injured Wasim Akram but boosted by the fire of Shoaib Akhtar, who picked up a highly legal five-for. Pakistan were going well in reply, and reached 137 for 2 before calamity struck: while Inzamam-ul-Haq watched from one end, his colleagues committed suicide at the other, and the last eight wickets fell for just 61. With a lead of 69 on a pitch beginning to take spin, Sri Lanka were in the box seat. They remained there thanks to Russel Arnold who held things together with 99. Set 294, Pakistan were given a solid 59-run platform by their openers, but when Shahid Afridi was stumped for 31, three more wickets followed quickly to leave them 103 for 4. Yousuf Youhana stroked them back into the game, and at 208 for 5, it was back in the balance. But Chaminda Vaas and Murali combined to snaffle the last five for 28 and Sri Lanka had reached their highest world ranking yet. Wisden verdict For the first time ever, neither Pakistan nor India is the best Test team in Asia. And while Murali's still around, Sri Lanka can get better. Third Test, Karachi, Mar 12-15 Pakistan won by 222 runs Pakistan 256 (Shahid Afridi 74, Inzamam-ul-Haq 86, Muralitharan 4-89) and 421 (Inzamam-ul-Haq 138, Younis Khan 61, Moin Khan 70, Pushpakumara 4-66, Muralitharan 4-107) Sri Lanka 227 and 228 Toss Sri Lanka Debuts Irfan Fazil (Pakistan) Inzamam-ul-Haq ensured that Pakistan, captained by Moin Khan in the absence of the injured Saeed Anwar, avoided not only a sixth successive Test defeat, but their first at the National Stadium for 34 matches, and their first whitewash in a home series. And in the process of hitting his ninth Test century, Inzy became only the fifth Pakistani to reach 4000 Test runs - after Javed Miandad (8832), Salim Malik (5768), Zaheer Abbas (5062) and Mudassar Nazar (4114). It was even stevens after the first innings, and even more when Pakistan stumbled to 159 for 5 second time round. But Inzy, who had already shepherded nightwatchman Shoaib Akhtar to a 42-ball duck, and the Khans helped add 262 for the last five wickets. Sri Lanka, set 451 to win, batted with the indulgence of a side that had already won the series, and went down in a blaze of strokes, eating up just 46 overs (a session and a half) while whacking 228. Wisden verdict Consolation victories are rarely this crucial. Pakistan must build on it for their tour of the Caribbean. India v South Africa First Test, Mumbai, Feb 24-26 South Africa won by four wickets India 225 (Tendulkar 97) and 113 (Pollock 4-24) South Africa 176 (Kirsten 50) and 164 for 6 (Kumble 4-56) Toss India Debuts Jaffer, Kartik (India), Boje (South Africa) A thriller on a turner. Set 163 to inflict a rare home defeat on the Indians (Cronje said 200 would have been the cut-off point), South Africa cruised to 107 for 2. But they then lost four for 21 as Anil Kumble, who moved joint-second with Bishan Bedi in India's all-time wicket-taking list on 266, exploited familiar insecurities against top-class spin. Mark Boucher, though, has nothing insecure about him, and proceeded to thump six fearless fours to steer the Proteas home as Jacques Kallis held firm at the other end. It was an unlikely victory after India had begun with the highest total of the match and Sachin Tendulkar in regal form, hitting 97 before Kallis had him caught behind down the legside. Ajit Agarkar even broke a run of five ducks with an aggressive unbeaten 41 from 42 balls. Gary Kirsten and Herschelle Gibbs then put on 90, but when all ten fell for just 86, India's thoughts turned batting South Africa out of the game But the Little Master went early, and from 73 for 3, the rest followed subserviently, Shaun Pollock picking up four cheap wickets. It was just the boost South Africa needed; India meanwhile slumped to their fourth Test defeat in a row. Wisden verdict Is India's invincibility at home becoming a thing of the past? Second Test, Bangalore, Mar 2-6 South Africa won by an innings and 71 runs India 158 and 250 (Azharuddin 102, Boje 5-83) South Africa 479 (Kirsten 79, Boje 85, Kallis 95, Cullinan 53, Klusener 97, Kumble 6-143) Toss India Debuts Chopra, Kaif (both India) It was Nicky Boje's match. And South Africa's series. Not since 1986-87, when Imran Khan led Pakistan to a 1-0 win, had India lost a Test series at home. Now they were outspun in their own backyard as slow left-armer Boje, playing in his second Test, returned match figures of 53-20-93-7, including 5-83 on a turning wicket in the second innings. Boje had already outstayed his welcome as nightwatchman, scoring 85 in almost four hours and adding 161 for the second wicket with Gary Kirsten to take South Africa past India's limp first-innings showing. Five of South Africa's top six passed fifty so it didn't matter that their last six wickets fell for just 44: with a lead of 321 and the pitch starting to break up, victory was a matter of time. Mohammad Azharuddin, back after more than a year on the sidelines, held South Africa up with a glorious century (his 22nd in Tests, and his first since Boxing Day, 1998), but Boje winkled out the others - and history was made. It was a dismal end to Sachin Tendulkar's reign as captain. India dropped to seventh in the Wisden World Championship, below New Zealand, while South Africa closed the gap on Australia at the top. Wisden verdict Indian cricket may be in disarray, but South Africa still did what no-one has managed for 13 years and beat them at their own game. New Zealand v West Indies First Test, Hamilton, Dec 16-20 New Zealand won by nine wickets West Indies 365 (Griffith 114, Campbell 170, Vettori 4-83) and 97 (Cairns 7-27) New Zealand 393 (Fleming 66, McMillan 51, Cairns 72, King 4-81) and 70 for 1 Toss West Indies Debuts Powell (West Indies) Comebacks should retire gracefully after this. Coached for the first time by Viv Richards, West Indies coasted to 276 for 0 and thoughts turned to an inngs victory. But they contrived to lose by nine wickets in one of the most sensational Tests of recent times. The unthinkable began late on the first evening when Sherwin Campbell departed for a blistering 170 to trigger an alarming collapse: all ten wickets, including Adrian Griffith for a maiden Test hundred, fell for 89. New Zealand replied with gutsy and - thanks to Chris Cairns - explosive batting to sneak a lead of 28. Cairns now exploded again, this time with the ball. He took wickets in each of his first two overs to help reduce West Indies, in a winter of disastrous starts, to 1 for 3. But that was just for starters: against batting that had ground to a halt, he added five more to humble West Indies for 93 and return Test-best figures of 7-27 from 22.5 overs. He was aided by left-arm spinner Daniel Vettori, who tightened the noose with 22-12-20-1. Chasing 70 to win, the Black Caps were never threatened, although Matt Horhe had to retire hurt after having his right index finger broken by a ball from Franklyn Rose. Wisden verdict Will anyone dare call New Zealand uncharismatic again? Second Test, Wellington, Dec 26-29 New Zealand won by an innings and 105 runs New Zealand 518 for 9 declared (Sinclair 214, Fleming 67, Astle 93, King 4-96) West Indies 179 (Griffith 67, Lara 67, Cairns 5-44) and 234 (Chanderpaul 70, Lara 75, Nash 4-38) Toss West Indies Debuts Sinclair (New Zealand) Mathew Sinclair became the fourth man in Test history to make a double-hundred on debut; only England's Reg Foster, who hit 287 at Sydney in 1903-04, has done better. On a placid Basin Reserve wicket, Sinclair put New Zealand on course for their highest total in home Tests against West Indies (beating 460 at Christchurch in 1979-80) - this despite a decline from 429 for 3. West Indies, a man short after Daren Ganga injured himself in the field, then collapsed to the rejuvenated Chris Cairns, losing their last four wickets in just 19 balls. Following on, they fared little better, and were skewered by Dion Nash as their final seven wickets fell for 86. Brian Lara hit two half-centuries, but the West Indian batting line-up is weaker now than it has been for years. It was the first time New Zealand had won two in a series against West Indies, and their first win over them since the controversial series in 1979-80, when Michael Holding kicked down the stumps and Colin Croft charged into the umpire in response to several unfavourable decisions. The 2-0 result overturns West Indies's 1-0 win here five years ago, and, although the Black Caps are still seventh in the Wisden World Championship, they extend their lead over eighth-placed England to 0.24. West Indies remain third, but are now just 0.01 in front of Pakistan. Wisden verdict A result that would have been inconceivable in the 1980s. New Zealand and the Windies have traded places in the new world order. Australia v India First Test, Adelaide, Dec 10-14 Australia won by 285 runs Australia 441 (Steve Waugh 150, Ponting 125, Warne 86) and 239 for 8 decl. (Blewett 88) India 285 (Tendulkar 61, Ganguly 60, Warne 4-92) and 110 (Fleming 5-30) Toss Australia Debuts None After deciding to bat on a typical Adelaide belter, Australia were almost caught with their trousers down, and faltered to 52 for 4. It was the sort of crisis made for Steve Waugh, who inscrutably added 239 for the fifth wicket with Ricky Ponting, an Aussie all-wicket record against India. Waugh hit his 21st Test century to join Sachin Tendulkar at the top of the list of contemporary players, and passed 8,000 runs in the process. He also completed a full hand of hundreds against the other eight Test nations - the first man to do so. Ponting uniquely hit back-to-back Test hundreds after registering a pair (he made 197 in the third Test against Pakistan at Perth, after two ducks at Hobart). And Shane Warne equalled the career-best he had established a few weeks earlier in Brisbane. Anil Kumble took his 260th Test wicket (Michael Kasprowicz) - but his first in Australia. India began badly, recovered to 215 for 4, but then lost their last six wickets for 70. Australia had all the time in the world to ensure against defeat, and promptly used it, batting almost 90 overs to reach 239 for 8 and leave India 396 to win. It turned out to be more than enough, as India stumbled to 76 for 5 on the fourth evening. The casualties included Tendulkar, controversially given out lbw to Glenn McGrath as he ducked into a short-pitched delivery that kept low, and was hit on the shoulder. India were outraged - but the ball would probably have clipped the bails. Next day, Fleming claimed career-best figures and was a dropped catch away from becoming the fourth man to take two Test hat-tricks: Warne spilt a catch at slip off Javagal Srinath. It was the most minor of blemishes as the Aussies notched up a fifth successive win - their best sequence since winning four on the trot against West Indies in 1975-76. Wisden verdict India are flat-track bullies who get scared when they leave their own patch - particularly when they go Down Under. Australia sorted them out again, and haven't lost a home Test against them for 19 years. Second Test, Melbourne, Dec 26-30 Australia won by 180 runs Australia 405 (Slater 91, Ponting 67, Gilchrist 78, Srinath 4-130) and 208 for 5 declared (Gilchrist 55, Mark Waugh 51*) India 238 (Tendulkar 116, Lee 5-47) and 195 (Tendulkar 52) Toss India Debuts Lee (Australia), Kanitkar (India) India put Australia in on an untypically hard and bouncy MCG wicket, took two early wickets, but were then batted out of the game by Michael Slater's eighth Test score in the nineties (only Steve Waugh, with nine near-misses, has shown more nerves), and a rasping stand of 144 for the sixth wicket in 32 overs between Ricky Ponting and Adam Gilchrist. Venkatesh Prasad was fined 35% of his match fee for getting carried away when he dismissed Slater. Rain had shortened the first two days, but Australia made up for lost time, as debutant Brett Lee took a wicket with his fourth ball, and later added three in six. He looked seriously quick and finished with 5-44. Only Sachin Tendulkar, egged on by a noisy Indian contingent, could find an answer. He made his 22nd Test hundred, his fifth against Australia and his first at the MCG. Australia then left India needing 376 to win. It was never a contest, especially after Shane Warne, to his obvious delight, had trapped Tendulkar leg before playing no stroke for 52. Wisden verdict Aussies make it six Test wins in a row and unearth a ferocious new fast bowler just for good measure. Can anyone stop them? Third Test, Sydney, Jan 2-4 Australia won by an innings and 141 runs India150 (McGrath 5-48, Lee 4-39) and 261 (Laxman 167, McGrath 5-55) Australia552 for 5 declared (Langer 223, Steve Waugh 57, Ponting 141*) Toss India Debuts None Australia made it a summer to remember with their second consecutive 3-0 series win, and their seventh Test victory in a row. After Glenn McGrath and the Brett Lee had blasted India out for next to nothing, Australia shrugged off the early loss of their openers to fly to 552 at almost a run a minute. Justin Langer, bowled by a Javagal Srinath no-ball on 46, moved to his highest score in Tests and the highest for Australia against India. Ricky Ponting's 141 took just 183 balls, and lifted his sequence to 572 runs in his last six Test innings at 143.00 after registering three consecutive ducks against Pakistan. Adam Gilchrist's 45* raised his Test average to 69.29 (485 runs). Only Vangipurappu Laxman, with 63.98% of the total, passed 25 second time round, as McGrath completed match figures of 10-103. Laxman added 121 between tea and the close on the final day: only Victor Trumper (133 for Australia v South Africa at Melbourne in 1910-11) has scored more in a Test-match session. Ajit Agarkar fell first ball in the first innings, and second in the second. It was his second pair in a row, and meant he had now been dismissed five times in six balls - an unprecedented catalogue of disaster in Tests. Wisden Verdict Steve Waugh said after the game that he'd back his side against any team in any era. It's hard to disagree. South Africa v England First Test, Johannesburg, Nov 25-28 South Africa won by an innings and 21 runs England 122 (Donald 6-53, Pollock 4-16) and 260 (Stewart 86, Donald 5-74, Pollock 4-64) South Africa 403-9 declared (Gibbs 85, Cullinan 108, Klusener 72, Gough 5-70) Toss South Africa Debuts Adams, Hamilton, Vaughan (all England) On a wet pitch and in gloomy conditions, England slumped to a sensational 2-4 against Allan Donald and Shaun Pollock - and never recovered. It was the second-worst start in Test history (Fred Trueman reduced India to 0-4 at Headingley in 1952), and the most unreal beginning to a Test series ever. Michael Vaughan (33) showed composure and Andy Flintoff (38) genuine moments of class as England clawed their way back to 90-5, but another collapse soon followed, and England were in the field shortly before tea on the first day. South Africa gathered runs slowly to begin with, but Daryll Cullinan lifted the tempo with the classiest innings of the match, and Lance Klusener flogged the tiring bowlers as only he can. Hansie Cronje's declaration deprived Darren Gough the chance of a hat-trick - he will have to wait for his first ball of the second Test after dismissing Pollock and Donald with successive deliveries. Batting again, England lost Mike Atherton for his second duck of the game: it was his second pair in consecutive overseas Tests, following Melbourne last winter, and he now has 19 Test ducks, equalling Derek Underwood's England record. No other specialist batsman in history has as many. Alec Stewart mixed fortune with blazing cuts and drives, and Flintoff (36) again played attractively, before Andy Caddick (48) biffed his way to a Test-best. Gavin Hamilton became the first Englishman since Graham Gooch (against Australia at Edgbaston in 1975) to make a pair on debut. It was South Africa's biggest win against England and their 10th win on the trot at home. Wisden verdict England undone by the pitch and the best new-ball attack of the last decade. Winning the toss would only have lessened the margin of defeat. Second Test, Port Elizabeth, Dec 9-13 Drawn South Africa 450 (Cullinan 58, Rhodes 50, Klusener 174, Tufnell 4-124) and 224 for 4 decl. (Kallis 85*, Rhodes 57*) England 373 (Atherton 108, Hussain 82, Hayward 4-75) and 153 for 6 (Hussain 70*) Toss England Debuts Hayward (South Africa) England were left clinging on to a draw on a slow wicket that became more uneven as the game developed. It was the first time in ten home Tests that South Africa had failed to win - although home umpire Rudi Koertzen at times appeared to be doing his best to make it 11 victories in a row. Six disputed decisions - all to the detriment of England - almost brought South Africa a victory which the ultra-defensive captaincy of Hansie Cronje scarcely deserved. On the first day, South Africa were helped out of a hole (146 for 5) by an innings of unconfined violence from Lance Klusener, who once and for all made the transition from one-day biffer to Test-match destroyer. England replied with their best first-innings total since Brisbane, over a year ago, and Mike Atherton, on the back of four consecutive overseas ducks, hit their first Test hundred since Alec Stewart at Melbourne last Christmas. He added 155 for the second wicket with the vibrant Nasser Hussain, and took on the frightening pace of debutant Nantie Hayward with the gusto of old. South Africa were soon in trouble at 50 for 3 (it could have been 4 if the cameras had picked up Chris Adams's excellent reflex catch to dismiss Jacques Kallis), and opted for safety, dawdling 92.5 overs for 224 runs. Eventually, England were left 79 overs to survive (Cronje thus bizarrely denying himself the use of a second new ball), and got off to a poor start. But from 5 for 2, Hussain and Vaughan dug in. And by the time wickets started to fall near the close, it was too late for South Africa. Wisden verdict South Africa paid the price for going on the defensive too soon. England are beginning to make a habit of irritating them with rearguards - when will Cronje learn? Third Test, Durban, Dec 26-30 Drawn England 366 for 9 decl. (Hussain 146*, Stewart 95) South Africa 156 (Pollock 64, Caddick 7-46) and 572 for 7 (Kirsten 275, Kallis 69, Boucher 108) Toss England Debuts None A game that entered the final day with the possibility of an England win ended in a bore draw as Gary Kirsten equalled the South African individual Test record with an innings that lasted 22 minutes shy of 15 hours. It was the second-longest in Tests, after Hanif Mohammad's 970-minute epic for Pakistan v West Indies at Bridgetown in 1957-58 (Hanif himself claims it was 999). Kirsten added 192 for the fifth wicket with nightwatchman Mark Boucher to snuff out England's hopes of levelling the series. Nasser Hussain and Alec Stewart had earlier put on 158 for the fourth wicket - more than any England pair had added all year - before Andy Caddick, extracting bounce and movement where the South Africans had found none, recorded Test-best figures of 7-46, passing 100 wickets in the process. It gave England their first first-innings lead for 17 Tests, and allowed them to enforce their first follow-on since New Zealand at Old Trafford in 1994. But they got little change from a bone-dry pitch second time round, and were left to regret a Phil Tufnell no-ball, which would have trapped Kirsten plumb in front when he had 40. Wisden verdict England still unable to dominate for an entire Test. Fourth Test, Cape Town, Jan 2-5 South Africa won by an innings and 37 runs England 258 (Atherton 71, Donald 5-47) and 126 South Africa 421 (Kirsten 80, Kallis 105, Cullinan 120, Silverwood 5-91) Toss England Debuts None At 213 for 3 with half an hour to go on the first day, England were on top of the world. But things quickly went downhill. Allan Donald won a battle of wits with Alec Stewart, the rest followed meekly - even Lance Klusener got a wicket, his first of the series - and South Africa reached 200 for 1 by the second-day close. A mini fightback next day, led by the persevering Chris Silverwood, limited the deficit to 163 (as Cullinan reached his third century in consecutive Tests at Newlands), but England, batting a man short after Andy Flintoff broke his foot while bowling, performed like a team that believed they had already lost. All out for 126 - and another overseas series had gone begging. South Africa, led for the 50th time by Hansie Cronje, had never beaten England by so much. Donald's six wickets in the match took him to 86 in Tests - three more than SF Barnes's previous record for South Africa-England Tests. Mark Boucher simultaneously held his 100th Test catch and 200th first-class dismissal when he caught Nasser Hussain in the first innings, while Hussain became the first man to bat for more than 1000 minutes in Tests between dismissals. Wisden verdict England regress to dark old days. Fifth Test, Centurion, Jan 14-18 England won by 2 wickets South Africa 248 for 8 decl. (Klusener 61*) and second innings forfeited England 0-0 decl. and 251 for 8 (Stewart 73, Vaughan 69) Toss England Debuts Strydom (South Africa) The purists cried foul: for the first time in 1483 Tests, an innings was forfeited (two, in fact, although England later amended their forfeiture to 0-0 declared, so getting round Law 14, which makes no provision for a first-innings forfeiture). But England weren't complaining and duly scraped home with five balls and two wickets to spare after heavy rain had washed out the second, third and fourth days. They were grateful to two factors: the generosity of Hansie Cronje, whose target of 249 in 76 overs on a pitch that was flattening out was about as generous as he can ever have been; and a fifth-wicket stand of 126 between Alec Stewart and Michael Vaughan, who became the first man outside the big three of Stewart, Mike Atherton and Nasser Hussain to pass 50 in this series for England. At 228 for 4, England were walking it. But, true to form, they stumbled, losing four wickets for 12 as the pendulum swung South Africa's way. Then Chris Silverwood and Darren Gough hit a boundary each and England had limited the series damage to a slightly flattering 2-1. Wisden verdict Ignore the purists: this was a victory for commonsense in a game that could do with more of it.

fields.headline: Free will or destiny
fields.standfirst: If you want to go to university next year, now is the time to make your choices. So be proactive and get down to those open days
fields.trailText: If you want to go to university next year, now is the time to make your choices. So be proactive and get down to those open days
fields.body:
Heard the one about the sixth-former on A-level results day? Beaming with success, he knocked on his careers adviser's door. "Guess what!" he said. "I've got an offer confirmed from Teesside. Where is it?"

The next few months are crucial if you're hoping to start university in October 2001. Not only does endless research in the careers library have to be done, but now comes the time to see what these books, CD Roms and advisers are really talking about. The season of the open day is upon us!

The importance of visiting as many of your likely choices of university as possible cannot be over-stressed. Of course, time and money constraints will inhibit a nationwide tour, but it's still a good idea to visit at least a couple of institutions on your list. The last thing you want to happen on your arrival next year is to find that the reality does not match the vision in your mind's eye - and the realisation that one visit would have done the trick. You are going to spend three or more years of your life in this place!

By this stage you will probably have some idea of where you want to go, maybe a list of 10 or so. It won't be possible to see them all, so do your research thoroughly and choose two or three you'd really like to see.

If you are still undecided and need to get a snapshot of the whole range, why not visit one close to home, another in a city centre and a single-site campus. Or contrast large with small, old with new. How far the university is from home, and how easy or difficult it is to get there, are the most important pieces of information.

Next, making the arrangements. Your school or college may well be organising visits to open days. No worries there, then. However, in addition, you and your parents and friends can also make your own arrangements. Consult the best reference book on Open Days for dates and contact details. Even if there is no formal visiting day, most universities will be happy to organise something for you. Before you go, spend time thinking about what you want to get out of the day or you'll return home none the wiser.

You'll want to find out more about your chosen course, particularly the content and how it is taught. How you will be accommodated is likely to be near the top of your list. If you get the chance to talk to current students then you will discover more on this and the joys of student life - they are unlikely to be slow in coming forward on these issues!

And what are your future lecturers like? Sitting through some of the talks on offer may give you an idea. But perhaps the most vital thing to be gained from an open day is that you will arrive home with a gut feeling, an overall impression based on an amalgam of factors that will heavily influence your later decisions. It may not be scientific, but with more than 250 higher education institutions an objective choice is impossible.

Universities are, by and large, wise to this, and are trying hard to put on a good show, realising that students and their parents are in many ways now consumers, who want value for the money a university education now costs. Teachers and careers advisers still get open day posters, but now glossy, detailed leaflets are becoming the norm.

A well-organised day will include a variety of possibilities. Bradford's open day on July 19 certainly aims to fulfil its motto of "Making knowledge work". It has tours and visits to academic departments, campus facilities and student accommodation and practical advice on how to apply, student life and becoming a mature student. "All are welcome" and thankfully, for such a busy programme, "free tea, coffee and fruit juice are available throughout the day".

Kent includes an invitation from their pro vice-chancellor in the leaflet encouraging you to "visit, view, talk and experience" on June 30.

Central Lancashire is offering walking tours of their Preston campus on April 19 and June 7 and 24. As a rucksack is pictured above this invitation, you may wish to choose sensible footwear!

Aberystwyth looks forward to welcoming you on May 17 and July 4 in their colourful and informative leaflet, which gives several reasons for choosing this Welsh seaside town for your studies, including "a friendly and supportive" atmosphere, "value for money" and "over 125 years of academic success".

These examples give a taste of what's not to be missed in the spring and summer terms. There's no substitute for the open day visit, so don't miss out. "Experience is what really matters," say Aberystwyth on their invitation. "See for yourself," say Hertfordshire on theirs. It's good advice. Take it.

What to look out for

 Course content, teaching styles, assessment
 Facilities - labs, computer spaces, lecture rooms, student union
 A year out - is it acceptable and encouraged?
 What is looked for on the UCAS form? - and is an interview likely?
 Job destinations from your course
 See the student accommodation - cost, location
 Talk to current undergraduates
 What will travelling to and from the university be like?
 Was the open day well-organised and informative?
 Can you see yourself in this environment for three years?

 University and College Open Days including Pre-Taster Courses and Education Conventions - published by and obtainable at £3 from Ucas on 01242 544610.

The season of the open day is upon us! The importance of visiting as many of your likely choices of university as possible cannot be over-stressed. Of course, time and money constraints will inhibit a nationwide tour, but it's still a good idea to visit at least a couple of institutions on your list. The last thing you want to happen on your arrival next year is to find that the reality does not match the vision in your mind's eye - and the realisation that one visit would have done the trick. You are going to spend three or more years of your life in this place! By this stage you will probably have some idea of where you want to go, maybe a list of 10 or so. It won't be possible to see them all, so do your research thoroughly and choose two or three you'd really like to see. If you are still undecided and need to get a snapshot of the whole range, why not visit one close to home, another in a city centre and a single-site campus. Or contrast large with small, old with new. How far the university is from home, and how easy or difficult it is to get there, are the most important pieces of information. Next, making the arrangements. Your school or college may well be organising visits to open days. No worries there, then. However, in addition, you and your parents and friends can also make your own arrangements. Consult the best reference book on Open Days for dates and contact details. Even if there is no formal visiting day, most universities will be happy to organise something for you. Before you go, spend time thinking about what you want to get out of the day or you'll return home none the wiser. You'll want to find out more about your chosen course, particularly the content and how it is taught. How you will be accommodated is likely to be near the top of your list. If you get the chance to talk to current students then you will discover more on this and the joys of student life - they are unlikely to be slow in coming forward on these issues! And what are your future lecturers like? Sitting through some of the talks on offer may give you an idea. But perhaps the most vital thing to be gained from an open day is that you will arrive home with a gut feeling, an overall impression based on an amalgam of factors that will heavily influence your later decisions. It may not be scientific, but with more than 250 higher education institutions an objective choice is impossible. Universities are, by and large, wise to this, and are trying hard to put on a good show, realising that students and their parents are in many ways now consumers, who want value for the money a university education now costs. Teachers and careers advisers still get open day posters, but now glossy, detailed leaflets are becoming the norm. A well-organised day will include a variety of possibilities. Bradford's open day on July 19 certainly aims to fulfil its motto of "Making knowledge work". It has tours and visits to academic departments, campus facilities and student accommodation and practical advice on how to apply, student life and becoming a mature student. "All are welcome" and thankfully, for such a busy programme, "free tea, coffee and fruit juice are available throughout the day". Kent includes an invitation from their pro vice-chancellor in the leaflet encouraging you to "visit, view, talk and experience" on June 30. Central Lancashire is offering walking tours of their Preston campus on April 19 and June 7 and 24. As a rucksack is pictured above this invitation, you may wish to choose sensible footwear! Aberystwyth looks forward to welcoming you on May 17 and July 4 in their colourful and informative leaflet, which gives several reasons for choosing this Welsh seaside town for your studies, including "a friendly and supportive" atmosphere, "value for money" and "over 125 years of academic success". These examples give a taste of what's not to be missed in the spring and summer terms. There's no substitute for the open day visit, so don't miss out. "Experience is what really matters," say Aberystwyth on their invitation. "See for yourself," say Hertfordshire on theirs. It's good advice. Take it. webTitle: 'I have never favoured legalising drugs' - Livingstone

fields.headline: 'I have never favoured legalising drugs' - Livingstone
fields.standfirst: Drugs tsar is 'a waste of money' says the front-runner in London's mayoral race
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone today claimed that his call in an interview with this week's New Musical Express to consider decriminalising ecstasy and cannabis had been widely misrepresented. But he fuelled further controversy by dismissing the government's drugs tsar as "a waste of money".
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone today claimed that his call in an interview with this week's New Musical Express to consider decriminalising ecstasy and cannabis had been widely misrepresented. But he fuelled further controversy by dismissing the government's drugs tsar as "a waste of money".

"My position on drugs has been completely clear throughout my political career. I have never favoured legalising drugs," said Mr Livingstone in a statement.

"The priority for the police and the criminal justice system must be to focus on stamping out the drug dealers rather than those who are their victims.

"I believe that drug pushers should be dealt with in the harshest possible way. Pushers should be subject to long prison-sentences and their profits should be confiscated for the use of the local communities they prey upon."

Interviewed today on the London independent radio station LBC, Mr Livingstone also dismissed Keith Hellawell, the government's £106,000-a-year anti-drugs co-ordinator, as "a waste of money".

"The context is, I'm saying I don't take drugs, and I don't think anyone should take drugs, but I'm also saying I think the drugs tsar is a waste of money," Mr Livingstone said.

"And it's rubbish to say that all drugs are the same, and that ecstasy, and heroin and cocaine are all the same, because it means kids don't believe you," he said.

He stressed, however, that he was not in favour of legalising drugs like cannabis and ecstasy but decriminalising them and would never do anything to encourage drug use.

Mr Hellawell criticised Mr Livingstone's comments to the NME, in which the independent mayoral candidate said the war against drug dealers had been lost and "we could consider decriminalising things like ecstasy and cannabis".

"Mr Livingstone, I presume, may be talking from a lack of in-depth knowledge of the wider spectrum of the government's anti-drugs policies," Mr Hellawell said.

"I would be extremely glad to go over with him, and anyone else, how effective they are in terms of education in schools, rehabilitation programmes and help to wean young people off drugs, through to the arrest and conviction of drug-dealers and the redeployment of their seized assets in anti-drugs programmes."

The government's programmes had never treated all drugs the same and had considered different ways to deal with different problems, insisted Mr Hellawell, who added that it was a widely held view that the UK's anti-drugs strategy was one of the most effective in the world.

Labour's mayoral candidate, Frank Dobson, criticised Mr Livingstone's call for drug decriminalisation, saying: "Parents in London will be very concerned because everyone knows both ecstasy and cannabis are harmful and decriminalising them will encourage their use.

"Some young people try them as a form of rebellion against their parents and if they are decriminalised more dangerous drugs will take their place."

The Liberal Democrat candidate, Susan Kramer, said that if she were elected, she would establish a commission to examine the whole drugs issue. If such a commission recommended that decriminalising cannabis would significantly reduce crime in London, that would be a strategy worth taking to the government, she added.

fields.headline: Testing the water
fields.trailText: Getting the real flavour - students reveal their open day experiences
fields.body:
Olivia Drennan, 21, is a third-year history student at Cambridge University. Four years ago, she says, she had a stereotyped image of Oxbridge institutions - hundreds of miles from her Glasgow home - based largely on a reading of Brideshead Revisited. However, she was curious enough to travel down for the university open day and is now thankful that she did.

"When I got there it was a real revelation that the students were not all snobbish," she says. "They were actually normal people.

"There is a big temptation for students in Scotland to stay put - at my school I would say that, of the 70 people who went to university, about 60 stayed at home and only two or three actually left Scotland.

"I was only allowed to go on one open day outside Glasgow during school time - which is daft. Schools should be encouraging pupils to look further afield." Despite the efforts of her teachers, Drennan managed to visit five universities before filling out her Ucas form. She chose to have a look at Edinburgh, Glasgow, St Andrews, Cambridge and Oxford based on their league table results and advice from friends and relatives. "The open day at Edinburgh was perhaps the most informative. There were busloads of students arriving all day and it was very difficult to find out exactly where you were going. But every time you got lost there was someone around to point you in the right direction.

"When I got lost on a visit to Glasgow university I spent two hours trying to find the philosophy department and had to give up in as there was no one to ask."

One of the main reasons she settled on Trinity Hall was because of the friendly atmosphere at a lunch on the open day.

Alan Senitt, 21, is a second year in physical education and community studies at Birmingham University. He discovered on open days that it is the people and the place - rather than any course syllabus - which gives a university its character.

"You read in a prospectus what a course involves," he says. "But it is difficult to read in a book what it is going to be like living there. To find that out you have to visit.

"When a university publishes a prospectus they will take photos of the nicest parts of the city and the campus, but when you get there it is nothing like you expected," he explains. "It's like McDonald's photographing their burgers to look amazing - when you actually get handed one it's not as attractive."

Alan, who is from Pinner in north London, visited Birmingham, Liverpool John Moores, Durham, Leeds Metropolitan and Sunderland.

He says that while most open days are useful, it can be hard getting a flavour of real student life.

"I got very bored at Liverpool when they sat us down for two hours and read through the entire syllabus. It's a shame, because the course looked really good. Durham was better because everyone got to stay overnight in halls and they organised activities and told us about different societies. It wasn't until the second day that we went to find out about the course. You are experiencing what university is like."

As a Jewish student Alan also wanted to find a university town with a strong Jewish community. He was able to contact Jewish societies on open days and this helped him settle on Birmingham.

Ange Davison, 23, is a second-year postgraduate psychology student at York University. She says going to a few open days made her feel that she was bright enough to be an undergraduate. "The whole idea of going to university and living on your own is intimidating and I always thought I would be out of my depth at a university full of posh people," she says. "But it wasn't like that at all. Actually you may even discover that you're as bright as - or brighter than - some of the students who are already there."

Davison's sixth-form college in Washington, Tyne and Wear, was very encouraging of students going on open day visits and she was able to visit Sheffield, Durham, Oxford, Teesside and York with a group of fellow students in the college minibus. It was the indescribable magic of York, however, which won her over as soon as she arrived.

"I just fell in love with the place," she says. "I don't know what it is about it - it's all concrete buildings and bird mess - but I love it. I think it just has a very informal atmosphere.

"It was definitely the open day which made me choose York. The students who showed us around and gave us a copy of the alternative prospectus were surprisingly honest and didn't try to hide the bad aspects of the place.

"I remember a hall full of stalls for different societies - Amnesty International were there getting people to sign petitions, students were selling rag mags - there was a lot of activity and everything seemed to be going on there. Another thing I remember was having a few drinks in the college bar - which might be another reason I liked York."

webTitle: David Irving: 'a propagandist, a polemicist, an apologist for Hitler'

fields.headline: David Irving: 'a propagandist, a polemicist, an apologist for Hitler'
fields.trailText: Tuesday, 1pm: Guardian writer Stephen Moss fallout from the Irving trial
fields.body:
David Irving said before the result of his libel action was announced that, whatever the judgment, his reputation had been "enhanced" by the trial. If he still believes that after Mr Justice Gray's withering condemnation of his historical methods, he is even more of a fantasist than his detractors have suggested.

"Irving has for his own ideological reasons persistently and deliberately misrepresented and manipulated historical evidence," said Gray in his judgment.

"For the same reasons he has portrayed Hitler in an unwarrantedly favourable light, principally in relation to his attitude towards and responsibility for the treatment of the Jews."

There can be no greater charge against a historian. Facts are slippery commodities; two historians can look at the same body of evidence and come to opposed conclusions; they will often be influenced by their personal perspectives and political standpoints; the notion of absolute history, absolute truth, has been argued over for centuries. But the assumption is that historians are fundamentally honest; they have not wilfully distorted the materials to serve their ideological ends. There may be a subconscious drive behind their reading of the sources, but there is no deliberate and systematic misrepresentation.

Gray's judgment means that Irving can no longer call himself a historian; he must now be seen as what his critics have always called him - a propagandist, a polemicist, an apologist for Hitler, whom he has sought to defend from demonisation.

After dismissing Irving the historian, the judge turned on Irving the man: "He is an active Holocaust denier, anti-Semitic, racist and associates with right-wing extremists who promote neo-Nazism." There can be no sympathy with those views, no respect for someone who has twisted facts in the cause of fascism. Irving is evidently an intelligent man and a tireless researcher; he could have been a good and respected historian; instead he chose to be a footsoldier for the far right.

We should remember, too, that it was Irving who brought this case, against the American academic Deborah Lipstadt. There is no law against Holocaust denial in the UK; no one here was seeking to arraign him for his views. Professor Lipstadt, in her book Denying the Holocaust, attacked him in the strongest possible terms, but she could not have stopped him having his say. He chose the ground on which to fight; he now bears the bruises. He is, in every sense, the author of his own misfortunes.

webTitle: Cook believes Zimbabwe elections will go ahead

fields.headline: Cook believes Zimbabwe elections will go ahead
fields.standfirst: Foreign Office travel advice
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said today that he fully expects Zimbabwe to hold elections in May, as the troubled nation's parliament met for the final time before facing dissolution.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, said today that he fully expects Zimbabwe to hold elections in May, as the troubled nation's parliament met for the final time before facing dissolution.

In a statement to the House of Commons, Mr Cook said that 11 other EU countries backed the British government, which has strongly criticised Mr Mugabe's tolerance of the mass occupation of white farmers' lands.

The dissolution of Zimbabwe's 150-seat parliament is the first concrete step toward fixing a timetable for national elections, which Mr Mugabe had first said he would call in March, before postponing polling until April, and now May.

An election date has yet to be set by the president, who is likely to face the biggest challenge to his rule since he led the nation to black majority rule and independence in 1980.

Parliament's five-year term expires at midnight on 11 April and, under the constitution, elections must be held within four months of its last sitting.

Mr Mugabe has assured British officials that voting would go ahead at an unspecified date in May, despite doubts about whether voters' lists and the three-month task of mapping out the boundaries of electoral constituencies could be completed in time.

Mr Mugabe's ruling Zanu-PF party, which holds 147 seats in the 150-seat legislature, suffered its biggest defeat in February when 55% of voters rejected a Mugabe-approved revised constitution in a referendum.

Eddison Zvobgo, Zanu-PF's senior legal affairs official, has predicted that the main opposition group, the Movement for Democratic Change, could win as many as 50 seats of the 120 that are being elected. President Mugabe is allowed to personally appoint 30.

Zimbabwe is facing its worst economic crisis since the former British colony of Rhodesia became independent in 1980.

Squatters led by veterans of the independence war have occupied more than 900 white-owned farms since early February, claiming plots for landless blacks.

Mr Mugabe has described the occupations as a justified protest against ownership by 4,000 white people, who are mostly the descendants of British settlers, and has ordered police not to evict the armed squatters.

Meanwhile, the leader of Zimbabwe's campaign to seize hundreds of farms claimed that white farmers had "declared war" on the country's black majority and vowed to defeat them.

Chenjerai Hunzvi, chairman of the Zimbabwe national liberation war veterans association, said the invasion of white-owned farms would go on "if the white people continue to be funny".

"They have declared war on us by trying to mobilise racist and imperialist forces against our country, against the revolutionary forces of our country, the entire black people and our government, led by President Mugabe. We will not let them win this war," he said.
