fields.headline: The cost of denial
fields.standfirst: Historian David Irving, who today lost his libel case against the American academic who accused him of Holocaust denial, was in financial difficulty even before the court case that is expected to cost him £2m, writes arts correspondent Fiachra Gibbons
fields.trailText: Historian David Irving, who today lost his libel case against the American academic who accused him of Holocaust denial, was in financial difficulty even before the court case that is expected to cost him £2m, writes arts correspondent Fiachra Gibbons.
fields.body:
For a man who was about to be condemned to certain bankruptcy, David Irving seemed curiously unconcerned this morning.

He was still railing against those "traditional enemies of the truth" - Irvingspeak for Jews - who have set out to take "my work, my reputation and my home" from me.

But even without waging his hugely-expensive libel case against Penguin and the American academic Deborah Lipstadt, Irving's finances were, in his own words, "on a knife edge".

The Guardian has discovered that he had mortgaged his large Mayfair apartment to the hilt to keep his Real History website - which propagated his views on Holocaust denial - going, and was having trouble keeping up with the service charges on the building.

While Penguin shouldered the brunt of the £2.5m costs of assembling the defence team to nail Irving, members of the Bronfman family, who own the distillers Seagrams, and who are leading figures in the World Jewish Congress, are also believed to have made sizeable contributions to the defence fund.

Irving, on the other hand, claims to have gathered donations from 4,000 "mostly ordinary people in America and Europe".

"Some of them have sent me as little as $2," he claimed, "though a dear old lady in Germany has sent me 500DM notes."

However, Jewish groups claim that most of his cash has come from a network of far-right groups like the neo-Nazi National Alliance in the US and the openly-racist German People's Union (DVU).

Irving denies that he has taken money from neo-Nazis, particularly the DVU with which he was once closely associated. He said his biggest donor was a man from the US who handed him $50,000 in cash in a brown paper bag at Amsterdam airport two years ago. He also claims that within the past month a banker's draft for £10,000 was sent to him from New York.

While Penguin shouldered the brunt of the £2.5m costs of assembling the defence team to nail Irving, members of the Bronfman family, who own the distillers Seagrams, and who are leading figures in the World Jewish Congress, are also believed to have made sizeable contributions to the defence fund. Irving, on the other hand, claims to have gathered donations from 4,000 "mostly ordinary people in America and Europe". "Some of them have sent me as little as $2," he claimed, "though a dear old lady in Germany has sent me 500DM notes." However, Jewish groups claim that most of his cash has come from a network of far-right groups like the neo-Nazi National Alliance in the US and the openly-racist German People's Union (DVU). Irving denies that he has taken money from neo-Nazis, particularly the DVU with which he was once closely associated. He said his biggest donor was a man from the US who handed him $50,000 in cash in a brown paper bag at Amsterdam airport two years ago. He also claims that within the past month a banker's draft for £10,000 was sent to him from New York.

fields.headline: Would Ken Livingstone kill capitalism?
fields.standfirst: Ken Livingstone has defended his assertion in an NME interview that capitalism kills more people each year than Hitler did in the second world war, despite fierce criticism from his political opponents, religious leaders and the City.
fields.trailText:
"Nothing I have said is not true. Why is it that the Labour government has spent most of the last two and a half years pursuing debt relief for the third world? You need to get across the scale of what is happening."
Ken Livingstone today

Ken Livingstone today

Corporation of London spokesman

Neil Parker, City economist

Frank Dobson, Labour candidate for London mayor

Steven Norris, Conservative candidate for mayor

"For Ken Livingstone to describe capitalists as killers is ridiculous."
Susan Kramer, Liberal Democrat mayoral candidate

"Ken Livingstone damns himself out of his own mouth. Personally I don't find his sense of humour particularly amusing, and it's actually quite offensive."
Spokesman for the board of deputies of British Jews

webTitle: Labour renews efforts for gay sex equality

fields.headline: Labour renews efforts for gay sex equality
fields.standfirst: More about section 28
fields.trailText: Lowering the age of consent for gay sex to from 18 to 16 is back on the agenda today.
fields.body:
Lowering the age of consent for gay sex to from 18 to 16 is back on the agenda today.

The government is renewing efforts to persuade the House of Lords to bring the age of homosexual consent into line with that of heterosexual sex.

Peers have twice rejected such a move, but the Sexual Offences (Amendment) bill is now being reintroduced under the Parliament Acts. This means that any successful attempt to amend or otherwise scupper the bill will not prevent it getting on to the statute book.

Rather than see that happen, the Lords is likely to give the bill an unopposed second reading.

The Lords has defied the House of Commons, which has repeatedly voted by significant majorities in favour of equality.

Last week, Baroness Young, the Tory peer who has led cross-party opposition to the bill in the Lords, said that, if possible, she would try to amend the bill at its subsequent Lords committee stage.

The baroness, who believes the bill poses a danger to children, described it as "thoroughly bad". "I think one should at least try to get some amendments in it which would improve it. I would certainly want to strengthen some of the provisions on abuse of trust, which are very weak."

fields.headline: Diary of a hypochondriac
fields.trailText: It is many weeks since I last reviewed my state of health on paper like this, but that is hardly an indicator that I have been well. Far from it, says Matthew Norman
fields.body:
Tuesday

It is many weeks since I last reviewed my state of health on paper like this, but that is hardly an indicator that I have been well. Far from it: for almost two months I have been assailed unceasingly by a sequence of nasty virusy symptoms - mild fever, achy limbs, heightened sensitivity to sound, taut scalp - that have rendered me weak and wretched. Until now I had assumed that my immune system was suppressed because I was run down, but a particularly virulent bug drove me to bed for most of last week and I begin to wonder if it might not be something more sinister.

Wednesday

Yet again I awake drained and sluggish despite having passed an untroubled night. It isn't drink, and although my breathing remains far from perfect, it has mystifyingly improved since I cancelled both conventional and laser surgery on my significantly deviated septum in February. I am seldom one to jump the diagnostic gun, but a lymphatic cancer would explain things, albeit I have yet to suffer that classic lymphoma symptom, the night sweat.

Thursday

When I complain over dinner of feeling lousy, Rebecca continues to read the Jane Austen novel which lies open in front of her on the table, while forking dainty morsels of kedgeree into her mouth. I repeat my point, louder.

"Yes, I heard you the first time," replies my wife, elegantly flipping over a page with her fork. "If you're that ill, why don't you sod off to bed?"

Pausing only to say what enchanting news it is that the delicacy of Jane Austen's prose is rubbing off on her like this, I collect a bottle of Glenlivet and morosely head upstairs as advised by W12's very own Emma Woodhouse.

Friday

Last night there came the night sweat. Or rather, when I awoke at 3.30am from a nightmare (I was a roadie for the neo-punk band Mandy's Chinless Wonders , who had just had a big hit with Lymphomaniac), my neck and surrounding areas were drenched. After breakfast, I call the Grove surgery and am told that Dr Jarvis now does "walk-in clinics" on Mondays and Fridays, and would I like to pop in? No I would not. A patient of my long service and stature? "Pop in"? I have arranged to see Dr Jarvis at the emergency clinic tomorrow. Pop in, indeed.

Saturday

As I enter Room 19, Dr Jarvis makes a Pavlovian lunge for the latex gloves, but when I explain the problem she begins a thorough inspection of the neck and surrounding areas.

"It's lymphoma, isn't it?" I say. "You've found a lump the size of a golf ball, and I have six to nine months."

"I haven't found a damn thing," she says, sitting down. "You haven't got lymphoma. Your lymph nodes are all normal. You're fine."

"In that case," I ask her, "explain the night sweat."

"That would be the night you drank a third of a bottle of 12-year-old malt, would it?"

Clearly, she has been speaking to Rebecca behind my back.

"Have you heard of Hippocrates of Cos?" I ask her.

Ignoring this with all the insouciance of one reading Jane Austen at dinner, she goes on: "As for the tiredness, have you thought about losing some weight and going to the gym?"

Of course I bleeding well have. For years I've thought of little else. Doing it, that's the problem.

Sunday

By way of inaugurating a new health regime, I clear out my bathroom chest, throwing away many old friends - antioxidants, omega fish oils, zinc enzymes, high protein fibre tablets, and vitamins A, B, C D and E - that are past their sell-by date. Some of the bottles are baffling. A preparation for menstrual cramps takes some explaining, as does the contact lens cleanser, which passed its best in 1994. I have never worn contacts.

Monday

In order to replenish stocks, I pay a visit to the Mortar and Pestle pharmacy on Kensington High Street, where Dipak smiles good-naturedly as I ask him about the efficacy of various pills.

We have been going through this ritual for years: I ask him if they're any good, and he - too tactful to voice the obvious truth - smiles sweetly. Of course, what I am really asking Dipak to tell me is what I want to hear from Dr Jarvis: that death is something which, with a bit of luck and the right pills, I should be able to avoid. But Dipak can tell me no such thing.

"And this milk thistle, or silybum marianum?" I inquire. Dipak smiles and says nothing.

"It's completely useless, isn't it?"

"It's a tonic," he says, "for the liver."

"Absolutely useless, then, for me?"

Dipak smiles again. "Utterly," he says. "And how many bottles do you want?"

"Just the two, for now," I reply. "Let's just see how it goes."

fields.headline: In need of attention
fields.standfirst: It's estimated that nearly 200,000 British children are on psychiatric medication. Many parents feel there is no alternative. But such widespread use of drugs may be eclipsing other viable - and possibly safer - options, says  Eileen Tracy
fields.trailText: It's estimated that nearly 200,000 British children are on psychiatric medication. Many parents feel there is no alternative. But such widespread use of drugs may be eclipsing other viable - and possibly safer - options, says Eileen Tracy
fields.body:
What would you do if, at 24 months, your daughter slept only two hours a day, started drinking turpentine and threatened to stab her siblings? The chances are, you would follow doctors' orders and put her on medication - though perhaps not so willingly if you watched last night's Panorama programme, which showed the dangers and limitations of giving stimulants to children diagnosed with attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD).

A decade ago, Janice Hill's toddler was attacking her sister and trying to throw herself over the banister to see if she could fly. The GP mumbled something about "terrible twos", then when she continued to be terrible at three, four and five, he eventually referred her to psychiatric services where she was diagnosed with ADHD and offered methylphenidate, or MPH (commonly known as Ritalin). But Janice did not want her child on stimulant medication. Her eldest son's lactose intolerance had made her aware of the role of nutrition in controlling difficult behaviour. So she set about monitoring her daughter's diet.

She sent blood samples to laboratories and consulted biochemists. The girl was deficient in various vitamins and minerals (B6 and zinc), essential fatty oils, and hydrochloric acid - so sugary cola drinks and artificial additives were eliminated from her diet, and supplements were added. But Janice's child, it turned out, was also poisoned. She had been exposed to organophosphates in sheep dip and also to lead, from the water pipes in the farm where the family used to live.

It was an uphill struggle, but Janice cured her daughter. She did it defiantly, because she resented the doctors who labelled without looking into causes: "No one ever examined her or asked about her medical history. If it hadn't been for my experiences with my eldest son's diet, I hate to think where my daughter would be now." She also learned better parenting skills: to be more patient through the difficult times. Janice now runs the Scottish mental health charity Overload, which is suing various NHS trusts on behalf of 34 parents whose children suffered adverse side effects on psychotropic medication.

It is believed that up to 10% of children with an ADHD diagnosis can recover on a managed diet. In the UK, the Hyperactive Children's Support Group offers advice on diet and nutrition - so no parent needs to go it alone as Janice did. But for the remaining 90%, diet isn't the answer.

And that's the difficulty of ADHD: it isn't easy to pin down. For some, diet, acupuncture, neurofeedback, osteopathy or homoeopathy can be the answer. For others, not. To focus too much on the physical aspect (specifically the unsubstantiated genetic hypothesis) can be to overlook emotional triggers. This means missing an opportunity to release the child from his or her distress, and a possible lifetime of medication.

Take babies: they cannot verbalise anything, so very few parents realise how much babies feel. Closely observed, however, they show signs of terror and depression when abandoned or subjected to violent events. It's ironic that their emotions are least apparent in what may well be their most formative years.

David, for instance, was two when his mother was beaten by her husband. She remarried, and circumstances changed for the better. Still, David grew into a difficult, hyperactive adolescent. Their GP prescribed medication and psychotherapy. But it wasn't just David who had to change. His parents had to consider his behaviour as something meaningful in itself, rather than the mere outcome of what may or may not have been his genetic predisposition for ADHD. This involved coming to terms with the painful details of the mother's first marriage, and revising their view that "babies don't notice".

Under such emotionally charged conditions, the attraction of the "brain disorder" theory can be hard for parents to resist, especially as stimulant medication often has a dramatic effect - at least in the short term. But the trauma that underpinned David's hyperactivity had to be acknowledged if David was ever to be properly helped. And he needed help: his own hyperactivity so frightened him that, unusually, he requested medication to control himself. Psychotherapy helped him see that his ADHD expressed a constant wariness, a feeling of being on edge. He realised he didn't need to be that way any more.

Children like David who receive emotional or behavioural support can come off medication, under close professional supervision. Dr Steve Baldwin, director of clinical and counselling training units (Cactus) at the University of Teesside, uses behavioural self-control training (BSCT) to cure ADHD-style behaviour. "If the drug is withdrawn too suddenly, you can get 'rebound'. The carer imagines that this spiking of behaviour is the ADHD resurfacing, when in fact the child is showing normal drug withdrawal symptoms."

When a child bullies others children, or disrupts classes, parents can feel tremendous pressure to medicate. But a behavioural therapist like Baldwin can teach the child self- control, by working closely with the parents to encourage appropriate behaviour whilst discouraging disruptive outbursts. After a few weeks, the child learns to behave, and the effect is usually long-lasting.

Sometimes a resolution can be found just by withdrawing drug treatment, because stimulants themselves can cause disruption. Eleven-year old Mark, for instance, was given medication for ADHD. Initially, he improved, but after a few weeks, he started to relapse, fighting with his younger sister and displaying aggression which Baldwin recognised as a common side-effect of amphetamine-style drugs prescribed for ADHD. "Before medication, Mark had developmental, growing-up type problems. One teacher reported he couldn't concentrate, the other said he was one of the best in class. He was moved to the front of the class, and his behaviour returned to normal. There was no reason to medicate him."

One of Baldwin's concerns is to make a correct assessment. "Children can be misdiagnosed with ADHD because it suits the needs of busy professionals, when in fact the children may have a developmental problem or a specific learning disability. Some have epilepsy. Others have poor eyesight or bad hearing. If you give them stimulants, you can create a new problem." Baldwin has seen many children think, on one hand, that they need the drug to control their behaviour and yet blame the drug for the way they act. "They say, 'It's not me, it's the drug.' That makes it harder for them to take responsibility."

 Usefull sources:

On the web: The Santa website www.SANTA.inUK.com has information on drug-free solutions.
In print: Ritalin Nation by Richard DeGrandpre is published by W W Norton & Co and its paperback edition will be available from May (£9.95). Further info: contact Overload on 0131 555 4967 or write to the Hyperactive Children's Support Group at 71 Whyke Lane, Chichester, Sussex PO19 2LD.

fields.headline: Taking the strain
fields.standfirst: As Stephen Moss's three-month quest for the body  beautiful nears its end, his personal trainer, Sam Jenkins,  gives the other side of the story
fields.trailText: As Stephen Moss's three-month quest for the body beautiful nears its end, his personal trainer, Sam Jenkins, gives the other side of the story
fields.body:
Stephen is indisposed this week and has asked me to write his fitness column. He is feeling a little irked that people are not taking what he likes to see as his spiritual odyssey seriously: one colleague questioned his mental well-being when he admitted last time to feeling a kind of latent fascism; two friends thought the exercise kick was a substitute for a sex life; and the Guardian's editor said he was evidently having a mid-life crisis. If he wasn't depressed before, he certainly is now. He also took his liking for boxercise a little too far and did a few rounds in the ring: he now has a throbbing head, a tender nose and a bruised ego.

He wanted me to tell you what a model client he has been and how I see the role of the personal trainer. The former is broadly true: he's had his emotional ups and downs but most of the time has been committed and enthusiastic. After 10 weeks, he is in much better shape physically and is now able to do things that were unimaginable at the beginning. He went on a 40-minute run last week - further than he'd run for 20 years - and said he felt he could have run for another 40.

Exercising regularly is like anything: the better you become at it, the more you tend to enjoy it. Exercise will become a habit, and then a habit you don't want to do without. Sometimes it can become an obsession. I don't advocate this; my philosophy on exercise and nutrition is the same as that for life in general - moderation in all things. It's important not to be obsessed by weight loss or the way you look: it's how you feel that counts, and feeling good means a balanced diet and a sufficient amount of exercise.

You will feel the benefit almost as soon as you start training, but it could be a couple of months before you start to see a major change. Training makes you feel more self-confident and more alive. Some people don't realise that until they start doing it; they come purely for the weight loss or muscle gain, but I try to get away from that and emphasise the way you feel mentally as well as physically.

It's important to see clients regularly, say twice or three times a week. If you meet regularly, you are more at ease with each other and it's more productive. You can get to know people well, maybe even socialise with them, but you have to realise where to draw the line. I've never dated any of my clients and I'm keen to keep it that way.

The important thing is to remember the objectives you have set. Seeing a client mustn't just become an opportunity to chat and gossip, though there may be times when the client has had a really bad day and you have to be supportive and willing to talk. But you shouldn't get too close; you have to keep a lid on the relationship. It shouldn't go beyond professional boundaries.

Meeting a client for the first time is like a blind date. It's not someone you meet through a shared interest - most clients and trainers are at opposite ends of the spectrum in terms of age, income and status - but that's one of the interesting things. First appearances can be deceptive: sometimes I've disliked a client on first meeting but come to like them later. Problems only arise if the client thinks he knows it all or is not sufficiently committed, or if he looks down on you or treats you as a servant. It has to be a relationship of equals; after all, the gym is a great leveller.

I'd originally wanted to be a footballer and was an apprentice at Shrewsbury Town but that didn't work out (I was never quite quick enough) and I went to the US on a soccer scholarship. I'd always kept myself fit, and got interested in coaching and personal training over there. I like to think it's because I want to help people; anyone who is just doing it for himself is eventually going to be found out.

That's hard to do when you are tired, but you have to remember why they're coming - they're coming for help and advice and they expect you to be on form. Sometimes it's hard: if I do eight people in a day it gets tough. You can burn out and feel yourself thinking, "I don't want to deal with these people any more"; some days you go home at night and you just can't bear to be nice to your friends and flatmates. Perhaps I should get a personal trainer too.

fields.headline: Off the hook
fields.standfirst: A dying smoker is $20m richer after suing two tobacco firms. But her victory is based on a dangerously ignorant view of addiction, says  Dr Theodore Dalrymple, because there is no such thing as a habit that cannot be overcome
fields.trailText: A dying smoker is $20m richer after suing two tobacco firms. But her victory is based on a dangerously ignorant view of addiction, says  Dr Theodore Dalrymple, because there is no such thing as a habit that cannot be overcome
fields.body:
A 40-year-old woman in California called Leslie Whiteley has just been awarded $20m (£12.6m) in damages against two giant tobacco companies, RJ Reynolds and Philip Morris. A mother of four, she now suffers from lung cancer with secondaries, and therefore cannot have long to live. She started to smoke in 1972, at the age of 13, and continued to do so for quarter of a century.

At first sight, this might seem like a triumph for the small man (or woman) over the big wicked companies. After all, they sell a product that is, in the words of our late sovereign, James I, "lothsome to the eye, hatefull to the Nose, harmefull to the braine, dangerous to the Lungs, and in the black stinking fume thereof, neerest resembling the horrible Stigian smoke of the pit that is bottomlesse". Welcome indeed to Marlboro country. At long last, the award to Leslie Whiteley offers a ray of hope to thousands, and perhaps millions, of potential litigants in a similar predicament.

In fact, the award is deeply demeaning of the capacity of the ordinary person to regulate his own affairs and is subversive of the rule of law into the bargain. While every sympathy must of course be extended to the sufferer from this horrid disease, especially at so early an age, the fact is that she took up smoking almost certainly knowing that she ought not to have done so (packets were already marked with health warnings in those days, and knowledge about many of the dangers of smoking was already so general that I never met anyone at the time who was unaware of them). It is hardly the companies' fault if the adults responsible for her welfare failed to exercise sufficient control over her to prevent her from smoking.

But once having started, whether through the natural perversity of youth or the negligence of her adult guardians, she would quickly have become addicted to nicotine: at least, that must be the justification for considering her the helpless victim of the companies she later sued. And, having once become addicted, what could she do but continue smoking for another 25 years, until her health (presumably) forced her to give up?

But is addiction really synonymous with helplessness? Does addiction so deprive us of the ability to choose between alternative courses of action that we become helpless pawns of drug pushers, whether they be tobacco companies, publicans or street corner heroin dealers?

This is an utterly self-serving conception of addiction, and the answer to the question is clearly no. Perhaps it is conceivable that there could be an addiction so powerful that it would be unreasonable to expect anyone to overcome it: but so far no such addiction has ever come to medical knowledge. Even the plaintiff, be it remembered, gave up smoking in the end - though too late, alas.

Contrary to what is commonly supposed, addiction is not a straightforwardly physiological phenomenon. Of course, there is a physiological component to it: but it is only one component among others. Even withdrawal symptoms of opiate drugs are powerfully affected by the pre-existing state of mind of the person who is withdrawing.

Addiction is not an abject state of slavery, nor does the addicted person cease to make choices. The idea that someone who is addicted to a drug has thereby lost all control of himself is nonsense. Epidemiological studies demonstrate that many people who were once drug-addicted, and who never even came to medical attention, stop taking their drug of addiction of their own volition. Only a small minority of the thousands of heroin-addicted US soldiers, for example, continued their drug abuse on returning home from Vietnam.

Experimental work suggests that even alcoholics who are physically dependent on alcohol are able to modify their drinking, if given immediate incentives to do so. Many heavy smokers who have heart attacks never smoke another cigarette afterwards. And millions of smokers have given up without having been ill in the first place. In other words, the cultural and psychological circumstances of a person powerfully affect whether he continues to take a drug of addiction or not.

Among the psychological circumstances that affect his behaviour is the belief he holds about his own ability to control himself. If he believes - self-servingly - that he is a slave to his passion, he will not even try to control himself. And the mistaken belief that withdrawal symptoms from opiates are very severe is one of the factors that keeps a person miserably in thrall to his drug.

Thus a verdict that treats a person as having been a helpless victim of a drug (in this case nicotine) actually promotes the very evil it purports to redress - much to the delight of the lawyers, who certainly do not want people to stop smoking or the tobacco companies to go bankrupt. For no egg will ever be more golden than that laid by the goose of tobacco litigation in the United States.

The American verdict is subversive of the rule of law because the companies were engaged in a business that was, and still is, perfectly legal. Sufficient bad effects from smoking were known in 1972 to deter any sensible person from taking up the habit, if he or she paid any attention to such matters. No number of subsequent revelations about the effects of smoking has induced any government anywhere in the world to ban smoking altogether, and in most juris- dictions the government profits more from the consumption of a packet of cigarettes than does the tobacco company that manufactured them.

Why, then, is the government not sued along with the tobacco companies? Because the chances of extracting large sums of money in compensation from the government are vanishingly small and would suit no demagogic purpose.

Meanwhile, the American verdict treats addicts (and a great many of us are addicts of something or other, at least at some time in our lives) as legal minors who lack capacity to alter their behaviour. The authoritarian implications of this are frightening.

webTitle: Britain finds the world is just not listening

fields.headline: Britain finds the world is just not listening
fields.standfirst: Robin Cook is pursuing a policy of political dialogue wherever it may prove beneficial, but, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall, he is handicapped by the country's declining diplomatic leverage
fields.trailText: 4pm analysis: Robin Cook is pursuing a policy of political dialogue wherever it may prove beneficial, but, writes Guardian foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall, he is handicapped by the country's declining diplomatic leverage
fields.body:
In a speech last January defining Britain's foreign policy goals, the foreign secretary Robin Cook outlined a strategy of "critical engagement". He described this as "the pursuit of political dialogue wherever it can produce benefits" and listed, by way of illustration, the government's efforts to repair and expand relations with post-Falklands Argentina, Libya, Iran and Cuba.

Mr Cook's pragmatic approach reflects both Britain's considerable experience of international affairs and its diminished leverage. But as recent events have shown, even this modest policy has inherent problems. Take the following examples:

In Zimbabwe, where President Robert Mugabe is fighting for his political life, Britain is pushing hard for "free and fair" elections to be held as soon as possible, as required by the country's constitution.

It has eschewed the use of punitive sanctions, as urged by the Conservative opposition following the farm seizures backed by Mr Mugabe. It also opposes, for the time being at least, the suspension of Zimbabwe from the Commonwealth.

But the government's line is proving increasingly hard to sustain. Public pressure to act against Mr Mugabe is growing in Britain. Many in southern Africa fear an economic collapse, and possible bloodshed, if Mr Mugabe is not stopped. The US has already cut aid to Zimbabwe. Most problematically of all, Britain's "dialogue" with Mr Mugabe has virtually ceased. "He's just not listening," a British g official said.

In Pakistan, another Commonwealth member (currently suspended), Britain is also having difficulty making its voice heard. The country's military ruler, General Pervez Musharraf, who seized power in a coup last October, has turned a deaf ear to British envoys who have urged him to curb Pakistan's nuclear weapons programme, back arms control treaties, and resume a dialogue with India over Kashmir.

Even US President Bill Clinton, who travelled to Islamabad recently, found that a face-to-face talk failed to make any significant difference on key issues. The benefits for Britain of "critical engagement" with Pakistan are clear, not least when it comes to foreign aid and weapons proliferation. But Gen Musharraf basically refuses to be engaged.

The limitations of Mr Cook's policy have been amply illustrated elsewhere. He visited Moscow earlier this year, but in common with European Union and US politicians, failed to persuade the president-elect, Vladimir Putin, to curb his armed forces in Chechnya (where the war continues). The Anglo-Russian dialogue will continue this weekend when Mr Putin visits London. But that is unlikely to help the Chechens.

In the Horn of Africa, where famine threatens up to 16m people, British concerns about Ethiopia's senseless war with Eritrea have fallen on deaf ears. Instead, Ethiopia accuses Britain and the west of using the conflict as a pretext for withholding food aid. Ethiopia calculates that the west will provide the aid anyway, eventually, leaving it free to prosecute its war aims.

Even the US, Britain's closest ally, is quite capable of closing its ears when Britain applies "critical engagement" to subjects it finds uncomfortable. It is becoming increasingly clear, for example, that many in Britain are concerned about American plans to involve the UK in its new "national missile defence" scheme. Defence officials worry it could make Britain a target for missiles from "rogue states".

But Washington does not want to hear this; or, for that matter, British criticism of the continuing, widespread use in the US of the death penalty, now abolished by all EU states and regarded here with increasing disgust.

Mr Cook believes in doing what is possible, when it's possible, in the British and the general interest. That is fine in theory. But the sad fact, when it comes down to it, is that a lot of leaders and countries are simply not listening to Britain any more.

webTitle: Aardman's Angry Kid debuts on the web

fields.headline: Aardman's Angry Kid debuts on the web
fields.trailText: Angry Kid, the new stop-motion creation from the award-winning Aardman Animations, the company behind Wallace and Gromit, will make his first appearance on the web
fields.body:
Angry Kid, the new stop-motion creation from the award-winning Aardman Animations, the company behind Wallace and Gromit, will make his first appearance on the web, it was announced today. The first of a series of 60-second shorts will go online at Atom Films from midnight on 7 May, with further adventures following in the ensuing weeks.

Working from their base in Bristol, Aardman has become synonymous with the whimsical antics of Wallace and Grommit. But Angry Kid - a bug-eyed juvenile delinquent in an unzipped Parka - promises to be an altogether more abrasive animal, a character more in tune with the Stateside shock-tactics of South Park or The Simpsons than the cosy world of British family animation. Angry Kid is the brain-child of Aardman employee Darren Walsh and has been described as "anarchic, irreverent and definitely not family viewing."

Perhaps wary of offending the sensibilities of mainstream TV audiences, Aardman have elected to establish a presence and cult following for Angry Kid on the web "We believe the internet could well prove to be one of the most exciting platforms for entertainment distribution," said co-founder and managing director Dave Sprockton. The news follows hot on the heels of last month's announcement that director David Lynch is developing a series of animated shorts to be aired exclusively on the American website Shockwave. The web, it seems, is fast becoming the best place to test-drive a new show or character.

webTitle: Police question father after Newcastle injury baby dies

fields.headline: Police question father after Newcastle injury baby dies
fields.trailText: A five-month-old baby found with head injuries in a pram at a Newcastle Metro station has died.  Police are questioning his father in connection with the incident.
fields.body:
A five-month-old baby found with head injuries in a pram at a Newcastle Metro station has died. Police are questioning his father in connection with the incident.

The policeman leading the investigation, Det Supt Chris Symonds, said the death of the infant was now being treated as murder.

Northumbria Police arrested the baby's 25-year-old father and three juveniles after the incident at Manors station on the city's train network. Detectives have been allowed to detain the father for another 36 hours. The three boys were released on police bail pending further inquiries.

Police discovered the baby in a blue pram on Sunday afternoon at Manors Metro station on the edge of Newcastle city centre. His father was with him.

The baby was taken to Newcastle General Hospital where he spent two nights in intensive care.

This afternoon police renewed appeals for witnesses.

Anyone with information is asked to contact the incident room on 0191 214 6555 or Crimestoppers on 0800 555111.

webTitle: In brief, and the latest casting news

fields.headline: In brief, and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Almodovar gets artistic, Chabrol and Friedkin get musical, and NBC and Martin Landau take on the greatest story ever told
fields.body:
 While in LA to receive his Oscar, Pedro Almodovar is reported to have been approached by Miramax to direct a film on Mexico's art luminaries Frida Kahlo et Diego Rivera. The biopic, which has been in the pipeline for many years now, had until recently been entrusted to the Brasilian Walter 'Central Station' Salles. Mexico's other famous daughter Salma Hayek and Alfred Molina (Magnolia, Dead Man) are being considered for the leads.

 Claude Chabrol, the French director best known in the UK for Le Boucher and the Ruth Rendell-based La Cérémonie, is in the middle of shooting his latest endeavour, Merci pour le chocolat. Set in the chocolate industry, it is again a sinister thriller based on a novel, written this time by Charlotte Armstrong. It stars Chabrol veteran Isabelle Huppert - last seen in London's West End last year playing Mary Stuart - and 60s singer Jacques Dutronc, who fittingly plays a virtuoso pianist who weds Huppert for the second time.

 Biopics continue to be a popular genre for many, including William Friedkin, the director of French Connection and The Exorcist, who is to begin work on a film about the life of composer Giacomo Puccini. Tenor Placido Domingo will play the tortured musician. Screenwriter Luciano Vincenzoni, better known for his work on spaghetti westerns in the 60s - For a Few Dollars More and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly - will write the script in collaboration with Domingo's wife.

Casting couch

 US TV station NBC has announced the creation of a four-hour mini-series of the Bible's most enduring stories, entitled In the Beginning and starring Martin Landau, Jacqueline Bisset and Omar Sharif. The TV movie begins with the story of Creation and ends with Moses delivering the Ten Commandments. Landau will star as Abraham and Bisset as his wife, Sarah, while Sharif will play Jethro, the father of Moses' wife, Zipporah. Shooting began yesterday in Morocco and will move to Budapest.

It stars Chabrol veteran Isabelle Huppert - last seen in London's West End last year playing Mary Stuart - and 60s singer Jacques Dutronc, who fittingly plays a virtuoso pianist who weds Huppert for the second time.  Biopics continue to be a popular genre for many, including William Friedkin, the director of French Connection and The Exorcist, who is to begin work on a film about the life of composer Giacomo Puccini. Tenor Placido Domingo will play the tortured musician. Screenwriter Luciano Vincenzoni, better known for his work on spaghetti westerns in the 60s - For a Few Dollars More and The Good, the Bad and the Ugly - will write the script in collaboration with Domingo's wife. Casting couch  US TV station NBC has announced the creation of a four-hour mini-series of the Bible's most enduring stories, entitled In the Beginning and starring Martin Landau, Jacqueline Bisset and Omar Sharif. The TV movie begins with the story of Creation and ends with Moses delivering the Ten Commandments. Landau will star as Abraham and Bisset as his wife, Sarah, while Sharif will play Jethro, the father of Moses' wife, Zipporah. Shooting began yesterday in Morocco and will move to Budapest.

webTitle: Search for Harry Potter draws thousands

fields.headline: Search for Harry Potter draws thousands
fields.trailText: The search for a young British actor to play the role of Harry Potter, the child wizard hero of JK Rowling's immensely popular novels, is now officially under way. Thousands of children are expected to audition for the part, with the casting kicking off in three weeks' time.
fields.body:
The search for a young British actor to play the role of Harry Potter, the child wizard hero of JK Rowling's immensely popular novels, is now officially under way. Thousands of children are expected to audition for the part, with the casting kicking off in three weeks' time.

The ideal candidate is described as aged between 9 and 11, with some drama experience, gained either at school or in a drama club, and who will not "be fazed by working with a film company" - a tall order for anyone, let alone a school kid. But that doesn't seem to have deterred the 8,000 applicants who have already contacted casting director Susie Figgis.

The hunt is also on for two young actors to play Harry's best friends, Ron and Hermione. "For Ron, red hair, freckles, a little bit bigger than Harry, and needs to be able to act Hermione - she's annoying and too clever by half and a little bit bossy, but she's wonderful because she's utterly loyal and a friend," said Ms Figgis.

The high profile movie, entitled Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone after the US title of the first book in the series, will begin filming in its home country at the end of the summer. Harry's character will be created by director Chris Columbus, who seems to have cornered the market in kids movies - previous efforts include Mrs Doubtfire and Home Alone.

 Any aspiring child star should send a photograph with their age, acting experience, height and phone number to: Harry Potter Production Office, c/o Pinewood Studios, Iver Heath, Buckinghamshire, SL0 0NH.

fields.headline: Suren, Sergei and Slaps
fields.trailText: GALATASARAY HIT BACK
fields.body:
GALATASARAY HIT BACK

In 24 hours, Uefa will decide whether or not to allow Galatasaray fans to travel to Elland Road for next week's Uefa Cup semi-final tie. Rumours as to the possible outcome remain contradictory. So it's not surprising to find Galatasaray putting the case for the defence today.

Club president Faruk Suren led the charge, responded to Peter Ridsdale's accusations of insensitivity by offering his sympathies to the families of the murdered Leeds fans. He also promised to follow whatever decision Uefa eventually makes. "While we think it is unfair that this matter carries on and that Turkish supporters should not be allowed to travel, we will come and play without our supporters if that is what Uefa decide," he told Radio 5 Live.

After the humility came further defensive gestures. The club's general secretary Sinan Kalpikciolu said that as the events had occurred away from the stadium they had "nothing to do with football or Galatasaray". Club captain Gica Popescu claimed the crimes took place in Istanbul's answer to Compton. "The incident happened in the most dangerous zone of Istanbul - not a place where anybody would be advised to go", he said of the Taksim Square area which has alternatively been described as the city's entertainment district.

Popescu went on to remind Britons that "Here in Turkey people are genuinely distressed by what happened." A heart-warming sentiment, but one that varies substantially from that of vice-president Senes Erizik. Erizik claimed today that the deaths were the responsibility of a minority of Leeds fans. "The achieved their goal," he said. "On the night they were the provokers." We await Uefa's decision with interest.

REBR-OFF

He's a beacon for stumpy footballers everywhere, and was the man tipped to put the glitter back into White Hart Lane. Today he's the subject of a £10m bid from AC Milan, and David Pleat is wearing the glitter to make himself look more alluring to big-name strikers. Ladies and gentlemen, we give you Sergei Rebrov.

The man who was expected to link Steffen Freund with Chris Armstrong has been the subject of transfer speculation all season - ever since he showed that he could still score goals in the absence of strike partner Andrei Shevchenko. Rebrov scored eight times in Big Cup this season, and his reward looks to be a reunion with Shevchenko in surroundings rather more glamorous than Kiev's Grushevskii Street.

Milan have made their move after reports suggested they weren't the only big club chasing Rebrov. Spurs were also supposed to be interested. But Milan have always had first dibs on Rebrov and, along with Valencia's midfield star Gerard, he is likely to be one of the key components in the summer rebuilding plans at the San Siro. Fortunately for Spurs though, Geoff Horsfield's Fulham future is still in some doubt.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"They're European champions for God's sake!" - Paul Ince explains why Middlesbrough's valiant fightback came to nothing last night.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

SLAP HAPPY

The city of Liverpool hasn't witnessed much snorting, sniffing, smacking or slapping for a while now. So thank God for the return of the top flight's top two top scouse scallies - yes, Robbie Fowler and Francis Jeffers are on their way back to the Premiership.

Snort! Robbie, whose best display this season was a sheepish televised apology for his touchline antics during a Merseyside derby, has not played since Boxing Day. Sniff! The staunch heterosexual will return in Liverpool's reserve match at Bradford tonight.

Slap! Francis, who made his mark on this campaign by weakly wafting his hands around Sander Westerveld's head during a(nother) Merseyside derby, has been injured since an England U-21 game at Fulham in February. Smack! He's been earmarked - stop sniggering - to play for Everton reserves at Leeds this evening.

Both players are likely to return to their respective first teams for... oh lordy... the Merseyside derby on Good Friday. Clobber! Clank! Cosh! Clout!

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Dutch striker Ruud van Nistelrooy will stay in Holland if discussions about a move to the Premiership have not begun by May Day. The £20m-rated PSV Eindhoven star, who has attracted the interest of Arsenal, Manchester United and Chelsea, told the Express: "If none of the clubs interested in me open discussions with PSV by the start of May, I'll stay another year in Holland. I will sign the improved contract PSV have put before me."

Gordon Strachan is after Romanian international midfielder Constantin Galca. The defensive midfielder who plays for Primera Liga side Espanyol, will be out of contract this summer, and Strachan looks set to pounce.

Sheffield Wednesday defender Peter Atherton could move back to Wigan Athletic, his hometown club, this summer. Relegation-bound Wednesday are looking to offload a number of players to cut their wage bill, and captain Atherton would jump at the chance to move to rejoin the Latics if they are promoted.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

West Ham are close to agreeing a £4m deal for Lyon's Frederic Kanoute, currently on loan at Upton Park. The arrival of the French U-21 international may see Paulo Wanchope move to Leicester.

Bolton have been fined £45,000 by the Football League for poaching manager Sam Allardyce from Notts County last October. They are considering an appeal.

John Duncan has been sacked as manager of Chesterfield. The Spireites are currently nine points adrift at the bottom of the Second Division and have won just five of their 40 league games this season.

Everton will ban for life any fans they can identify as having hurled racist abuse at Leicester's Turkish midfielder Muzzy Izzet. "I have written to both the chairman of Leicester and the player," said Everton chairman Philip Carter, "and I have asked if there are any instances that have been recorded where they were able to identify individuals then we should know about it."

Rangers boss Dick Advocaat has been named the Bank of Scotland SPL Manager of the month for March.

fields.headline: House prices
fields.standfirst: Everything you need to know about the ups and downs of the housing market on the net
fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the ups and downs of the housing market on the net
fields.body:
1. House price growth is on the wane, says the Halifax: it has slowed for the second quarter in a row.

2. But before you rush out and snap up a bargain piece of property with the loose change in your pocket, you should consult the figures again: a typical London house has still risen by 4% this year, while prices in the west Midlands and the south-west rose 5.1% and 5%. In the north of England, they increased by just 1%.

3. There should continue to be "a robust housing market during 2000", purrs a Halifax spokesman, happy to watch all that mortgage money roll in as the British pursue their peculiar obsession with owning their own home.

4. If you're one of the lucky owners of property in a house price hot spot, you can consult the multitude of price indexes to calculate how much money you've made and how much other properties up your street have been sold for.

5. With the hazards of mortgage mis-selling and gazumping, buying and moving house is said to be the third most traumatic life event after death and divorce. And money made in the housing price boom can be as hard to realise as the Queen's internet fortune.

6. However, you can consult Money Unlimited's handy guide to moving house and tips on cashing in on the property boom.

7. If you're one of the unlucky ones priced out of the housing market, you can take (cold) comfort from the fact that you're not alone. The National Federation of Housing has found that buyers need annual earnings of more than £20,000 to buy an average home in three-quarters of England's counties. In parts of London, you need £70,000.

8. The good news is that a new government green paper promises to help "key workers" in the public sector afford astronomically priced homes, offering interest-free top-up loans of around £50,000 for people unable to get a mortgage in the south and London, where house prices rose by 23% last year.

9. The bad news? It's a commitment unlikely to be fulfilled by the government until well after the next general election.

10. If you're among the unluckiest of all and have to make your home on the street, you can ponder the paradox that has emerged during the house price boom, which for every single homeless person in England has left seven homes empty.

fields.headline: Ethiopian crisis
fields.standfirst: Clare Short, the international development secretary, has hit back at those who have criticised her department for cutting aid to Ethiopia at a time when it faces famine. Mark Tran examines how much Britain is giving to the beleaguered African nation
fields.trailText: Clare Short, the international development secretary, has hit back at those who have criticised her department for cutting aid to Ethiopia at a time when it faces famine. Mark Tran examines how much Britain is giving to the beleaguered African nation
fields.body:
Is Britain reducing aid for Ethiopia?
Yes. The Department for International Development (DFID) last year planned to give £39.2m in long-term development aid to Ethiopia over the next three years. But this year, Clare Short decided to cut the amount to £19m.

Why?
Aid officials say they cannot be sure that the money, which is handled by the Ethiopian government, is getting through to the people who need aid. DFID is also worried that development money is being diverted to Ethiopia's war with its northern neighbour and former ally, Eritrea. "I do not believe anyone in the UK believes we should be providing long-term assistance to a country which is increasing its spending on arms, year on year," Ms Short told the Guardian.

What about relief efforts for the threatened famine?
The government draws a distinction between development aid for schools and roads and relief aid to stave off famine. DFID says the UK is one of the main contributors to the international relief effort and has provided some £2.4m of food aid, which will be distributed to some of the worst-affected regions.

What is behind the latest famine scare?
Landlocked Ethiopia is regularly afflicted by drought. In 1985, up to a million people died. Mengistu Haile Mariam, the dictator at the time, refused to admit that there was a problem, thereby aggravating the crisis. The current dry spell began in 1998 and the government was able to draw on well-positioned reserves to feed people until international aid arrived.

So what is the problem?
The European Union has been slow in replenishing the stocks even though the Ethiopian government warned of impending shortages in December last year. DFID officials says Britain replenished its stocks last year and added to them, although other EU countries have not been as prompt. Unicef has estimated that 900,000 tonnes of supplies are urgently needed.

To what extent has the conflict with Eritrea hampered the relief effort?
In a recent statement, Ms Short said: "The failure of the last three years' rains is the root cause of Ethiopia's current crisis, but there is little doubt that the continuing conflict with Eritrea is hampering the response to relief efforts and valuable resources are being diverted to perpetuating the conflict." UN secretary general Kofi Annan has made the same point. The fighting has been confined to the border strip, away from the highlands, where potentially eight million people are at risk. The highlands' closest port, Assab, is part of Eritrea, but the docks in neighbouring Djibouti have been improved, although Djibouti is further away.

What is the cause of the conflict?
The war between Eritrea and Ethiopia started nearly two years ago over the demarcation of their common border. There has not been any serious fighting for about two months, but both sides are believed to have about 500,000 troops available.

webTitle: The Falash Mura: Ethiopia's other tragedy

fields.headline: The Falash Mura: Ethiopia's other tragedy
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown, former Guardian correspondent in Jerusalem, reports on the uncertain
welcome in Israel for the dispossessed descendants of Jews who converted to Christianity
fields.trailText:
The Israeli interior minister Natan Sharansky is in Ethiopia, holding out hope
for thousands of its dispossessed and suffering citizens.
fields.body:
The Israeli interior minister Natan Sharansky is in Ethiopia, holding out hope for thousands of its dispossessed and suffering citizens.

But these are not famine victims. They are the so-called Falash Mura, descendants of local Jews who converted to Christianity, and now want to embrace Judaism again as their ticket to Israel.

There are an estimated 26,000 Falash Mura, of whom some 18,000 have abandoned their homes and now live in squalid transit camps in Addis Ababa and the northern city of Gondar.

Their status is hotly controversial in Israel, which is struggling to assimilate hundreds of thousands of immigrants from the former Soviet Union - among them Natan Sharansky.

More than 50,000 Ethiopian Jews already live in Israel. Many were secretly whisked out of their homeland during the Mengistu dictatorship. Although they have been officially welcomed and given full citizenship, most of the community live in visibly poorer circumstances than other Israelis.

That does not deter the Falash Mura, who are determined to escape the infinitely poorer conditions of Ethiopia. Many have Jewish relatives already in Israel, but proving their relationship is desperately hard in a land where identity documents are scarce or non-existent.

Some of the Falash Mura have endured the squalor of the transit camps for years. They study Judaism and Hebrew in their anxiety to prove their allegiance, but only a trickle are rewarded with Israeli passports.

Sharansky has expressed sympathy with their plight. "I was in jail in Russia for nine years because I wanted to reach Israel," he told one group. But, he added, Israel could not accept everyone who wanted to come.

Israel's Law of Return, which lies at the core of the state's very existence, says that anyone with a Jewish grandparent can settle in the Jewish state. But halachic, or religious, law specifies that a person can be Jewish only if he or she has a Jewish mother. Within the tidal wave of post-Soviet immigration, there are thousands of non-Jews with only a tenuous claim to citizenship of Israel.

To complicate the issue still further, there are bitter disputes between rabbinical authorities about the conversion of gentiles. Some orthodox Jews believe that conversion is impossible. Liberal opinion holds it to be perfectly permissible.

Underlying the arcane debates about Jewishness is an uncomfortable if rarely voiced suspicion that Israel is holding the Falash Mura at arm's length because they are poor - and black.

fields.headline: Testigo
fields.standfirst: Eduardo Bastos was one of the first to go to Mozambique with Médicos sin Fronteras
fields.trailText: Eduardo Bastos was one of the first to go to Mozambique with M*dicos sin Fronteras
fields.body:
Al principio, y durante quince días, en Mozambique sólo había cuatro helicópteros de rescate. Son helicópteros con dos horas de autonomía de vuelo. Mozambique es un país llano. El río Seva, que normalmente se cruza a pie, tenía siete kilómetros de ancho. Había grupos de personas dispersos y distantes, algunos de 300 personas, otros de 15.000 personas. Y al inundarse nuevas áreas, la situación cambiaba constantemente. Estos factores complicaron mucho la operación de rescate.

Mi trabajo consiste en organizar la logística de las ayudas para Médicos sin Fronteras España. Volé a Maputo con un médico de la organización tan pronto como tuvimos la certitud del desastre que se anunciaba. La información metereológica no dejaba dudas. Durante tres días nuestro trabajo fue recoger información. Y tres días más tarde aterrizó el primer Boeing de Médicos sin Fronteras España. La mayoría de la ayuda internacional no llegó hasta una semana después.

En estas situaciones, ante una masa abúlica de dos mil o tres mil personas, es sorprendente cómo un megáfono puede evitar muchos desastres. En Mozambique, sin embargo, no teníamos ni megáfono. Y el agua avanzaba un kilómetro por hora. Para movilizar a la gente reuníamos a grupos de diez personas y les decíamos que dijeran a sus familiares y amigos que se desplazaran de la zona. Con calma, pero que se fueran. En una ocasión, tras estudiar los riesgos de una área, montamos un campamento. Calculamos que llegarían allí unas 15.000 personas, y llegaron hasta 80.000.

Lo más duro de mi trabajo es que en el ochenta por ciento de los casos las catástrofes son predecibles y evitables.

evitar to avoid
montar to set up
no dejaba dudas left no doubts
tan pronto como as soon as

 Eduardo Bastos was speaking to Eulölia Furriol.

fields.headline: Ridsdale rounds on Galatasaray
fields.standfirst: Full background
fields.trailText: Peter Ridsdale has accused Galatasaray of showing a "lack of respect" and being "opportunistic" in the wake of last week's murder of two Leeds fans in Istanbul.
fields.body:
Peter Ridsdale has accused Galatasaray of showing a "lack of respect" and being "opportunistic" in the wake of last week's murder of two Leeds fans in Istanbul. Uefa will decide tomorrow whether to uphold Leeds's decision to ban Galatasaray fans from the Uefa Cup semi-final second leg at Elland Road on Thursday week for fear of reprisals.

Indications suggest that it will support the west Yorkshire club. "We are confident Uefa will back Leeds' position," Steve Double, the Football Association's spokesman, said yesterday. But what has upset Ridsdale is the way he feels Galatasaray have used last Wednesday's stabbings of Christopher Loftus and Kevin Speight to try to gain advantage on the field.

When Leeds announced they wanted to ban the Istanbul club's fans from the second leg Galatasaray immediately argued that, if the safety of their supporters could not be guaranteed, then the Premiership club should play the game at a neutral venue.

Now, in a move seemingly designed to exert pressure on Uefa, Galatasaray have threatened to pull out of the tie if European football's governing body decides their fans should be banned.

Yesterday Uefa formally asked Leeds and the FA whether the security of Galatasaray fans can be guaranteed. Leeds have made their position clear but only Uefa can sanction the withholding of tickets. Uefa has also asked what Leeds and police plan to do if Galatasaray supporters arrive without tickets.

Galatasaray will almost certainly face Uefa punishment if they pull out of the tie, which they lead 2-0. But yesterday Ridsdale described a withdrawal as "the best thing they can do, frankly".

The Leeds chairman added: "Since [the stabbings] happened Galatasaray appear to me to have been opportunistic. They have been trying to find any means possible to get through to the final without kicking a football. Two people were murdered. I saw the stab wounds and I never want to see anything like that again.

"I just wish Galatasaray would step back and realise the impact that the events of Wednesday have had and at least show some respect, which at the moment appears to be lacking. The only thing that seems to be happening is to see every loophole and opportunity to get through to the final whilst undermining everything Leeds United have tried to do, and I think that's unfortunate."

He also defended the club's decision to go ahead with last Thursday's first leg. "We played in circumstances which nobody should have been expected to. We played it because I'm not prepared for people to feel that the only way to progress through to the final of a competition is to go out and murder innocent people.

"Galatasaray, from my perspective, would be best served by acknowledging there's a game to be played a week on Thursday. They should turn up as a team, with their officials. They will be afforded every respect and given every opportunity to savour the hospitality which is afforded to any visiting club; and, whatever the result, it should stand.

"But to try and undermine what we wish to have, which is a return leg at Elland Road without any risk to any individual no matter what nationality, I feel saddened by the response."

Five Turkish youths have been charged with the murders. Eighteen were brought before prosecutors but 13, including five juveniles, were freed without immediate charges.

fields.headline: The invisible man
fields.standfirst:
In the 50s he helped invent pop art. In the 60s his huge, advert-inspired canvases were the talk of the London art scene. In the 70s oil millionaires were queuing up to buy them. Then, in the 80s, he vanished. What happened to Richard Smith? And what does his story tell us about the nature of fame in art? Continuing his revealing series, Gordon Burn meets the quiet star who fell to earth
Gordon Burn meets Damien Hirst
fields.trailText: In the 50s he helped invent pop art. In the 60s his huge, advert-inspired canvases were the talk of the London art scene. In the 70s oil millionaires were queuing up to buy them. Then, in the 80s, he vanished. What happened to Richard Smith? And what does his story tell us about the nature of fame in art? Continuing his revealing series, Gordon Burn meets the quiet star who fell to earth
fields.body:
If Richard Smith had been looking for a metaphor for how his reputation has withered and his work become discarded, for how (as he believes) he has been written out of recent British art history, he found an indelible one a couple of Thursdays ago, on a fleeting visit to London from his home in New York.

Every British artist - "living and dead", as Smith puts it - had been invited to turn up at a picture-call to mark the relaunch of the Tate Gallery as Tate Britain. Smith had a career retrospective at the Tate in 1975, when he was still in his 40s. A number of his pantechnicon-sized, three-dimensional "constructed" canvases are in the permanent collection.

And he duly took his place on the steps at Millbank alongside the great and the good, the young and not-so-young Turks, the ennobled and bearded grandees, freighted with reputation and achievement. Present were some of the eminent pop-ists who with Richard Smith invented pop art in this country in the late 50s. Peter Blake was there, and so was Patrick Caulfield. Also present was Smith's old friend and former Wiltshire neighbour, Sir Howard Hodgkin, who, in the years that Smith's standing has been steadily eroded, has made himself enormously famous and important.

The PR persons with the clip-boards had ticked off who had turned up and who hadn't, the artists had been whipped into some sort of order, the snappers had been assembled beneath the scrubbed-up portico... and suddenly there was a stampede away from the official picture opportunity in the direction of another one that had unexpectedly presented itself. Tracey Emin in a biker jacket and brassy jewellery had arrived in a taxi. Smiles froze on the faces of the official group. "Tracey, give us a smile, Tracey..." Mad Tracey from Margate, whose career still has a lot of heat under it. Our lady of the photo op. "Give me eyes, Tracey!" Smiles broadened on the faces of the PR contingent. Aluminium ladders crashed. Pandemonium.

But enough of symbolism. The reality for Smith was even crueller. When he wandered inside to take a look at the radical new rehang, it brought home to him that - while there were Hodgkins and Peter Blakes and Hockneys (a whole room full of Hockneys, his stablemate at the Marquess of Dufferin and Ava-backed Kasmin Gallery in New Bond Street throughout the 60s) - there were no Smiths on display. No Gift Wrap; no Flip Top. None of the extraordinary, bulking, built-out paintings that he came under particularly heavy attack for in the early 60s, accused of strengthening advertising's success by taking it, in the form of abstracted Salem and Philip Morris cigarette packets, as his subject. His best paintings were generally large, sharing a sense of scale with cinema and billboard advertising where, as Smith said at the time, "you could drown in a glass of beer and live in a semi-detached cigarette packet".

Twenty years later, at the main tobacco-sponsored tournaments during the heyday of televised snooker, where the sets echoed the brand "livery" and product packaging, it often looked as if the players were walking around inside a Dick Smith painting.

So he was invisible in terms of his work at the Tate, and almost invisible in his person. Two recent, massively invasive operations on his heart have left him looking frail and almost transparent. He has apparently always been quiet and self-effacing. I remember seeing him many years ago at the movable piss-up that is the Venice Biennale. Howard Hodgkin was the official British representative that year and he was being supported by a roistering group of friends who included Mick Moon, Patrick Caulfield and John Hoyland, plus a man with a rather shuffling, grey, careworn air, who turned out to be Dick Smith.

Just 14 years earlier it had all been very different. In 1970, Smith was the official British artist in Venice. Bernard Jacobson, his current London dealer, remembers being smitten at that time by the glamour surrounding Smith and his American wife, Betsy. "I always thought of him as being like [Scott] Fitzgerald. They were the beautiful people. They had everything. I remember the millionaires all wanting to meet Richard Smith at Venice. I mean real millionaires. Oil millionaires. Multi-millionaires, all over him. The party at Cipriani was amazing: one prominent gallery owner snorting up under the trees, Robert Fraser fixing up, lakes of champagne.

"In the 70s," Jacobson adds, "the market was very, very strong. Stronger than the 60s. The 60s were very, very glamorous. But people were buying in the 70s, when you had the big collectors jumping on board. And Dick was part of that. He was a star."

The world, however, moves on. Although stars may shine for ever, stardom always fades. And in an art world that has been described as being like a carnival with a casino attached, it has a tendency to fade faster than in other arenas. It can be brutal. Up like a rocket, down like a stick. "It's the difference between being recognised in restaurants and being talked about in restaurants," as Louis Menand wrote recently in the New Yorker. "It's the difference between being in evidence and being inevitable."

By 1984, Smith's allure had dulled. The spotlight had shifted. His prices were faltering. "It's when I took up smoking again." he told me, "in Venice for Howard in 84. After that, I was hooked for another many years."

We met for lunch at the Ivy, in London. It is a kind of shrine to the artists of Smith's generation - a Joe Tilson painting on wood is the centrepiece in the bar; paintings by Caulfield, Blake, Hodgkin and Allen Jones line the walls. All his friends. But no Dick Smith. Again Dick Smith was invisible. Just as you will look in vain for him in most recent books on post-war British art.

He arrived before me. I couldn't help noticing that he had positioned himself in such a way that he was looking at one of the Ivy's opaque, leaded windows with its shifting shadows of passing pedestrians, and not directly at any painting. Chris Corbin, who meets and greets at the Ivy at lunchtimes, pressing the flesh of the famous and familiar, schmoozing the hot and happening, failed to materialise at our table.

Smith was born in the commuter- belt in Hertfordshire in 1931. His father was employed at the House of Commons as a printer on Hansard, working nights. Smith did his national service in the RAF, stationed in Hong Kong. And then - like Eduardo Paolozzi, Richard Hamilton and other members of the Independent Group at the ICA half a generation earlier - he got fired up by everything bright and synthetic and American. Living in a country still in the grip of austerity and rationing, he fell in love with the subversive glamour of America.

He was an affront to his teachers at the Royal College of Art, where he started in 1954, on two counts: his paintings were big and splashy and content-free at a time when English painting was still very pastoral, in the landscape tradition; still ruled by "good taste" and common sense. This was especially the case after he had seen the Klines and Pollocks and other abstract expressionist pictures that came to the Tate as part of a hugely influential show of American art in 1956. And then on top of that, he gave them deliberately poppy, throwaway titles like Everly, Staggerly, Packet of Ten, Special Offer. His work was hard-nosed, anti-romantic and urban. He has come to be seen as a precursor of the generation of pop artists that included Allen Jones, Derek Boshier, Pauline Boty, Caulfield and Hockney, which emerged at the Royal College between 1959-62.

He was a thinker. His work had a pronounced intellectual, as well as a purely visceral, dimension. He wrote articles for Ark, the RCA magazine, on men's fashion - "The male image at mid-century" - and interior design in the movies. Smith shared a flat-cum-studio with Peter Blake in his second year at the RCA, and then again for two years after he left the college in 1957. When Terence Conran's Soup Kitchen opened on Fleet Street in the late 1950s, it featured a letter-collage mural by Smith and Blake. Michael Chow would later commission Smith to design installations for his restaurant in Los Angeles, and Chow and Conran have remained two of his biggest supporters.

He went with Peter Blake to see Bill Haley at the Kingston Empire, and Johnny Ray, the "Nabob of Sob", at the London Palladium. "It was really scraping around," he says of their truffling for pop culture in London in the mid-50s. "It seems funny now, but you really had to search it out." In order to feel American - urban and out there and modern - Smith decided it was important to look American. "You liked to dress in an American way, which was immensely problematical. I had a buzzcut. Gerry Mulligan. Gerry Mulligan had a great haircut. Wonderful haircut."

Smith's lifelong subject was to be surface appearance: the resounding shallows of consumer culture; the complex sheen of advertising and packaging. The artists of the first phase of British pop used popular material objectively. Smith and the artists of the second phase shifted their attention to the shrieking, jabbering mediated environment itself.

"I was always an abstract painter," he says. "So I was to do with form and mood and shape and colour. I had no icon. I wasn't into being very specific about the imagery. I didn't want to make it that explicit. Mainstream pop was all about supermarkets and stuff. Low-grade, debased imagery. What intrigued me wasn't the nitty-gritty, down dirty popular culture. It was the high end. These beautiful ads for Smirnoff vodka and glamorous films and store windows and Cinemascope. The upscale. It was an uptown, smart kind of culture that would drive my art."

For the 15 years up to his 1975 Tate retrospective, Smith's life seemed charmed. A Harkness Fellowship took him to New York for two years at the beginning of the 60s. Transplanted from a bedsit studio in Turnham Green to a high-ceilinged, light-filled industrial space in lower Manhattan, his work became correspondingly optimistic and expansive. It spread outwards across the wall, and eventually, on three-dimensional constructed canvases, out into the room. He made a series of paintings based on billboards in Times Square, and gave them titles like Chase Manhattan, Revlon and McCalls. "Richard's paintings had a breathiness and colour and a kind of newness absolutely separate from pop art," Richard Bellamy, his New York dealer in those days, has said. "Those paintings were suffused with light, a different kind of light than I had ever seen."

Back in London, he was visited by John Lennon at his studio in Hoxton, an area then still untouched even by beatnik bohemia; they listened to Motown, hung out. Ken Russell used the studio for the final party section in his film about the British pop artists, Pop Goes the Easel. Smith had a big show at the Whitechapel in 1966, and won the Grand Prize at the Sao Paolo Biennale two years later. He used the money to buy a spread in Wiltshire. "You had that Wiltshire country life," he says, "with Howard [Hodgkin] 20 miles away in this stunning house. This mill. Joe Tilson, John Hoyland. Robyn Denny was living in Bath. You know, it was that. I had a big studio in a schoolhouse. I was the right kind of artist for that kind of time. I just expected to be in international group shows. Then... I don't know."

In Britain, in the years after his retrospective at the Tate, it all suddenly started to go quiet. In 1978, he decided to sell up and move with his wife and son to Manhattan. There was a glamorous three-storey loft in Tribeca. A house in Teluride in Colorado for the skiing. And the other snow - the cocaine. He got heavily into it for a period following his return to America. "There was a lot of it about. Max's Kansas City was going, and the [Warhol] Factory, and I had lots of artist friends. It was there and I started to buy it. Then I tried to turn people on. I was romantic about it, but it didn't mean being a drug-head. It was a passing phase."

He says it was the long winters skiing and the intrusive social life that eventually started to give him the feeling that he wasn't minding the store. "I think Dick got too close," Bernard Jacobson says. "Like [Scott] Fitzgerald in Antibes." Plus Kasmin in London had shut up shop, and the Feigen Gallery in New York had gone over to old masters. Which meant there was nobody stoking the star-maker machinery, turning him into one of those remembered names.

"To be successful as an artist, you have to have your work shown in a good gallery for the same reason that, say, Dior never sold his originals from a counter in Woolworth's," Andy Warhol once wrote. "You need a good gallery so the 'ruling class' will notice you and spread enough confidence in your future so collectors will buy you, whether for $500 or $50,000."

Smith's is no hard-luck story. He is looking forward to a show at Tate Britain next year to mark his 70th birthday, and is still painting every day. He lives comfortably in SoHo. But in 1997, he swapped his place for Gary Hume's place in Hoxton. That was the summer of Sensation and the accompanying mania. It gave him a glimpse of what he had and how it can go.

David Bowie has Dick Smiths in his collection. The Bowie who wrote: "Fame - what you get is no tomorrow."

"Robyn Denny keeps saying, 'Our time will come, Dick. Our time will come.' And he's been saying this for years and years," Smith says. "Years and years and years."
