So he was invisible in terms of his work at the Tate, and almost invisible in his person. Two recent, massively invasive operations on his heart have left him looking frail and almost transparent. He has apparently always been quiet and self-effacing. I remember seeing him many years ago at the movable piss-up that is the Venice Biennale. Howard Hodgkin was the official British representative that year and he was being supported by a roistering group of friends who included Mick Moon, Patrick Caulfield and John Hoyland, plus a man with a rather shuffling, grey, careworn air, who turned out to be Dick Smith. Just 14 years earlier it had all been very different. In 1970, Smith was the official British artist in Venice. Bernard Jacobson, his current London dealer, remembers being smitten at that time by the glamour surrounding Smith and his American wife, Betsy. "I always thought of him as being like [Scott] Fitzgerald. They were the beautiful people. They had everything. I remember the millionaires all wanting to meet Richard Smith at Venice. I mean real millionaires. Oil millionaires. Multi-millionaires, all over him. The party at Cipriani was amazing: one prominent gallery owner snorting up under the trees, Robert Fraser fixing up, lakes of champagne. "In the 70s," Jacobson adds, "the market was very, very strong. Stronger than the 60s. The 60s were very, very glamorous. But people were buying in the 70s, when you had the big collectors jumping on board. And Dick was part of that. He was a star." The world, however, moves on. Although stars may shine for ever, stardom always fades. And in an art world that has been described as being like a carnival with a casino attached, it has a tendency to fade faster than in other arenas. It can be brutal. Up like a rocket, down like a stick. "It's the difference between being recognised in restaurants and being talked about in restaurants," as Louis Menand wrote recently in the New Yorker. "It's the difference between being in evidence and being inevitable." By 1984, Smith's allure had dulled. The spotlight had shifted. His prices were faltering. "It's when I took up smoking again." he told me, "in Venice for Howard in 84. After that, I was hooked for another many years." We met for lunch at the Ivy, in London. It is a kind of shrine to the artists of Smith's generation - a Joe Tilson painting on wood is the centrepiece in the bar; paintings by Caulfield, Blake, Hodgkin and Allen Jones line the walls. All his friends. But no Dick Smith. Again Dick Smith was invisible. Just as you will look in vain for him in most recent books on post-war British art. He arrived before me. I couldn't help noticing that he had positioned himself in such a way that he was looking at one of the Ivy's opaque, leaded windows with its shifting shadows of passing pedestrians, and not directly at any painting. Chris Corbin, who meets and greets at the Ivy at lunchtimes, pressing the flesh of the famous and familiar, schmoozing the hot and happening, failed to materialise at our table. Smith was born in the commuter- belt in Hertfordshire in 1931. His father was employed at the House of Commons as a printer on Hansard, working nights. Smith did his national service in the RAF, stationed in Hong Kong. And then - like Eduardo Paolozzi, Richard Hamilton and other members of the Independent Group at the ICA half a generation earlier - he got fired up by everything bright and synthetic and American. Living in a country still in the grip of austerity and rationing, he fell in love with the subversive glamour of America. He was an affront to his teachers at the Royal College of Art, where he started in 1954, on two counts: his paintings were big and splashy and content-free at a time when English painting was still very pastoral, in the landscape tradition; still ruled by "good taste" and common sense. This was especially the case after he had seen the Klines and Pollocks and other abstract expressionist pictures that came to the Tate as part of a hugely influential show of American art in 1956. And then on top of that, he gave them deliberately poppy, throwaway titles like Everly, Staggerly, Packet of Ten, Special Offer. His work was hard-nosed, anti-romantic and urban. He has come to be seen as a precursor of the generation of pop artists that included Allen Jones, Derek Boshier, Pauline Boty, Caulfield and Hockney, which emerged at the Royal College between 1959-62. He was a thinker. His work had a pronounced intellectual, as well as a purely visceral, dimension. He wrote articles for Ark, the RCA magazine, on men's fashion - "The male image at mid-century" - and interior design in the movies. Smith shared a flat-cum-studio with Peter Blake in his second year at the RCA, and then again for two years after he left the college in 1957. When Terence Conran's Soup Kitchen opened on Fleet Street in the late 1950s, it featured a letter-collage mural by Smith and Blake. Michael Chow would later commission Smith to design installations for his restaurant in Los Angeles, and Chow and Conran have remained two of his biggest supporters. He went with Peter Blake to see Bill Haley at the Kingston Empire, and Johnny Ray, the "Nabob of Sob", at the London Palladium. "It was really scraping around," he says of their truffling for pop culture in London in the mid-50s. "It seems funny now, but you really had to search it out." In order to feel American - urban and out there and modern - Smith decided it was important to look American. "You liked to dress in an American way, which was immensely problematical. I had a buzzcut. Gerry Mulligan. Gerry Mulligan had a great haircut. Wonderful haircut." Smith's lifelong subject was to be surface appearance: the resounding shallows of consumer culture; the complex sheen of advertising and packaging. The artists of the first phase of British pop used popular material objectively. Smith and the artists of the second phase shifted their attention to the shrieking, jabbering mediated environment itself. "I was always an abstract painter," he says. "So I was to do with form and mood and shape and colour. I had no icon. I wasn't into being very specific about the imagery. I didn't want to make it that explicit. Mainstream pop was all about supermarkets and stuff. Low-grade, debased imagery. What intrigued me wasn't the nitty-gritty, down dirty popular culture. It was the high end. These beautiful ads for Smirnoff vodka and glamorous films and store windows and Cinemascope. The upscale. It was an uptown, smart kind of culture that would drive my art." For the 15 years up to his 1975 Tate retrospective, Smith's life seemed charmed. A Harkness Fellowship took him to New York for two years at the beginning of the 60s. Transplanted from a bedsit studio in Turnham Green to a high-ceilinged, light-filled industrial space in lower Manhattan, his work became correspondingly optimistic and expansive. It spread outwards across the wall, and eventually, on three-dimensional constructed canvases, out into the room. He made a series of paintings based on billboards in Times Square, and gave them titles like Chase Manhattan, Revlon and McCalls. "Richard's paintings had a breathiness and colour and a kind of newness absolutely separate from pop art," Richard Bellamy, his New York dealer in those days, has said. "Those paintings were suffused with light, a different kind of light than I had ever seen." Back in London, he was visited by John Lennon at his studio in Hoxton, an area then still untouched even by beatnik bohemia; they listened to Motown, hung out. Ken Russell used the studio for the final party section in his film about the British pop artists, Pop Goes the Easel. Smith had a big show at the Whitechapel in 1966, and won the Grand Prize at the Sao Paolo Biennale two years later. He used the money to buy a spread in Wiltshire. "You had that Wiltshire country life," he says, "with Howard [Hodgkin] 20 miles away in this stunning house. This mill. Joe Tilson, John Hoyland. Robyn Denny was living in Bath. You know, it was that. I had a big studio in a schoolhouse. I was the right kind of artist for that kind of time. I just expected to be in international group shows. Then... I don't know." In Britain, in the years after his retrospective at the Tate, it all suddenly started to go quiet. In 1978, he decided to sell up and move with his wife and son to Manhattan. There was a glamorous three-storey loft in Tribeca. A house in Teluride in Colorado for the skiing. And the other snow - the cocaine. He got heavily into it for a period following his return to America. "There was a lot of it about. Max's Kansas City was going, and the [Warhol] Factory, and I had lots of artist friends. It was there and I started to buy it. Then I tried to turn people on. I was romantic about it, but it didn't mean being a drug-head. It was a passing phase." He says it was the long winters skiing and the intrusive social life that eventually started to give him the feeling that he wasn't minding the store. "I think Dick got too close," Bernard Jacobson says. "Like [Scott] Fitzgerald in Antibes." Plus Kasmin in London had shut up shop, and the Feigen Gallery in New York had gone over to old masters. Which meant there was nobody stoking the star-maker machinery, turning him into one of those remembered names. "To be successful as an artist, you have to have your work shown in a good gallery for the same reason that, say, Dior never sold his originals from a counter in Woolworth's," Andy Warhol once wrote. "You need a good gallery so the 'ruling class' will notice you and spread enough confidence in your future so collectors will buy you, whether for $500 or $50,000." Smith's is no hard-luck story. He is looking forward to a show at Tate Britain next year to mark his 70th birthday, and is still painting every day. He lives comfortably in SoHo. But in 1997, he swapped his place for Gary Hume's place in Hoxton. That was the summer of Sensation and the accompanying mania. It gave him a glimpse of what he had and how it can go. David Bowie has Dick Smiths in his collection. The Bowie who wrote: "Fame - what you get is no tomorrow." "Robyn Denny keeps saying, 'Our time will come, Dick. Our time will come.' And he's been saying this for years and years," Smith says. "Years and years and years."

fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Our daily round-up of all the paper talk and website warblings
fields.trailText: The Mirror Benito Carbone's permanent move to Aston Villa is in doubt again, after Sheffield Wednesday demanded a fee of £750,000 - the result of a gentleman's agreement between Wednesday and Villa chairman Doug Ellis.
fields.body:
The Mirror Benito Carbone's permanent move to Aston Villa is in doubt again, after Sheffield Wednesday demanded a fee of £750,000 - the result of a gentleman's agreement between Wednesday and Villa chairman Doug Ellis.

The Express PSV Eindhoven have issued a May day deadline to any clubs interested in signing their £20m-rated striker Ruud van Nistelrooy. If nobody meets the deadline van Nistelrooy claims he will sign an improved contract at PSV and stay at the club for another year.

Planet football Celtic are likely to approach current French under-21 coach Raymond Domenech to become their new coach. "Nothing is official but I know Celtic have expressed an interest in me going there", said Domenech. "I am flattered and very proud that they are interested."

Former Villa target Haim Revivo looks likely to leave Spanish side Celta Vigo in the summer. The Israeli international winger has fallen out with coach Victor Fernandez, although Revivo said of the dispute: "It is not just Victor, but many more things too."

Daily Star Spurs' highly-rated goalkeeper Espen Baardsen says he will leave White Hart Lane in the summer if he is not given the opportunity of first team football. Norwegian Baardsen is believed to be a target for Wimbledon.

fields.headline: Netconomie: miracle ou grosse arnaque?
fields.standfirst: As the dot.com revolution forges ahead,  Karine Vandenhove asks French youngsters about their relationship with the Internet
fields.trailText: As the dot.com revolution forges ahead,  Karine Vandenhove asks French youngsters about their relationship with the Internet
fields.body:
Livres, bouquets de fleurs, ordinateurs, pneus de voiture, voyages de rêve, chemises sur mesure, vins rares, on trouve de tout sur Internet. Selon le cabinet d'études Benchmark Group, le montant des transactions réalisées dans l'Hexagone par Internet s'est élevé à 1,3 milliards de francs en 1999. Soit trois fois plus qu'en 1998. En 2000, il devrait atteindre 2 milliards de francs. Le nombre de cyberacheteurs français (700 000) ne cesse de croître. Pourtant, d'après un sondage Ernst & Young, 22 % des internautes n'ont pas confiance dans les modes de paiement d'Internet.

Cette Neteffervescence est-elle un phénomène ponctuel ou va-t-elle profondément modifier la structure économique des pays développés ? C'est ce que nous avons demandé à trois jeunes Français, à l'occasion de la Fête de l'Internet qui s'est déroulée les 17, 18 et 19 mars.

Qu'avez-vous fait pour la Fête de l'Internet?

Sophie, 25 ans, informaticienne: Je suis devenue une star sur Internet ! À l'Espace Vivendi, on pouvait créer sa page perso en participant l'opération Devenez une vedette de l'Internet: après avoir été prise en photo, j'ai tourné une mini vidéo sur le thème : Si j'étais une vedette, je serais.... Le résultat: une page perso avec ma photo, ma vidéo et un dessin humoristique.

Damien, 19 ans, lycéen: Rien de spécial. J'ai fait comme d'hab.

Christa, 20 ans, étudiante: Rien, mais ça aurait été sympa que ce soit gratuit tout le week-end !

Quelle est votre relation à l'Internet?

Sophie: Je l'utilise surtout pour communiquer par mail avec des amis à l'international. Je surfe peu sur la Toile, sauf pour visiter de nouveaux sites qui semblent intéressants.

Damien: Je l'utilise 3 à 4 heures par jour, chez moi. Je discute sur les chats ou les IRC, de tout, de la vie de tous les jours, de ce que je fais en cours, etc.

Christa: Les e-mails, les chatlines et la recherche d'informations. Tu trouves tout sur le web (la presse, les plans sorties, les voyages pas chers, etc). C'est mon passe-temps préféré. J'ai l'impression d'étre reliée au monde en permanence.

Quelle sera l'évolution de l'Internet dans le futur?

Sophie: Avec le temps, Internet va se structurer et se banaliser : tout le monde l'aura chez soi, comme le téléphone. Pour l'instant, il y a un peu tout et n'importe quoi. On peut passer des heures à avoir rien, c'est du zapping puissance 1000 ! Pour ne pas se perdre dans la Toile, il faut vraiment savoir ce que l'on recherche. L'idéal, c'est de connaître les adresses des sites.

Damien: Aucune loi ne le réglemente, ça va pas tarder à dégénérer ! Internet s'est développé trop vite, trop soudainement, on ne savait pas par quel bout le prendre. C'est forcé qu'il y ait des dérapages, comme le piratage. Le jour où le gouvernement instaurera des lois sur Internet, tout rentrera dans l'ordre.

Christa: C'est l'avenir ! On est en plein dedans, et ce n'est que le début ! Il y aura de plus en plus de services, d'offres alléchantes, mais aussi de sites craignos. . . Il faut réguler le web et interdire les sites porno, pédophiles ou racistes. Une censure concernant ce genre de sites est nécessaire: il faut créer une police internet internationale.

Que pensez-vous du développement phénoménal des start-up?

Sophie: Cette croissance exponentielle crée beaucoup d'emplois, mais d'ici deux ans, le soufflé va retomber, et on assistera au krach boursier tant redouté. Tout le monde se rue sur les start-up mais elles n'ont aucune valeur réelle. Économiquement, elles ne valent rien.

Damien: C'est trop rapide et trop beau pour que ça dure. La plupart des start-up cotées en bourse sont déficitaires. Elles ne tiendront pas le coup, et se casseront la gueule. Ceux qui les ont financées aussi.

Christa: C'est du pipeau. Ce que veulent les entreprenautes, c'est faire du fric, sans rien produire en échange. Ce n'est pas logique qu'une boîte pèse plus de 25 millions de francs, quelques mois seulement après sa création.

La Netéconomie va-t-elle supplanter l'économie traditionnelle?

Sophie: Jamais de la vie. Elles sont complémentaires. Les gens iront toujours dans les boutiques acheter leurs fringues pour les essayer, les toucher, voir du monde et sortir de chez eux.

Damien: Non, c'est virtuel tout ça, ça ne remplacera jamais le monde réel. Internet, c'est juste un mode de distribution supplémentaire, rien de plus.

Christa: Les gens achètent peu sur le net, ils n'ont pas confiance car les paiements ne sont pas aussi bien sécurisés qu'on veut le faire croire. Ils préfèrent aller dans un bon vieux magasin et voir, en vrai, ce qu'ils achètent.

Glossaire/Glossary

se casser la gueule (very familiar) to come a cropper
comme d'hab (fam.) as usual
le courrier électronique e-mail
craignos ( very fam.) in this context, undesirable
un entreprenaute (neologism) an internet entrepreneur
c'est du pipeau that's a load of rubbish
c'est forcé! it's inevitable!
un internaute an internet user
tout rentrera dans l'ordre everything will return to normal
se ruer sur quelque chose to fling oneself at something
supplanter to supersede
la Toile the world wide web

webTitle: 'Dishonest' Cronje sacked as South Africa captain

fields.headline: 'Dishonest' Cronje sacked as South Africa captain
fields.trailText: The South African Cricket Board's decision to dismiss Hansie Cronje as captain for lying about receiving money from bookmakers was tonight shrouded in mystery after he denied accepting "any financial reward".
fields.body:
The South African Cricket Board's decision to dismiss Hansie Cronje as captain for lying about receiving money from bookmakers was tonight shrouded in mystery after he denied accepting "any financial reward".

Cronje issued his denial just minutes after Dr Ali Bacher, the managing director of the United Cricket Board of South Africa, claimed the player had admitted receiving "between 10,000 and 15,000 US dollars" for "providing information and forecast, but not match-fixing". As yet, no-one is quite sure exactly what this means.

But Bacher did say that the matter related to the triangular one-day series between South Africa, Zimbabwe and England - and not the India v South Africa series last month.

Bacher said: "During the triangular one-day series in South Africa between Zimbabwe and England and South Africa, contact was made with him (Cronje) by a local South African and a bookmaker of Indian origin, based in London.

"Discussions took place and the end result of this in South Africa is that Hansie Cronje was given between 10 and 15,000 US dollars which he took home. As of today he has not deposited the money in an account, but he did take that money."

Bacher said Cronje maintained that he was not guilty of match-fixing and that the other three players - Herschelle Gibbs, Nicky Boje and Pieter Strydom - were also innocent of the charges.

Bacher added: "He denies match-fixing. Our information is that there was a detailed providing of information and forecasting - not match-fixing. He was asked about match-fixing but he denies throwing the match."

"He said in India he never received any money. It only happened once in South Africa. He was continually harrassed on his phone by these bookmakers. He does acknowledge that in India there was communication by telephones. Whether he met them personally I cannot tell you."

Bacher revealed that the UCB had asked the South African Government to set up an urgent inquiry into the allegations of match fixing.

He said: "We do have a crisis on our hands in South African cricket - we cannot escape that reality. As a matter of urgency I have asked the Government to institute an enquiry into these allegations."

"At quarter past one we asked all the South African players if they had been involved in match-fixing... all of them denied any involvement. In conclusion we said to them that we had to move away from this crisis. Shaun Pollock has been made captain."

But Bacher insisted that the door had not yet closed on Cronje's international career. "There will be an independent enquiry," he said. "I think to be fair to Hansie let's complete this process and see what the findings are," he added.

"I suppose it will be asked of us why did we take the stance that we took with Hansie, the support that we did give him. The answer is that prior to this issue he's done South African cricket proud and I think everyone will acknowledge that.

"When these allegations arose by virtue of our long-standing relationship with him, he denied emphatically there was any involvement. "It may be asked why did we back him to the hilt? Well, if it was an errant judgement then so be it."

Warwickshire coach Bob Woolmer, who worked alongside Cronje during his five years as South African coach, claimed the news could seriously damage the growth of cricket in that country.

"It will devastate cricket in South Africa," said Woolmer. "It will be the end of Hansie's career and it would be a real kick in the teeth for South African cricket."

"There will be an independent enquiry," he said. "I think to be fair to Hansie let's complete this process and see what the findings are," he added. "I suppose it will be asked of us why did we take the stance that we took with Hansie, the support that we did give him. The answer is that prior to this issue he's done South African cricket proud and I think everyone will acknowledge that. "When these allegations arose by virtue of our long-standing relationship with him, he denied emphatically there was any involvement. "It may be asked why did we back him to the hilt? Well, if it was an errant judgement then so be it." Warwickshire coach Bob Woolmer, who worked alongside Cronje during his five years as South African coach, claimed the news could seriously damage the growth of cricket in that country. "It will devastate cricket in South Africa," said Woolmer. "It will be the end of Hansie's career and it would be a real kick in the teeth for South African cricket."

webTitle: Farmer 'set booby traps and waited in the dark'

fields.headline: Farmer 'set booby traps and waited in the dark'
fields.standfirst: Death at Bleak House: Jury told of eccentric accused of murdering 16-year-old
fields.trailText: A farmer accused of murdering a teenage boy who tried to burgle his house had laid booby traps and slept fully clothed with his boots on, a jury heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A farmer accused of murdering a teenage boy who tried to burgle his house had laid booby traps and slept fully clothed with his boots on, a jury heard yesterday.

Tony Martin, 55, who described himself and his way of life as eccentric, lived in an isolated property called Bleak House, kept three rottweilers in a nearby cottage and had lashed a number of ladders to trees and outbuildings to make a series of "lookout posts", Norwich crown court was told.

Ground floor windows and doors of his home at Emneth, Norfolk, had been fitted with iron bars, parts of the inside staircase had been removed and there was "a booby trap at the top end of the landing".

The farmer had regularly professed his hatred of burglars, once threatening that if he caught them he would blow their heads off. The jury heard he had told police that Gypsies should be rounded up, put in the middle of his field and machine-gunned.

Martin is accused of killing 16-year-old Fred Barras, a market trader from a Gypsy travelling family based in Newark, Nottinghamshire, during a late-night incident at his home last August. He is also accused of attempting to murder and unlawfully wounding Brendon Fearon, 29, with intent to do him grievous bodily harm.

He has denied these charges and another charge of possessing a firearm and ammunition with intent to injure life. Yesterday he pleaded guilty to possession of a Winchester pump-action shotgun without holding a firearm certificate.

Barras and Fearon had gone to Bleak House with another friend, Darren Bark, with the intention of burgling the property. They had heard that the place was filled with antiques. As Bark waited in his car, Barras and Fearon were shot while prowling in the house. Fearon was severely injured and Barras, who was shot in the back, was found dead the following afternoon. The court heard that Barras had pleaded for his life, saying: "I'm sorry. Please don't. Mum."

A courtroom filled with friends and family of Martin and Barras heard that the farmer, a bachelor, had "security measures" and "he would also sleep fully clothed, wearing his boots in contemplation of something happening". Police had found rounds of ammunition all over the house and its outbuildings.

Rosamund Horwood-Smart QC, prosecuting, said Martin had been burgled in May last year and items were stolen. "When he reported the burglary he told the police operator, Mrs Wood, that the burglars had left some furniture outside and that they may come back and if they did he would blow their heads away," she added.

"Over the years Mr Martin and his family had undoubtedly been the victims of crime. Mr Martin was well known to have strong views on policing matters."

Ms Horwood-Smart said that when officers visited his house to take details of the May burglary, Martin was "vitriolic about criminals, especially Gypsies, and talked of putting Gypsies in one of his fields, surrounded by barbed wire, and machine-gunning them".

At a meeting of a local Farm Watch group, Martin showed his contempt for the police. "During that meeting he said 'out there you are on your own and you are the law'." The police were "a waste of time".

A neighbour who saw Martin two or three days before the shooting remembered him referring to burglars as "light-fingered pikeys". Ms Horwood-Smart told the jury: "He said if he caught the bastards he would shoot them."

The jury heard that Fearon and Barras spotted a dresser in Bleak House and began shining a torch towards it. "Fearon remembers Fred Barras following closely behind him. He saw a man on the stairs. Then he heard Barras shout 'he's got me' at the same time as he heard a loud bang. He then made his way towards a window. He was going towards that window when he heard a second shot and his left leg at that moment went numb.

"He then heard a third bang and felt pain in his right leg and in his panic he managed to pull the whole window out of the wall."

Sobs from the Barras family could be heard when she added: "At that point he heard Fred Barras say: 'He has got me. I am sorry. Please don't. Mum.' "

The jury was told that Barras followed Fearon out of the window. The teenager would have died within two minutes but it was not until the following day that his body was found. Barras was wearing rubber gloves and a chisel was found nearby. Fearon was badly injured and approached the cottage of one of Martin's neighbours who called an ambulance.

"In the meantime, Mr Martin took a pump-action shotgun to his mother's house and left it in her lavatory and that was the gun that was used in the shootings," said Ms Horwood-Smart.

Martin claimed that he had not fired the gun before and did not know how many cartridges it held.

"He said he kept it under his bed," she said. "He had gone to bed that Friday evening at around 9pm having put his two rottweilers to bed and leaving another dog, Bruno, to patrol the grounds.

"He said that he was wakened by noises. At first he thought that Bruno had got into the house. Then he saw flashes of light downstairs. He said he returned to his bedroom and retrieved the gun.

"He loaded it until it was full. He did not know how many cartridges it held. He says he returned to the landing. He negotiated the step at the top and he says that he went halfway downstairs. At that point a torch was pointed at him. He took aim and fired a shot below the light of the torch and he continued to fire until the gun was empty."

Ms Horwood-Smart said: "He told the officers that he had at no time warned the intruders or given them the chance to surrender. He said he thought he would hide upstairs but then thought 'I have had enough' and went downstairs with the gun."

The case continues today.

webTitle: One too many lands fan a Bafta

fields.headline: One too many lands fan a Bafta
fields.trailText: It took the Spanish film director Pedro Almodovar 51 years and 10 acclaimed films to get his hands on a Bafta award. It took Tony Blain, a salesman from Islington, north London, one too many drinks and a dare from a friend.
fields.body:
It took the Spanish film director Pedro Almodovar 51 years and 10 acclaimed films to get his hands on a Bafta award. It took Tony Blain, a salesman from Islington, north London, one too many drinks and a dare from a friend.

Mr Blain woke up after a night spent partying at the Bafta awards ceremony on Sunday to find he had picked up the award for best director - literally. Mr Blain said that he took the prize - awarded to Mr Almodovar for his film All About My Mother - in a moment of madness. "One minute I was at a party sneaking a look at his Bafta, the next I was looking at it on my mantlepiece," Mr Blain told the Sun newspaper. "I don't know what came over me."

Mr Blain snatched the award at an after show party hosted by the film company Miramax. Mr Almodovar did not realise it had gone until 30 minutes after Mr Blain had disappeared. "I noticed this bag with a bronze face looking up at me and realised it was one of the awards," Mr Blain said.

"Also in the bag was an envelope with the words 'the award goes to...' on it. I am a real Almodovar fan. I showed it to my friends and one of them egged me on to take it as a souvenir."

The award was returned to Mr Almodovar yesterday and the director said he would not be taking any action against Mr Blain. "I am very, very happy to have it back. I never thought I would see it again," he said.

webTitle: Garbo 'lesbian affair' letters to go on display

fields.headline: Garbo 'lesbian affair' letters to go on display
fields.trailText: Letters that the great Swedish star Greta Garbo wrote to her alleged lesbian lover Mercedes de Acosta will be going on display at Philadelphia's Rosenbach Museum and Library on 16 April.
fields.body:
Letters that the great Swedish star Greta Garbo wrote to her alleged lesbian lover Mercedes de Acosta will be going on display at Philadelphia's Rosenbach Museum and Library on 16 April.

The 55 letters, 17 cards and 15 telegrams that the two women exchanged were bequeathed to the museum by Acosta with the stipulation that they should not be made public until both she and Garbo had been dead for 10 years. The letters may shed light on the exact nature of the relationship between the two women, who were friends from 1931 to 1959. Biographers and historians disagree on whether Garbo and Acosta were lovers.

The elusive star who featured in 26 films over a 17-year period, including classics such as Anna Christie, Mata Hari, Grand Hotel and Queen Christina, walked away from Hollywood in 1941 for a private life insulated from the public and press.

The latest edition of the Sunday Telegraph quotes a close friend of the actress as saying that during the time of the alleged affair, Garbo was told by star photographer Cecil Beaton that she faced exposure as a lesbian unless she paid hush money to her lover.

For Garbo fans and gossip merchants the world over, all will be revealed in a week.

webTitle: Oscar-winning hostage film bows to critics

fields.headline: Oscar-winning hostage film bows to critics
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: The makers of an Oscar-winning documentary about the 11 Israeli athletes killed at the 1972 Munich Olympics have agreed to obscure forensic photographs of the slain hostages following protests by the victims' families.
fields.body:
The makers of an Oscar-winning documentary about the 11 Israeli athletes killed at the 1972 Munich Olympics have agreed to obscure forensic photographs of the slain hostages following protests by the victims' families.

"They made a moral request that the families of the victims still live here, and it is not nice to see how they are murdered," Arthur Cohn, the producer of One Day in September, said yesterday. "They want to remember them the way they lived, and I respect that."

The 91-minute documentary, directed by Briton Kevin MacDonald, had its first screening in Tel Aviv on Sunday. But the event was eclipsed by the clamour created by relatives of the victims who were appalled that an international audience might view gruesome forensic photographs, and the film makers' efforts to win their blessing for their project.

In the compromise that was eventually reached, six photographs, amounting to 36 seconds of film, are to be blurred so that the faces of the dead atheletes are not visible. The changes are more far-reaching for the Israeli version of the film. "We could have saved all this suffering and conflict if they would have done what was promised three months ago - which was to take out the pictures," said Ankie Spitzer, whose husband, Andre, was the fencing coach of the doomed Olympic squad.

Ms Spitzer, and the widow of wrestler Yosef Romano, led the protest against the inclusion of the photographs - taken by German police at the Olympic village dormitory where the athletes were held for 20 hours by Palestinian gunmen of the Black September group, and in the airport where nine Israelis were killed during a botched rescue attempt.

Romano was among those killed in the Israelis' living quarters, and in the original version of the film his face, and mutilated corpse, were clearly visible.

Mr MacDonald argued that the changes dilute the film's impact. He said it had the support of some of the victims' families, but they were less vocal than Ms Spitzer and Romano.

"The pictures are very horrific, but I think that they are very important," he said.

"The German government, and the Bavarian government have been trying to sweep this under the carpet for 28 years," he said.

"Having the photographs would have made the German public and the international community sit up and take notice of the story."

One Day in September opens in London on May 19.

fields.headline: Northern Districts triumph in NZ
fields.trailText: New Zealand
fields.body:
New Zealand

Northern Districts won the first-class Shell Cup, thrashing Auckland by 267 runs in the final at the Owen Delaney Park in Taupo. ND started well enough with 292, as opener James Marshall and Scott Styris both made 81. But the innings was given a vital boost by No.10 Simon Doull, the Test seamer, who blasted a speedy 63* off just 59 balls, and added 82 for the last wicket with Bruce Martin (20). In reply Auckland managed just 208, as Aaron Barnes hit 56* and former Test opener Blair Pocock scored 50. But ND's first-innings lead meant a draw would be enough for them to lift the trophy. So they proceeded to bat with more care in their second innings, scoring at two an over while compiling 367; Joseph Yovich ground out 99. This left Auckland a nominal 452 to win: obliged to go for the runs, they flailed their way to 184 all out in just 30.5 overs, with Stephen Lynch whacking 81* from only 59 balls. Martin returned figures of 11.5-0-75-5.

Northern Districts 292 (Brooke Walker 4-61) and 367 (Walker 4-95)

Auckland 208 and 184

Northern Districts won by 267 runs

India

A superb display from Test opener Vangipurappu Laxman propelled Hyderabad into the semi-finals of the first-class Ranji Trophy at the expense of Uttar Pradesh. Laxman hit 128 and 177* as Hyderabad, who will meet reigning champions Karnataka in the last four, triumphed by 92 runs at Green Park in Kanpur. Hyderabad began with 291, with only Laxman passing 29, and then found themselves in trouble when UP totalled 362 in reply. Mohammad Kaif, who recently captained India to the Under-19 World Cup and made his full Test debut against South Africa, top-scored with 66, while Jyoti Yadav chipped in with 61 and Ashish Zaidi 52. But Kanwaljit Singh kept Hyderabad in touch with 6-97 off 48.2 overs. Laxman, though, was unfazed by his team's first-innings deficit of 71, and weighed in with 177* off 241 balls, smacking 16 fours and three sixes, to allow Hyderabad to declare on 381 for 5; Ammanabrole Nandakishore hit 93. This left UP 311 to make the semis. They got to 163 for 3, but then lost their nerve as ex-Test offspinner Venkatapathy Raju picked up 6-57 in 37 overs. The last seven wickets fell for just 55, despite Kaif making 86, and Hyderabad were through.

Hyderabad 291 (Mishra 4-30) and 381 for 5 decl.

Uttar Pradesh 362 and 218

Hyderabad won by 92 runs

Sridaran Sriram, who made his international debut for India in the now-infamous one-day series against South Africa recently, inspired Tamil Nadu to victory over Punjab in the other semi-final, at Chennai. Sriram hit a majestic 165 in TN's first innings of 461 to set up his side's seven-wicket victory; they will play Mumbai in the semis. Punjab, who trailed by 203 after beginning with 258, did better in their second innings, as Vikram Rathore made 127 and Reetinder Singh Sodhi 89. But TN were never stretched by their eventual target of 164, Sadagopan Ramesh finishing unbeaten on 77.

Punjab 258 (Vikram Rathore 57) and 366 (Harbhajan Singh 5-106)

Tamil Nadu 461 (Hemang Badani 70) and 167 for 3 (Sridaran Sharath 53*)

Tamil Nadu won by seven wickets

Zimbabwe

Mashonaland romped to victory in the final of the first-class Logan Cup, thumping Manicaland by 257 runs at Harare. Their win was built around two century opening partnerships between international seamer John Rennie and recent Test cap Trevor Gripper. The pair began with a stand of 126 (Rennie 52, Gripper 86) and added 155 in the second innings (Rennie 87, Gripper 78) as Mashonaland tightened their grip. In between Bryan Strang shot Manicaland out for 123, finishing with figures of 21-12-20-7. Set 498 to win, Manicaland managed 240 as Rennie added five wickets to his runs.

Mashonaland 345 (Bradley Robinson 61, Donald Campbell 50) and 275 for 5 decl.

Manicaland 123 (Hamilton Masakadze 53) and 240 (Stuart Matsikenyeri 73*, Neil Ferreira 55)

Mashonaland won by 257 runs

Mashonaland reached the final on the back of two extraordinary matches. The first came against old rivals Matabeleland at Bulawayo, when Dirk Viljoen (173*) and Craig Evans (153 in 143 balls with five sixes) added 330 for the fourth wicket. It was a Zimbabwean first-class record for any wicket. Evans then returned figures of 6-5-5-4 to help skittle Matabeleland for 86 in the fourth innings.

Mashonaland 170 (John Rennie 5-70) and 448 for 4 decl.

Matabeleland 256 (Mark Vermuelen 87, Rennie 63) and 86

Mashonaland won by 276 runs

In the second miracle match, Midlands, playing in the Logan Cup for the first time, totalled just 87 in their two innings to go down to a 251-run mauling at Harare. They began with 31 all out in 12.5 overs (a recovery from 6 for 5), as Mashonaland's Angus MacKay took 6-16 and Brighton Watambwa 4-15. Then, left 308 to win, Midlands reached a triumphant 56, Mackay adding 5-19, and Daniel Peacock rejoicing in figures of 2.3-0-8-4. There were 11 ducks in the two innings.

Mashonaland 165 and 173 for 8 decl.

Midlands 31 and 56

Mashonaland won by 251 runs

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: Straw unveils 24-hour pubs revolution
fields.standfirst:
Plans for more continental-style opening hours balanced by measures to clamp down on drink-related crime

Cartoon: Steve Bell on the new licensing laws
Matthew Fort's comment
fields.trailText: Pubs and supermarkets will be able to sell beer, wine and other alcoholic drinks around the clock, including on Sundays, under the most radical overhaul of the licensing laws for 40 years unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.
fields.body:
Pubs and supermarkets will be able to sell beer, wine and other alcoholic drinks around the clock, including on Sundays, under the most radical overhaul of the licensing laws for 40 years unveiled by the home secretary, Jack Straw, yesterday.

But the Home Office's proposals to introduce a more European approach to alcohol in Britain is accompanied by measures to clamp down on drink-related crime, including 10-year bans from named pubs for "habitual drunkards" and others convicted of violent assaults. The extra powers are designed to act as a counterweight to the growing trend of cheap drink promotions, such as happy hours.

Under the proposals, outlined in a white paper, the police will be given powers to order the immediate closure of rowdy pubs, and every landlord will have to obtain a personal licence which will include passing a test involving questions about the licensing laws and their social responsibilities.

Police will also be able to close off-licences, including those near football grounds. Warehouses involved in the burgeoning trade of selling beer and wine "by the case" will have to get a licence if they sell to the public, in a clampdown on cross-Channel smuggling of alcohol.

Children will be allowed into all licensed premises and 16- and 17-year-olds with an adult will be allowed to drink wine and beer with a meal. The restrictions on Sunday opening will be abolished and the remaining bans on selling alcohol on Sundays in parts of Wales will be lifted without holding a referendum.

Mr Straw told MPs yesterday the licensing laws, which had barely changed for a century, contributed to public order and policing problems. "Fixed closing times encourage binge drinking around last orders. The result is lots of people hitting the streets - and sometimes each other - at the same time," he said.

"Our proposals introduce a radical system which would allow greater freedom and flexibility for people to enjoy themselves, but balances these liberties with tough and uncompromising powers for the police, courts and licensing authorities to punish those who abuse those freedoms."

There has been a rapid growth in town centre pubs in the past two years in anticipation of Mr Straw's 24-hour licensing revolution.

The power to set local opening hours will be removed from the licensing magistrates and given to local authorities. The 179,000 venues which sell alcohol including pubs, night clubs, theatres and cinemas, and late night food outlets will each have to apply for a licence specifying their operating times.

A typical licence might cover up to midnight on weekdays and 1am at weekends with up to 20 late openings a year for special occasions. The local authority is likely to use the licensing system to stagger opening hours in a particular part of town. The Home Office says that two-thirds of violent assaults occur between 11pm and 3am.

Some ancient exemptions, such as the bylaw allowing Cambridge University and the City of London vintners to sell wine without a licence, are to be removed.

The Campaign for Real Ale said: "A more permissive approach to liquor licensing will benefit all customers, whether they are regular pubgoers or not. It is highly unlikely that all pubs will be allowed to open 24 hours a day and residents and communities will have a say in the permitted hours set for each pub.

"There is a real problem with all pubs closing at the same time. It leads to chaos in many towns and cities which become war zones on Friday and Saturday nights. A more relaxed approach will ease these problems and benefit us all."

Alcohol Concern's director, Eric Appleby, said the test of the new laws would be whether they helped reduce the 13,000 violent incidents each week which were linked to licensed premises. "The authorities must realise there is more to 24-hour continental-style life than allowing people to drink whenever they like. The measures must be backed by adequate public transport and proper consultation with residents."

The proposals

 Flexible opening hours: up to 24 hours, seven days a week, for pubs, off-licences and shops selling alcohol

 Children to be allowed into pubs

 Those aged 16 and 17 allowed to buy alcohol, except spirits, with meals

 New 10-year personal licences for landlords, who will face a knowledge test

 Pubs where there is persistent rowdiness to be closed for short periods

 Bans on habitual drunks and violent drinkers

 New clampdown on underage drinking, including a new offence of buying alcohol for under 18s

 New controls on sale of alcohol on boats in wake of the Marchioness tragedy

 Drinks licences to be issued by local authorities instead of magistrates

 Ban on the sale of alcohol at garages and motorway service stations to remain

Calling time since the 13th century

Licensing laws were first passed in the 13th century to control purity of drinks and their price.

The 1660s saw the advent of beer taxation to raise revenue but this led to increased spirit sales and the widespread drunkenness shown in the illustrations of Hogarth.

From 1729 pubs and gin houses were subject to sky-high duties to counter the public's drunken behaviour. Retailers' licences were set at £20 and later raised to £50 - a vast amount at the time.

Many sellers were unable to afford the new fee and operated illegally. As a result many taverns degenerated into dens of iniquity and "nurseries" of highwaymen and robbers.

In 1787 a royal proclamation on vice and immorality closed many pubs. The measure was judged a success, with crime and widespread drunkenness reduced.

The Temperance Society had a great influence in the mid-19th century, successfully lobbying for reduced opening hours and stricter punishments.

By 1886 sales of alcohol to children under 13 were outlawed. The current age restriction did not come into place until 1923.

The Defence of the Realm Act introduced during the first world war ordered pubs to close during the afternoon and cease trading by 9.30pm to ensure factory employees were fit for work.

In 1921 modern hours were introduced: a maximum of nine hours allowed between 11am and 11pm, with five hours on Sundays, except in Wales, where Sunday closing prevailed. Since 1994 a number of minor deregulatory measures have been introduced.

 Graham Diggines

webTitle: Lord of the Rings trailer sets internet record

fields.headline: Lord of the Rings trailer sets internet record
fields.trailText: The internet exclusive preview (see Friday's news) of New Line Cinema's The Lord of the Rings was downloaded 1.7m times in the first 24 hours it was available, according to Apple Computer, one of the companies providing download capabilities.
fields.body:
The internet exclusive preview (see Friday's news) of New Line Cinema's The Lord of the Rings was downloaded 1.7m times in the first 24 hours it was available, according to Apple Computer, one of the companies providing download capabilities.

The number of downloads eclipses the record set by the trailer for Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace, which managed a mere 1m downloads in its first day online.

The Tolkien trailer consists of battle footage, brief interviews with star Elijah Wood and helmer Peter Jackson, as well as behind-the-scenes shots of the special effects team. The preview was made available at the start of the weekend on Friday and can be downloaded in a number of formats, including a full-screen version.

Additional teaser trailers will be posted at www.thelordoftherings.net as the movie's release date approaches. The first instalment in the Rings trilogy, The Fellowship of the Ring, has a tentative release date of Christmas 2001, with The Two Towers and The Return of the King bowing in successive years. All three films are being shot consecutively in New Zealand, and star Cate Blanchett, Ian Holm, Ian McKellen, Viggo Mortensen and Liv Tyler.

· Watch the trailer here.

fields.headline: Livingstone attacks 'killer' capitalism
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone's attempts to win credibility with the City of London for his mayoral campaign appeared to backfire last night when he claimed that global capitalism killed more people annually than Hitler.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone's attempts to win credibility with the City of London for his mayoral campaign appeared to backfire last night when he claimed that global capitalism killed more people annually than Hitler.

The former GLC leader, standing as an independent candidate and by far the front-runner in the capital's mayoral contest, made the claim in the New Musical Express, published today.

Answering a series of readers' questions, he said: "Every year the international financial system kills more people than world war two. But at least Hitler was mad."

In a further comment seized on by the Tories last night as evidence that Mr Livingstone is unfit to run London, the Brent East MP suggested decriminalising ecstasy and cannabis to curb the international drugs trade. He argued that "ecstasy is clearly not addictive, cannabis is clearly less damaging than booze".

Mr Livingstone's confirmation that he stands by past comments that the leaders of the International Monetary Fund should "die painfully in their beds" came amid attempts to restore his reputation with the capital's financial sector after he expressed common cause with rioters in the City of London.

In an interview in the style magazine The Face in January, not long after police-protester battles at the World Trade Organisation conference in Seattle, the Brent East MP said he had "always been in favour of direct action", adding that he would not invite the WTO to London "unless we can get vast stocks in so we can throw stuff at them in an organised way".

He later laughed off the remarks as media misrepresentation, but campaigners for Labour's official candidate Frank Dobson sought to capitalise on the gaffe, claiming business and city organisations had been "very angry".

Mr Livingstone says in today's NME: "The IMF and the World Bank are still appalling, and now the World Trade Organisation too. All over the world people die unnecessarily because of the international financial system." The economist Susan George has estimated that in any year since 1981 between 15-20m people have died as a result of the debt burden on developing countries.

Asked by another questioner whether cannabis should be legalised "sooner rather than later", Mr Livingstone predicted the drug will be de criminalised, arguing that the war against drug barons had been lost and that young people recognised that, contrary to the view of the government drugs tsar, Keith Hellawell, drugs are "not all the same".

He added: "I do think we could consider decriminalising things like ecstasy and cannabis, but I would never do anything to encourage people to take drugs any more than I would encourage people to drink".

A spokesman for the Conservative mayoral candidate, Steven Norris, said last night: "These comments prove that Livingstone is a hardline leftwing extremist who cannot hide his own agenda from sensible Londoners or from business. The mask always slips at the most important moment. London can ill afford the kind of danger to which Ken Livingstone is quite prepared to subject it. Londoners want safe streets and a safe transport system and not anarchy in the UK."

Meanwhile police officers heckled Frank Dobson yesterday as he outlined his vision for policing in the capital.

Mr Dobson, speaking at a specially-convened meeting into the issue of police pay, was forced to halt his speech, despite backing calls for improved pay for Metropolitan officers.

The response for Mr Dobson was in contrast to Mr Livingstone, who received a warm ovation from the audience of rank-and-file officers.

fields.headline: Bereavement
fields.trailText: Books can provide the ideal medium for addressing issues associated with the loss of a loved one
fields.body:
The death of a loved one is never easy to cope with, whatever age you are. However, it can be especially difficult to explain to a child and enable them to explore their feelings; be it the death of a family member, a friend or a pet. A book can provide the ideal medium for addressing and exploring issues which are associated with bereavement. The following titles are just a few which successfully broach the subject with a degree of sensitivity and tact, without being patronising or sentimental.

It Isn't Easy
Margaret Connolly, illustrated by Rosita Manahan (OUP, £4.99)
Age: under 5s

This book is for the very young and it focuses on a child whose brother has been killed in an accident. It follows him and his parents through their emotional reactions: sadness, anger and pain, and shows how they begin to come to terms with their loss. Written by an experienced counsellor in the field, this is an honest and brave look at coping with the death of a child and sibling.

Drop Dead
Babette Cole
(Red Fox , £4.99)
Age: 5+

Only Babette Cole could make life and death so entertaining. Exploring all the stages of growing up to getting older and finally facing death, Cole takes a humorous look at all those awkward questions children love to ask with witty text and wildly amusing illustrations. Ideal for children and their parents!

Scrumpy
Elizabeth Dale, illustrated by Frederic Joos
(Andersen Press, £4.50)
Age: 6+

In stark contrast to Cole's approach to this issue, this is a very touching and sensitively delivered story about how a child copes with the death of a pet. When Ben loses his beloved dog, he really believes that he can never be happy or want another pet again. However, with time he slowly learns to find happiness in his memories and, in doing so, he also discovers that he can look to the future. This is a reassuring book for children with some distinctive illustrations.

Chasing Redbird
Sharon Creech
(Macmillan Children's Books, £3.99)
Age:11+

Zinny is confused. She wants to be alone, but feels isolated at the same time. Wrongly blaming herself for the deaths of two family members, she channels all her mental and physical energies into clearing a ten-mile trail which starts at her backdoor. It is a huge job, but brings her satisfaction and eventual relief from the difficult situation she has been facing. This is a beautifully told story, with some very funny moments.

Dancing Through The Shadows
Theresa Tomlinson
(Red Fox £3.99)
Age: 11+

Just at the time when thirteen-year-old Ellen learns that her mother has breast cancer, she also becomes very involved with a dance project at her school and with her history teacher's attempts to restore an ancient well near her home. All these elements come together to create an involving story which has a strong, positive message. With Ellen, the reader is asked to face the anxieties of her mother's stressful operation, chemotherapy and radiation therapy, but also to share in the joys of performing, friendship and the tentative beginnings of a boy-girl relationship. This is a well-written story which will provide useful support for a young adolescent reader who has a parent who is seriously ill.

webTitle: Americans choose the road not taken

fields.headline: Americans choose the road not taken
fields.standfirst: A search for the nation's favourite poem has drawn a huge response, with Robert Frost's reflective lines emerging as the winner
fields.trailText: The idea of the United States as a nation of poetry lovers may not fit the European stereotypes of a gun-toting, execution-obsessed land of couch potatoes. All the same, it turns out to be true. Poetry is alive and well and living in America.
fields.body:
The idea of the United States as a nation of poetry lovers may not fit the European stereotypes of a gun-toting, execution-obsessed land of couch potatoes. All the same, it turns out to be true. Poetry is alive and well and living in America.

Two years ago, America's poet laureate launched a campaign to discover the nation's favourite poem. It was an act of faith rather than logic, Robert Pinsky said at the time. But Mr Pinsky's appeal hit the spot. Now, more than 18,000 written, videotaped and recorded suggestions later, he has been overwhelmed by the response.

The Favourite Poem Project, which Mr Pinsky has coordinated through the Library of Congress, where the US laureate is based, has yielded a massive and diverse archive, with contributors ranging in age from four to 99.

Though submissions have come from every state in the union, the muse seems to be strongest in the north-eastern US, with New York and Massachusetts supplying the most responses to Mr Pinsky's appeal.

Mr Pinsky and his colleague Maggie Dietz have collected many of the suggestions into a bestselling book, Americans' Favourite Poems, which is already into a fourth reprinting. Last week, he presented the Library of Congress with a video and audio archive, in which 100 Americans from all walks of life are heard and seen reading their choices.

"The archive is dramatic and gripping beyond my hopes and expectations," said Mr Pinsky, who steps down as poet laureate next month.

"My dearest hope is that this will affect the way poetry is taught in school. If our generation decides the young can do without great works of art, we will be cursed."

America's favourite poem, on the basis of Mr Pinsky's bulging postbag, is the characteristically reflective and solitary The Road Not Taken, written by the San Francisco-born poet Robert Frost, one of the laureate's predecessors.

Frost, who at the age of 86 read one of his poems at President Kennedy's inauguration in January 1961, maintains an awesome grip on the American poetic imagination nearly 40 years after his death.

In addition to The Road Not Taken, Frost's Stopping By Woods on A Snowy Evening also wins a place in the top five.

Although most of the poems nominated by American poetry lovers were by US authors, the project placed no bar on the nationality of respondents' choices. Submissions ranged across more than 2,500 years of verse, ranging from Sappho to Seamus Heaney.

The most popular poem by a British writer proved to be Rudyard Kipling's indestructible If, a regular poll-topper in surveys in Britain.

Five works that won the hearts of US readers

1 - The Road Not Taken

Robert Frost

Two roads diverged in a yellow wood,

And sorry I could not travel both

And be one traveler, long I stood

And looked down one as far as I could

To where it bent in the undergrowth;

Then took the other, as just as fair,

And having perhaps the better claim,

Because it was grassy and wanted wear;

Though as for that, the passing there

Had worn them really about the same,

And both that morning equally lay

In leaves no step had trodden black.

Oh, I kept the first for another day!

Yet knowing how way leads to way,

I doubted if I should ever come back.

I shall be telling this with a sigh

Somewhere ages and ages hence:

Two roads diverged in a wood, and I -

I took the one less traveled by,

And that has made all the difference

2 The Raven by Edgar Allen Poe

3 Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening by Robert Frost

4 Sick by Shel Silverstein

5 If by Rudyard Kipling
fields.bodyText: The idea of the United States as a nation of poetry lovers may not fit the European stereotypes of a gun-toting, execution-obsessed land of couch potatoes. All the same, it turns out to be true. Poetry is alive and well and living in America. Two years ago, America's poet laureate launched a campaign to discover the nation's favourite poem. It was an act of faith rather than logic, Robert Pinsky said at the time. But Mr Pinsky's appeal hit the spot. Now, more than 18,000 written, videotaped and recorded suggestions later, he has been overwhelmed by the response. The Favourite Poem Project, which Mr Pinsky has coordinated through the Library of Congress, where the US laureate is based, has yielded a massive and diverse archive, with contributors ranging in age from four to 99. Though submissions have come from every state in the union, the muse seems to be strongest in the north-eastern US, with New York and Massachusetts supplying the most responses to Mr Pinsky's appeal. Mr Pinsky and his colleague Maggie Dietz have collected many of the suggestions into a bestselling book, Americans' Favourite Poems, which is already into a fourth reprinting. Last week, he presented the Library of Congress with a video and audio archive, in which 100 Americans from all walks of life are heard and seen reading their choices. "The archive is dramatic and gripping beyond my hopes and expectations," said Mr Pinsky, who steps down as poet laureate next month. "My dearest hope is that this will affect the way poetry is taught in school. If our generation decides the young can do without great works of art, we will be cursed." America's favourite poem, on the basis of Mr Pinsky's bulging postbag, is the characteristically reflective and solitary The Road Not Taken, written by the San Francisco-born poet Robert Frost, one of the laureate's predecessors. Frost, who at the age of 86 read one of his poems at President Kennedy's inauguration in January 1961, maintains an awesome grip on the American poetic imagination nearly 40 years after his death. In addition to The Road Not Taken, Frost's Stopping By Woods on A Snowy Evening also wins a place in the top five. Although most of the poems nominated by American poetry lovers were by US authors, the project placed no bar on the nationality of respondents' choices. Submissions ranged across more than 2,500 years of verse, ranging from Sappho to Seamus Heaney. The most popular poem by a British writer proved to be Rudyard Kipling's indestructible If, a regular poll-topper in surveys in Britain. Five works that won the hearts of US readers 1 - The Road Not Taken Robert Frost Two roads diverged in a yellow wood, And sorry I could not travel both And be one traveler, long I stood And looked down one as far as I could To where it bent in the undergrowth; Then took the other, as just as fair, And having perhaps the better claim, Because it was grassy and wanted wear; Though as for that, the passing there Had worn them really about the same, And both that morning equally lay In leaves no step had trodden black. Oh, I kept the first for another day! Yet knowing how way leads to way, I doubted if I should ever come back. I shall be telling this with a sigh Somewhere ages and ages hence: Two roads diverged in a wood, and I - I took the one less traveled by, And that has made all the difference 2 The Raven by Edgar Allen Poe 3 Stopping By Woods on a Snowy Evening by Robert Frost 4 Sick by Shel Silverstein 5 If by Rudyard Kipling

webTitle: Plea for US-style university entrance tests to end 'bias' against poor

fields.headline: Plea for US-style university entrance tests to end 'bias' against poor
fields.trailText: Education ministers are investigating US-style intelligence tests to measure 16-17-year-olds' aptitude for university, after evidence that selection based on A-level results is prejudiced against candidates from poor families and state comprehensives.
fields.body:
Education ministers are investigating US-style intelligence tests to measure 16-17-year-olds' aptitude for university, after evidence that selection based on A-level results is prejudiced against candidates from poor families and state comprehensives.

The Department for Education said it would study the scholastic aptitude tests used by the top American universities to assess candidates' potential as an alternative to relying on exam papers that tend to measure how well they have been coached.

Its decision follows the publication yesterday of research showing that pupils from private schools are 25 times more likely to get to one of the top British universities than those who come from a lower social class or live in a poor area.

Peter Lampl, founder of the Sutton Trust, investigated university admissions policy at Oxford, Cambridge, Birmingham, Bristol, Durham, Edin burgh, Nottingham, St Andrews, Warwick, York, Imperial College London, the London School of Economics and University College London.

He said the results revealed a "scandalous waste of talent". According to the trust, working class children from poor neighbourhoods have less than a one in a hundred chance of reaching one of these top universities.

Mr Lampl is commissioning a further study to test the feasibility of introducing Sats tests for lower sixth-formers.

David Hart, general secretary of the National Association of Head Teachers, said discrimination was inevitable as long as universities based admission mainly on A-level achievement.

"If you come from a poor background and you are educated in a state school serving a deprived community, the dice are already loaded against you. The chances are that you will do your A-levels in a small sixth form without the benefit of feeding off other academically able pupils."

It was difficult for pupils from poor backgrounds to demonstrate what they could do with the resources of a top university behind them. In contrast, US universities such as Harvard and Yale sought out the brightest students from poor areas, using Sats scores to measure potential.

John Dunford, general secretary of the Secondary Heads Association, said: "We have known about this problem for more than a generation, but universities have failed to do anything about it.

"A radical solution is needed which gets away from reliance on A-level results. I'm in favour of using the equivalent of Sats as well. Only in that way will we start to get a level playing field."

A spokesman for the Committee of Vice Chancellors and Principals said: "This research presents a challenge for universities, but they already work hard to encourage young people from all backgrounds to aspire to higher education."

No university in Britain yet uses the equivalent of Sats, or puts the same resources into seeking out unrecognised talent, although Oxford is researching the possibility of its own tests of academic potential, as a means of widening access.

The education department said recent A-level reforms should help to make university recruitment fairer. Places would increasingly be offered on the basis of exams in the lower sixth instead of predictions of A-level grades. A new "world class test", advanced extension level, would assess the performance of the ablest students in comprehensives and colleges as well as independent schools.

But for the first time the department accepted there might be lessons to learn from the US. "We should study the way Sats are used in the US. We share the aspirations of those who designed them that all students should have the opportunity to demonstrate their ability, regardless of income, class or social status," a spokeswoman said.

fields.headline: Ministers' pre-school cash boost
fields.trailText: The government is to make a big push to ensure that children from deprived homes are "ready for school" by the age of four after new research has shown that this is the key to educational achievement, which in turn is the most effective way to break out of poverty.
fields.body:
The government is to make a big push to ensure that children from deprived homes are "ready for school" by the age of four after new research has shown that this is the key to educational achievement, which in turn is the most effective way to break out of poverty.

A significant shift in resources to improve advice and services to poor parents with pre-school children is expected in the summer spending review.

Research by the respected Institute of Education, commissioned by the health minister Yvette Cooper, shows that higher state benefits for poor families is not sufficient to break the cycle of deprivation.

The findings will be used as powerful ammunition in an attempt to secure extra resources for Sure Start, the new £450m government programme designed to improve help to poor parents with pre-school children. The scheme, due to operate in 250 areas in England by 2002, has the enthusiastic support of the chancellor, Gordon Brown.

It aims to target parents of every child under four in a deprived area, including offering advice on parenting, children's health, access to playcentres and childcare.

The scheme, shaped by a multibillion-dollar US government programme backed by Hillary Clinton, is open to the charge of massive state social engineering. Controversial US neurobiological research cited by Ms Clinton, for instance, claims to show that reading to children aged under four will improve the capacity of their brains.

The US scheme, called Head Start, is heavily influenced by research showing that children can be "ruined" by three, especially if they are not "school ready". Head Start has so far served nearly 18m US children. Research has shown beneficiaries do better in terms of high school graduation and marks, as well as having reduced arrest rates.

In Britain, key determinants of Sure Start's success will include a child's birthweight, early language development, emotional health, access to quality play and number of visits by health workers. Children who have appropriate language skills and are eager to learn will be deemed as "ready for school". The scheme will be voluntary.

The Institue of Education's research shows that educational achievement is now the single most important factor in determining later success. "While income still matters, educational opportunities matter even more," Ms Cooper said yesterday.

The research underlines the degree to which children from poorly educated parents will fall behind in later life. It also suggests that the life chances of the children of poorly educated parents have improved little over the past 20 years.

"If you want to tackle child poverty across the generations, there is substantial evidence that you cannot just look at income, such as child benefit," said Ms Cooper. "You also have to make sure that by the time children get to school, they are not already falling behind."

The research shows that children from a professional background gained qualifications significantly higher than those from a working class background - differences between a degree and GCSEs, or A-levels and no qualifications.

Girls are nine times more likely to become teenage mothers if they come from a low skill background.

Sure Start is designed to provide new facilities including drop-in centres, childcare and mobile health clinics for parents with children under four as well as ensuring there is co-ordination between health, pre-school and social services departments. The government hopes to end the stigma associated with help to poor parents by making advice available to all parents in a Sure Start area, each covering 800 children.

Sometimes, parents will be visited as many as 10 times to persusde them to take up the local services on offer.
