fields.headline: The real life class
fields.standfirst: Claire Laurent joins a group of reception parents on a course to help them help kids cope with school
fields.trailText: Claire Laurent joins a group of reception parents on a course to help them help kids cope with school
fields.body:
Jenny Blacker is mum to Ben, 5, and Harry, who is 3. And she is glad to be taking part in a project to support children in reception class. "I want to enjoy being a mum, to be able to look back on it as a nice time. I don't want bringing up children to be a task."

Blacker describes Ben as an angel in school who is often out of control at home: "I was a nanny for eight years, and thought I'd seen it all until I had my own children. I knew I had to do something the day I smacked Ben and actually didn't care that I'd smacked him. I want to go back to being a nice mum, and when my boys grow into young men I want other people to like them."

Ben is in the reception year group of Clapham Manor Primary School in London. Parents of children in his class, and from five other schools in Lambeth, were invited to take part in a project to improve children's progress through school.

The director of Spokes - Supporting Parents on Kids Education - is Stephen Scott, a child psychiatrist at Kings College, London. "If the children settle in well in the first year," he says, "it sets them up for later on, but if they get blown off course in their first year it's hard for them to get back on."

The issue of behaviour problems among primary school pupils has been causing concern at a national level. Statistics for 1995/6 show that there were 12,500 permanent exclusions from primary, secondary and special schools, an increase of 13% over the previous year. Of these, 1,400 (13%) were from primary school, an increase of more than 18% over the previous year. Research into the reasons for this indicate that the children involved had suffered several significant stresses in their lives which had combined together to affect their schooling.

Spokes is a three-year research project, funded by a £500,000 Department of Health grant as part of a programme to discover the best way to support parents and promote the wellbeing of their child. It aims to give children a good start in school by developing their self-esteem, concentration and social skills. It also helps parents develop strategies for improving their child's behaviour and build a good relationship with their child's teacher, as well as fostering the relationship between parent and child.

The programme is based on the work of Carolyn Webster-Stratton, professor and director of the parenting unit at the University of Washington. A copy of her book The Incredible Years 3-8 is given to each parent on the Spokes programme.

Scott says: "The first 12 weeks of the programme are about play, praise, rewards, setting limits and how to give clear commands when necessary. It's about turning around people's perceptions. It's a long-term investment but parents do get something back; they notice the difference."

Families are videotaped at the start and interviewed by the group leaders. They meet weekly for two hours in term, at their child's school, to take part in the programme and discuss progress. Refreshments and a creche are provided.

Over the previous week, the Clapham Manor parents set aside 10 minutes a day to play with their child. All reported how unnatural this felt, and everyone found it difficult to find 10 spare minutes.

They were reassured, by group leader Jenny Price, that it is very common to feel strange about giving this time. Suzanne Wood, the mother of Callum, 6, and Kirstie, 5, voiced a feeling many parents will recognise when she said that if her daughter is badly behaved she feels like sending her to her room rather than giving her 10 minutes of play.

Price agreed that it's hard to be positive and play with children when you feel cross with them. But she reassured her that the programme would give her the skills to cope. The unspoken message was that the programme would help parents feel positive about themselves and their ability to look after their children.

The second 12 weeks of the programme helps develop children's literacy. This was devised by Carolyn Crook, research officer at the Institute of Psychiatrists, and Professor Kathy Sylva, co-director of Spokes and professor at Oxford University's Department of Education Studies.

Pauline Mitchell, a mother of four who has completed the 2-term Spokes programme, says it "really changed the way I approach helping them read. Now when Katherine, who is six, brings a book back home I have a quick flick through it and we have a chat about the background to the book, picking up any big words that going to come up. And now, when she's reading and gets stuck on a word, instead of me jumping in and telling her and rushing her on, I give her 10 to 15 seconds to think about it. That way I'm not taking away her confidence."

The last six weeks of the programme bring the literacy and parenting skills together and look at fostering the children's problem-solving skills and increasing their independence.

At the end of the programme the children are assessed again: families are videotaped and complete another questionnaire. "We want to see children progressing educationally as well as increasing their ability to handle their emotions and friendships," says Scott. "The purpose of the project is to see whether such programmes really work, or whether an access line would do just as well."

If the project is a success, Scott hopes it will be incorporated in all schools: "It could be led by the school's special educational needs co-ordinator with some input from an educational psychologist, and involve a volunteer parent who has completed the programme."

Pauline Mitchell is sure of the project's effectiveness. "Our house is much calmer. It has improved the behaviour of all my children. The 10-year-old has matured unbelievably and now comes in from school and gets on with his homework.

"The children moved schools and I have worked at developing a good relationship with their new teachers, which has helped with my eight-year-old. Instead of criticising his teacher when she tells him off, I find something good to say and ask her how we can sort out problems together. Katherine, who was in reception when I did the course, now no longer wets the bed or comes into our bed, and even the two-year-old has benefited from the literacy skills work. He recognises M for McDonald's as we walk to school!"

Brian Hazell, the headteacher at Clapham Manor Primary, says: "If you have good home-school links the child benefits. You may not see immediate academic improvement but their confidence will be boosted."

The school is now celebrating an excellent Ofsted report that found that it "is built on very strong foundations of mutual respect, celebration of diversity and effective partnership between staff, home and community".

'The trick is to ignore the bad'

Five is a strategic age to give children the skills to deal with issues that last a lifetime, believes Carolyn Webster-Stratton, of Washington University. "This is the age they are going from creche and preschool to first year in school. It's a good time to intervene, because these kids are going to have to behave at school and get along with other kids."

She uses videotape to work with parents. "You can show a child throwing a temper tantrum and see how the parent reacts - is it in a way that makes it worse or better?"

Parents can practice new techniques for managing their children's behaviour. "A child that whines and whines for a biscuit until he gets one is a child who learns to whine to get what he wants," she says. With practice, parents can learn to ignore the whining by seeing on videotape that it works if they do.

"But you have to prepare them for the fact that the whining (or whatever it is) will get worse before it gets better, because the child will escalate the whining at first to get what he wants. But, once he realises it's not working, it will stop."

Webster-Stratton says some parents might not consider it good parenting to allow their child to do these things. "The trick is to ignore the bad and give a lot of attention to the positive behaviour, so the child learns there is much more to be gained from being positive."

Studies in the States have shown her parenting programmes continue to work for parents and children some years after the programme. "I really feel the social and emotional confidence is a foundation for academic learning. If you are feeling insecure, have low self-esteem or don't have any friends, it can be hard to focus on the academic stuff.

"The idea is to weave these things into the curriculum so children can be doing a lot of activities which are not only teaching them numbers and reading, but tie into social skills too.

"There are lots of ways you can intergrate these concepts without it being an extra item on the curriculum. For instance the children could be working together on a big poster and you might not have a crayon, glue and glitter for everyone, so children are forced to negotiate for what they want and to take turns.

"You are meeting their needs for creativity and developing fine motor skills and also their social skills."

For instance the children could be working together on a big poster and you might not have a crayon, glue and glitter for everyone, so children are forced to negotiate for what they want and to take turns. "You are meeting their needs for creativity and developing fine motor skills and also their social skills."

fields.headline: Win a trip to Washington
fields.standfirst: Let Tom Hanks check out your story in this transatlantic writing contest
fields.trailText: Let Tom Hanks check out your story in this transatlantic writing contest
fields.body:
Oscar-winning film star Tom Hanks has been appointed by the US government to support a nationwide essay contest for Britain's teenagers, to stimulate their interest in the "special relationship" between the two countries and the role they played in the second world war.

Hanks - who starred in the 1998 blockbuster Saving Private Ryan - has agreed to be a judge for the competition, which is being launched in London today by education and employment secretary David Blunkett.

The contest is the brainchild of the American ambassador in Britain Philip Lader, who has been struck by how little British youngsters know about the US/UK wartime alliance. It was due to Steven Spielberg that awareness was raised about the devastating carnage of the D-day landing on Omaha Beach through his film, Saving Private Ryan.

Ambassador Lader, the first serving US ambassador to have been born since the end of the war (in 1946), believes it is vital that young people take advantage of the opportunity to tap the knowledge of their grandparents and the older generation who still have stories to tell.

"I have two daughters at British schools," he told the Guardian, "and I have become increasingly aware of how little teenagers know about British and American co-operation. It is a big chunk of their heritage."

The aim of the contest, he explains, is for 14- to 16-year-olds to write an essay of up to 1,000 words on how the US-UK relationship during the war impacted on their communities. To do this they can interview their grandparents, other members of the older generation or use original research material. For example, mixed marriages have had an enormous effect on people's families, and the American communities that sprang up around airbases in areas such as Norfolk are still alive and well.

He also hopes the competition - which has prizes for teachers, too - will revitalise teachers' own interest in this element of history within the curriculum.

The contest will be launched at the Imperial War Museum in London, which chronicles the relationship between the two countries through its unique wartime archives. David Blunkett, accompanied by Pamela Smith, the US Minister-Counselor for Public Affairs, will be there in an original Red Cross jeep used during the war.

It is estimated that there are around 600,000 potential young people who will be invited to enter.

Accompanied by a parent or teacher, the three main winners will be invited to Washington where they will attend meetings at the White House and Congress. It's not clear at this stage whether president Clinton will be present! American Airlines and Marriott Hotels will provide transport and accommodation. Twelve further winners and their nominating teachers will each win a personal computer provided by Gateway Computers.

Ambassador Lader has lined up an impressive judging team which, as well as Hanks, includes Stephen Ambrose, an eminent historian and biographer of presidents Eisenhower and Nixon; the US secretary of state for education Dick Reilly; the ex-Republican presidential candidate Robert Dole; and the Supreme Court judge Sandra Day-O'Connnor. On the British side, the judges will include the best-selling author Ken Follett.

This is a great opportunity to learn more about history and build trans-generational relationships at the same time - as well as winning some great prizes.

fields.headline: Technical trouble
fields.standfirst: Are words ousting practice in the unsettled arena of design and technology at school?  Phil Revell asks if the national curriculum is failing future James Dysons
fields.trailText: Are words ousting practice in the unsettled arena of design and technology at school? Phil Revell asks if the national curriculum is failing future James Dysons
fields.body:
Young designers are steering clear of design and technology in schools - they see it as a subject that Leonardo da Vinci would fail because it has become so bureaucratic and paper-based.

Research for the Department for Education published tomorrow will show that recruitment of trainee teachers to the subject remains at crisis level two years after being declared a shortage subject by the Teacher Training Agency. Postgraduate teaching courses are attracting fewer than half their target numbers. "The crisis in recruitment for design and technology teaching has deepened, despite it being designated a shortage subject," Professor Richard Kimbell, of Goldsmiths College, London, will tell this week's Design and Technology Association (DATA) conference.

He looked at final-year students on design and engineering degree courses and examined their attitudes towards a career in teaching.

The results make it clear that the marketing-led People Remember Teachers approach to recruiting for shortage subjects was doomed to failure, and that the government's reforms are part and parcel of the negative image that is deterring graduates from entering the profession. "Their attitude is that teaching is not a creative activity," says Kimbell. "It's seen as managerial and bureaucratic."

Design and technology didn't exist 30 years ago. In the sixties, if schools offered anything it would be craft skills like woodwork and needlework. The subject grew because teachers were allowed to experiment, in some cases writing their own syllabuses and setting their own exams. And then came the National Curriculum. Technology was given a place, but at a cost. "When I started there was a lot of freedom," says D&T teacher Simon Badcock, who will receive the James Dyson teacher of the year award at the Data conference. "Then the new orders came in and we went from one extreme to the other."

"The first five years were disastrous," says Andrew Breckon, chief executive of Data. "Everyone had a view about D&T and none of them had very much practice at it." Schools were faced with turmoil as the curriculum created a mega department from craftwork, textiles, design, food, IT - and at one stage art - and labelled the whole edifice "technology".

"I guess it's academics who have insisted that you have to write a proper report," he says. Andrew Breckon pins the blame on the GCSE exam boards. "It's highly likely that Leonardo da Vinci would fail D&T GCSE," he says. The assessment structure sets out a framework within which schools have to operate. "Design doesn't work like that," he argues. "If you go through an arid step-by-step approach the likelihood is that you will end up with an arid solution."

Data research showed students' experience of D&T in schools to be generally positive, and while there were recurrent references to the fact that their D&T teachers had been "good" teachers, parents have been less impressed. An electronics engineer attempting to help his son with a school project was rebuffed when the teacher clearly didn't understand what was proposed. Other parents complain children spent an inordinate amount of time planning and writing - with little doing.

It's a situation that James Dyson would like to see reversed. "The whole point of design and technology is the discovery of effect. You learn by seeing what works and what doesn't work. Not by writing a report." Dyson, who developed the ballbarrow and the bagless vacuum cleaner, thinks he knows where the demand for a written process comes from.

Many teachers had no training in the new skills they were expected to deliver. Lisa Thomas entered the profession with a degree in three-dimensional design on which she had specialised in silversmithing - hardly the best preparation for work in a school. But she has built a successful department at the Oldbury Wells School in Bridgnorth, where her students regularly win awards.

"D&T is a very complex subject area," she says, "It requires an all-round understanding of materials and processes. There are new requirements, new skills - but no training for the teachers to deliver the new skills is expected."

Another issue is the resourcing. A D&T classroom - with lathes, mills, bandsaws, computer-assisted machinery, specialised work benches and technician support - is an expensive environment.

Oldbury has machines more than 30 years old. Battered wooden benches are ill suited for lessons that feature vacuum forming, electronics or CAD/CAM. Thomas has invested in technology, but she could easily spend £60,000 re-equipping one room. "The new equipment is good, it's well designed, well-thought-through for the needs of children, but we can't afford it." Yet despite the problems her students like the subject and several are going to study industrial design.

Simon Badcock argues that some schools play safe with the projects they allow children to attempt. "With league tables there is a lot of pressure to perform, some teachers will play the game to get the grades - and children lose out." The government has abandoned its reluctance to throw money at problems with a £6,000 salary for PGCE students and a golden hello for shortage subject teachers - which will include D&T. The Goldsmiths report advocates more measures, including designers in residence for schools and a 2-year PGCE course for D&T.

But the report suggests money is not the only issue. The graduates believed teaching lacked "variety, professional freedom and creativity". Practitioners like Thomas and Badcock think it a false perception.

"There's paperwork and management responsibility in any job," says Badcock. Kimbell points out that there is no mention of creativity in the standards trainee teachers must meet. "It's a managerialist view of teaching and the same view dominates Ofsted."

He'd like to see politicians exhibiting the best design and technology projects produced by young people: "Blair and Blunkett talk about millennium products and how important design and creativity are for the nation - yet there were no millennium products for children, and there's no celebration of the creativity in schools."

fields.headline: No losers
fields.trailText: Now that we actually have a government that appears to have both the money and the political will to improve educational funding, there is renewed hope that a fairer funding system can soon be introduced to benefit the losers without harming the winners. The Department for the Environment is expected to produce a Green Paper this summer outlining ways of funding the public sector, including schools.
fields.body:
Now that we actually have a government that appears to have both the money and the political will to improve educational funding, there is renewed hope that a fairer funding system can soon be introduced to benefit the losers without harming the winners. The Department for the Environment is expected to produce a Green Paper this summer outlining ways of funding the public sector, including schools.

Governors could be forgiven for developing a severe headache each time they think about the school budget. The local management of schools was supposed to simplify budgeting, but budget headings and sources of income have become increasingly diverse. There are, for example, the New Opportunities Fund for teacher training; the Standards Fund, enabling schools to employ extra teaching assistants among other things; and the one-off Budget Bonus - as well as money coming into schools taking part in specific government initiatives.

There is continued uncertainty about funding from 2002 onwards, the upper-salary range of payments to those teachers who have "crossed the threshold". As senior teachers start to transfer to the new leadership payments spine, it may be necessary to commensurately raise the salary of the deputy head. It is unclear, at the moment, if this will fall on a school's local management of schools' budget, or be funded by central government.

So, how could funding arrangements be altered to remove the unfairness and the obscurity of the current arrangements?

Some argue that tinkering with them will produce a much fairer distribution but leave the local councillors free to spend what is received on whatever they see fit. Others propose that local education authorities should prepare a plan and bid for funds, leaving central government to decide whether or not it funds the plan in full or in part. A third proposal, advocated by the Secondary Heads Association, is for a clear national formula derived from a costed analysis of the needs of pupils and the activities of schools set against government expectations.

This entitlement would take into account the schools' varying circumstances and would be sent direct to schools without passing through the local authority.

The authority would receive its formula-driven amount for the work it would be expected to do in relation to school improvement, admissions, transport, audit and special needs. On top of the national entitlement, every local education authority would be free to raise supplementary funding to enhance provision in its schools and communities.

 Peter Downes is chairman of the Advisory Centre for Education and has produced a publication on this subject: 'Fairer Funding: Proposals for a national funding entitlement for schools', which is available from the Secondary Heads Association, 130 Regent Road, Leicester, LE1 7PG. Tel: 01162 991122.

fields.headline: Oscars are coming
fields.standfirst: At last lecturers will be able to shine in new teaching awards
fields.trailText: At last lecturers will be able to shine in new teaching awards
fields.body:
For Academy Awards read Academic Awards. At last, lecturers throughout the land will get the chance to bask in glory, and thank all and sundry as they accept national awards and whopping cheques in a £1m extravaganza designed to put some hype into higher education. The Oscars are coming. Who knows, they may even dress up.

Twenty star lecturers stand to win £50,000 each and a "small and tasteful" award presented by one of the government's more glamorous ministers, Baroness Blackstone. Gifted teachers who until now have been cast in supporting roles to their colleagues achieving big research awards will have their chance of the limelight. The "Dons' Oscars" will reward a variety of lecturing styles though probably not in the full range of Oscar categories - best actor and actress, yes; best visual effects, maybe; best make-up and costume design, no. And definitely no Irving Thalberg Memorial Award.

Universities and funding councils in England and Northern Ireland have launched the scheme to raise the status of teaching - for too long regarded in universities as a poor relation of research. But proposals for videos of star lecturers performing, suggested by Lord Dearing, when he carried out his inquiry into higher education, have been dropped.

There will be 20 Dons' Oscars - sorry, National Teaching Fellowships - and each university or college can nominate one star lecturer for consideration by a national panel, including two students. An ability to "inspire and enthuse" students is one of the key qualitites sought and students' views of their lecturers' performance will be taken into account, although this would not be the only test, said Professor Sally Brown, of the Institute of Learning and Teaching, which is organising the prizes.

Similar schemes in Australia, Canada and the US have encouraged the institute and the Higher Education Funding Council for England to try a bit of razzmatazz to raise the status of teaching, but perhaps more influential has been the success of last year's teaching awards for schools instigated by Lord Puttnam.

Winners will have considerable freedom in how to spend their £50,000 - travel, for instance, is allowed, provided it can be shown as essential to improving the standard of future teaching. The money can also be used to pay someone else to do some of the fellowship holder's work (although the organisers are anxious that these star teachers keep on teaching), to buy equipment or to attend meetings with other fellows.

Holders will have three years to spend winnings - and, if they change jobs, the unspent money goes with them, making them extremely employable.

Several universities already have their own award schemes to encourage teaching. Napier University in Edinburgh is in the fourth year of its scheme with 25 active fellowship holders who have each received about £500 for their record in teaching and promoting students' learning. Professor Freed Percival admitted there was scepticism to begin with but there had been no backbiting or criticism of winners. The judgment of colleagues was taken into account, unlike the US "hall of fame" approach which is based solely on students' opinions.

"We had a feeling that that could stifle innovation. If you are the biggest comedian around, you might not stretch your students. It may be valuable to push them beyond their comfort zone." Very un-Hollywood.

 Nominations by May 19 to the Institute of Learning and Teaching, Genesis 3, Innovation Way, York Science Park, Heslington, York YO10 5DQ.

fields.headline: On trial in class
fields.standfirst: Teachers are either calm, cuddly or gruff, but the best should be all three
fields.trailText: Teachers are either calm, cuddly or gruff, but the best should be all three
fields.body:
 This character analysis of the teaching profession comes from Lee Turvey, 11, of Melcombe Primary school, Fulham Palace Road, London.

There are three types of teacher in every school - the Rottweilers, the soft and cuddly, and the calm and placid. The Rottweilers growl at you as soon as the day begins, especially if you are having a test. It really makes your day. After you have survived the first lesson, they come along and scrutinise your books, and swiftly grab a pen to write something nasty like: "You have not done what you were told". If you dare to speak up, they glare at you.

Next we come to the soft and cuddly model. As soon as you arrive in the playground, they smile at you sweetly. They always praise you for what you have done. Once in a while they may shout at you, but they always come and hug you after. They stamp smiley faces over your books and write: "Well done."

Lastly, we come to the calm and placid model. These are the ones that can teach in any amount of noise. Even if a chair gets hurled across the floor, they will politely tell the child to go and pick it up. Their feathers will not be ruffled. At the same time, you can be busy doing your best and really working hard, and it will never get noticed.

So there they are, the three kinds of teacher, but the best is the one who has aspects of them all.

 The article appears in the first issue of TheNewspaper, a monthly for schools started by three teachers. Aimed at 8- to 13-year- olds, it is distributed free to 3,000 schools. In September the promoters hope to send it to all UK primary and secondary schools.

fields.headline: Basic skills pledge
fields.standfirst: If we are to solve the problem of poor basic skills among adults, employers must get involved, insists  Alan Wells
fields.trailText: If we are to solve the problem of poor basic skills among adults, employers must get involved, insists Alan Wells
fields.body:
Nearly half the estimated 7m adults with poor basic skills are in work. Of the rest, a fifth are in the workforce, but unemployed at present. So it seems perverse that if you are one of these adults, the only way you can get the type of intensive teaching you may need is by doing something irresponsible.

First, you can lose your job and get on a government-funded training scheme such as the New Deal. In this way you can usually get help to improve literacy or numeracy as part of the training to help you find another job.

Or, second, you can commit a crime serious enough for a longish sentence in prison, where you can also get some intensive teaching.

If you fancy neither option, you are likely to get just a couple of hours teaching in your local college or adult education centre, usually at the end of a hard working day. Progress is very slow under these conditions. Teaching is usually only available during term time, and often adults who begin courses with enthusiasm become disheartened and give up.

To be fair, some large employers do provide help with improving basic skills. If you're lucky enough to work for one of these companies - and you have the courage to ask and don't think that it might put you at the top of any future redundancy list - you can get on a programme, although these are often for no more than a few hours a week. Sympathy is the best you can hope for with smaller employers.

I must say it seems odd that people who never mastered such essential skills in 11 years or so of full-time schooling can be expected to do so in a couple of hours a week.

This conundrum was much discussed by all of us involved in producing the Moser Report last year. How could we help adults in full-time work, and get more companies involved in raising standards?

Learndirect - the former University for Industry - has a key part to play here. It will revolutionise learning and can put learners, rather than institutions and administrators, at the heart of learning. All of us involved in Moser continue to have high hopes of it.

But what else could be done?

One of our key recommendations is a "pledge" in which employers, often in partnership with trade unions, signal that they were prepared to help.

Some will say it isn't their problem. Fair enough. In an ideal world every young person should leave school with good basic skills. However, the reality is that some don't, nor have they in any year over the last few decades.

At least the government is helping schools improve, but that's no use to all those adults who left school some time ago.

So we hope that our pledge idea might encourage employers to commit themselves to helping in our crusade. We suggest a three part pledge: an employer would commit to estimating their company's scale of need; to producing a strategy and action plan to help employees wanting to improve their basic skills; and to putting written communications with employees in plain English.

We envisage an award for employers who fulfil the pledge.

We also want something for employers of every size rather than a number of different pledges.

Of course, a pledge is no use unless something actually happens. But nor is apportioning blame or adopting a "can't do" approach. Only if we all take responsibility and all make a pledge, will we be able to put poor basic skills among adults in the "solved" file.

 Alan Wells is head of the Basic Skills Agency.

fields.headline: Set design
fields.trailText: Set design
fields.body:
What do set designers do? Everything, love. Without us there's no show.

Of course, you are wonderful. But what do you do? What do we do, love? Are you serious? We work in theatre, film, video or television, and often cross between them. We're responsible for everything that can be found on the set that creates the production's "look", from the scenery backdrop to the placing of an item of furniture.

A big job, then. Huge, love, huge. One week we're creating authentic battle scenes for 300 warriors, the next we're making sure the style of kitchen is just right socially for the class of the characters.

How do you go about it? Want to know a lot, love, don't you?

I'm interested. Well, we get involved from the beginning, helping with the planning, reading the script beforehand. If the production is set in a particular period, we do lots and lots of reading to make sure everything is just so. If it is to be shot on location the designer will, with the help of the location manager, find the right setting.

What then? The designer will create a floor plan, then a working model. This is done with the movement of scenes and cameras in mind.

What about the actors? Well, yes, them too.

What's wrong with actors? They spoil a good set, love. But onwards, onwards! A designer has to work with many others, such as the costume designer and lighting director.

What then? The set content. The director and producer will give the opinions and ideas to the designer, who will then translate them on to a storyboard showing the transition of the set throughout the different scenes.

So it's the director who tells you what to do? Ha! Well, if you want to see it that way, I suppose so.

What qualities do you need? Molti talenti, love. And imagination, attention to detail, drawing and communication skills.

And the ability to follow instructions. Don't do it to death, love, it wasn't funny the first time. I was going to say that a designer usually has a keen interest in fashion, architecture and furniture.

Can you start in telly? It's possible, sure. Set designers often start in theatre before moving into film and television.

I suppose one is much the same as another. Oh no! Film and television screens produce images that are seen up close and from every different angle. The set has got to withstand close scrutiny, otherwise the "atmosphere" can be ruined by a shaky wall or a piece of false fruit etc.

How do you get in to it? Most set designers have a degree, usually in interior design, art and design, sculpture, industrial 3D design or stage design. Many art colleges provide specialised courses in set design.

What do you need for college? A portfolio of work to show potential and the necessary skills, and that is usually required at interview. Entry requirements vary: after A levels either a one-year foundation course or advanced GNVQ in art and design can be taken; or an art and design access course.

 The Chartered Society of Designers (CSD), 32-38 Saffron Hill, London EC1N 8FH, Telephone: 0207 831 9777

 Association of British Theatre Technicians (ABTT), 47 Bermondsey Street, London SE1 3XT, offer AutoCAD-distance learning course, Telephone: 0207 403 3778

 The Society of British Theatre Designers, 47 Bermondsey Street, London SE1 3XT, Telephone: 0207 403 3778

fields.headline: Web publishing
fields.trailText: Even if you helped build your school's website, you may be unfamiliar with hyper-text mark-up language...
fields.body:
Even if you helped build your school's website, you may be unfamiliar with hyper-text mark-up language (HTML), because packages such as Microsoft's FrontPage make it perfectly feasible to cobble together a website rapidly without having to learn how to code.

Some very successful sites - notably The Archbishop's School in Kent, which was School Website of the Month on the Guardian's Education Unlimited site in January - use Frontpage, and it certainly allows pupils to become quickly involved in building the site. "We give it over to the kids," says teacher David Lister. "We use their expertise. My role is the manager. At the moment, the technical responsibility and the material collection lies with sixth-formers. In the next generation we have year 11 students who are taking on the technical responsibilities for some of it.

"You'll always find someone in a staffroom who's prepared to sit up all night writing cgi script [programming language]," he adds, "but the two important things are topicality and appropriateness. Many school websites fall into the vanity publishing category. They don't change." Some parents may be just as willing to help out with the technical expertise.

Using a package, however, can be a bit like buying all your flowers from the garden centre and planting them in an empty plot. Many webmasters eventually want the freedom to produce their own results and to do that they need to learn HTML.

Anyone can see the HTML that allows a browser to read a web page by going to the View menu on their browser and clicking on Page Source. Plenty of courses exist, and so do a number of online tutorials. One of the most accessible of these is Webmonkey. There's also a children's version which also includes a guide for parents and teachers. If you don't know the first thing about web publishing, try the BBC's Webwise guide or one of the bright yellow Dummies books on sale in bookshops.

Lister's key advice is "Clarify what you're trying to achieve, and what it's for." Is the site a PR tool to impress prospective parents? Or do you want it to be a space where pupils can develop their ICT skills, departments can add pages, and teachers and parents can talk to each other? It may take a while to emulate the pioneering Ambleside school site, but revisit the relatively hardcore CNet Builder in just a few months and you may be surprised by how much techie jargon you can understand.

fields.headline: Diana magic
fields.standfirst: Rebecca Smithers was at the national launch of awards for special achievements by children at school
fields.trailText: Rebecca Smithers was at the national launch of awards for special achievements by children at school
fields.body:
Every secondary, middle and special school in Britain will over the next few days receive a nomination pack inviting them to name pupils who have made their mark on their schools and local communities through unusual and spectacular personal achievement.

The mailing marks the national launch of the Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Award, piloted last year in nearly 250 schools. The scheme - for 11- to 18-year-olds - is part of the official commemoration of the late princess being taken forward by the government-chaired memorial committee.

Last week education secretary David Blunkett handed out awards to some of the first recipients at a London ceremony, and was visibly moved by the touching stories of children who have battled against the odds to take exams while seriously ill, encouraged truants to return to school, and helped to set up anti-bullying strategies and after-school facilities for the benefit of children less fortunate themselves.

"What this award brings home is that other achievements can be just as valuable as academic results," said Mr Blunkett. "Anything which encourages children and young people to take part in the life of their community should be welcomed by all."

The 237 award-winners include: Omar Anayat, 15, of Beardwood High School in Blackburn. He organised a football match in memory of a friend in just two weeks and raised £1,300 for Royal Manchester Children's Hospital where his friend was treated. His home-school links officer believes Omar's achievements have helped to dispel the "macho" boy image prevalent in his age-group.

Stephen Green,17, of Great Sankey High School, Warrington, has helped give local young people a voice in their community. Since becoming responsible for the youth page of the local Warrington Guardian newspaper in 1997, Stephen has set up a youth club and a teenage hang-out centre. His teacher, Miss Morris, said he was the only pupil nominated by the school because he stood "head and shoulders" above the others.

Stephen's mother admitted she had not known that her son, who has a visual impairment, was being bullied until he initiated a bullying awareness programme at the school.

Lisa Hart, Ian McCardle, Danielle Williams, Stephen Woolvine, Lucy Hayes and Jenny Houghton all attend Brookfield High School in Knowsley, which has close links with a local special school, Springfield School. They noticed that several disabled pupils could not take part in after-school sports clubs. Backed by their PE/special needs co-ordinator, they set up a sports club at the local school to which they each devote around 90 minutes a week.

Ian Cordingley, headteacher at Springfield, said: "Many of our youngsters have developed a great deal more confidence as a result of these activities."Amy Revens, 15, from Bedford High School in Wigan has helped set up a mentoring scheme for younger pupils just starting at the school. It now has 24 pupils in year 9 and 10 who give advice and support to youngsters - usually at lunchtimes in a special room called "The Sanctuary".

Amy's head of year, Mrs Kay, said the scheme is a "real partnership" between teachers and pupils. Many more trivial issues were dealt with through this initiative without needing to be referred to teachers.

Finally Natalie Peirce, 15, of Stewards School in Harlow, Essex, clearly impressed Mr Blunkett who said he had adopted her as his "own little spice girl". Oozing confidence, she explained how she had given up school to look after her three young brothers after her mother had turned to drugs following her father's death from a heroin overdose when she was six years old. She realised the importance of her education and returned to school where she threw her energies into persuading other non-attenders to come back to school. Despite the disruption to her education, she is on course to take her GCSEs this year.

 Completed nomination forms must be returned by June 2, 2000. The scheme covers Scotland, Northern Ireland, Wales and England and is being run by Education Extra - a national charity that helps schools develop out-of-hours learning activities. If your school does not receive a form, or you need more details, contact: Diana, Princess of Wales Memorial Award for Young People, Education Extra Achievements, 17 Old Ford Road, London E2 9PL, tel: 020-8709 9935.

fields.headline: Hard-nosed arts
fields.standfirst: The idea that performing arts can be researched has long been scoffed at by many academics - but new research scholarships are turning the tide
fields.trailText: The idea that performing arts can be researched has long been scoffed at by many academics - but new research scholarships are turning the tide
fields.body:
"There's an assumption that the arts don't involve thinking - especially dance," says Sophia Lycouris. As a dance artist and one of the first holders of a creative and performing arts fellowship she is part of a national experiment trying to overturn that idea.

Her research at Nottingham Trent University will result not only in a traditional paper in an academic journal and perhaps a CD Rom but also in performances that she has choreographed. The idea that a performance - dance, music, drama - can be researched has met with considerable distrust among academics and would probably baffle most of the public. But since it was set up two years ago, the Arts and Humanities Research Board has nailed its colours to the mast by including creative arts in its £50m research programme, and setting up a fellowship scheme for the purpose.

With the board poised to become a fully fledged research council the argument will become more public. Lycouris, a senior lecturer in contemporary arts, admits it is a problematic area. But she argues that not only does a lot of intellectual effort go into producing dance, as with other arts, but that they generate knowledge, even if it is from an ephemeral performance.

"In any art form where you create anything you have to make decisions about how to use your materials. You have to be aware of what is going on around you and how these things come together in society.

"The experience of an audience as they watch a performance is knowledge. The experience of a live performance can be very intense. It is a 'floating' notion of knowledge that circulates in a different way from papers you find in libraries," she said.

For Paul Langford, the research board's chief executive who is due to stand down in September, there is no doubt the decision to give as much weight to the creative arts as to the traditional scholarship of the humanities has been the right one in principle.

It also allows the research board to make a case for funding activities with huge economic impact on UK plc (not to mention Cool Britannia). The creative industries, as the Department of Culture, Media and Sport points out, generate jobs. So research into design or dance begins to look a good deal less airy fairy.

Certainly there was no open challenge to the idea of creative arts research at a recent seminar mounted by the board. As one speaker noted, the proportion of employment in the creative industries would go on rising. Not only would more people be involved in producing all forms of arts and music but more would be spent on consumption. That suggested a need to study audiences and how they interacted with the arts.

There was, however, some confusion about the boundaries between research and creative work. Concerns were raised about the future for lone scholars in the light of the board's encouragement of teamwork and collaboration. (In two years' time the ring fence between arts and humanities is to be removed - a "bold move", predicted one speaker, which would prove a "cold bath" for some in the traditional humanities.)

Because the research board has 12,000 research active staff in the arts and humanities - one in four of all UK university researchers - to support, it has very few funds to distribute compared with the science research councils or even with social science, but its arrival has raised the status of work in their fields, it was felt.

The board has penalised 12 departments (including one at Oxford) for poor submission rates by PhD students, but should it attempt to steer this research effort?

The issue split the seminar. On one side it was argued the field was so broad that the board was already making choices and these ought to be spelled out. "The board should be honest enough to say it has some priorities," urged one vice-chancellor.

Another felt identifying themes would be disastrous. "Most of the good ideas will come from people finishing their PhDs. Our job is to bring home the money for the young people to do their stuff. We have got to let them play the key role in deciding what the stuff is."

But pointing to the lack of research in pre-colonial history as an example of a neglected minority area, one participant felt the board needed to take a strategic approach and give academics a "delicate nudge" in the direction of where the "silences" were.

With the prospect of European, as well as British government, money dangled in front of the arts and humanities, the mood of the seminar was optimistic. But would the safest funding pipeline lie through the Department of Culture, Media and Sport - sympathetic but less powerful in Whitehall - or with the other research councils under the Department of Trade and Industry?

No decisions have yet been made but the majority mood was summed up in the comment: "There are friends and there are funders and we have got to follow the money."

Because the research board has 12,000 research active staff in the arts and humanities - one in four of all UK university researchers - to support, it has very few funds to distribute compared with the science research councils or even with social science, but its arrival has raised the status of work in their fields, it was felt. The board has penalised 12 departments (including one at Oxford) for poor submission rates by PhD students, but should it attempt to steer this research effort? The issue split the seminar. On one side it was argued the field was so broad that the board was already making choices and these ought to be spelled out. "The board should be honest enough to say it has some priorities," urged one vice-chancellor. Another felt identifying themes would be disastrous. "Most of the good ideas will come from people finishing their PhDs. Our job is to bring home the money for the young people to do their stuff. We have got to let them play the key role in deciding what the stuff is." But pointing to the lack of research in pre-colonial history as an example of a neglected minority area, one participant felt the board needed to take a strategic approach and give academics a "delicate nudge" in the direction of where the "silences" were. With the prospect of European, as well as British government, money dangled in front of the arts and humanities, the mood of the seminar was optimistic. But would the safest funding pipeline lie through the Department of Culture, Media and Sport - sympathetic but less powerful in Whitehall - or with the other research councils under the Department of Trade and Industry? No decisions have yet been made but the majority mood was summed up in the comment: "There are friends and there are funders and we have got to follow the money."

fields.headline: Economics
fields.trailText:
Tutor2UEconomics
*****
Aimed at: everyone
fields.body:
Tutor2UEconomics
*****
Aimed at: everyone

Subjects outside the national curriculum tend to be overlooked by bigger education sites. Tutor2U more than redresses the balance. Revision resources, essay plans, links, and an active forum and advice section from an A-level examiner are available. It also has regular economic news updates. Tutor2U is a brilliant site and undoubtedly the leader of the field.

The Motley Fool
***
Aimed at: everyone

For those interested in personal finance, the Fool launched in the UK last year. It provides an engaging way of learning about stock markets and how they are influenced. For example, setting up an imaginary stock portfolio and tracking its progress.

Health Economics
**
Aimed at: everyone

A dry, but comprehensive study, prepared by the Office of Health Economics. It includes teachers' notes and is suitable for A-level students.

Virtual Economy
****
Aimed at: everyone

The Virtual Economy allows you to take on Gordon Brown's job and work in an online 11 Downing Street. There is information and help in the library; and the economic policy floor and virtual model of the economy let you tinker with the Budget. Teachers will find suggestions on how to use the site for A-level and GNVQ economics and business studies.

Economics UK
**
Aimed at: teachers

David Smith is the economics editor of the Sunday Times and author of several books on economics. The site consists of articles and an invitation to purchase them. For up-to-date news, though, FT.com is a better choice.

The Economist Big Mac
***
Aimed at: everyone

The Economist is only available online for subscribers. But some resources, such as their annually-updated Big Mac index are made public. It suggests the theory that the price of a Big Mac in a particular country indicates whether the local currency is over- or undervalued.

BizEd
***
Aimed at: everyone

Unusually, BizEd takes account of the International Baccalaureate requirements, although that is not the only reason to visit the site. It also has a growing database of company facts - prepared by companies with students in mind - and graded resources for post-16 students.

Business Education
***
Aimed at: teachers

The Economics and Business Education Association is about to launch a 'value-added' website for members only. It costs between £10 and £45 to join, depending on whether you are a teacher or a student. Until that time, the links, discussion forums and teaching advice on this site are free. Notably, the site has a section on pre-16 economics and business studies, which is difficult to find elsewhere.

fields.headline: If you ask me...
fields.trailText: At the secondary school where I teach, a wide range of fizzy drinks is on sale. These drinks seem to turn reasonable young people into pupils from hell...
fields.body:
At the secondary school where I teach, a wide range of fizzy drinks is on sale. These drinks seem to turn reasonable young people into pupils from hell. This causes extra work and stress for all, and has a big impact on their learning. I have tried to get the drinks banned from school, but to no avail.

Margaret Tulloch is a spokesperson for CASE - the Campaign for State Education.

I would advise you to do a little background research. You need to ascertain whose decision it was to install the vending machines. This can expose a grey area as regards who is ultimately responsible. In theory, the headteacher takes all the key decisions on the day-to-day management of the school, but it is likely that the governing body will have played a major part in agreeing to contract them in view of the revenue that can be accrued.

Many cash-strapped schools are having to explore the benefits of taking on commercial ventures such as these. If you want to open up a debate about the legitimacy of having them in your school, your case would be enhanced by knowing if they do generate a valuable source of additional income.

Assuming that the governing body did play a role in making the decision, you should look at school policy in general. Does the financial benefit of the machines really outweigh the wider educational benefits in terms of a whole school policy to promote healthy eating amongst young people?

It could also be argued that the very existence of these machines in the school implies that the school is endorsing these brands being sold. This issue may well be something which you feel merits further discussion. This would be especially relevant in the current economic climate in education.

Enabling this discussion can be difficult. The governing body of a school should be responsive to the community it represents. But establishing a system of communication that enables real two-way dialogue can be easier said than done.

We at CASE are campaigning to improve democracy within the school system which will allow all "stakeholders" to have an equal say in the way that a school is run. Parent councils, such as those in other parts of Europe, would make it possible for the governors to consult with parents or guardians more frequently.

In the absence of such bodies in your school, and as a member of staff, express your concerns to the teacher governor(s). If your school has a forum for staff to talk through policy issues, raise your concerns there. Mention it to the parents or guardians yourself whenever you can to make sure that the future of these vending machines in your school remains top of the agenda.

Margaret Tulloch's key points:

 Establish who gave the go ahead for the vending machines to be installed. Research what, if any, real financial benefits are gained by the school in having the vending machines.

 Place your objections within the framework of school policy. Raise the issue with the governing body through as many channels as you can: parents or guardians and staff.

 Remember that the governing body must be responsive and accountable to the school community. But bear in mind, schools are often caught between a rock and a hard place. They may have to choose between financial necessity and educational ideals.

 Whether drinking fizzy drinks, such as Pepsi and Coke, has any effect upon children's behaviour is a controversial issue. Caffeine causes most concern - which in higher doses can cause anxiety, headaches and dehydration; as well as making it harder to absorb calcium needed for healthy bones and teeth. Doctors recommend that people should consume no more than about two cans of Coke. Drinks made with clear soda, such as Sprite or 7-Up do not contain caffeine. CASE is based at 158 Durham Road, London SW20 0DG, tel: 0181-944 8206.

Next week's query: I fear drugs may be openly bought and used by pupils at my son's school. I have heard him and his friends discussing other pupils, who apparently go to a park to get "stoned"at lunch and then return to school. My son says "everyone" knows it is going on, but "no one cares". A teacher at the school told me in confidence that their hands are tied. Is this really the case?

fields.headline: Community spirit
fields.standfirst: Desperately seeking a European strategy on lifelong learning
fields.trailText: Desperately seeking a European strategy on lifelong learning
fields.body:
The timing could hardly have been worse. Just a few weeks after one of the first training schemes to cross national borders collapsed when BMW pulled the plug on Rover, CEDEFOP, the EC-funded think tank for vocational training, has released a report, The Age of Learning, which suggests that European countries need a radical rethink of training policy with far greater cooperation between member states.

The irony of the situation is not lost on Steve Bainbridge, one of the report's authors, but he remains in buoyant mood. "Just because the Rover training scheme failed, it doesn't mean it was a bad idea," he says. "There was a fusion of British autonomy and self-reliance and German emphasis on quality that inherently worked well, and we should be looking to introduce similar ventures into other industries."

Bainbridge is no innocent abroad; he understands that when push comes to shove, the realpolitik of national self-interest will kick in. But he also genuinely believes that there is much to be gained from mutual cooperation and that the lack of any coherent framework for analysing European attitudes to vocational training will ultimately work to the detriment of all member states.

"There is a growing recognition of the importance of lifelong learning, and human capital and skills," Bainbridge continues, "but there is no European strategy for what this all means. In the past, member countries have identified common interests and got together to create a framework for dealing with them. The same thing needs to happen with vocational training."

Which prompts the question, "Why"? Only 3% of the British workforce show any interest in working abroad, and the reason the figure is so low almost certainly has everything to do with family, language and culture and little to do with any perceived lack of uniformity of training qualifications within the EU. Moreover those that do want to leave these shores don't appear to find much to stop them; the 1980s Auf Wiedersehen Pet generation of builders have morphed into the present day Mirupafshim Pets now working in Kosovo.

But Bainbridge reckons that any initiatives that don't take in the wider issues are condemned to fail. "We talk about lifelong learning, but we're not willing to think it through," he says. "Our education system is centred around the acquisition of qualifications at the beginning of one's working life, yet the skills one learns may well be out of date within five years. There is a recognition that we need people to acquire new skills, yet Britain has no direct link between its qualifications systems and its training for the unemployed."

CEDEFOP's core argument that European governments display an innate hostility to joined-up thinking holds good because the key debate over who should pay for retraining has been fudged, as there is no firm line on whether the state, the employer or the individual should be responsible. "We're not suggesting that every country should adopt exactly the same policy," says Bainbridge. "But governments should at least be aware of what the options are and what others are doing before they act."

Although CEDEFOP's report has been welcomed by the EC, one hardly detects an all-consuming passion to implement its recommendations. Bainbridge believes the governmental responses to his report will be a measure of a country's commitment to lifelong learning; I'm not so sure.

fields.headline: Free will or destiny
fields.standfirst: If you want to go to university next year, now is the time to make your choices. So be proactive and get down to those open days
fields.trailText: If you want to go to university next year, now is the time to make your choices. So be proactive and get down to those open days
fields.body:
Heard the one about the sixth-former on A-level results day? Beaming with success, he knocked on his careers adviser's door. "Guess what!" he said. "I've got an offer confirmed from Teesside. Where is it?"

The next few months are crucial if you're hoping to start university in October 2001. Not only does endless research in the careers library have to be done, but now comes the time to see what these books, CD Roms and advisers are really talking about. The season of the open day is upon us!

The importance of visiting as many of your likely choices of university as possible cannot be over-stressed. Of course, time and money constraints will inhibit a nationwide tour, but it's still a good idea to visit at least a couple of institutions on your list. The last thing you want to happen on your arrival next year is to find that the reality does not match the vision in your mind's eye - and the realisation that one visit would have done the trick. You are going to spend three or more years of your life in this place!

By this stage you will probably have some idea of where you want to go, maybe a list of 10 or so. It won't be possible to see them all, so do your research thoroughly and choose two or three you'd really like to see.

If you are still undecided and need to get a snapshot of the whole range, why not visit one close to home, another in a city centre and a single-site campus. Or contrast large with small, old with new. How far the university is from home, and how easy or difficult it is to get there, are the most important pieces of information.

Next, making the arrangements. Your school or college may well be organising visits to open days. No worries there, then. However, in addition, you and your parents and friends can also make your own arrangements. Consult the best reference book on Open Days for dates and contact details. Even if there is no formal visiting day, most universities will be happy to organise something for you. Before you go, spend time thinking about what you want to get out of the day or you'll return home none the wiser.

You'll want to find out more about your chosen course, particularly the content and how it is taught. How you will be accommodated is likely to be near the top of your list. If you get the chance to talk to current students then you will discover more on this and the joys of student life - they are unlikely to be slow in coming forward on these issues!

And what are your future lecturers like? Sitting through some of the talks on offer may give you an idea. But perhaps the most vital thing to be gained from an open day is that you will arrive home with a gut feeling, an overall impression based on an amalgam of factors that will heavily influence your later decisions. It may not be scientific, but with more than 250 higher education institutions an objective choice is impossible.

Universities are, by and large, wise to this, and are trying hard to put on a good show, realising that students and their parents are in many ways now consumers, who want value for the money a university education now costs. Teachers and careers advisers still get open day posters, but now glossy, detailed leaflets are becoming the norm.

A well-organised day will include a variety of possibilities. Bradford's open day on July 19 certainly aims to fulfil its motto of "Making knowledge work". It has tours and visits to academic departments, campus facilities and student accommodation and practical advice on how to apply, student life and becoming a mature student. "All are welcome" and thankfully, for such a busy programme, "free tea, coffee and fruit juice are available throughout the day".

Kent includes an invitation from their pro vice-chancellor in the leaflet encouraging you to "visit, view, talk and experience" on June 30.

Central Lancashire is offering walking tours of their Preston campus on April 19 and June 7 and 24. As a rucksack is pictured above this invitation, you may wish to choose sensible footwear!

Aberystwyth looks forward to welcoming you on May 17 and July 4 in their colourful and informative leaflet, which gives several reasons for choosing this Welsh seaside town for your studies, including "a friendly and supportive" atmosphere, "value for money" and "over 125 years of academic success".

These examples give a taste of what's not to be missed in the spring and summer terms. There's no substitute for the open day visit, so don't miss out. "Experience is what really matters," say Aberystwyth on their invitation. "See for yourself," say Hertfordshire on theirs. It's good advice. Take it.

What to look out for

 Course content, teaching styles, assessment

 Facilities - labs, computer spaces, lecture rooms, student union

 A year out - is it acceptable and encouraged?

 What is looked for on the UCAS form? - and is an interview likely?

 Job destinations from your course

 See the student accommodation - cost, location

 Talk to current undergraduates

 What will travelling to and from the university be like?

 Was the open day well-organised and informative?

 Can you see yourself in this environment for three years?

 University and College Open Days including Pre-Taster Courses and Education Conventions - published by and obtainable at £3 from Ucas on 01242 544610.

webTitle: Quirky start but, oh, how dull

fields.headline: Quirky start but, oh, how dull
fields.standfirst: Offensive T-shirts, disillusioned pagans and an equivocal NUS president... Simon Bowers reports from Blackpool
fields.trailText: Offensive T-shirts, disillusioned pagans and an equivocal NUS president... Simon Bowers reports from Blackpool
fields.body:
As the janitor sweeps his way through oceans of discarded Morning Stars and Anti-Nazi League leaflets at Blackpool's Winter Gardens, Owain James, the newly-elected NUS president, leaves the annual conference as the movement's first independent leader in over 20 years.

He fought a tough campaign and was not afraid to criticise the outgoing Labour president who had consistently failed to pressurise the government on its controversial approach to student funding.

"It is time for change," the Owain James T-shirts proclaimed around Blackpool last week. And Labour Student, knowing delegates would not stomach another party stooge, did not even bother to field a candidate. Or so it seemed.

Fresh from his comfortable victory, Owain was ushered into a press room to give his first interview as president.

"I'm really pleased to have won the vote," he said. "This is a vital year for students in the run-up to the general election and this vote for unity means we can actually influence and change education policy."

But would he be able to work with Labour students after having campaigned against them? He paused, then said: "The vote for me was a vote for unity."

So what exactly is your relationship with Labour, Owain? "Well, yes. I am personally a member of the Labour party," he said.

"I got involved in the Labour movement because of the devastation I saw growing up in the mining communities in Wales. But my personal politics have nothing to do with my job. I am an independent."

And if the Labour party asked you to stand as a parliamentary candidate some time in the future - as they have asked so many former NUS presidents - could you say now that under no circumstances whatsoever would you agree? Another pause from Owain.

"Look," he said, glancing down at his pager then over at his press officer, "I'm afraid I really have to go now."

Is that under absolutely no circumstances at all, Owain? "I could not give you an honest and straightforward answer on that," he replied, while making for the door. "I really have to go."

Not the most auspicious of starts.

And whether Owain, like Ken Livingstone, will face expulsion from the Labour party for standing as an independent candidate still remains to be seen. It looks unlikely; as does a vigorous NUS campaign for increased student funding.

Back in the conference hall, Mark Tweedale, one of the candidates who lost out to Owain, was sitting on his own looking disheartened. He was wearing a full-length shimmering black dress with frilly lace cuffs, a fitted black velvet jacket and a pentangle-shaped necklace and earrings.

He said the NUS was a corrupt sham, a stitch-up, a conspiracy of Blairite careerists. And he sounded quite convincing until he mentioned religion.

When the union was producing a leaflet on religious intolerance, he said, they refused to make any mention of pagans (Mark is a pagan).

"I couldn't believe it," he said. "They were refusing to acknowledge the nine million pagans burnt at the stake by Christians during the burning times." Hmm.

To many of the 1,100 delegates at Blackpool it was all a new and confusing experience. It was also unspeakably dull. Subjects raised on the conference platform included such gripping and pertinent issues as whether to allow a Derbyshire student to take photos of the hall for a dissertation project (she was not) and whether the slogan on another delegate's T-shirt was offensive (it was).

May '68 it was not.

fields.headline: Post-modern references
fields.standfirst: Donald Hiscock  writes a creative reference
fields.trailText: Donald Hiscock writes a creative reference
fields.body:
I had struggled to write something positive about Roxanne for her UCAS reference and had succeeded, but when an American summer camp agency sought evidence of her suitability for employment I was temporarily defeated.

Under a sense of obligation as her personal tutor I grappled with the headings they specified: Reliability, Punctuality, Honesty and Appearance. I was sitting uncomfortably on the horns of a professional dilemma, made worse by the dyspeptic feeling brought about by a bolted down pastie at lunchtime.

"Roxanne is bright, outspoken and makes a colourful contribution to the atmosphere of the college." What I really want to say is that she is too bloody clever, always interrupting, drifts into class whenever she feels like it and mutters phrases with the word "boring" in them whenever I introduce something new.

"I can't believe that you've applied for this job," I remarked to Roxanne.

After two days hopefully expecting her to attend college I resorted to contacting her on a mobile number.

"It's for my gap year," she said.

"Have you done this kind of work before?" I asked searchingly. There was a lot of noise in the background. I asked again.

"What? Oh... no." There was a long pause.

"Roxanne, this isn't a very good line. What's that moaning? It sounds like there's someone having his teeth pulled out."

"Got to go."

I suppose Roxanne is an extreme case. In the course of an academic year there are many other students whose vices and foibles are glossed over, re-phrased and turned into a kind of pale purple prose. Euphemisms are my stock in trade. Occasionally I get to tell the truth. But then the reference on a student who never misses a class, hands work in on time and laughs dutifully at my jokes often reads as just plain dull.

For those types who do nothing else but turn up at college, go to classes and then go home again I have to work hard at building up a personality profile.

"Have you ever done anything extra-curricular?" I ask.

"No," mumbles Gary.

After intense interrogation and the kind of memory recall techniques I imagine top notch psychotherapists employ I can usually grind out the appropriate paragraph.

Writing about Gary in a good light is relatively easy, whereas Roxanne calls for some pretty hardcore flights of fancy, embroidered reality or total truth bending. You could call it lying. I call it ironic post-modernism.

I amazed myself at being able to commend Roxanne's communication skills for their directness. "Her capacity for independent thought and her decision-making skills could be an asset at summer camp. Her work with groups is often imaginative and she can be credited as a truly original team player in any situation. She takes a creative view of time management."

If Roxanne gets this job I shall be amazed. I shall also have to get something out on the internet warning all parents in Connecticut who are planning to send their children to summer camp. If you are reading this in North America then please spread the word. And please remember that I am only doing my job. Honest.

fields.headline: Check them out
fields.standfirst: Learning mentors offer real hope to disadvantaged kids, but schools must take care, says  Nick Tester
fields.trailText: Learning mentors offer real hope to disadvantaged kids, but schools must take care, says Nick Tester
fields.body:
Rigorous checks on the fitness of adults to work in colleges and schools with some of the country's most disadvantaged and vulnerable children are to be announced soon by the Department for Education and Employment.

The move coincides with the rapid expansion of people from non-teaching backgrounds being appointed to advise and cajole youngsters, from primary school onwards, who are easily distracted from their studies, underachieve or who drop out at 16 with no qualifications. Just under one in 10 young people are currently not in education, training or work, a figure David Blunkett has pledged to cut.

Most of the adults entering classrooms and visiting youngsters' homes in evenings and weekends are being appointed under the new Connexions service set up by Ministers to transform support for young people. "Personal advisers" will be recruited to make sure those whom Blunkett calls the "disconnected" are not passed from pillar to post.

"Learning mentors", Standards Minister Estelle Morris proclaims, will be the start of a new education profession. They were unveiled on these pages last week and are a major strand of the service. So far, 800 mentors have been recruited by schools, but this figure is set to soar to thousands over the next few years as, coupled with the emergence of personal advisers, the entire Connexions service comes on stream.

Research for last week's article in Further discovered flaws in the existing system and evidence of why a tightening up of appointment procedures for non-teaching adults is needed.

In the article, learning mentor Radlyn Booth was introduced by Jacqueline Valin, head of Southfields Community College, Wandsworth, where he's just been appointed. Valin proudly described Booth as "a role model, an ex-professional footballer with Millwall".

A request by this paper to Millwall FC for a picture of Booth, who said he wore the number 8 shirt for half of the 1979-80 season, drew a blank. After making several checks, the club categorically denied that anyone call Radlyn 'Roy' Booth had ever been on their books, a claim confirmed by the Professional Footballers Association.

So what? Glorifying one's cv is not a hanging offence and hands up anyone who's not tweaked their background to help them get the job they really want to do. On the other hand, professional teachers are likely to be sacked if discovered to have glamorised their qualifications.

The episode exposes a dilemma for heads. Rightly, they want to help kids overcome enormous obstacles to learning. They recognise that the new mentors, chosen in response to newspaper adverts, have credentials to offer a ray of hope, especially if the mentor can identify with their young charges - and vice versa - by sharing similar backgrounds and learning experiences.

Yet there are obvious risks, especially for a high-profile strategy being introduced speedily by education ministers, and a dilemma for those who employ mentors. How far do they examine for truthfulness the assertions of possible Walter Mitty-type characters? Where do they draw the line under their investigations and how much of a blind eye should they turn?

"You don't want to limit people coming into schools and colleges who operate as brilliant role models for students," says Jeff Holman of the National Association of Head Teachers. "But parents and schools need to be sure that their youngsters are safe. It only takes one case to emerge and the whole thing could be brought into disrepute."

"List 99" - shorthand for "police checks" - is the only official guide to help education institutions make appointments. It names all people barred or restricted from teaching on grounds of misconduct or for medical reasons.

Thus far, admits the DfEE, background checks on non-teachers "have not been a top priority". A spokesman explained: "At present, mentors and others who have only supervised access to children don't qualify for a criminal police check".

However, this is about to change because of the 1997 Police Act that established the Criminal Records Bureau. "What's likely to happen," the spokesman confirmed, "is that checks will be made on all those seeking positions which involve working with persons under age 18."
