fields.headline: Building for the future
fields.standfirst: An innovative scheme has taken off using construction and architecture as tools for developing life skills
fields.trailText: An innovative scheme has taken off using construction and architecture as tools for developing life skills
fields.body:
The idea of an "invisible school" would appeal to young people up and down the land - and, according to Adrian Wills, director of the Building Experiences Trust, this is precisely the type of school that he is involved in promoting.

At present, this invisible school boasts a catchment area stretching from Cornwall to Suffolk. Its alumnus includes children with emotional and behavioural difficulties, deaf children, as well as mainstream school children and those aspiring to building-related professions. The pupils work on projects related to architecture and construction.

One school that has taken part in the activities offered is Cherry Trees Special School in east London. Self-esteem and team-building skills were developed using workshop sessions to construct a dome. Susan Sowerbutts, headteacher at Cherry Trees, was impressed by the result.

"Children with severe emotional and behavioural difficulties can be a challenge in any situation. They are reluctant to try anything new, or they mask this with difficult and disruptive behaviour. Into this situation, the trust brought an exciting and different activity, which sparked the boys' interest. It was really great to see their satisfaction and delight in their construction," she says.

Recently the trust has been awarded a grant from The Aldgate and Allhallows Barking Exhibition Foundation to implement a programme of its workshops in special schools in the London borough of Tower Hamlets.

Wills spent last week in Suffolk primary schools, carrying out a series of workshops to celebrate National Construction Week. The participants built 3D models of the Millennium Dome, and considered the application of sustainable building materials in the re-design of a derelict building.

There are also plans for One World Week in November this year, where a total of 13 institutions will gather to build a giant tetrahedron which will then act as an art gallery for the participants' work on the themes of land, sea and air.

The programme will be assessed by an educational psychologist to see the impact such projects can have on pupils with learning and behavioural difficulties - certainly the deputy headteacher at Cherry Trees, Brian Steedman, can see real benefits. He says, "It was useful to have sections of the workshop where the children worked alone, in pairs, in fours and as a whole group. It was especially valuable for the boys to see the project through, from beginning to end - and to end finally with a clean floor!"

 The Building Experiences Trust can be contacted on 01453 756575.

fields.headline: Bulldogs in China shop
fields.standfirst: Are you being served breaks the bamboo barrier
fields.trailText: Are you being served breaks the bamboo barrier
fields.body:
A British organisation which has been training shop assistants in China has achieved the ultimate prize as the first foreign body officially approved by the Beijing government to deliver vocational qualifications.

After eight years of negotiations, City & Guilds has clinched a deal which, it is hoped, will transform Chinese retailing methods, and help the country's bid to join the World Trade Organisation.

The agreement, signed with the Ministry of Labour and Social Security in Beijing, is described by City & Guilds as a major breakthrough with potentially huge rewards. China, with its vast population, is number one target for foreign businesses, and training organisations are no different.

This government stamp of approval, effectively designating City & Guilds the official Chinese retailing qualification, is likely to carry significant weight with shops and stores across the nation.

The qualification, which 140 staff at one Beijing department store have just achieved in a trial scheme, teaches a customer-centred approach that is apparently not standard in China.

"We were told that people who work in department stores take their instructions from their superiors, and assume whatever their superiors say is the case, and don't think of the customer as the number one person," said Nick Parkes, product development manager with City & Guilds International.

City & Guilds has been operating in China since 1993, although its vocational qualifications and those of other foreign awarding bodies have lacked government approval.

The scale has been modest. Hardly more than 1,000 students a year have been taking City & Guilds qualifications in motor vehicle engineering, catering and hospitality, and retailing.

So far the retailing qualification has two levels which students, for example employees at the Hualian department store, which has 15 branches in the capital, should be able to complete in a year. Training only needs slight tweaking to accommodate the lack of computerisation and the comparatively rare use of credit cards.

The breakthrough for City & Guilds has come after eight years' running pilot schemes, stringent scrutiny by Chinese officials, and patient negotiation, Parkes said. Then finally Nick Carey, City & Guilds director general, signed the agreement with the Ministry of Labour and Social Security for "certificate 001", the first ever issued to a foreign awarding body.

As well as switching the focus of retailing onto the customer, City & Guilds is bringing a new mode of delivery.

"Typically a student would study retailing at university and come out and be regarded as an expert without ever having worked in a shop," said Parkes.

"What we've introduced, which the Chinese welcome, is an approach in which people training in retailing, for instance, must have on-the-job experience."

Parkes has been impressed at how quickly universities in Beijing adopting the qualification have accepted this change and started inviting retailers in to lecture to students.

"The Chinese have told us they want to adapt retailing in a way compatible to western standards, so they can become an effective trading partner in the World Trading organisation," he said.

fields.headline: Bust-up in Basildon
fields.standfirst: As the principal is suspended and funding council investigators move in,  Simon Midgley looks into the troubles at Basildon College
fields.trailText: As the principal is suspended and funding council investigators move in, Simon Midgley looks into the troubles at Basildon College
fields.body:
A culture of intimidation and fear, or an efficiently managed organisation driving up standards of student achievement? This is one of the fundamental questions that a special investigation team will have to answer about the character of a troubled tertiary college in south-west Essex.

A week ago the Further Education Funding Council took the unprecedented step of sending the team into Basildon College after the college received the third worst college inspection report since the council's inception.

The investigation was also prompted by fears about the college's deteriorating financial health and by the receipt of more than 50 complaints about management leadership style which, it is alleged, created a culture of fear.

Chris Chapman, the college's principal since September 1997, has been suspended by the governors while the investigation takes place and John Gould, director of marketing and business development, has been made acting principal.

The October 1999 inspection report gave the college eight (out of 10) grade 4s (the second lowest grading classification) for curricula and cross college provision. Management, governance, quality assurance and support arrangements for students were all judged to be unsatisfactory.

Maths and science, business and professional studies, health and childcare and English and access to higher education were also judged to be unsatisfactory.

David Melville, the funding council's chief executive, said: "This is the third worst inspection report ever and represents a decline in standards of teaching since the college's previous inspection. The governors and managers of Basildon College have only recently begun to address the real problems of low levels of retention and achievement with support from the Standards Fund."

Staff, who say they are too frightened to be named, allege that there is a culture of blame, fear, retribution and intimidation in the college and that employees are subject to bullying and harassment. One lecturer talks of "general intimidation of staff through extremely effective bullying tactics", unmanageable workloads, impossible deadlines and repeated threats of disciplinary action against staff.

"People are afraid," she said, "because they know there will be reprisals and retributions. If anything goes wrong it will always be the responsibility of the academic managers or the academic staff."

After indications that the college inspection in October had not gone well, some 20 employees were threatened with disciplinary procedures. Only one case went to a hearing, the other charges were later all dropped.

"People feel that this is no longer a safe working environment. It can be quite terrifying. I think people feel all the time that they need to keep their backs covered, the amount of emotional energy and physical labour that goes into covering one's back is quite phenomenal.

"I think it's astonishing that some people are able even to go in the classroom and string a sentence together quite honestly, because some of what they have had to put up with has been horrendous - systematic bullying, being sought out, and undermined, ridiculed, named and shamed, you name it and they have got a way of doing it."

Another lecturer said: "The atmosphere is dire at the moment. There is a lot of scaremongering going on, people are very frightened, but they are also very angry and very desperate.

"We are being treated as if we are worth nothing. Our professionalism is constantly undermined. For some people it's hell on earth coming into work every day. We are in a people organisation, and the people in charge of us don't know how to behave."

A third member of staff added that apart from the bullying there is the stress caused by working in an organisation with inconsistent and untimely decision and policy making.

Natfhe, the lecturers' union, is also in dispute with the college over a proposal to use unqualified teaching staff, and 45 proposed staff redundancies.

Mr Chapman was unavailable for comment. John Gould, the acting principal, said that he was not aware of there being a culture of fear in the college. Until last week, he added, no members of staff had sought to use the college's grievance procedure.

Eight grievance procedures, however, have just been initiated.

Part of the reason, he added, for the poor inspection report was that the college has had a noncompliance culture where some members of staff chose not to do things, for example, pastoral care, that most lecturers would regard as a normal part of their jobs.

Mr Gould added that while he was not aware of a culture of bullying, a new management team was trying to manage successfully and drive up standards. In 1996, 40% of the college's students completed their courses and passed their exams. By 1998/9 this rate had risen to 76%.

"Clearly that improvement was not by accident," he said. "That was a managed situation." It was unfortunate that the college received a poor inspection report in October, he added. This is one of the fundamental questions that a special investigation team will have to answer about the character of a troubled tertiary college in south-west Essex. A week ago the Further Education Funding Council took the unprecedented step of sending the team into Basildon College after the college received the third worst college inspection report since the council's inception. fields.headline: Against the odds
fields.standfirst: Sarah Biffen on how an article in the Guardian helped a student from Cape Town to get a degree
fields.trailText: Sarah Biffen on how an article in the Guardian helped a student from Cape Town to get a degree
fields.body:
Happy endings aren't too common these days, and it is not often that you have the Guardian Education Section acting as fairy godmother!

A year ago, I wrote a piece on these pages entitled Cape Crusaders. This was a report of interviews I did with three first-year black students at Cape Town University. The sub-title of the piece read "If you think tuition fees are bad, try adding diet, language and cash-flow - just three of the many hurdles faced by a new generation of black South African students."

I described how South African universities were bending over backwards to produce as many graduates as possible. How both the entrance criteria and exam standards had dropped. But despite these measures and an orientation course for new students, life for the black student from remote rural areas was still immensely difficult.

The backgrounds of my three interviewees were completely different. The one I admired and respected the most was Agnes, 30, a mature student with a 14-year-old child. Coming from Colesberg in the Northern Cape, she left school pregnant at 15 and supported herself and her son with jobs in hotels and restaurants. She then started a 10-year battle to get an education.

After years of evening classes, she finally made it to Cape Town University. Even then the problems had only just started. The difficulties of attending lectures and studying during the day, while working five nights a week in a bar to pay for it all, seemed overwhelming. I doubted that she would manage to stay the course.

Last year I revisited Cape Town and was delighted to find that Agnes was still at the university. My article was repeated in the Guardian Weekly, and I was very surprised to receive a letter from a retired Afrikaner who was living in France. He wrote: "I hail from the same town as Agnes - Colesberg. I most probably knew her family. My father used to be the main employer in the town. I would like to send her a contribution which might help her to complete her studies. Please send me her address - and her family name!"

This proved to be fairly difficult, but eventually I discovered that she was Agnes Vuyiswa Mcinziba and was living in Bergvliet.

Some months later, I heard from our benefactor in France, enclosing a copy of a letter he had received from Agnes. He now had a friend for life. She was ecstatic. She thanked him and asked a mass of questions. "I have never had a letter from anybody overseas. How is life where you live; I mean, what sort of people live there, is it kind of like what Colesberg used to be?... Do you have anybody that you speak Afrikaans to?..."

Since then, I have heard several times from my Afrikaner friend. Born in Colesberg in 1929, he studied botany and spent eight years working in the Herbarium at Kew Gardens. He then retired to a small village in a remote corner of France. What a strange and circular route that led him to help a student from the Northern Cape.

Two months ago, I was back in Cape Town and met up with Agnes. The last year had been particularly difficult. Her dad "had got retrenched", and she had been sick in hospital twice. The money from France had been crucial in helping her complete her degree.

Agnes was looking wonderful and was much more confident and self-assured than when I first met her. She was working as a part-time cashier for Ratanga Junction Park - a sort of Disney Fun Park - while on the lookout for a permanent job.

Although employment prospects in South Africa are very difficult, I have great confidence in Agnes' future. To have overcome the incredible hurdles she has done to get a place at university, then stick out the three-year course and obtain a degree, shows great determination and staying-power.

fields.headline: Beyond the basics
fields.standfirst: Jerome Monahan examines the impact of the United Nations on basic human rights
fields.trailText: Jerome Monahan examines the impact of the United Nations on basic human rights
fields.body:
We are entitled to more than just enough food, air and water in order to survive. Beyond these needs are basic human rights which underline our freedom; protecting us from abuse, illegal arrest, torture or execution.

Unfortunately, governments have a bad track record of preserving their citizens' human rights. This became clear when the full scale of Nazi crimes emerged at the end of the second world war. Out of this grew the desire that it should never happen again. The result was the United Nations Organisation. It was hoped that the UN would provide a place where nations could go to resolve conflicts peacefully.

In 1948, the 48 members of the UN signed the Universal Declaration of Human Rights. It contained 30 separate articles describing the basic rights every person can expect from fair pay to the right to a fair trial. A special United Nations Commission was also established to monitor countries for any signs of human rights' abuses. The UN also gave itself the muscle to implement economic sanctions on countries that were found guilty of human rights' abuse or to send in armed troops to protect civilians - particularly during wars.

Then in 1950 a special European Convention on Human Rights was passed by the 15-member countries of an organisation called the Council of Europe. This created a Human Rights Court in Strasbourg, France. Now, if individuals or organisations in any of these European countries felt that their human rights had been violated by their government, they could ask for permission to bring their case to the Strasbourg court - where any decision made in their favour was binding on the home state.

Since 1950, UK governments have lost more than 50 cases in Strasbourg and have been found guilty of violating 11 of the 15 UN Convention rights.

Many people believe that Britain has a strong tradition of freedom and tolerance, but in fact its law has never had a definite statement of its citizens' rights. This will change on October 2, when the European Convention on Human Rights is adopted by the UK legal system.

Previously, if you wanted to approach the European Court you had to go through the British courts first. It used to cost thousands of pounds and could take up to seven years to get a decision from the Strasbourg court and this inevitably put people off. There are worries that now it is simpler, there will be a huge rush to bring cases against the government by people that feel their rights are being ignored. There is also uncertainty about how some of the Convention articles will work together - for example, the right to privacy in Article 8 seems to be in conflict with Article 10 which lays down the freedom of expression.

One weakness of the UN Declaration was felt to be Article 26 (the rights of children). Because so many countries were ignoring it, a separate convention on the Rights of the Child was drawn up. Every country has signed up to it, except Somalia and America.

With all these laws in place, you might think that human rights are strong across the world, but this is not the case. Governments do often ignore or suspend them, and just as one country outlaws abuses so another turns to torture. The famous saying remains true: "If you want to establish what any society is like, visit its prisons."

fields.headline: A double helping
fields.standfirst: Paddy Heaney  on a Kent scheme in which noisy or truant kids teach younger children
fields.trailText: Paddy Heaney on a Kent scheme in which noisy or truant kids teach younger children
fields.body:
An all-new American scheme is being used by a number of schools in Kent to improve academic performance and discipline while reducing levels of absenteeism.

The Valued Youth Programme (VYP) encapsulates the old adage that the best way to learn is to teach. In essence the programme is simple - children in year 9 who are frequently absent, disruptive in class or suffer from low self-esteem become "tutors" at a local primary school where they teach their "tutees" for two hours every week.

Originally developed in 1984 by a research group from San Antonio, Texas, the programme has grown from 10 schools in San Antonio to 171 schools in the USA, Puerto Rico, Brazil and now England.

The programme was discovered by the Kent Education Business Programme, a charity that seeks to prepare young people for an adult working life.

Following a successful pilot scheme last year, the Valued Youth Scheme has been fully adopted by Walderslade Secondary School for Girls and Oaklands Junior School in Chatham, Kent. Jade, now in year 10 at Walderslade, took part in the pilot scheme last year and claims that her behaviour has "definitely" changed. "I've put my head down this year, I've been doing my homework and I'm not as mouthy as I used to be."

Confessing to having "always" been in detention last year, Jade has yet to be detained in the new school year. She said: "When I started with my tutees it made me look from a teacher's point of view."

More touchingly Jade added: "Seeing my tutees achieve so much because of me, makes me feel I have achieved something. It showed me that I am someone special and I can take that responsibility." Marissa, also a pupil at Walderslade, is taking part in the programme and admits that in the past she "talked a lot" and was "very loud".

Her experiences as a tutor have made her see the error of her ways. "It makes me feel sorry for the teachers that I had, because it's hard to work with three, never mind a whole class," she said.

Since starting her work as a tutor, Marissa believes her behaviour "has improved a lot. I have calmed down a lot more and I have started to work better," she said.

Undoubtedly both Jade and Marissa have benefited from their experiences as tutors. But the results from the pilot scheme show that in vital areas children failed to make any real progress.

Improving child discipline and reducing absenteeism are among the key goals of the programme, yet the results of the pilot scheme noted that there was no "significant" difference in the behaviour of tutors who had been on the course. Likewise, the level of tutor absenteeism was not "significantly" reduced as a result of taking part.

Students did make progress in an area called "the quality of school life". This is a scale that measured tutors' attitudes toward school - and tutors improved "significantly" in their reactions to teachers, satisfaction with school and commitment to the classroom. But what are the benefits for the primary schools that take part in the Valued Youth Programme? Tom French, head teacher at Oakland Junior explained how "tutees" are selected. "We look for the very quiet children in the classroom. The children who might be afraid to speak up and answer because they don't want to be wrong."

French is convinced by the merits of the programme. "We saw most definite benefits, namely greater confidence and better attendance.

"They knew when their tutor was coming and looked forward to that day. They had a deep attachment to their tutor because they were making them feel special, and therefore they wanted to be in school," he said.

While the tenets of the programme are simple, the Kent Education Business Partnership has paid £15,000 to the Intercultural Developmental Research Association (the American body which designed the programme) for the official contract.

The IRDA in turn oversees the implementation of the initiative, conducts the pre- and post-test evaluations and produces the annual report.

Considering the cost of the programme it is not surprising that the scheme has its detractors. Reservations have been raised and these were highlighted in the pilot scheme report.

The chief concerns centred on the fact that the scheme provided opportunities denied to "good students" and the fact that tutors got paid meant that some peers and staff saw this as bad behaviour being rewarded. In addition to this was the problem that students on the scheme missed a part of their normal curriculum.

webTitle: A doubled population: and no aid

fields.headline: A doubled population: and no aid
fields.standfirst:
While we give millions to feed Ethiopia, banks and governments take it back in interest

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: While we give millions to feed Ethiopia, banks and governments take it back in interest
fields.body:
The pictures are heart-wrenching, as always. The crisis has been highlighted by television, as usual. But the famine which has started to ravage parts of Ethiopia is not as before. Luckily. This time, unlike the great famine of 1984/5 when up to a million people died, the alarm has sounded early and the world has a chance to prevent a disaster turning into a catastrophe provided donor governments quickly improve their act.

Ethiopia's farmers are more dependent on rain than those of almost any other country in Africa. They live in areas which are unbelievably remote with most of them more than a day's walk from the nearest dirt road, so that aid is very hard to distribute. Fifteen years ago tens of thousands died unseen, and those still able to walk barely managed to trek to rural towns and "feeding centres" before they too succumbed.

At that time, too, a war was going on across much of the famine-affected areas, making it even harder for food aid to reach people. Ethiopia was ruled by a dictator, Mengistu Haile Mariam, who took a long time to admit there was a problem. When he did, he exploited it to cram famine refugees from the rebel region of Tigray into aircraft and buses by force and dump them hundreds of miles from their homes.

Yet even within this harsh context, as I and other journalists were able to report at the time, the United Nations aid agencies and foreign charities achieved a great deal. The image, still occasionally trotted out by armchair critics, that the west kowtowed to the government in Addis Ababa and refused to mention the war was wrong. Around 70% of the aid was delivered independently of the government and direct to the starving. Western governments constantly criticised the use of force in the resettlement programme and refused to support it. Thanks to Michael Priestley, who took over as the UN's special representative in Ethiopia in October 1985, they eventually managed to get it stopped. When Mengistu refused to let food reach the starving through the lines of war, charities and governments found ways to deliver it "round the back" by going to rebel areas direct. No relief operation is perfect and there was overlap, lack of coordination, and delay, but in 1985 the aid may have saved as many as seven million lives.

This time the ground is more favourable. A low-level hit-and-run guerrilla war plus dangerous banditry is having an effect in the pastoral areas of the Ogaden, where scores of people are already dying. This has made it hard for agencies to assess needs or get lorries of aid past marauders. The main war is hundreds of miles away in the highlands but even there, where potentially eight million people are at risk, the region is nothing like as war-ravaged as in 1985.

Ethiopia's conflict with Eritrea is confined to the border strip. The fact that the highlands' closest port, Assab, is part of Eritrea now is not a major obstacle since Djibouti's docks have been improved. The country has more lorries than before, and fewer have been taken over by the army to move men and material as the war currently is static. There has been no fighting for two months. The war's worst effect is that 350,000 displaced people are living in overcrowded villages which do not have the resources to feed newcomers, let alone themselves.

A second change from 1985 is that the new government, which overthrew Mengistu in 1991, set up a system of emergency grain stocks to cover the threat of famine. This meant, for example, that when the current three-year drought began in 1998 it was able to draw on well-positioned reserves to feed people until international aid arrived. The problem it now faces is that the European Union has been woefully slow in replenishing the stocks even though the Ethiopian government warned of impending problems in December last year, and again early this year. Britain is one of four European countries which provides grain in addition to the EU's contribution and Clare Short's Department for International Development insists it replenished the stocks that were drawn down last year. But the EU's total is much greater in size and Britain shares a measure of blame, along with other EU governments, in not having pressed the commission in Brussels to act sooner and faster.

Famines are complex things since parts of Ethiopia produce a grain surplus. This is not a countrywide disaster. The Ethiopian government is buying around 100,000 tonnes of grain from local traders but, market forces being what they are even in famine conditions, it has asked the EU and western charities not to submit tenders at the moment for fear of the price being driven up. What Europe must do is speed up its promised deliveries of foreign-grown grain in the next two months before the threat of famine becomes real.

Governments also need to look to the long term. One of Ethiopia's difficulties since 1985 is that its population has doubled. Rural overcrowding and a lack of urban jobs mean that more and more families are getting poorer daily. With foreign help the Ethiopian government has been constructing small earth dams to catch the country's limited rainwater, building rural roads, and setting up local credit schemes. Sadly, larger-scale projects are not moving forward partly because foreign governments, including Britain's, have been cutting back on development aid because of the war with Eritrea. Ethiopia has been thrown out of the Highly Indebted Poor Countries' debt reduction scheme for the same reason. Last year this poorest of countries paid £60m in debt service.

Herein lies the cruellest of the current ironies. While thousands of ordinary citizens in the west give generously to help the hunger-ravaged children of the Ogaden, our governments and banks take millions back in interest. War is relevant, but the government in Addis Ababa has justice on its side when it says it did not start it, and has tried hard to negotiate its end. That does not mean its record is entirely clear. When the war broke out, it brutally expelled thousands of Eritrean civilians living in Ethiopia, many of them for decades. But it cannot be described as the aggressor in the current war, nor are its tactics as brutal as those of the Mengistu regime.

So Britain and other foreign countries need to be more flexible. The distinction between emergency and development aid for countries at war - "we give the one, but not the other" - is often too facile. So too is the policy of "no long-term help until you make peace". Otherwise we may scrape by in averting real famine this time, but not prevent a new one coming along again.

fields.headline: Army Bloody Sunday claim 'not backed'
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: No civilians or journalists present on Bloody Sunday corroborated military testimony of a single shot fired at paratroopers before soldiers targeted demonstrators, the Saville inquiry in Londonderry was told yesterday.
fields.body:
No civilians or journalists present on Bloody Sunday corroborated military testimony of a single shot fired at paratroopers before soldiers targeted demonstrators, the Saville inquiry in Londonderry was told yesterday.

Several soldiers referred in evidence to a shot from the Rossville Flats in the republican Bogside area, hitting a drain-pipe above a churchyard where paratroopers were waiting before mounting an arrest operation. They timed it at just before 4pm.

The army fired its first shots soon afterwards, wounding John Johnston, 59, who died five months later, and Damien Donaghy, 15.

Paratroopers later shot dead thirteen more unarmed Catholics during the illegal anti-internment march in the city on January 30, 1972.

But Christopher Clarke QC, counsel for the inquiry, said: "Despite military evidence about the shot, there remains a serious question as to whether it was fired, at any rate as to whether it was fired from Rossville Flats, and, if so, whether it was fired before or after the shooting of Damien Donaghy and John Johnston. There is no contemporaneous report of the shot in any of the army logs or radio transcripts...

"Despite the presence of many people in the area, no evidence from civilians or journalists gives any clear support to the proposition that a shot was fired in the direction of the Presbyterian church before the shooting of Donaghy or Johnston."

webTitle: Short denies Ethiopia famine aid cut back

fields.headline: Short denies Ethiopia famine aid cut back
fields.standfirst:
Britain is right to reduce longterm funding while it is being spent on waging war, says furious international development secretary

Ethiopia: special report
fields.trailText: A furious Clare Short last night lashed out at critics of the government's disaster relief programme, accusing the media of "distorting" Britain's record on aid spending.
fields.byline: Charlotte Denny in Dar es Salaam
fields.body:
A furious Clare Short last night lashed out at critics of the government's disaster relief programme, accusing the media of "distorting" Britain's record on aid spending.

The international development secretary was responding to accusations over the weekend that Britain is planning to cut back its help to Ethiopia just as famine tightens its grip on the country. The story was "absolutely and completely factually wrong", she said.

Speaking to the Guardian, Ms Short said Britain's relief programme for the victims of the famine was entirely unaffected by the decision to cut back long-term assistance to Ethiopia over concerns that money was being diverted to fuel the country's long-running war with its northern neighbour, Eritrea.

She said Britain's humanitarian assistance programme for Ethiopia was funded from a separate budget and was untouched by the decision to cut the UK's annual spending on development projects in the country from £39m to £13m.

"I do not believe anyone in the UK believes we should be providing long-term assistance to a country which is increasing its spending on arms, year on year," she said.

"They [the media] want to pretend people are going hungry in Ethiopia because we are not providing aid. Our food is there and will continue to be."

Ms Short is clearly angered by the hammering her department has received over its recent performance in global disaster zones.

Britain was accused of doing too little too late during the floods in Mozambique and Honduras, while the UK's efforts to help the victims of the volcanic eruption on Montserrat were marred by the furore over her comments that the inhabitants were demanding "golden elephants" from their former colonial power.

Reports at the weekend also claimed that Britain is cutting its aid budget to Mozambique despite the need to rebuild the country after last month's devastating floods. In fact, the figures show that Britain spent £57m in the country this year - nearly £30m more than it planned to, and that the annual aid budget has increased steadily from less than £20m three years ago.

Ms Short said Britain was recognised by international bodies as among the fastest and most effective deliverers of emergency aid. "We have a world-renowned and widely admired ability to deliver speedy humanitarian operations," she added.

The international development secretary was speaking in the Tanzanian capital, Dar es Salaam, on a joint trip with three fellow European development ministers to coordinate their work.

Britain spends more on development assistance in Tanzania than in any other country except India and Ms Short regards the country as a model of what can be achieved when both donors and local governments focus aid on reducing poverty.

Since Labour came to power, foreign aid spending has been targeted at helping countries which are committed to economic reform and achieving the internationally agreed development targets, by putting money into primary health care and education, rather than military spending.

Ms Short has not been afraid to tell countries that she will not countenance them wasting British taxpayers' money on guns and tanks.

While her plain-speaking style wins her few friends in Westminster, she is admired for her conviction by developing countries, even by those who disagree with her views.

"She puts her money where her mouth is," one World Bank official said yesterday, adding that she had brought a "a sense of urgency" to achieving longstanding goals for reducing poverty which had been gathering dust.

Ms Short has also succeeded in mustering more money for Britain's development budget, which was slashed by successive Tory governments. Spending has increased by 28% after inflation, the largest increase of any government department.

webTitle: Towers discusses rescue plan with Rover

fields.headline: Towers discusses rescue plan with Rover
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: John Towers, the former Rover Group chief executive now putting together an alternative buyout for the troubled car group, could table formal proposals within days.
fields.body:
John Towers, the former Rover Group chief executive now putting together an alternative buyout for the troubled car group, could table formal proposals within days.

Mr Towers held talks yesterday with Rover chief Walter Sämann at a meeting "facilitated" by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers.

Last night the DTI described the talks, which included trade union representatives and Mr Byers, and lasted for more than an hour, as "constructive" but declined to elaborate.

Others described the meeting as "exploratory" - aimed at assessing BMW's attitude to alternative proposals to those put forward last month by Alchemy Partners, the venture capital group. "The plan is for Mr Towers to make a formal proposals towards the end of the week," according to one source.

Alchemy's plan involves splitting Rover, with the venture fund taking the Longbridge plant, where it will concentrate on the production of sports cars - a move that is expected to lead to heavy job losses in the West Midlands.

BMW insisted yesterday that that it would retain the rights to its planned new Mini and the Rover R30 model.

"The Mini is a core part of our brand strategy and we won't give it up," a spokesman for the Munich-based group said. BMW would also keep in tellectual property rights to the R30, which is the successor to the R25.

The comments came after reports suggested Mr Towers' bid included making the Mini and winning rights to the R30's design.

The Towers proposal is expected to centre on keeping volume car production at Longbridge although observers believe that would require a link-up with a leading manufacturer as well as support from the government.

webTitle: Police action against black farm squatters ruled out

fields.headline: Police action against black farm squatters ruled out
fields.standfirst: Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Zimbabwe's most senior legal officer in effect consolidated the occupation of white-owned farms yesterday when he ruled out using the police to evict black squatters.
fields.byline: Ewen MacAskill  and Andrew Osborn  in Brussels
fields.body:
Zimbabwe's most senior legal officer in effect consolidated the occupation of white-owned farms yesterday when he ruled out using the police to evict black squatters.

The attorney general, Patrick Chinamasa, described the farm occupations, which have created mayhem, as "minor transgressions of trespass laws".

He said the police could not hope to reverse the takeovers by veterans of Zimbabwe's civil war, who are close to President Robert Mugabe.

Mr Chinamasa said use of the police "would be a match that would ignite the country into a bloody conflagration". He called the farm occupations a just fight against unfair laws that allow some people to own more land than others, and compared the takeovers to neighbouring South Africa's struggle against apartheid.

As legal channels were being choked off, European foreign ministers met in Luxembourg to consider action against Zimbabwe. Eventually, they decided against stopping aid, which is worth £70m-£95m, and instead issued a joint statement urging an end to the farm seizures. They also called on Mr Mugabe to hold free and fair elections and to accept EU monitors.

Confusion followed the meeting as European commission sources said the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, had been rebuffed in an attempt to get aid suspended. But the Foreign Office vehemently denied this and said Mr Cook had only raised the issue for discussion.

The Netherlands, Sweden and Belgium said there was a case for discussion of suspension of aid quite soon. But France, Greece, Portugal and Italy argued that such action was premature. Finland suggested waiting to see how the Zimbabwe election turned out and consult among themselves after that. Mr Cook agreed.

An EU spokesman said that as there had not been the necessary majority for suspension of aid, no vote was taken. "It was felt that such a move might backfire at this stage."

webTitle: Zimbabwe's whites lift their heads above the parapet: 'Some of our guys want to kill ...'

fields.headline: Zimbabwe's whites lift their heads above the parapet: 'Some of our guys want to kill ...'
fields.standfirst:
'I am not a party political person but things are so bad I had to get involved. If democracy does not return, the economy of this country will collapse' 'Monty' Montgomery, white ex-policeman

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Comrade Edward Musuaka's note was to the point. "The hour has come to take what is rightfully ours. You have clearly shown us that you have ill feelings against the land issue. If you continue doing that we will bring five lorries of war vets tomorrow or any day. You are not the only farmer who has his farm taken. For your information we have taken Van Tonder's today and he was very cooperate," he wrote.
fields.body:
Comrade Edward Musuaka's note was to the point. "The hour has come to take what is rightfully ours. You have clearly shown us that you have ill feelings against the land issue. If you continue doing that we will bring five lorries of war vets tomorrow or any day. You are not the only farmer who has his farm taken. For your information we have taken Van Tonder's today and he was very cooperate," he wrote.

The note warned a white Zimbabwean farmer, Richard Bedford, to stop resisting the occupation of his sprawling tobacco farm by hundreds of poor blacks who now claim the land as their own. Their leader, Comrade Musuaka, arranged for a few dozen men to pound out revolutionary songs while demonstrating what their machetes could do to a tree. Richard Bedford gave in.

Gunpoint

At a neighbouring farm, Derek Hinde has spent three weeks answering distress calls on the radio. When they come - some panic-stricken at the mob at the gates, some resigned - he cannot help reflecting that there was a time when Zimbabwe was Rhodesia and all he had to do was shoot the enemy. Now he has to negotiate.

"Confronted by guys trying to take your farm away, you lose your head. Some of our guys want to kill them. I can understand it but where will it get them? When you've got a guy standing two feet away shouting 'Down with white people,' it's hard to negotiate but we do," he said.

Mr Hinde's vast tobacco and rose plantation is one of about 20 farms that have been invaded in the Wedza district, an hour's drive south-east of Harare.

On the face of it, Zimbabwe's burgeoning political crisis is a tussle over land between the descendants of British settlers, who stole it at gunpoint, and those of the black Zimbabweans robbed of their birthright. But almost everyone involved knows that is not the real issue. Parliamentary elections loom and land has become a political weapon in a myriad of ways: redistribution is a means of buying votes from landless peasants; farmworkers' votes will prove decisive in deciding whether the ruling Zanu-PF party is humiliated at the polls next month; and racial confrontation is a convenient distraction from the imploding economy.

Mr Mugabe accuses Zimbabwe's whites of more than just trying to cling to the land. He says they are trying to reassert political power by providing the cash and organisation for the fledgling opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). It is, he alleges, an unholy alliance between white business and black trade unions led by the MDC's chief, Morgan Tsvangirai.

Mr Mugabe is not wrong.

For the first time since independence, whites are sticking their heads above the political parapet. When Mr Mugabe came to power in 1980, he viewed whites as a defeated people. Under Zimbabwe's new constitution they could remain citizens and keep their property and lifestyle. But they were implicitly expected to keep out of the business of governance and not to criticise publicly.

That is the way it stayed for 20 years. But now influential whites among the 70,000 who remain argue that the weeks and months ahead could decide whether they even have a future in Zimbabwe, and that they cannot remain bystanders.

Many have swung their support behind the MDC in the belief that if Mr Mugabe's government is not reigned in, Zimbabwe's economy will collapse and with it will go their businesses.

"Monty" Montgomery heads the MDC's campaign in the Hurungwe and Kariba regions where he is responsible for three constituencies crucial to the opposition. His family's lineage in Zimbabwe goes back to the 1890s. His parents were teachers in Bulawayo at the junior school once attended by HF Verwoerd, the architect of South Africa's apartheid.

Mr Montgomery, 49, came of age during Ian Smith's rule. Two days after leaving school he was conscripted into the police. By the time majority rule loomed, he was an officer in the notorious special branch responsible for the interrogation of political prisoners and "terrorists".

These days, Mr Montgomery runs an agricultural supply business fallen on hard times. "I am not a party political person but the economic state of the country and business is so bad I had to get involved," he said. "If democracy doesn't return, the economy will collapse. There's a fuel crisis. We're looking at currency devaluation. The last 10 years were the worst, particularly corruption. It is being allowed to kill the economy."

White support is proving crucial to the opposition. The party will not say how much money it has raised, or from where. But the head of its campaign in Mashonaland West's 10 constituencies, Duke du Coudray, concedes that a significant proportion of campaign funds comes from white-owned businesses.

"It is not that black businesses don't support us, it is just much more difficult for them to get involved. Zanu-PF has forced representatives onto the boards of almost every big company and corporation and they make sure no donations come to us. They make threats, warning that the 'people' will protest and there could be attacks," he said.

When 5,000 black MDC delegates elected the party's executive in January, three out of the top four were whites.

"There's only one reason we whites are so visible," said Mr du Coudray. "The mass of this party is black but the black bourgeoisie is afraid to take a public stand. They are intimidated away from public support. They are pushing us to the fore, saying we support you but we can't do it in public."

Conspiracy

Mr Tsvangirai, the MDC leader, publicly welcomed white support at a rally on Sunday. "We are going to take whites because they are creating jobs. The whites are our cousins in this country and we are not betraying people by being in alliance with them," he said.

Mr Mugabe sees it as a conspiracy in which blacks are a front for unreconstructed Rhodesians. He was delighted at Ian Smith's efforts to use the political crisis to make a comeback but Mr du Coudray says the former Rhodesian prime minister's posturing gave whites a chance to show they had changed.

"Ian Smith did us a favour because he gave white people of this country a choice. They could back him or back Morgan Tsvangirai and they went with Tsvangirai. This is not about reviving white political power," he said.

For the moment, the primary battleground remains the farms, where the invasions are not only about grabbing land but also votes. Each of the 1,000 or so occupied farms is home to about 800 workers and dependants who are potential voters. They account for nearly one-fifth of the electorate, and will cast the deciding ballots in many constituencies.

The government does not want them to slip beyond its grasp. On some farms, the squatters have insisted that the labourers join them. On others, workers have been ordered to attend political meetings. But it all has the same purpose: making sure the farmworkers' votes go to Zanu-PF.

"We've been targeted because we employ a large section of the voters," said Mr Hinde. "No doubt there's a racial element as well but they want to make some of our labourers vote for the party. So we've become a prime target, both politically because they have made land an issue and because they want the labour to vote for them."

For some whites, the upheaval has proved too much. The final straw for John Guimbeau was a note from the 250 or so squatters on his tobacco farm demanding to strip the roof off his house for their shacks. On Saturday, Mr Guimbeau visited the Australian high commission to lodge an application to emigrate. It is the favoured route for many farmers.

"If the opposition gets in I'll stay. But if this government stays I'll go because I've seen how vicious they can be," he said. "Groups of these guys swear at us and wave pangas. They throw stones onto the roof all night to keep us awake. The kids were terrified. I had to send them away. I know what these poor Jews felt like with the Nazis. We haven't been gassed yet but they want to take everything from us."

Whatever the outcome of the land dispute, it is causing further economic dam age that Zimbabwe can ill afford. Much of the tobacco crop has been harvested but it has not been treated and will probably not be ready in time for the auctions that bring in much of the country's foreign currency.

Foreign banks are edgy. Many of the targeted farms are heavily mortgaged to local branches of Barclays and Standard Bank of South Africa. If the white farmers are thrown off, they will default. But the banks can hardly seize the farms when they have already been taken over.

In any case, the government's desire to redistribute without compensation has stripped most agricultural land of any value. No one is going to buy a farm in Zimbabwe right now.
fields.bodyText: Comrade Edward Musuaka's note was to the point. "The hour has come to take what is rightfully ours. You have clearly shown us that you have ill feelings against the land issue. If you continue doing that we will bring five lorries of war vets tomorrow or any day. You are not the only farmer who has his farm taken. For your information we have taken Van Tonder's today and he was very cooperate," he wrote. The note warned a white Zimbabwean farmer, Richard Bedford, to stop resisting the occupation of his sprawling tobacco farm by hundreds of poor blacks who now claim the land as their own. Their leader, Comrade Musuaka, arranged for a few dozen men to pound out revolutionary songs while demonstrating what their machetes could do to a tree. Richard Bedford gave in. Gunpoint At a neighbouring farm, Derek Hinde has spent three weeks answering distress calls on the radio. When they come - some panic-stricken at the mob at the gates, some resigned - he cannot help reflecting that there was a time when Zimbabwe was Rhodesia and all he had to do was shoot the enemy. Now he has to negotiate. "Confronted by guys trying to take your farm away, you lose your head. Some of our guys want to kill them. I can understand it but where will it get them? When you've got a guy standing two feet away shouting 'Down with white people,' it's hard to negotiate but we do," he said. Mr Hinde's vast tobacco and rose plantation is one of about 20 farms that have been invaded in the Wedza district, an hour's drive south-east of Harare. On the face of it, Zimbabwe's burgeoning political crisis is a tussle over land between the descendants of British settlers, who stole it at gunpoint, and those of the black Zimbabweans robbed of their birthright. But almost everyone involved knows that is not the real issue. Parliamentary elections loom and land has become a political weapon in a myriad of ways: redistribution is a means of buying votes from landless peasants; farmworkers' votes will prove decisive in deciding whether the ruling Zanu-PF party is humiliated at the polls next month; and racial confrontation is a convenient distraction from the imploding economy. Mr Mugabe accuses Zimbabwe's whites of more than just trying to cling to the land. He says they are trying to reassert political power by providing the cash and organisation for the fledgling opposition Movement for Democratic Change (MDC). It is, he alleges, an unholy alliance between white business and black trade unions led by the MDC's chief, Morgan Tsvangirai. Mr Mugabe is not wrong. For the first time since independence, whites are sticking their heads above the political parapet. When Mr Mugabe came to power in 1980, he viewed whites as a defeated people. Under Zimbabwe's new constitution they could remain citizens and keep their property and lifestyle. But they were implicitly expected to keep out of the business of governance and not to criticise publicly. That is the way it stayed for 20 years. But now influential whites among the 70,000 who remain argue that the weeks and months ahead could decide whether they even have a future in Zimbabwe, and that they cannot remain bystanders. Many have swung their support behind the MDC in the belief that if Mr Mugabe's government is not reigned in, Zimbabwe's economy will collapse and with it will go their businesses. "Monty" Montgomery heads the MDC's campaign in the Hurungwe and Kariba regions where he is responsible for three constituencies crucial to the opposition. His family's lineage in Zimbabwe goes back to the 1890s. His parents were teachers in Bulawayo at the junior school once attended by HF Verwoerd, the architect of South Africa's apartheid. Mr Montgomery, 49, came of age during Ian Smith's rule. Two days after leaving school he was conscripted into the police. By the time majority rule loomed, he was an officer in the notorious special branch responsible for the interrogation of political prisoners and "terrorists". These days, Mr Montgomery runs an agricultural supply business fallen on hard times. "I am not a party political person but the economic state of the country and business is so bad I had to get involved," he said. "If democracy doesn't return, the economy will collapse. There's a fuel crisis. We're looking at currency devaluation. The last 10 years were the worst, particularly corruption. It is being allowed to kill the economy." But the head of its campaign in Mashonaland West's 10 constituencies, Duke du Coudray, concedes that a significant proportion of campaign funds comes from white-owned businesses. "It is not that black businesses don't support us, it is just much more difficult for them to get involved. Zanu-PF has forced representatives onto the boards of almost every big company and corporation and they make sure no donations come to us. They make threats, warning that the 'people' will protest and there could be attacks," he said. When 5,000 black MDC delegates elected the party's executive in January, three out of the top four were whites. "There's only one reason we whites are so visible," said Mr du Coudray. "The mass of this party is black but the black bourgeoisie is afraid to take a public stand. They are intimidated away from public support. They are pushing us to the fore, saying we support you but we can't do it in public." Conspiracy Mr Tsvangirai, the MDC leader, publicly welcomed white support at a rally on Sunday. fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Richard Adams
fields.trailText: Richard Adams
fields.body:
 Wales's Western Mail newspaper yesterday did its bit for universal harmony with a sick-making Hello-style profile of Nick Griffin, the "new face" of the British National Party. "Under his leadership the BNP is moving away from its 'bully boy' image," according to writer Toby Mason, "positioning itself in mainstream politics, committed to democratic means." What grand news, and surely not the result of journalistic naivety? "I feel my leadership is going extremely well," says Nick, "for example the issue of asylum seekers has been enormously good for us, it has created advantages for us." Ugh. The paper claims this soft soap is balanced by other articles, but Toby neglected to mention that this "new face" has a conviction for inciting racial hatred as recently as 1998, and his deputy was found guilty on an explosives charge. And the profile is accompanied by a creepy photo of Nick, who appears to be tying a noose. When we ring the Western Mail to speak to Toby, a colleague says: "He's actually skiing in Austria at the moment." So look out for "Jörg Haider invites us into his lovely home" next week.

 "Curves and elements combine at the Millennium Dome," gushed the Independent on March 29, "as the heavens open over the unveiling of works of art" - alongside a front page photograph of Anish Kapoor's new sculpture, Parabolic Waters. But alas, no sooner was the work unveiled than the New Millennium Experience Corporation re-veiled it, using a six foot high metal mesh fence of the kind seen around building sites. "There was a slight concern that a small child could fall inside and not be able to get out," said Adam Liversage, a Dome press officer. But good news: a summit meeting was held yesterday between artist and management, and a modification has been agreed to the satisfaction of all.

 With obituary columns concentrating on Bernie Grant yesterday, there was no room to report the demise of "comedian" Jack Docherty, who comprehensively died on his feet presenting the Bafta awards on Sunday. After giving the best director award to Spain's Pedro Almodovar, Jack quipped: "Pedro's off to celebrate by chucking a donkey off a bell tower!" This went down like a lead balloon with the audience, as did Jack's asking Joseph Fiennes where his family was hiding the ugly Fiennes brother. Spookily, Jack foresaw his own fate in Friday's G2 section: "At an awards ceremony you're dying on your feet in front of an industry."

 Kilts off to Charles Gordon, leader of Glasgow city council. Faced with some angry accusation from Wandsworth council over Glasgow's handling of a group of asylum seekers last month (tipping them back on to a bus to London in the middle of the night), Mr Gordon replied in keeping with the great Scots literary tradition of Irving Welsh and James Kelman. The full text of Mr Gordon's letter reads as follows: "Away an' bile yer heid".

webTitle: Russia hints at compromise on missile defence

fields.headline: Russia hints at compromise on missile defence
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia indicated yesterday that it may be looking for a way to end a dispute over the United States' plans to build a limited nuclear defence system, possibly by creating its own version.
fields.body:
Russia indicated yesterday that it may be looking for a way to end a dispute over the United States' plans to build a limited nuclear defence system, possibly by creating its own version.

The speaker of the lower house of parliament, the duma, said yesterday the body is likely to ratify the Start II treaty on Friday, following a push for approval by President Vladimir Putin.

The treaty's prospects have improved since a new parliament was elected in December. Communists and nationalists who had blocked ratification lost their dominance of the duma in the election.

Ratification could help to clear the way for a compromise with the US over the anti-ballistic missile treaty. Washington wants to amend the treaty to allow for the construction of a limited missile-defence system to protect against nuclear attacks by so-called "rogue states".

Russia has objected strongly, saying that such a defence could unravel all nuclear arms control treaties with Washington.

But there were signs that Russia is reconsidering its strategy of outright objection.

The Russian security council, which includes Mr Putin, the parliamentary speakers and other officials, discussed Start II as part of a "package" including a possible "non-strategic missile defence system", the Itar-Tass news agency cited the security council sec retary, Sergei Ivanov, as saying.

Mr Ivanov said such a system would be designed to defend against attacks by countries that do not have nuclear weapons, but could develop them. Further details were not immediately available.

Mr Ivanov insisted that Moscow was acting independently. "This is not related to the ABM treaty," Itar-Tass quoted him as saying.

Russia's failure to ratify the Start II treaty, which would halve each side's nuclear arsenal to about 3,000-3,500 warheads, has long been an lirritant in relations with the US. The US Senate ratified the treaty in 1996.

But Mr Putin has urged the duma to ratify the treaty, saying that reducing the nuclear arsenal does not mean becoming weaker. Reducing the number of warheads is seen as a good economic move, saving the government substantial sums that it spends on maintaining the weapons.

The international affairs committee of the duma discussed Start II's prospects yesterday at a meeting attended by the foreign minister, Igor Ivanov, and the defence minister, Igor Sergeyev. Eleven members of the committee backed ratification and seven spoke out against it, committee chief Dmitri Ragozin said.

The duma speaker, Gennady Seleznyov, said later that the international affairs and defence committees will urge it to address the issue at its next regular session on Friday. - AP

webTitle: Putin visit to London claimed as No 10 coup

fields.headline: Putin visit to London claimed as No 10 coup
fields.standfirst:
Protests as Downing St calls for 'engagement, not isolation'

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: The president-elect of Russia, Vladimir Putin, is to arrive in London on Sunday for talks with the prime minister and to be received at Buckingham Palace, in his first foray to the West since succeeding Boris Yeltsin on New Year's Eve.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor  in Moscow and  Ewen MacAskill
fields.body:
The president-elect of Russia, Vladimir Putin, is to arrive in London on Sunday for talks with the prime minister and to be received at Buckingham Palace, in his first foray to the West since succeeding Boris Yeltsin on New Year's Eve.

Downing Street billed it as a diplomatic coup that Mr Putin should make Britain his first port of call. Tony Blair and the foreign secretary, Robin Cook, have been working hard to establish a rapport with Mr Putin, a former KGB career officer.

But the visit will be controversial. The Council of Europe, of which Britain is a member, has begun a process of suspending Russia because of its involvement in Chechnya.

The Liberal Democrat foreign affairs spokesman, Menzies Campbell, who sits on a joint cabinet committee with Mr Blair, said there should be no question of a visit until Mr Putin's words about respect for human rights were matched by deeds in Chechnya.

Downing Street said the two leaders will discuss Chechnya as well as the Russian economy, the Balkans, crime and drugs. Mr Blair's spokesman said the visit would cement a "new strategic relationship" between the two countries .

The 24-hour visit - arriving in London on Sunday evening and leaving the following evening - followed an invitation from Mr Blair when he met Mr Putin in St Petersburg last month, a fortnight before Mr Putin's sweeping victory in presidential elections.

The St Petersburg trip left the prime minister open to charges that he was taking sides in Russian politics and also strongly suggested that Mr Putin's brutal prosecution of the war in Chechnya would be no bar to developing closer relations with the West.

That view was further confirmed last week when European Union envoys met Mr Putin in Moscow and stated afterwards that their "basic message was that we don't want to make of this issue [Chechnya] a global confrontation with Russia. We want a strategic partnership with Russia".

A Downing Street source said yesterday: "It is important to send a strong signal to Russia about our concerns over Chechnya but the prime minister thinks the best way to get a response is through engagement, not isolation."

After a year of estrangement between Russia and the West because of Chechnya, the Kosovo war and Nato expansion into eastern Europe, the British are spearheading a rapprochement. In addition to the Putin visit, Russian officials said leading Blair advisers from Downing Street's policy unit are soon to visit Moscow as well as a Treasury team.

Apart from meeting Mr Blair and having talks with Mr Cook, Mr Putin is to be received by the Queen at Buckingham Palace and is also to have a dinner in the City with leading British industrial figures. The signs are that Mr Putin is inaugurating a drive to attract foreign investment, though he has yet to name a government or unveil any coherent economic policies.

In coming to London before he is even sworn in as president, Mr Putin is ignoring constitutional niceties. Until after May 7, his inauguration day, Mr Putin is simultaneously Russia's president-elect and prime minister. The Russian constitution prescribes that either the president or the prime minister have to be in the country if the other is absent.

fields.headline: Northern lights
fields.standfirst:
Labour cannot abandon the regions

North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Since the brusque exit of Peter Kilfoyle from the government in January, evidence has been accumulating that the "heartlands" - the northern English regions, Wales and Scotland - are not getting a fair share of the United Kingdom's general prosperity. Labour MPs of the Kilfoyle, Doug Henderson stripe look like winning the argument. The likelihood of their winning the war - and securing a major shift in policy and resources northwards - is lessened by the strength of the cynical/psephological argument. It says that even if Labour supporters stay at home in their droves in Gateshead, Bootle or Glamorgan, the cushion of huge Labour majorities there will hold up. More important for the party's future is the south, where Labour won against the historical odds in 1997.
fields.body:
Since the brusque exit of Peter Kilfoyle from the government in January, evidence has been accumulating that the "heartlands" - the northern English regions, Wales and Scotland - are not getting a fair share of the United Kingdom's general prosperity. Labour MPs of the Kilfoyle, Doug Henderson stripe look like winning the argument. The likelihood of their winning the war - and securing a major shift in policy and resources northwards - is lessened by the strength of the cynical/psephological argument. It says that even if Labour supporters stay at home in their droves in Gateshead, Bootle or Glamorgan, the cushion of huge Labour majorities there will hold up. More important for the party's future is the south, where Labour won against the historical odds in 1997.

But even a government with only a residual commitment to equality must find this argument hard to sustain. North-south remains a proxy for the system's inegalitarianism and cannot be winked at. National indices are dragged down by regional underperformance. Yes, unemployment is well down, even in Mr Kilfoyle's Merseyside - though conventional definitions exclude those who have withdrawn from the labour market. The "northern" economy shows signs of rosy health at sub-regional level in the cities of Leeds or Manchester. Newcastle upon Tyne is reinventing itself. But persisting imbalance in economic (and social) prospects between the south and east of England and most of the rest of the United Kingdom is too stark.

A new report on competitiveness in the regions compiled by Robert Huggins of the University of Cardiff shows how the disparity will grow as capital and employment moves to e-business. One of his indicators is the proportion of firms which are "knowledge-based", which these days as good as means future-proofed. If the south-east is 30% above the UK average, Yorkshire and Humberside is at 34% below and Wales scores two-thirds of the average. Such uneven development demands active government intervention - whether it is on the Third Way script or not.

Because regional assistance has such a long pedigree it gets characterised - for example by the chancellor - as old Labour interventionism. There is a lot to be said against profligate support for manufacturing investment, subsidising branch plants and industries in decline - though the fact that Longbridge and Harland and Wolf are mass employers makes sudden abandonment of support politically difficult. Call centres could be the next sector to fall. But subsidy can work. The remarkable success of the Irish Republic in recent years proves that being on the geographical edge is not itself an obstacle to attracting external investment. Yet the evidence favours indigenous growth based on small and medium enterprise and the enrichment of a region's human capital. Until school attainment rates are raised and mass higher education arrives in the back streets of Sunderland and Sefton cruel regional disparities will persist.

Tony Blair has lately warmed to the devolution of political decision-making within England - oddly late in the day for a north-eastern MP. His remarks about the Alun Michael-Rhodri Morgan affair reported at the weekend may be a sign of a lesson painfully learned. How can the English regions start organising to compete, marshalling their human resources, making a case for construction of the infrastructure which is a precondition of prosperity unless Newcastle upon Tyne, Manchester and Leeds become centres of active politics?

His remarks about the Alun Michael-Rhodri Morgan affair reported at the weekend may be a sign of a lesson painfully learned. How can the English regions start organising to compete, marshalling their human resources, making a case for construction of the infrastructure which is a precondition of prosperity unless Newcastle upon Tyne, Manchester and Leeds become centres of active politics?

fields.headline: In bed with Putin
fields.standfirst:
A Labour analyst welcomes Tony Blair's love-in with the new Russian leader

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: A Labour analyst welcomes Tony Blair's love-in with the new Russian leader
fields.body:
Margaret Thatcher once hailed Mikhail Gorbachev as a "man she could do business with", so helping to open up the Soviet Union to the west, unfreeze the cold war, and hastening perestroika and ultimately the collapse of the Berlin wall and the Warsaw Pact. At the time, in the mid-1980s, Gorbachev was a new Soviet leader, on his first state visit to Britain and as yet ignored by the US. Following Mrs Thatcher's initiative, the US finally sat up and noticed they had a reformer and potential global partner in the Kremlin; the rest, as they say, is history.

Britain has been one of the first western countries to pursue a critical engagement with the new man in the Kremlin, president-elect Vladimir Putin. Robin Cook and George Robertson (as Nato secretary general) have been swift to beat a path to Moscow, followed by Tony Blair's initiative as first western head of government to meet Putin in his native St Petersburg, just before the presidential election.

There are several reasons behind this renewed interest in Anglo-Russian relations, and a desire to build bridges with Putin despite the bloody carnage in Chechnya. The first concerns the opportunities offered by a change of regime in Moscow. It has been apparent since at least December that Putin would succeed Boris Yeltsin as Russian president. Yeltsin had become increasingly difficult to do business with, as he was either unwell, under the influence, distracted by internal palace intrigues - or all three at the same time. Putin, on the other hand, is young (at 47 only a year separates him and Tony Blair), vigorous (a judo black belt), and has indicated he knows he has a great deal to do to reform and modernise Russia, even if he has not yet worked out how he can do it.

Despite 16 years as a KGB officer, and one year heading its successor, the FSB, Putin has also been exposed to reformist influences, working as deputy to former St Petersburg mayor Anatoly Sobchak. Putin has spoken of the need to overhaul the tax system, and encourage western investment in Russia by improving legislation in this field. However, lest anyone should be starry-eyed about his liberal reformist credentials, it should be noted that he wrote last December that "western-style democracy and the free market must be adapted to Russian realities".

In other words, Putin wants reform while adopting a "Russia first" approach - creating a uniquely Russian variant of democratic and economic models, and developing a more assertive foreign policy to express Russia's great power status.

None of this, however, should discourage the west from developing a closer relationship with Russia. Putin realises Russia needs the west: it needs western investment and support through international financial institutions like the IMF and World Bank.

With his St Petersburg background, Putin is naturally orientated towards the west and especially Europe. He speaks fluent German, his wife Lyudmila speaks French, Spanish and German. Equally, the west needs Russia, hence the strategy of critical engagement emanating from the Foreign Office and Downing Street.

Russia is still a major nuclear power, with 3,500 inter-continental nuclear warheads, 13 nuclear missile submarines and 70 nuclear-bomber aircraft. The west desperately wants the ratification of Start II, and would like to see further nuclear cutbacks with a Start III. Putin is hinting he might be amenable, as Russia is hard-pressed to pay for its nuclear arsenal, especially with the development of the new Topol ICBM. The state of Russia's nuclear arsenal, its security and degradation, are major threats to global stability and the environment. The US would like to see Russian agreement to amend the 1972 anti-ballistic missile treaty, so it can introduce its controversial missile defence system, aimed at "rogue" states.

No one wants to see an isolated and aggrieved nationalistic Russia, and a new arms race, difficult as that may seem given Russia's parlous finances (Putin has already sanctioned a 50% increase in defence spending, although this is still only 25% of Britain's). There is also the question of handling Russia's attitude to further demands for Nato expansion (Lithuania wants to join by 2002), and further potential crises in the Balkans and elsewhere. Putin has pledged to vigorously defend the rights of Russians in the former Soviet republics.

Given all these factors, it makes sense to try to engage critically with the Russians and their new president. While calling for an end to the bloodshed in Chechnya, a political solution and an urgent inquiry into human rights abuses, it is also important to foster a long-term relationship with Russia. With the US focused on its presidential elections, Tony Blair is best placed amongst the heads of EU member governments to build a personal relationship with Putin. He can show the US and other Europeans that Putin is a man we "can do business with", encouraging him along the path of economic and political reform.

Personal relationships are important in history, and who knows, this could lead to a new entente cordiale between our two countries -or, given that Putin does not drink, perhaps an entente cordial.

 Dr Peter Truscott is visiting research fellow at the Institute for Public Policy Research and the author of Russia First
