fields.headline: Regional divide widening, ministers told
fields.standfirst: North-south divide: special report
fields.trailText: Government attempts to play down the significance of a north-south divide were in disarray last night when a new report pointed to growing regional inequalities in Britain caused by a booming southern economy.
fields.body:
Government attempts to play down the significance of a north-south divide were in disarray last night when a new report pointed to growing regional inequalities in Britain caused by a booming southern economy.

A survey backed by the government's own economic and social research council painted a gloomy picture of Labour's recession-hit heartlands. Its author accused the Deparment of Trade and Industry of concealing regional disparities "for political reasons".

But ministers pointed to the redrawing of the map of areas which qualify for government industrial aid as evidence that they are intent on reviving flagging regional economies. The map, published yesterday under presssure from Brussels, reduces the number of so-called asisted areas. But some northern areas gain at the expense of the south.

The report, from Cardiff University's centre for advanced studies, found that while London and the south east were performing as well as the world's top 10 competitive countries, places like Yorkshire and the Humber, the north east and Wales ranked alongside Malaysia, Hungary, Chile and Portugal.

It "conclusively highlighted the continuance of a north-south divide" and warned of a widening gap unless attempts are made to encourage new home-grown businesses and entrepreneurs in the regions.

The report strongly challenges a Cabinet Office report, recently commissioned by Tony Blair, which maintained that disparities within regions were often wider than any north-south divide. On a visit to Wales last week - ranked second bottom in Cardiff University's regional competitiveness table - the prime minister said he would not fall into the "Tory trap" of making a "false distinction" between Labour's heartlands and middle Britain.

This followed an attack on dissident backbenchers, notably the former defence minister and Liverpool Walton MP Peter Kilfolyle, at Labour's local government conference.

Mr Blair laid into Labour critics who "peddled the myth" that the south was entirely prosperous while the north was overwhelmingly poor.

"It's not true and it is a false illusion that the answer to the problems of the north are somehow to punish the south," he said.

However, the Cardiff report's author, Dr Robert Huggins, warns of bleak prospects for many areas away from the south - apart from northern "hot spots" such as oil-rich Aberdeen and the booming Scottish capital of Edinburgh - because there is little likelihood of companies in the south moving north.

He said: "Although the Department of Trade and Industry has carried out certain research on competitiveness in the UK, for political reasons it has been reluctant to measure the actual comparative performances of regions." Dr Huggins said the Cardiff analysis identified those parts of the UK "that are becoming so economically uncompetitive that the end result is widespread deprivation and misery for the people who live there".

His report uses a new index measuring wealth - or gross domestic product per head - along with average earnings, unemployment, and the new "knowledge based" industries so beloved by the government.

While the south east, London, the south west and East Anglia - all home to high-tech clusters, or booming financial service industries - perform above the average, the midlands, the north west and north east, Yorkshire and the Humber, Scotland and Wales significantly under-perform.

Ministers were stung by the findings.

Some dismissed them as over-simplified by failing to recognise measures to encourage science parks in the midlands and north. "We can't turn things round overnight," one said.

Alan Beith, deputy leader of the Liberal Democrats, said: "The south is not all success and the north is not all unsuccessful - but overall the north is in serious need of help. Britian's economy is seriously unbalanced and the evidence might be that divisions are getting wider."

webTitle: Banks plan trading network for $52 trillion derivatives

fields.headline: Banks plan trading network for $52 trillion derivatives
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The arcane business of derivatives took a step into the future yesterday when six of the world's biggest dealers announced plans to set up an electronic system for trading.
fields.body:
The arcane business of derivatives took a step into the future yesterday when six of the world's biggest dealers announced plans to set up an electronic system for trading.

The system, to be known as SwapsWire, will allow interest rate derivatives to be traded by computers, eventually eradicating the current method of doing business over the telephone.

Interest rate derivatives, among the most complicated in the financial world, are used by major corporations to protect themselves against major movements in interest rates.

SwapsWire is being set up by the six biggest players in the interest rate derivatives market: Chase Manhattan, Citigroup, Deutsche Bank, JP Morgan, Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and Warburg Dillon Read. It is named for one of the leading derivative products, known as a swap.

The new system, which will be jointly-owned by the six institutions, is not intended to act as an exchange in setting prices at which the trades are done. But it is intended to allow the majors to communicate with each other. Eventually, members may pay access or fees per trade.

The average outstanding value of swaps worldwide was estimated at $52 trillion in 1999, up from $37 trillion the year before, a 41 percent increase.

To support this growing volume of business, each of the big banks involved employs hundreds of staff. For example, one of the SwapsWire founders, JP Morgan, employs 300 in the back office of its derivatives operation in London.

The SwapsWire system is expected to be tested towards the end of this year and be more widely available in the early part of next. The six founders say they intend to encourage their rivals to participate in the network.

webTitle: Affinity discovers free is not easy

fields.headline: Affinity discovers free is not easy
fields.standfirst:
One-stop shop policy draws big brands in tough first year

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: A little over a year ago Wayne Lochner and Terry Plummer, former commodities brokers from Essex, were touring the City trying to persuade sceptical institutional investors to take a punt on the £12m flotation of their fledgling internet service provider (ISP) Affinity Internet Holdings.
fields.body:
A little over a year ago Wayne Lochner and Terry Plummer, former commodities brokers from Essex, were touring the City trying to persuade sceptical institutional investors to take a punt on the £12m flotation of their fledgling internet service provider (ISP) Affinity Internet Holdings.

In early April, three months before Freeserve listed, Affinity became one of the first publicly traded British ISPs, armed with £2m of new funds. By February this year Affinity's stock market value had risen to £1.9bn and that was before its broker, Charles Stanley, had got around to publishing any research on the company.

Mr Lochner, the company's 43-year-old chief executive, and Mr Plummer, its 49-year-old chairman, were sitting on holdings with paper worth more than £500m each.

Then, almost as quickly as the millions piled up, they started to disappear. By the start of this month the sell-off of technology stocks had burnt a £300m hole in each of their pockets as Affinity's market value plummeted to "just" £600m. Few companies can have ridden the internet wave as dramatically as Affinity.

Yesterday, as the company reported maiden preliminary results for the year to December 31, 1999 and the shares closed up 5% at £35, Mr Lochner was struggling to give a straight-faced assessment of proceedings.

"A year ago when I told some of my co-directors I was aiming for a billion pound-plus valuation they thought I was mad and were reaching for men in white coats," he said.

Affinity floated on Aim, offering to run websites for well-known brands. Since then it has gone into integrated telephony, e-commerce, convergent billing and online enter tainment services for more than 150 brands and 1.4m registered users.

Mr Lochner says clients such as PowerGen, Unisys and Arsenal football club can offer customers branded internet, mobile telephone, credit card and email services, and bill them through a single point thanks to Affinity's billing and telephony companies.

"It means PowerGen has becomes a part of the customer's life and makes it extremely unlikely they're going to switch to another gas or electricity provider just because they get a 20% discount leaflet through their letterbox," Mr Lochner said.

With other blue-chip clients including Vodafone and TransNational, and a planned move to Techmark, Affinity is well positioned to fulfil plans to expand into six overseas markets by the end of the third quarter.

However, rapid growth has come at a price. Group revenues may have increased nearly twenty times in 12 months but are only £3.4m. Losses were £9.17m, including an exceptional of £3.11m, up from £922,000. Affinity's £15m cash reserves will be tested in coming months and more than £20m should be raised in the move to Techmark. The directors are likely to sell shares to cover the £2m initial investment they made.

Mr Lochner believes Affinity will meet the financial chal lenge and those brought by the introduction of broadband services and ADSL, plus the move towards unmetered internet access.

Most ISPs offering free net access depend on interconnection revenues, paid by telecoms operators to ISPs or their telcos for generating traffic. Affinity said 23% of its first quarter revenues in 2000 came from non-interconnect sources.

"Interconnect revenues have been very nice, thank you, but they can't be the core of the revenue stream," Mr Lochner said. "Last year they were material; this year they'll become less material. And in 12 months' time people won't even think about it."

fields.headline: Mobile auction bids hit £16bn
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: The government's third generation mobile phone auction reached another milestone yesterday as the total bids topped £16bn, driven by Vodafone and BT Cellnet's battle to win the prized licence B.
fields.body:
The government's third generation mobile phone auction reached another milestone yesterday as the total bids topped £16bn, driven byVodafone and BT Cellnet's battle to win the prized licence B.

Licence B - one of five on offer - offers the broadest spectrum available to the four existing mobile operators.

Yesterday Vodafone bid £4.24bn for the licence, which pushed its shares down 17.25p to 338.25p as investors became concerned about the cost to the company.

In addition to the payment for the licence, the five winners will need to spend at least £2bn each building networks for the Universal Mobile Telecommunications System on which third generation phones will operate.

Stephen Pentland, a partner at Spectrum Strategy Consultants, said that the winners might open up their networks to new retailers offering mobile services as part of a bundled package to their customers.

He said this could be vital because the winners would need to generate revenues quickly to cover the potential £6bn-plus cost of the licence and network to operators such as Vodafone or BT.

"Just as credit cards are no longer marketed just by retail banks - even Yahoo! now offers a credit card to its portal users - so too it is possible that mobile communications services will no longer be the exclusive domain of telecoms operators," he said.

The second highest bid came from NTL Mobile, backed by France Telecom, which offered £3.25bn for licence A. This licence, which is reserved for a new entrant, has become a battleground for Telefonica of Spain, TIW of Canada and WorldCom of the Netherlands.

Telefonica, which has waived its bidding rights twice and has only one more chance to abstain before it has to drop out of the race, offered £2.84bn for licence D.

One2One bid £2.85bn for licence C while Orange offered £2.86bn for licence E.

Round 111 of the auction resumes today, with eight bidders still in contention. The number of contenders is expected to drop before the end of the week as prices rise further.

Some analysts have said the total value of the bids may go as high as £22bn.

fields.headline: Doctors you can talk to
fields.standfirst: The future of the NHS: special report
fields.trailText: While the government is hell bent on "modernising" the NHS, some doctors obviously think what patients really want is a traditional doctor-patient relationship.
fields.body:
There's a new service available in my area of London. It's for a private GP practice which will allow you to "see your doctor when you want", "not have to wait in a busy waiting room", and "have longer appointments".

This is not Mayfair, but a socially mixed area with no precedent for private medicine, so such a development is extremely revealing. While the government is hell bent on "modernising" the NHS, some doctors obviously think what patients really want, even if they have to pay for it, is something much simpler: a traditional doctor-patient relationship.

You might have thought all the talk of revitalising the NHS would involve a GP service like this - accessible, local (but free) - as its cornerstone. But New Labour's modernisation implies the exact opposite. Getting to see a GP will soon be more difficult than getting an audience with the Pope. The new health initiatives are aimed at reducing the public's dependency on that direct relationship. Now we are encouraged to phone NHS Direct or use drop-in centres. Last week it became clear that Labour's new "primary care groups" are being encouraged to identify local needs and develop front line nursing services to perform uncomplicated medical procedures. Only when these quick fix solutions have been exhausted will appointments with doctors be appropriate.

One aim behind these reforms is reducing costs, on the assumption that nurses on phone lines with access to information about the cheapest drugs, or specialist nurses performing minor procedures, are cheaper that doctors. But nurses can take longer than doctors to perform similar procedures so might actually be less cost effective. There's also already anecdotal evidence of people misinformed by NHS Direct. My own practice picked up the pieces after a patient was given inaccurate information about post-coital contraceptives.

It seems crazy to marginalise highly trained general practitioners in favour of an unproven alternative of dubious financial advantage. But cost is only one imperative. The government is also determined to drive down waiting lists, as this would be a measurable indication of a functioning health service.

In fact, reduced waiting lists is only proof of quality care in a highly medicalised model of doctor-patient relationships, where it's assumed patients present readily identifiable medical problems, and doctors deliver quick, cost effective diagnoses. Yet people's relationship with their health is much more complicated. The vast majority of GP visits are not with conventional medical problems. Numerous recent research projects show that 70-90% of visits are to do with social problems, depression, anxiety and, according to one London doctor I know, increasingly exhaustion. Most of these patients present with a physical ailment. It takes time and repeated appointments to eliminate physical causes and help them understand what's wrong. This doctor says the skill is helping patients see what's wrong, without them feeling criticised. The doctor often has to take risks, delaying referrals to hospital while helping patients work out their own solutions.

Certainly doctors feel very pressurised by massive demands on their services; most blame increasing expectations of health inflamed by politicians' wild promises of quick fix solutions. But I've yet to meet one who feels the answer is to become less available to patients. On the contrary, all still value the old ideal of a doctor who knows his or her patients individually, who can keep track of their total use of health services, and who has time for them, even - or especially - when their ailments don't have easy solutions.

What's worrying is that this perception of what makes a good doctor is now seriously at odds with the government's, which is measuring quality by what can be measured; patient numbers, length of waiting lists, appointment times. Doctors believe that what makes them good are qualities which can't be measured; making themselves available, being good listeners, empathising with people's pain and frailties, easing suffering where they can. One Edinburgh doctor described this conflict as soul-destroying: "We're being made to feel what we value as important is irrelevant, and what matters are externally imposed targets. We don't own any of the current intitiative around health and we're being asked to abandon our inner individual source of value for a corporate one."

He's clearly not alone. As in my area, Edinburgh has now acquired a new private GP. Perhaps these doctors are cynically cashing in on nostalgia, but perhaps not. It may be that the government has seriously misdiagnosed what's wrong with the health service and, in an ultimate irony, will now preside over the first boom in private GP services since the birth of the NHS.

fields.headline: Clampdown inflames asylum row
fields.standfirst:
Kent ban could be followed by 20 councils
Immigration & Nationality Directorate (Home Office)
Commission for Racial Equality
Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Jack Straw is facing mounting pressure to step up the national dispersal programme for asylum seekers after conceding for the first time last night that at least one local authority could handle no more refugees because of weight of numbers.
fields.body:
Jack Straw is facing mounting pressure to step up the national dispersal programme for asylum seekers after conceding for the first time last night that at least one local authority could handle no more refugees because of weight of numbers.

Asylum seekers landing in Britain from next Monday will be barred from living in Kent and will be compulsorily bussed around the country, the home secretary said last night.

Mr Straw bowed to pressure from local authority leaders and declared that Kent had taken "more than its share" of asylum seekers.

He faces pressure from a further 20 local authority areas, including the Isle of Wight, the New Forest and Northampton, to declare that they too are "full up". The measures will apply to all new asylum seekers whether they lodge their claim on the day they arrive "at port" or later "in-country".

At the same time, Mr Straw said that 9,000 decisions on asylum cases had been taken in March, again outstripping applications, which was evidence that the asylum system was recovering from its breakdown over the past year.

Figures released to MPs yesterday revealed the pressure facing the immigration service and the councils tasked with housing those seeking asylum. According to the junior Home Office minister Lord Bassam of Brighton at least 74,490 individuals or families applied for asylum in the year to the end of February, compared with 49,395 in the same period last year. The figures showed last September as a peak month, with 7,355 applications, and December with 7,180. Totals for January and February 2000 are estimated at 6,110.

The decision to declare part of south-east England a "no- go" area for refugees came as William Hague and Ann Widdecombe brushed aside government pleas for calmer language and pressed ahead with their charge that Labour had made Britain "a soft touch for a massive influx of bogus asylum seekers".

Mr Hague claimed at a fund-raising dinner last night that "genuine asylum refugees are suffering most at the hands of a system on the verge of collapse".

What looked like a concerted attempt to push the issue up the political agenda in advance of next month's local elections came only hours after Downing Street had appealed to both sides to moderate their language rather than "play the race card".

It came as the Liberal Democrats were reporting both their main rivals to the commission for racial equality, although last night the party's home affairs spokesman, Simon Hughes, praised government efforts to "cool the heat and lower the temperature".

The political row continued as Southwark council, in south London - which includes Mr Hughes' North Southwark and Bermondsey constituency - prepared to bus 50 families of asylum seekers, more than 150 people, to Glasgow. Some of those being moved had been settled for months in the London borough while they waited for a decision on their case.

During Commons question time, at which Mr Straw denied Tory allegations that Labour had created current levels of asylum applications, Miss Widdecombe launched a vehement attack on the government's record since 1997.

"The message went out to the rest of the world that Britain is a soft touch for asylum seekers," the shadow home secretary said. "You sent the message, it's your responsibility."

Tony Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, used the word "bogus" at least once yesterday, but avoided directly accusing the Tories of playing the race card - as the immigration minister, Barbara Roche, and Trevor Phillips, Labour's No 2 in London, have done.

Instead he told reporters: "The prime minister would never, ever allow the Labour party - to use that unpleasant, unfortunate phrase: to play the race card in relation to asylum seekers."

fields.headline: Learning the lessons of the 90s
fields.standfirst:
Korea Web Weekly
Democratic People's Republic of Korea
fields.trailText: Recalling his days as a correspondent on the Northern side during the Korean war, the Hungarian writer Tibor Meray spoke about travelling through a landscape so devastated by US bombing that cities had become no more than collections of chimneys.
fields.body:
Recalling his days as a correspondent on the Northern side during the Korean war, the Hungarian writer Tibor Meray spoke about travelling through a landscape so devastated by US bombing that cities had become no more than collections of chimneys.

"I don't know why houses collapsed and chimneys did not," he told Thames television, "but I went through a city of 200,000 inhabitants and I saw thousands of chimneys and that - that was all."

Without some such image it is difficult to understand the Koreas. Both were traumatised by the war, and both have been embattled, in some sense, ever since. But while South Korea has found a relatively secure place in the world, thanks to American and Japanese support and to its own economic success, North Korea has never escaped from the sense of vulnerability captured by Meray.

Both states have feared one another - and one another's allies - but it is arguable that the North has been more fearful than the South.

The summit planned for June between Kim Dae-jung and Kim Jong-il represents an easing of these Northern anxieties precisely because it is a step away from the unification, which both sides theoretically proclaim as an aim, rather than a step towards it.

Despite the fact that some of the politicians involved bear titles which include the word "reunification", and in spite of the rhetoric on both sides, good relations between the Koreas depend on postponing unification to the distant future. This has been the difficult lesson of the 90s.

The uninformed expectation that North Korea would be more or less peacefully folded into the south in the manner that East Germany joined West Germany - or that it would collapse and be taken over - caused an increase in tension that could have led to war, particularly in 1994. It probably also pushed on the North Korean nuclear weapons and missile efforts which were the main cause of the military tension.

After 1989 the idea that Korea would be unified on the German model was examined. The South Koreans were unenthusiastic only because findings suggested that incorporating the North would be hugely expensive. North Korea's leaders, by contrast, were enraged that people around the world were happily discussing the extinction of their regime.

The renunciation of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty in 1993 was a signal that their powerful sense of encirclement had become intense. The rest of the decade has been spent persuading the North Koreans that the US, South Korea, Japan, and their many allies, far from wishing North Korea dead and gone, are ready to help it survive and even prosper.

The former US president Jimmy Carter helped defuse the crisis of 1994 by creating the basis for an agreement to freeze North Korean civil nuclear development.

US efforts to reassure North Korea have continued, most recently with talks based on the recommendations of the former defence secretary William Perry. These led to a lifting of American sanctions and to a deal last year under which North Korea is to suspend missile development and conduct no more long range missile tests like the one in 1998..

The food crisis in North Korea, which began in 1995 and remains serious, brought into that closed society hundreds of foreign aid workers. A degree of trust has gradually been established. Kim Dae-jung, the former dissident who became president of South Korea in 1998, has pursued what he calls a "sunshine policy" which stresses helping North Korea.

The results of this emphasis on help by the United States, international agencies and South Korea have paid off this year in diplomatic contacts and negotiations with Japan, the Philippines, Italy, Australia and now between the two Koreas.

Kim Jong-il and the North Korean leadership actively sought this help because it was the only way their state could cope, but they remain suspicious of the deeper motives of those aiding them. But while swings between between trust and suspicion will continue to shape Korean relations, it is permissible to hope that the worst may be over.

webTitle: Juggling with numbers, dropping the facts

fields.headline: Juggling with numbers, dropping the facts
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText: How many asylum seekers are there in Eastbourne? asked Nigel Waterson, the Conservative MP for the town. I thought I had written down the number Jack Straw gave but government by numbers means that the parliamentary sketch writer is soon lost in a sea of rapid-fire statistics. When   moral issues impose upon them, MPs seek asylum in figures.
fields.body:
How many asylum seekers are there in Eastbourne? asked Nigel Waterson, the Conservative MP for the town. I thought I had written down the number Jack Straw gave but government by numbers means that the parliamentary sketch writer is soon lost in a sea of rapid-fire statistics. When moral issues impose upon them, MPs seek asylum in figures.

Ann Widdecombe lambasted Mr Straw for allowing "unbelievable and unprecedented levels" of asylum seekers to remain in the country despite being refused permission. Britain is becoming a "soft touch for the organised asylum racketeers who are flooding our country with bogus asylum seekers". Anyway, that's what it says in the Tory manifesto for May's local elections.

What flood? How many? Who are these organised asylum racketeers? Sadly, I cannot give you answers. Miss Widdecombe's theatrical outburst was just that, a plea for the attention of giggling and smirking Tory backbenchers. Words delivered for the benefit of the TV cameras, signifying nothing.

Mr Straw reprimanded her. Tory votes on asylum seeking, he explained, would have cost the country £500m. But that's not nearly as much as the £1bn we Brits are being ripped off each year by the motor trade, I learned an hour later when asylum seeking was off the agenda.

That is around £1,100 per average car (I imagine a Mondeo 1.8L without the air-con options) and 10-12% above the average price paid on the continent. Britain is clearly a soft touch when it comes to the unloading of the unbelievable and unprecedented numbers of foreign cars seeking asylum on our crowded roads.

One Tory chap in a shinier suit than average said he was pleased to be able to support the home secretary's new proposals based on liberal continental practice. There's something to be said for foreigners after all then? Well, yes - their licensing laws, as long as they themselves stop at Calais.

Miss Widdecombe knows their knavish tricks and did something about it, or so she said. Under Tory legislation of 1996, asylum seeking fell by 40%. Under Labour it has doubled. Why does the government waste so much time processing these asylum seekers, asked another Tory suit: 87% will be rejected anyway. Could be dealt with in a month. Get Johnny Foreigner out of Kent and back on a boat to wherever he comes from, you could imagine him saying. Chop chop.

The home secretary said hundreds of new Home Office employees were processing the outstanding applications (100,000, someone said helpfully). Last month no fewer than 9,000 were processed, said Mr Straw. A record and well up on last year's 1,000 a month.

Not only this, but cheaper new foreign cars, I mean non-bogus asylum seekers, were now being distributed around the country, to get them out of the hair of Kent council tax payers, not forgetting Eastbourne, by means of the Home Office's new national dispersal system. This is effective from April 17, said Mr Straw, brim ming with confidence, knowing that he had scored a feather in his hat by giving Miss Widdecombe a black eye. On or after that day no asylum seeker in Kent will be eligible for financial support.

Yesterday in the Commons also taught me that domestic violence is 10% higher in London than elsewhere (Eastbourne, for example). Alcohol kills 45,000 people in Britain a year. The prime minister, according to Ms Widdecombe, has himself used the word "bogus" in relation to the flood of asylum seekers "five times in recent weeks". But I don't recall the word "people" or "persons" being applied to them by MPs of either side of the house. Nor how many reside in Eastbourne.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.standfirst: Parliament: special report
fields.trailText:
Good day
Lobby journalists. MPs have decided to let journalists use mobile phones in certain parts of the palace of Westminster to "make it easier to file their stories". The latest modernisation gesture comes after the use of tape recorders was allowed in the press gallery, along with TV filming in MPs' offices.
fields.body:
Good day
Lobby journalists. MPs have decided to let journalists use mobile phones in certain parts of the palace of Westminster to "make it easier to file their stories". The latest modernisation gesture comes after the use of tape recorders was allowed in the press gallery, along with TV filming in MPs' offices.

Spat of day
Lord Longford, the veteran prison reformer, and Lord Bassam, Home Office minister. Lord Longford made an impassioned plea for the "supposedly dangerous" prisoner Charles Bronson who was being forced to sleep on a concrete bed with no window. Rubbish, replied the minister. It's a concrete plinth with a mattress. And a window.

Confession of day
To the gasps of Tory MPs, home secretary Jack Straw labelled himself a socialist. Talking on pub opening hours comrade Jack said: "As a socialist my aim in life is to secure a safe, just and tolerant society in which people who are law abiding have the maximum of liberty to pursue their lives as they wish."

Today
Commons: Foreign office questions. Local government bill, second reading. Lords: Powers of criminal courts (sentencing) bill, committee. Sexual offences (amendment) bill, second reading.

fields.headline: A question of respect
fields.trailText:
My deepest sympathies go out to the families of the two Leeds supporters who were killed in Istanbul (Letters, April 8). However, the UK media must be living in cloud cuckoo land if they believe that a gang of animals posing as football fans can go to another country, get blind drunk, abuse the locals and then insult the entire nation by desecrating the flag without expecting some kind of retribution. When will English people abroad (Greece, Turkey, Ibiza, or anywhere else) realise that the world outside Britain is not a playground which exists merely for frustrated Englishmen.
R Jobanputra
Istanbul

fields.headline: Inquest on Ofsted
fields.trailText: Two teachers have now committed suicide in the aftermath of what colleagues describe as severe Ofsted inspections (Ofsted stress too much for teacher who killed herself, April 7). The broader context in which inspections occur has been well-documented. It is one of unprecedented, centrally driven and under-resourced change, especially in primary school education. Ministers talk tough, often on matters about which they know little; naming, shaming and differentially rewarding are lauded as virtues.
fields.body:
Two teachers have now committed suicide in the aftermath of what colleagues describe as severe Ofsted inspections (Ofsted stress too much for teacher who killed herself, April 7). The broader context in which inspections occur has been well-documented. It is one of unprecedented, centrally driven and under-resourced change, especially in primary school education. Ministers talk tough, often on matters about which they know little; naming, shaming and differentially rewarding are lauded as virtues.

Grassroots' experiences of inspections suggest that the death of Pamela Relf represents the extreme point of a continuum of personal anguish and suffering, ranging from sleepless nights and anxiety attacks through to depression, stress-related illness and premature retirement. It is a judgmental and bullish climate, where the message to teachers is that if they can't stand the heat they should get out of the classroom.

The realignment of time, ef fort, finance and scarce resources to "satisfy" inspection teams and secure safe-standing is scandalous. The pressure on all involved, including children, is unacceptable. There has to be a radical restructuring of the burdensome and threatening aspects of the process and for this the voices of teachers must be heard and listened to.
Prof Phil Scraton
Burscough, Lancs
Scratonp@edgehill.ac.uk

 It is not just those teachers who are criticised by inspectors who find the Ofsted system threatening, stressful and demeaning. I am chair of governors of a school for children with learning difficulties which has just passed its second inspection with flying colours. Outstanding teachers that this school and the education system as a whole can ill afford to lose are quite determined to move, probably via early retirement, rather than go through the experience another time. I know of several highly regarded headteachers who have led their schools successfully through one Ofsted and are adamant that they will never go through another one.

Perhaps, if the whole process were genuinely improving standards in the long term, the stress inflicted on teachers could be justified, but it is not. Its main effect is to drive many of the most effective, as judged by Ofsted itself, classroom teachers and heads out of the profession prematurely, denying children the benefit of their expertise and limiting the opportunity to pass their skills on to a new generation of teachers.
Name and address supplied

 I wonder what the inspectors are feeling who gave Miss Relf and her school a bad report? Teachers get enough stimulation and stress from standing in front of 30 children all day. It has been obvious from its inception that Ofsted could do nothing but harm by adding to this pressure.
Steve Lupton
Manchester
shlpictures@eggconnect.net

 The public humiliation of teachers and schools who, as judged by a fallible Ofsted, fail to reach their targets of achievement, is a nasty bullying business. The approach which the government selects to improving achievement in schools should provide a model of respectful relationships for children and young people. It is to be hoped that the loss of this teacher's life will provoke a public debate about the inspection of schools which will lead the government to switch from a punitive to a supportive method for encouraging their development. One teacher's death is enough.
Tony Booth
Cambridge

fields.headline: No brake on the car
fields.trailText: The government's refusal to back European car-free day on September 22 would appear to be another indication that it is now living in fear of antagonising Britain's motorists (UK to snub car-free day, April 10).
fields.body:
The government's refusal to back European car-free day on September 22 would appear to be another indication that it is now living in fear of antagonising Britain's motorists (UK to snub car-free day, April 10).

John Prescott's reason for dismissing the idea is that a single car-free day would quickly be over and done with and then perhaps forgotten. Surely even that would be better than it never entering the consciousness at all? A single day is all it takes. Remembrance Sunday, Valentine's day and Mothering Sunday are also lone days but no one has suggested scrapping them.

The problem of leaving car-free day to local authorities to participate in, or not, as they wish is that it will lead to a fragmented approach. Car culture is an issue that deserves greater recognition and wider debate. This will be read as another sign of the government distancing itself from principles it once held dear.

If it really wanted to lead the way out of the traffic jam, it would embrace car-free day and challenge all public transport operators to match Virgin's offer to provide free services on the day.
Steve Hounsham
Transport 2000

 Running scared of the AA and RAC and with an election looming, nothing will be countenanced that could possibly upset the "motorist lobby". Analysis of schemes held in cities such as Milan have shown that emissions of carbon monoxide have fallen by 35% and the Italians, who have one of the highest rates of car ownership in the world, are broadly in favour of this happening on a weekly basis. Here, anything that is innovative and forward-thinking is stifled for fear of upsetting someone. With an estimated 80,000 Europeans dying every year directly from vehicle-related pollution, is it not time that Mr Prescott and his team reassessed where their priorities lie?
Dave Whyte
Manchester
dave_whyte@email.com

fields.headline: SP on Arkle
fields.body:
You were mistaken about the death of Arkle in the piece on the accidents that occur in National Hunt racing (Four horses killed at National meeting, April 7). Arkle was not put down after being caught up in barbed wire. In fact, as a yearling the greatest ever steeplechaser saw some mares passing his paddock and tried to jump the wire to press his suit. This precocious ambition led to 40 stitches. Twelve years and a remarkable career later he could not overcome the rheumatism or brucellosis with which he had been afflicted. The final injection was administered on May 31, 1970.
Brian Hartigan
Banstead, Surrey

webTitle: Recycling money from the landfill tax

fields.headline: Recycling money from the landfill tax
fields.trailText: Your articles on the landfill tax (April 5, 6 and 7) missed one of its fundamental flaws. The core principle, which allows private companies to distribute tax money, is fatally misconceived. According to the act, they cannot directly receive a commercial benefit. However, most companies now treat this money as a huge PR budget.
fields.body:
Your articles on the landfill tax (April 5, 6 and 7) missed one of its fundamental flaws. The core principle, which allows private companies to distribute tax money, is fatally misconceived. According to the act, they cannot directly receive a commercial benefit. However, most companies now treat this money as a huge PR budget.

True money is been spent on some excellent projects and some interesting innovative activities. But are the landfill companies really going to allow funding for projects which threaten their pre-eminence over the waste stream?

The government should reform Entrust and remove the tax distributing powers from the landfill operators. Only a tiny fraction of the landfill tax money is finding its way to the real innovators in waste management.
Paddy Johnston
Magpie Recycling Coop
paddy@xpad.demon.co.uk

 The £250m landfill tax money is sufficient to provide first-class kerbside recycling services for every household in the country. This would still leave some spare to fund market development for recycled products, and for public waste education and awareness-raising to drive recycling and waste reduction rates to a level comparable with the rest of the western world. Several countries recycle well over 50%, whilst we lag way behind at around 8%.

Waste material collections are generally labour intensive and expenditure would create tens of thousands of new and meaningful jobs, and allow communities to realise the value in their domestic waste streams.
Andy Moore
Community Recycling Network
andym@crn.org.uk

 Whatever the alleged shortcomings revealed by the inquiries of the Guardian and Channel 4, the Landfill Tax Credit Scheme is an innovative and valuable measure. At the end of its second year in September 1999, the fund had offered support to 126 projects amounting to £4.2m out of their total value of £21m. Without the assistance provided, many of the projects simply would not take place. It is an example to be followed as and when other green taxes are introduced.
John Dutton
Chief executive, Staffordshire Environmental Fund

fields.headline: The car rip-off exposed
fields.standfirst: It is not the only reason prices will fall
fields.trailText: The Competition Commission's conclusion that car prices in the UK are 10% to 12% more expensive than in Europe will come as no surprise to most observers including the Consumers' Association, which recently set up an organisation to import cheaper cars from the continent. The car industry, unsurprisingly, warned that there was "little scope" for significant price reductions - but it may have to eat its words if consumers refuse to pay the higher prices and either delay new purchases or shop abroad.
fields.body:
The Competition Commission's conclusion that car prices in the UK are 10% to 12% more expensive than in Europe will come as no surprise to most observers including the Consumers' Association, which recently set up an organisation to import cheaper cars from the continent. The car industry, unsurprisingly, warned that there was "little scope" for significant price reductions - but it may have to eat its words if consumers refuse to pay the higher prices and either delay new purchases or shop abroad.

It is very difficult for the UK car industry to duck the effects of globalisation and the spread of the internet enabling customers to surf the globe for bargain buys. It may take some time to break the block exemption system that gives (temporary) EU protection to the anti-competitive exclusive dealer system. But it ought to be a simple matter for dealers to be forced to give consumers the large discounts of 17% to 35% that they offer some fleet customers (as opposed to un der 8% for a typical private customer). The downward pressure on prices is even stronger in other consumer sectors. People who know what they want to buy can search the internet for the cheapest and most reliable online shop for delivery. Consumer websites are popping up everywhere offering ever cheaper prices for "commodity" products like digital cameras, laptop computers, clothes, pet food and so on. Other sites gather customers together in consumer cooperatives to negotiate lower prices for larger quantities.

Car buyers will be the eventual beneficiaries of the huge "intranets" that manufacturers like Ford are building to cut up to 15% from component costs. The saving is bound to be passed on to consumers because of the way globalisation and the web are equalising prices across national barriers. But it is only when the majority of the population is online that we will truly realise the submerged power of the global consumer.

fields.headline: What's in store on privacy
fields.trailText: The issues raised in your report (BBC's secret film was invasion of store's privacy, April 7) goes beyond determining whether a company like Dixons can enjoy a right to privacy. They are of general public interest and importance, concerning the nature of privacy and whether the right to privacy extends to the filming of events in a place to which the public has free access. Liberty was granted permission to intervene in this case and made submissions contending that filming a person without his or her consent is a breach of the right of privacy because it interferes with the idea of personal autonomy or control every person has over his own identity. Many of the comments in the decision are to be welcomed, especially that it was open to the Broadcasting Standards Commission to decide that secret filming of an individual was in itself an infringement of privacy - consisting of depriving the person filmed of the possibility of refusing consent.

fields.headline: Star signs
fields.trailText:
You should apply the star rating used to rate arts reviews to news stories (Letters, April 10). A one-star story would merit little attention, but a five-star story, such as a huge natural disaster, would immediately gain our notice. The distribution of stars for news would be a more objective matter than in the case of the arts. Then perhaps you could see your way to dropping the use of stars on the arts pages, as I feel that they trivialise artistic endeavour. What is the point of rating a concert one has missed?
Roger Ollerhead
Beccles, Suffolk

fields.headline: Uncertain Korea path
fields.standfirst:
But summit is a step in the right direction

Korea Web Weekly
Democratic People's Republic of Korea
fields.trailText: The announcement that the North and South Korean heads of state have agreed to hold a first-ever summit meeting in June received a broad welcome yesterday. It was cheerful news for Japan, which has never quite got over the shock caused by North Korea's menacing ballistic missile test in 1998. China and Russia, Pyongyang's Cold War backers, both issued what sounded like a diplomatic sigh of relief. Russia recently renewed its friendship treaty with North Korea, but pointedly dropped a mutual defence clause. Chinese diplomats have long professed to be as puzzled as everybody else by North Korea's eccentric approach to international relations. The US, which still maintains a large garrison in South Korea, 50 years after the Korean war, and lists North Korea as a terrorist "rogue state", also made approving noises, as did countries in Asean - the regional group which North Korea has declined to join. As politicians reacted to a development few had anticipated, the word "historic" came readily to many lips.
fields.body:
The announcement that the North and South Korean heads of state have agreed to hold a first-ever summit meeting in June received a broad welcome yesterday. It was cheerful news for Japan, which has never quite got over the shock caused by North Korea's menacing ballistic missile test in 1998. China and Russia, Pyongyang's Cold War backers, both issued what sounded like a diplomatic sigh of relief. Russia recently renewed its friendship treaty with North Korea, but pointedly dropped a mutual defence clause. Chinese diplomats have long professed to be as puzzled as everybody else by North Korea's eccentric approach to international relations. The US, which still maintains a large garrison in South Korea, 50 years after the Korean war, and lists North Korea as a terrorist "rogue state", also made approving noises, as did countries in Asean - the regional group which North Korea has declined to join. As politicians reacted to a development few had anticipated, the word "historic" came readily to many lips.

The summit, if it goes ahead (unlike the last one planned in 1994), could indeed prove to be the long-sought watershed in a what has become a protracted, destructive and largely pointless dispute between kith and kin. The initiative fits with what appears to be a new policy of limited engagement pursued by North Korea's communist "Dear Leader", Kim Jong-il. Pyongyang has recently held bilateral talks with Japan and the US, and has opened diplomatic relations with Italy. Such moves may reflect a new awareness of global interdependence in a country of fabled isolation. Or they may reflect the sheer desperation of a leadership which cannot feed its people. North Korea's economy is said to have shrunk by up to 70% since the end of the Cold War and 200,000 people or more have died from famine and disease.

Much as we wish it, predictions of the "historic" dawn of a new era of peace and reconciliation on the Korean peninsula must be treated with caution. North Korea has repeatedly traded agreements on nuclear and missile curbs for economic assistance in recent years. With a South Korean general election due on Thursday, it may be that the summit - news of which will boost the ruling party at the polls - is offered on condition of a large-scale infusion of South Korean aid. Not so much a deliberate, seismic geopolitical shift, perhaps; more a matter of hungry tummies and political timing.

With a South Korean general election due on Thursday, it may be that the summit - news of which will boost the ruling party at the polls - is offered on condition of a large-scale infusion of South Korean aid. Not so much a deliberate, seismic geopolitical shift, perhaps; more a matter of hungry tummies and political timing.

fields.headline: Up front and personal
fields.standfirst: Big breasts might get you taken seriously if you're Julia Roberts. But it's time the truth was told about life in a E-cup, says  Louisa Young
fields.trailText: Big breasts might get you taken seriously if you're Julia Roberts. But it's time the truth was told about life in a E-cup, says  Louisa Young
fields.body:
Julia Roberts does not have very big bosoms. Cute, yes; large, no. So to give the impression of large-breastedness when she was playing the part of Erin Brockovich, who has very large bosoms, the make-up and costume people at Paramount gave her low-cut necklines, maximum-uplift bras and lots of glimpses of lace and straps.

The real Erin Brockovich does, apparently, dress in a flashy way, but, as she said in a recent interview: "Actually, I never show my bra. I wouldn't. It's not my style."

As a person of existent bosom, I find this interesting. I would love to conduct an experiment: take an outfit - say a pair of jeans and a sleeveless T-shirt. Polka dotty, to give it that fashionable touch. Put it on a flat- to medium-chested woman (up to a C-cup, say). Put the identical outfit on a more than C-cup woman. Which one looks fresh and groovy? Which one looks like a trashy show-off who's forgotten to put her shirt on? No prizes.

There's another facet of a woman's appearance that compares: body hair. If the small-breasted woman hasn't shaved her armpits, you get outcry (as we did when Ms Roberts didn't). But God forbid that a woman with big tits doesn't shave her armpits in this vest. Tramp! Slut! Yuk!

It's not too hard to get rid of that particular sign of female sexuality and maturity. Getting rid of tits is more difficult - but in many ways it's the same story. Our modern aesthetic likes women not to be big, we know that - but, specially, we mustn't be too big "there". Not outside the lapdancing club, anyway. Not if we want to be anything other than our tits.

I'm not saying it's not possible to be shadow home secretary, or top US diplomat, or famous agony aunt, when you have the bosoms; it depends how you wear them. But I am hard put to think of any woman who is at once successful in a "serious" post, has big ones, and is commonly held to be sexually attractive. The bosom for a pillow, yes. The bolster of authority, yes. But not phwooar, big tits. If you have them, and want to be more than the sum of them, be prepared to hide them away, because no way is anybody else going to ignore them.

If we are big "there", we are expected either to put them away and pretend we aren't - the saggy-shouldered, instant-neckache, baggy-jumper, low-self-esteem, saving-up-for-a-reduction look - or to put up with the fact that what is for us an everyday aspect of life is, to a lot of men, something so fantastic that they can't sit in the same room without coming over all funny. The idea that the breasts are passively sitting there during a meeting, say, rather than being an active sexual entertainment, is still alien to a lot of men.

So here, for the record, are a few facts about life over a D-cup. Bras are more expensive. They wear out and you have to buy new ones. You may need different sizes for different times of the month. You can't get them at Marks and Spencer (I was once told, when inquiring after a double D: "The only thing we have that big is the Minimiser." With a little sneer). You can't pull on a white vest on a sunny morning. You can't slip into a little spaghetti-strapped thing on a warm evening. You can't, between the ages of 12 and 40, walk past a building site without some bright yob informing you that you have large breasts (as if you'd never noticed). There is no way you could have have burned your bra for the revolution; you can't even go downstairs in the morning without support. You can't run for the bus without knowing deep in your heart that though you consider yourself a human being of dignity, onlookers will be thinking of Benny Hill. You will never be an Olympic athlete.

If a dress fits round the bum, it won't fit round the bust, and vice versa. You can't dress up to show off a little without looking worryingly like a tart.

You don't want to look like a tart. You'd like to look nice. You'd like to have done that visible underwear thing a year or two back; you'd like to wear a suede shirt open to the waist. A lot of fashion, unless you look pretty much like a boy, looks vulgar. Classy animal print on Kate Moss; Bet Lynch on you.

Things have got better. At least fashion pretends to love breasts sometimes - even if they're on a gazelle like Gisele. At least you can get some fabulous underwear by mail order from Bravissimo. But generally, the message remains the same: just what Julia Robert's costume people are telling us. Having big breasts is the same as flashing your undies: ooh, you tart.

webTitle: See you in a week, darling

fields.headline: See you in a week, darling
fields.standfirst: It's rejuvenating, less likely to end in a row and new research shows more and more women are doing it.  Nicky Holford on the rising appeal of holidaying alone
fields.trailText: It's rejuvenating, less likely to end in a row and new research shows more and more women are doing it.  Nicky Holford on the rising appeal of holidaying alone
fields.body:
Carol Esslemont remembers lying in a mud bath in Abano Terme, a small spa town in northern Italy near Padova. She'd left her children and husband at home in Britain but she didn't feel guilty. "About five years ago I started going on holiday alone," she says. "At first I felt guilty for a few days, now I don't waste so much time."

Women are travelling alone. Not just single women, but mothers and wives are finding the benefits of taking time out for themselves. A survey carried out by NOP for insurers Directline.com reveals that not only are more women travelling alone but that many of them are leaving their husbands and children behind.

"I don't go to get away from my family," explains Carol, "but I love the time to myself. I'm 47 in May, had my first child at 17 and was always, and still am, family orientated. But for that little moment in time, 10 days, it was just me and I didn't have to worry about anyone. I just took a break from all the problems and worries and stresses and it was fantastic."

Carol's break in northern Italy set up a pattern of holidaying alone which she looks forward to every year. She's planning another 10-day break in July.

"At first I was scared to go by myself and felt a bit selfish. But it did my confidence a lot of good. I felt I was thrown in at the deep end but I've made a lot of friends from all over the word. It was such a polarisation in as much as I'd done everything for my family and suddenly I discovered this other world where you just had to be responsible for yourself and it was so refreshing. I love opera and my husband doesn't. He was a little bit insecure in the beginning but he trusts me."

Juggling home, family and work is a lifestyle many women are accustomed to, but more and more realise that to remain sane they need time to themselves. "Women today are different from my mother's generation," says Anita Avery, who works as an office manager and PA for a marketing company and is married with two children. "It's important to feel good about yourself and you are not just there to look after everybody else. I've noticed many of my friends are going away on their own or with girlfriends. You have to make time to do things for yourself. It's a way of staying sane. I think your family appreciates you more if you do make time for yourself."

Anita first went on a short break alone when treated to a few days at a health spa. "Since then, I've noticed that a lot of my friends take short breaks on their own. I think women now are thinking: I do have some money and it's important to do something for myself. A friend of mine goes to New York on shopping trips. This November I'm going, too."

The NOP survey shows many changing trends in holiday habits. Not only are more women leaving their loved ones behind but they are also booking more holidays on the internet. According to the survey taken of 15- to 65-year-olds across Britain, 53% of women book their holiday online compared with 47% of men. Barbara Mclaughlin, who takes one holiday herself and another with her partner, says she will probably book her main holiday on the internet.

"The internet means you can access companies abroad, it gives you much more information. It's a much more convenient way of doing business." Barbara, who runs a regeneration initiative in Hume, Manchester, knows how important quality time to herself is. "I work very long hours and weekends. My job could be 24-hours a day if I let it. It's a job I love but it's both time and mentally consuming. I'm a committed flamencoist and recently went to Granada on a dance holiday. It was wonderful; the holiday mixed flamenco teaching, entertainment and beautiful cities."

"I don't have any children and flamenco has been one of the ways of claiming back my own time. My husband is delighted I can do it - he doesn't reciprocate, he's perfectly happy at home without me."

Four out of five women interviewed in the NOP survey said that arguments increase most when couples go on holiday. "It's not surprising," says Anita Avery. "At home, most couples go out to work for eight hours or more a day then on holiday you are suddenly together for 24 hours. My husband and I went to the Caribbean for two weeks and the first week we argued the entire time. There's bound to be a disagreement about something. Mostly it centred on our teenage daughter and the boundaries we should set for her."

"That's why when you go on your own it's so easy. I find many of my friends in their mid-30s go away. You get to that stage where you have your family and are in a long-term relationship and there's no harm in having a bit of time to do what you want and catch up with friends which you can't do with a partner. Family holidays can be such a fraught time."

As package holiday giant Thomson Travel last week launched a recovery strategy to stem falling profits and a see off a hostile takeover bid, debates raged over the death of the package holiday. It's clear there's been a fundamental change in what we want from our holidays. The lone woman traveller has no intention of languishing in Benidorm, so Thomson and their like would do well to sit up and take note. After all, she's where the profits are.

fields.headline: Supermarket pays sacked HIV employee £300,000
fields.trailText: A supermarket manager refused his job back after being diagnosed with HIV yesterday won an estimated £300,000 compensation, the highest sum awarded under disability discrimination laws.
fields.body:
A supermarket manager refused his job back after being diagnosed with HIV yesterday won an estimated £300,000 compensation, the highest sum awarded under disability discrimination laws.

Mark Hedley, 34, reached the settlement with German-owned Aldi ahead of an employment tribunal hearing in Newcastle upon Tyne.

The cut-price grocery chain is believed to have paid up to avoid damaging publicity after claiming staff had refused to work with the gay manager and warning his illness might put customers off.

The award is by far the largest in an HIV employment case.

His lawyer called for loopholes in anti-discrimination legislation to be closed and gay rights campaigners said it sent a clear signal to employers that prejudice would prove expensive.

Mr Hedley, who lives in Gateshead, Tyne and Wear, said: "I'm glad it's over and my life can move on.

"I'll take my mother on holiday to Florida because it's been a strain for her and I'm looking for another job." A confidentiality agreement prevented both sides from discussing the size of the settlement.

Mr Hedley had won plaudits from superiors but was barred in February last year from returning to his £34,000 job running Aldi's store in Seaham, Co. Durham.

He had been diagnosed HIV positive in November, 1998, and felt fit to go back after treatment.

Yet he was advised by the company to leave and sent on gardening leave.

Mr Hedley sued Aldi, alleging disability and sex discrimination, after the firm made disputed claims that staff did not want to work with him and profits would suffer.

About 20,000 people in Britain have been diagnosed with HIV, four fifths of them men.

Aldi's evidence submitted before the scheduled tribunal hearing said: "The decision to ask the applicant to remain away from work was justified in all the circumstances of the case given the nature of the applicant's condition, the fact that other staff in the same store said they would be uncomfortable with working with the applicant and the respondent's genuine and understandable concern that if the applicant remained in situ sales at the store would suffer."

Mr Hedley's solicitor, Stefan Cross, of the employment specialists Thompsons, called for the 1995 Disability Discrimination Act to be tightened to protect all employees from "prejudice and stigma" triggered by a diagnosis.

"This case raised significant legal issues, particularly related to the protection of people with progressive conditions - not only HIV."

The previous highest award under the act was £167,000 secured 18 months ago by a British Sugar worker with bad eyesight who was made redundant.

An agreed statement from Mr Hedley and Aldi was released yesterday.

It said: "After constructive discussions between the parties, terms have been agreed between Aldi and Mr Hedley in respect of those allegations and it has been agreed that his employment with Aldi will end by mutual consent.

"The parties have agreed to keep the detail of their agreement confidential."

webTitle: Noye's wife says police told her 'We won't rest till he gets life'

fields.headline: Noye's wife says police told her 'We won't rest till he gets life'
fields.trailText: The wife of Kenneth Noye, the man accused of murder in a road rage attack on the M25, told the Old Bailey yesterday that detectives once warned her they would not rest until her husband was jailed for life.
fields.body:
The wife of Kenneth Noye, the man accused of murder in a road rage attack on the M25, told the Old Bailey yesterday that detectives once warned her they would not rest until her husband was jailed for life.

Brenda Noye said she was approached in the Old Bailey foyer shortly after her husband, 52, had been acquitted of murdering Detective Constable John Fordham, an undercover officer stabbed to death in the grounds of Noye's house 15 years go. "They told me they would not rest until they saw him spend the rest of his life in prison, and that they would destroy my family."

She said her husband could not expect a fair trial in Britain because the police and press had "blackened" his name.

Noye, of West Kingsdown, Kent, denies murdering Stephen Cameron, 21, at the Swanley interchange of the M25 on May 19 1996. He admits stabbing Mr Cameron twice, but claims he was acting in self-defence.

Mrs Noye said her husband returned home after the fight sporting a cut nose, a badly battered face, swollen eyes and a large bump on his forehead.

She said she was sorry Mr Cameron had died, but had supported her husband's decision to flee the country.

She was in touch with her husband while he was on the run. Under cross-examination by Julian Bevan QC, she described her husband as an honest and "very honourable" man.

Another witness, Sean Johnson, told how Mr Cameron "went mental" when his fiancee, Danielle Cable, crashed his car. "He was shouting and bawling and calling her names," said Mr Johnson, who had a long-term relationship with Michelle Cable, Danielle's aunt.

He described challenging Danielle over a newspaper story which said Mr Cameron only shook his head when Noye's Land Rover Discovery had pulled in front of the couple's van, driven by Ms Cable, then 17.

He said he reminded Ms Cable of Mr Cameron's temper. She allegedly replied: "What do you expect me to say?"

Under cross-examination, Mr Johnson admitted having a previous conviction for attempting to rob a post office with a sawn-off shotgun. He also admitted smuggling £100,000 worth of cannabis to Britain. He now lives in Marbella, next door to Gordon Goody, a Great Train Robber.

Mr Johnson said Noye's son Kevin had approached him in Spain "in search of information". He had paid for him to fly to Britain and stay in a hotel for a week so he could give a statement to a solicitor.

Asked when he had last seen Kevin, he said: "Last night."

The case continues today.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Experienced lovers only | Supermarket sweep
fields.body:
Call Sidelines hum-drum, but nowadays, far from the achievement-orientated 80s, is it really necessary to judge a shag on how difficult one's chosen position is to acheive? Take this month's Cosmopolitan: "Naughty nine sex positions for experienced lovers only" which insists on giving each "embrace" a rating on its degree of difficulty. It marks The Carnal Crossing and Side Swiped the easiest, coming in at a number five and the Cosmo Angel and The Pinwheel rather more difficult at eight. Whatever happened to the slow comfortable screw where numbers are notable only by their absence? In Cosmo-world the concept has been banished to the cocktail bar. What the hell is a pinwheel anyway?

 Next time you're dragging your single basket around the supermarket, spare a thought for those store schemes designed to set you up with a love match while deciding which brand of toilet bleach would best match your bathroom suite. More than half of the men asked in a new survey said they regularly visit the supermarket and over a third take the main responsibility for the food shopping. Far from being single, the majority of men regularly spotted in the aisles are in a relationship. The survey by Neff also shows that over half of the men said their partner or wife provides the list, thus proving that old saying: behind every man in the supermarket is an organised woman.

Take this month's Cosmopolitan: "Naughty nine sex positions for experienced lovers only" which insists on giving each "embrace" a rating on its degree of difficulty. It marks The Carnal Crossing and Side Swiped the easiest, coming in at a number five and the Cosmo Angel and The Pinwheel rather more difficult at eight. Whatever happened to the slow comfortable screw where numbers are notable only by their absence? In Cosmo-world the concept has been banished to the cocktail bar. What the hell is a pinwheel anyway?  Next time you're dragging your single basket around the supermarket, spare a thought for those store schemes designed to set you up with a love match while deciding which brand of toilet bleach would best match your bathroom suite. More than half of the men asked in a new survey said they regularly visit the supermarket and over a third take the main responsibility for the food shopping. Far from being single, the majority of men regularly spotted in the aisles are in a relationship. fields.headline: Attenborough solves Easter Island mystery
fields.trailText: A wooden Easter Island carving owned by Sir David Attenborough for a decade has been linked to Captain Cook's great voyage of Pacific discovery in 1774.
fields.body:
A wooden Easter Island carving owned by Sir David Attenborough for a decade has been linked to Captain Cook's great voyage of Pacific discovery in 1774.

How a carved lump of extinct wood from an abandoned culture found its way from Easter Island in the 18th century to a broadcaster's home in Surrey is an anthropological detective story to be told in a documentary at Easter. The link is a Tahitian boy who sailed with the great explorer.

"Cook is my ideal man. He starts off as an unlettered Yorkshire lad as an apprentice on a collier, joins the navy on the lower deck, becomes a lieutenant in his 20s, teaches himself mathematics and becomes one of the great navigators, and discovers half the world as far as Europe is concerned," said Sir David.

"He is a strict disciplinarian, but with extraordinary humanity, and he treats all the people he meets with great forbearance and respect. He's the ideal human being. He treated his crew marvellously. He is just a wonderful man."

The carving - an emaciated figurine of an Easter Island fertility god - turned up in a New York auction room. "I bought it for nothing really. Well, quite enough to make my pockets shrivel a bit," he said. It was made of toromiro wood, which grew only on Easter Island - and became extinct 50 years ago.

Sir David could find only one similar carving, in a St Petersburg museum. Nobody knew how it got there; only that it had come from the Russian admiralty museum in 1826.

But while leafing through a three volume collection of the art of Cook's voyages, Sir David found a drawing of the St Petersburg figurine. He found another clue in the journals of Johann Forster, the naturalist who sailed with Cook.

"How could that be?" he said. "I looked in Cook's journals. Nothing. But if you look in Forster's journal there is, to my surprise, a precise description of these wooden figures. They are elongated, too long to be natural, made out of brown wood, grotesque but at the same time very artistic. OK, so how the hell did it get to Russia?"

Forster's journal reports that although carvings were offered as barter, the only person to take any was Cook's young Tahitian interpreter Mahine. "They sail back to Tahiti and drop Mahine and do their astronomical work and there is an absolutely precise description of how Mahine, poor devil, arrived home and all his relations, of whom there were thousands, demanded to have something he bought back. They stripped him of everything he had, including those figures," Sir David said.

The Russian Antarctic explorer Bellingshausen visited Tahiti. By that time, the islanders were Christian: once-sacred carvings had no value. Bellingshausen's journal records that Tahiti's King Pomare begged the Russians for linen. "There is a marvellous account of Pomare going on board the Vostok, Bellingshausen's ship, and he strips the sheets of Bellingshausen's bunk and so clearly he would have offered anything he could find, and what more likely than these bits of tat lying around from some place he had never heard of?"

Sir David returned to St Petersburg, and linked the museum's statuette with Bellingshausen. "What about mine? The grotesqueries, the goggling eyes, the crests are so similar it is impossible to believe the person who carved one was unaware of the other. They are twins: male and female partners."

The Lost Gods of Easter Island will be screened on Easter Sunday, April 23, on BBC2.

webTitle: Police hold four as baby fights for his life

fields.headline: Police hold four as baby fights for his life
fields.trailText: A baby was fighting for his life last night after being found with severe head injuries in his pram at a Metro station close to the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne.
fields.body:
A baby was fighting for his life last night after being found with severe head injuries in his pram at a Metro station close to the centre of Newcastle upon Tyne.

The five-month-old was injured in an incident on Sunday on the platform at Manors station. He is believed to have been with his father at the time.

Police made four arrests yesterday after appealing for information about a gang of youths allegedly at the station shortly before an emergency call at 4.20pm to police and ambulance crews.

Appeals for information were broadcast all day on the Metro and commuters were turned away from Manors, which was locked with police on guard.

The baby is in intensive care at Newcastle general hospital, with detectives waiting for the results of medical tests to get a clearer picture of the cause of his injuries.

Northumbria police said: "The baby, who is not being identified, was with an adult in the station.

"For reasons which have yet to be fully established he has suffered head injuries believed to have taken place on the platform. Exactly what happened in the Metro station is still being investigated."

Police have interviewed the child's parents and are examining security camera videos which cover the rapid-transit Metro system on Tyneside.

The incident caused shock in the area not just because of the brutality involved, but because the Metro is well staffed and has a good reputation for security.

Detective Superintendent Chris Symonds, who is leading the inquiry, said: "We are treating this as a very serious incident."
