fields.headline: National roundup
fields.trailText:
£40bn plea to improve UK's roads
An extra £40bn needs to be spent on roads over the next 10 years to ensure a quality network, a report says today. Average annual expenditure on roads needs to rise from £5.1bn in 1999-2000 to £9.1bn a year over the next 10 years, according to the British Road Federation.
fields.body:
£40bn plea to improve UK's roads
An extra £40bn needs to be spent on roads over the next 10 years to ensure a quality network, a report says today. Average annual expenditure on roads needs to rise from £5.1bn in 1999-2000 to £9.1bn a year over the next 10 years, according to the British Road Federation.

"This package needs to be implemented if the government is going to deliver on its promise of a world class transport system for Britain," said federation director Richard Diment.

The report, Roads - Investing in Britain's Prosperity, said that over the next decade around £75bn should be spent in England, £10bn in Scotland and £5bn in Wales. Most of this money should go on maintaining, improving and making best use of the existing network, with a limited new road construction.

Priorities should include eliminating the £5bn backlog in local road repairs and the implementation of "long overdue" bypasses. Maintenance should be a priority on motorways and trunk roads, where greater use should be made of new technology to increase traffic flow and improve safety.

Mr Diment said: "It will cost billions to put things right ... Investment in the road infrastructure and, where necessary, improvements and additions will not only secure our economic well-being and quality of life but actually improve them."

£55,000 tag on 1890s posters
A collection of seven posters by the Art Nouveau artist Alphonse Mucha, rolled in roofing felt and abandoned for decades in a coach house in southern England, is expected to fetch up to the £55,000 at auction.

Five of the 1890s posters depict the French actress Sarah Bernhardt, with whom he is rumoured to have a romantic liaison.

The earliest, estimated to realise up to £8,000 at Christie's in London on May 25, was commissioned on Boxing Day 1894 by the manager of the Theatre de la Renaissance in Paris to promote Bernhardt's performance in Gismonda.

An 1896 poster for Bern hardt's production of La Dame aux Camelias should also realise up to £8,000, while one for de Musset's play Lorenzaccio, also at the Theatre de la Renaissance, may go for up to £7,000. A poster for La Samaritaine (1897), written for Bernhardt by Edmond Rostand, one of her lovers, is estimated at up to £6,000. Two other Mucha posters - one for a cocoa-based medicine and another for a French beer - make up the collection.

Details of the find are being kept secret by Christie's at the request of the owner.

Neighbour accused of killing cat
Edward Masters killed his neighbours' pedigree cat Jade by setting an illegal noose with wire in his hedge, it was alleged at Yeovil magistrates court yesterday.

Masters denies setting an illegal snare and causing unnecessary suffering to a cat.

His neighbour, Alison Ruddle, told the court that in November last year she found Jade strangled with its neck caught in a snare in the hedge between the two properties in Yeovil, Somerset.

Her husband, Paul, knocked on Masters's door but he denied any knowledge of the snare.

Mr Ruddle called the police and the RSPCA who inspected Masters's garden.

The court heard that Masters was interviewed by RSPCA officers and admitted using curry powder, orange peel and bottles of water to stop cats entering his garden.

Masters said: "I have had to clean faeces off the lawn - I expect it was from cats."

RSPCA Inspector Guy Harrison said: "The hedge had strands of fishing wire and garden twine running through it. In the soil directly under the hedge I found shards of glass placed so they were pointing upwards.I made a thorough search of the garden looking for other evidence. There was a small garden gate and on the top it had lengths of carpet gripper nailed onto it."

Masters told RSPCA these were to stop human intruders.

The case continues.

Parents' plea for donor heart
A nationwide appeal has gone out for a donor heart to save the life of Tace Corcoran-Rees of Cardiff, who has just had her first birthday.

Doctors say her condition is critical and she has only days to live unless a heart can be found.

Tace's heart was weakened after a viral infection when she was 10 weeks old, her parents, Kirsti Corcoran and Derek Rees, said.

Tace, who weighs just 13lb, was admitted to hospital with heart problems last week, four days after her first birthday. She was is intensive care at the University hospital of Wales, Cardiff.

Her heart failure has brought on kidney problems and she is on dialysis. An air ambulance is on standby to fly her to Harefield hospital, Cambridge, if a donor heart becomes available.

The intensive care consultant, George Findlay, said: "She is a desperately unwell child and needs a donor very soon.

"She is very heavily sedated but she's comfortable and pain free."

Tace was in a "critical but stable condition" yesterday.

Steamed up over waste of energy
British workers drink 501m cups of tea every week, according to government statistics - and an estimated £48.9m worth of electricity is being needlessly boiled away every year in London alone by people over-filling kettles and failing to turn off appliances.

Launching a government campaign to encourage people to help save energy, the environment minister, Michael Meacher, said: "Small actions such as only using as much water as you need when boiling the kettle or turning off computers, monitors and printers at night can make such a difference."

The campaign is expected to last three years at a cost of £25m.

Woman jailed for air attack
A woman who became drunk on Bacardi and punched a member of the cabin crew on a flight to Florida was jailed for six months yesterday.

Doris Healy, 56, a care worker from Liverpool, swore in front of children, became abusive, and repeatedly pressed the call button for attention, Manchester crown court was told.

As the Air 2000 aircraft came in to land, she stood up and, when asked to sit down, struck flight attendant Paula Dilworth three times in the face. The court heard Mrs Healy was so drunk she had to be taken off the plane in a wheelchair.

Mrs Healy admitted being drunk on an aircraft and common assault. Judge Anthony Ensor told her: "It is a tragedy for you and your family that you should have acted totally out of character on this occasion."

Joanna Radikis, prosecuting, said the cabin crew noticed that Mrs Healy was "somewhat merry" and ordered she should not be served any more drinks.

But she had bought a bottle of duty-free Bacardi at Manchester airport, which was later found three-quarters empty under her seat.

Ms Radikis said that as a result of the assault, Ms Dilworth had experienced nightmares and lack of sleep, had been off work for three weeks, and was looking for a new job.

Gerald Baxter, defending, said: "[Mrs Healy] is extremely distressed about her appearance here and extremely ashamed of her behaviour."

Mrs Healy's husband, Thomas, told the court: "She feels ashamed now because of this thing and she doesn't remember. She would never do anything to hurt a stewardess." David Ward

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Woman charged over poisoning
A 35-year-old woman has been charged in connection with the poisoning of a girl of eight who fell into a coma after swallowing massive doses of salt.
fields.body:
Woman charged over poisoning
A 35-year-old woman has been charged in connection with the poisoning of a girl of eight who fell into a coma after swallowing massive doses of salt.

The girl is in Edinburgh's Royal hospital for sick children where her condition is "stable". She is under the care of social services.

Lothian and Borders police yesterday said they arrested and charged the woman, who is believed to suffer from the attention-seeking disorder Munchausen's syndrome by proxy.

Police officer dies in crash
A police constable, aged 34, was killed and another seriously injured when a 17-ton lorry ploughed into the back of a patrol car in Buckinghamshire yesterday.

The officers stationed at Aylesbury, were on a driving refresher course when the accident happened on the A418 at Gibraltar, near Cuddington, Bucks. The injured officer, who was driving, was airlifted to the John Radcliffe hospital at Oxford.

No buyer for Hockney snaps
A signed album of holiday photographs by artist David Hockney yesterday failed to find a buyer at the Scarborough auction house David Duggleby.

The painter took the photographs during visits to Bridlington, East Yorkshire. A mystery vendor expected at least £4,000 but the highest bid was £3,700 and the album was withdrawn.

33% 'take drugs at work'
One in three people have taken drugs - including ecstasy, cocaine, acid, speed, cannabis and poppers - during work time, according to a survey published in Time Out magazine today.

The survey shows a third of people have driven under the influence of drugs.

fields.headline: Animal protesters besiege pensioner
fields.trailText: A pensioner's home yesterday became the unlikely setting for an animal rights protest in an attempt by activists to force the 70-year-old man into selling his shares in a animal testing laboratory.
fields.body:
A pensioner's home yesterday became the unlikely setting for an animal rights protest in an attempt by activists to force the 70-year-old man into selling his shares in a animal testing laboratory.

Four protesters arrived at the large detached house of David Braybrook, on the outskirts of Huntingdon, Cambridgeshire, at midday yesterday, where they held a peaceful protest, holding up a placard adorned with the picture of a beagle.

The campaigners have threatened to maintain their vigil round the clock until Mr Braybrook sells his shares in Huntingdon Life Sciences, which operates Europe's biggest animal experimental laboratory.

The protest follows letters sent to all 1,700 of the company's shareholders, warning them to sell up or face the prospect of activists gathering outside their homes.

The protesters claim around 250 shareholders have already sold their shares following the letters, while the company's share price has dipped from around 20p to 13.5p as a result of publicity surrounding the campaign.

Mr Braybrook is alleged to hold almost 20,000 shares in the company, worth around £2,700. Yesterday he said he had no objections to a peaceful demonstration outside his home but was concerned that extremists might become involved.

"They have their freedom of rights and I believe I do too," he said. "They want me to sell my shares so they can bring the company down, but I don't want to do that at the moment. I feel I have the freedom to buy and sell shares.

"I'm concerned there might be extremists out there. We know what's happened at Huntingdon Life Sciences, where demonstrators have followed workers home, and I think that is an infringement of people's private rights."

The campaigners defended their right to protest outside Mr Braybrook's home, claiming the action was intended to prick his and other people's conscience about the ethical implications in investing in companies involved in animal testing.

Andrew Gay, marketing director at Huntingdon Life Sciences, said: "It is outrageous that these people can be threatened in their own home. We have had phone calls from shareholders, particularly elderly people, who say they feel threatened.

"The people who are selling are selling at a loss but the big institutions are going to make money."

The activists used shareholder lists available at Companies House which detail names and addresses.

The letter, sent out by a faction called the Group With No Name, was accompanied by a "factsheet" listing campaigners' allegations against the company.

A spokesman for the group said: "Every shareholder has been sent literature explaining what goes on at Huntingdon. Many were disgusted and have sold up.

"Those who have not have made a conscious decision to invest in cruelty, and we will make sure they are named and shamed in their communities."

A spokesman for the group said: "Every shareholder has been sent literature explaining what goes on at Huntingdon. Many were disgusted and have sold up. "Those who have not have made a conscious decision to invest in cruelty, and we will make sure they are named and shamed in their communities."

webTitle: Fresh doubts about the future of the established church

fields.headline: Fresh doubts about the future of the established church
fields.standfirst: Religion in the UK: special report
fields.trailText: The long-term prospects for the Church of England's survival as the established religion of the state receded yesterday after a report commissioned by the Home Office raised fresh doubts about the viability of the link.
fields.body:
The long-term prospects for the Church of England's survival as the established religion of the state receded yesterday after a report commissioned by the Home Office raised fresh doubts about the viability of the link.

The report questioned the "historically rooted religious disadvantage" suffered by other faiths and denominations in an increasingly diverse culture. It even questioned the suitability of the coronation rituals - last used in 1953 and said by some to pre-date the Norman conquest.

The home secretary, Jack Straw, commissioned the report from a University of Derby research unit. It was asked to look at religious discrimination against individuals in work, school and society.

Last night the Home Office gave the results a cautious welcome. It was an interim report involving "a lot of complex issues", officials stressed. But there was a predictably hostile reaction from traditionalists. The project will re-examine the effects of Britain's ceremonies and institutions on other Christian denominations and faiths. Their exclusively Protestant stress, which dates from when it was identified with political liberty against Catholic autocracies in France and Spain, is at odds with the secular mood of today.

Paul Weller, who led the research, said: "The interim report is saying the coronation is an event which symbolically focuses a lot of issues around national identity.

"The Church of England has a prime role but beyond that, within the Christian tradition and more broadly, it raises questions about what role they might have. These are questions that weren't in sharp focus in the 1950s as there was no minority population of the size we have today."

The Prince of Wales, who is forbidden by law from marrying a Catholic, caused controversy among traditionalists when he suggested he wanted to become "defender of faith" - rather than one faith as the coronation oath required his mother to be.

Leftwingers, who used to regard the Church of England as the "Conservative party at prayer," have long campaigned for disestablishment, even though the church has taken stances against free market excess in recent years.

Others have moved towards this position, including clergy. George Carey, the Archbishop of Canterbury, was quoted this week as predicting it would happen.

Partial Lords reform has also highlighted the problem by suggesting the 26 senior bishops be joined by representatives of other faiths and denominations.

Professor Weller's report, the final version of which is due in the autumn, said: "Looking to the future, coronations are state events which, historically, have expressed the close symbolic relationship between established religion and the state."

webTitle: Researchers on track of memory pill

fields.headline: Researchers on track of memory pill
fields.trailText: Scientists believe they could be on the track of a memory pill to help learning and memory in old age.
fields.body:
Scientists believe they could be on the track of a memory pill to help learning and memory in old age.

A team led by Karl Peter Giese at the new £50m Wolfson Institute at University College London, formally opened yesterday, have found a way to make old mice solve learning and memory tasks as swiftly as young mice.

Nobody knows what memory is, but researchers have begun to identify bits of chemical machinery in the brain that are linked with making and retrieving memories. With colleagues in California, Dr Giese has identified a potassium channel gene in the brain which affects learning and memory, benignly in early life, and adversely in later life.

"If the gene functions normally, there are difficulties in learning in old age. However, if the gene is inactive, then learning and memory in old age remain the same as in young age," he said yesterday. "We want to use pharmacology to mimic the same effects."

Yesterday scientists at the University of Illinois reported, in the latest Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences, that a single gene known as p21 could be involved in a number of age-related diseases, including cancer, atherosclerosis, arthritis and Alzheimer's. This also raises hopes that a drug could repair some of the damages of time.

The Wolfson Institute scientists have yet to work out why a gene that helps the young, by controlling flexibility in learning, should then go on to shut down memory in the elderly.

webTitle: CPS admits debacle as case against police is halted

fields.headline: CPS admits debacle as case against police is halted
fields.trailText: The crown prosecution service admitted yesterday that mismanagement and overwork had wrecked a big inquiry into claims of assault and corruption at the central police station in Derby.
fields.body:
The crown prosecution service admitted yesterday that mismanagement and overwork had wrecked a big inquiry into claims of assault and corruption at the central police station in Derby.

A judge yesterday threw out charges, including wounding, assault and perverting the course of justice, against three officers, ruling that the men could not get a fair trial because "unjustifiable delays" meant that key witnesses could no longer be traced.

A series of other allegations about police behaviour in the city, which partly accounted for the CPS workload, have failed to reach court, although 15 officers have attended internal disciplinary hearings.

The police complaints authority is also considering taking action against a number of staff at Derby's Full Street station.

The collapse of the case is particularly embarrassing for the CPS, because the police inquiry was considered so serious and sensitive that it was supervised by the police complaints authority.

Judge Peter Baker QC told Sheffield crown court that the police inquiry itself had been "detailed and careful", involving 298 statements and 640 other documents. The CPS said yesterday that its procedures had been changed as a result of the debacle, and that speedier reviews of such high profile cases "should now be ensured".

Publicly sensitive cases would in future be allocated by senior management to individual CPS lawyers, rather than being passed around colleagues.

The officers who walked free were involved in three complaints of alleged assault three years ago and subsequent claims of a cover up.

Sgt Louis Martin, 32, was accused of attacking Naweed Akram in the back of a police car and then lying about the incident.

PC Ian Parker, 40, was also accused of lying about Mr Akram and of using a spray weapon on another Derby man, James Fitzsimons.

Sgt David Simmonds, 36, was accused of assaulting a third man, Paul Gilbert, with a baton.

The case was halted after a defence submission that proceeding with the trial would be an abuse of legal process. Judge Baker said: "It seems to me that there is a very real prospect of there being serious prejudice because of the non-availability of witnesses.

"Police officers are not entitled to any favours but, on the other hand, they should not be in a worse position than an ordinary member of the public because they happen to be police officers."

Stephen Holt, prosecuting, accepted there had been a serious delay but defended police handling of the matters, which were part of a larger investigation into the Derby force.

The workload at the CPS meant that the complicated issues were passed from office to office within the service, resulting in months of delay.

The CPS said later: "We are conscious of the comments made by the judge.

"These cases resulted from a much wider police inquiry which necessarily required review both by CPS lawyers and independent counsel. Since these cases, CPS procedures have been changed and should now ensure a speedier review process."

webTitle: Call to set up national hip implant registry

fields.headline: Call to set up national hip implant registry
fields.trailText: The UK should set up a national hip registry to help monitor the long-term performance of implants, a government advisory body recommended yesterday, and the NHS should not use artificial joints that are not proven to last at least 10 years.
fields.body:
The UK should set up a national hip registry to help monitor the long-term performance of implants, a government advisory body recommended yesterday, and the NHS should not use artificial joints that are not proven to last at least 10 years.

The recommendations from the national institute for clinical excellence follow the scandal two years ago over the failure of a hip joint called the Capital 3M.

The artificial hips had been implanted in some 4,700 patients.

Efforts were made to contact them after academics discovered that the prosthesis could come loose in the body and erode healthy bone, but the records held by hospitals were incomplete and while 98% were tracked down, a few hundred have not been traced. A spokeswoman for 3M Health Care, manufacturers of the joint, said it was possible they had since died.

The institute was asked to look at the cost and clinical effectiveness of hip replacements as a priority because of the large number of joints on the market, some of which were more effective than others. They cost between £400 and £2,000 each.

The institute said yesterday that the NHS could save up to £8m a year by using effective but less expensive joints.

The best artificial hips last for at least 10 years in 90% of cases.

The NHS should buy only implants that meet this benchmark criteria, said Nice. New devices coming on to the market which were thought to be potentially superior should have at least a three-year track record before they were used in the NHS.

The government yesterday sent Nice's guidance to all orthopaedic surgeons and hospital trusts, but said setting up a national hip registry "raises a number of practical and legal issues".

The cost of such an enterprise is thought to be high.

fields.headline: Island loses its big cheese
fields.trailText: The Italians considered it such a powerful aphrodisiac they banned it in the 1960s. But this reputation will not save Islay cheese from ceasing to exist by the end of this year.
fields.body:
The Italians considered it such a powerful aphrodisiac they banned it in the 1960s. But this reputation will not save Islay cheese from ceasing to exist by the end of this year.

The slump in dairy farming and supermarket pricing have forced the closure of the creamery at Port Charlotte on the Hebridean island that produces the distinctive mild cheese. More than 800 milking cows are being shipped to the mainland for slaughter or sale, and all that remains of the brand is eight or nine months worth of maturing rounds.

Receivers called in two weeks ago have been unable to find a prospective buyer.

"What's happened to us is symptomatic of the decline of the dairy industry," said the creamery manager, Jack Phillips, yesterday.

For the island's 3,000-strong community, the creamery's closure has been a body blow. It was taken over as a limited company with eight farmers as shareholders four years ago.

"It's not just the eight jobs directly involved," said Mr Phillips. "There will be no tanker driver needed for the milk, possibly one less mechanic at the garage; one of the farmers has laid off four dairy workers with young families, that's maybe less kids going to the rural school. There may be about 30 jobs that go in all. And 30 jobs in a population of 3,000 puts it on a par with Rover."

webTitle: Nurse 'killed by colleague with rape drug'

fields.headline: Nurse 'killed by colleague with rape drug'
fields.trailText: A male nurse who drugged women in hospital to rape and sexually assault them killed a female colleague when the drug he illicitly administered caused her heart to stop, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.
fields.body:
A male nurse who drugged women in hospital to rape and sexually assault them killed a female colleague when the drug he illicitly administered caused her heart to stop, the Old Bailey heard yesterday.

Susan Annis, 31, was found dead in November 1996 in nurses' accommodation at the Royal Brompton hospital in London, where she had been attending a course with Kevin Cobb, then a nurse at St Peter's hospital, Chertsey, Surrey.

The court was told the pair had spent the evening eating and drinking, and Cobb slipped the anaesthetic Midazolam into a drink in order to rape her.

Ms Annis had a mild heart complaint which caused an adverse reaction to the drug. She suffered palpitations and was declared dead.

The cause of death was initially inconclusive despite a postmortem examination that revealed Midazolam.

Two years later, however, Cobb was allegedly seen sexually assaulting a female patient at St Peter's. Police traced two other women the prosecution claim were also drugged and raped at the hospital by Cobb, and he was arrested in July last year, it was stated.

Cobb, 38, who is married to a GP, denies one charge of manslaughter, four charges of administering a stupefying drug to commit rape, four charges of administering a stupefying drug to commit an indecent assault, and two charges of rape.

Victor Temple, QC, prosecuting said: "This defendant carried out a systematic course of conduct, abusing his position of trust towards patients and colleagues.

"On four occasions, he secretly administered Midazolam to young women. One was a fellow nurse Susan Annis. The remaining three were patients at St Peter's who had come to the accident and emergency department.

"His underlying reason was one of sexual gratification. Not withstanding that it caused the death of Susan Annis, who suffered an adverse and fatal reaction, the defendant carried on undeterred until his arrest in January 1999."

Midazolam was used in minor surgery and as a sedative, particularly for young children, the court heard. It was administered intravenously or orally in solution, and is widely used in accident and emergency departments.

It takes effect within minutes and in larger doses can be dangerous.

The court was told an antidote was always kept at hand during its use. Taken with alcohol it could cause a deeply comatose state and retard the breathing. Crucially for Cobb's purposes, said Mr Temple, a further side effect could be memory loss.

"For an ill-intentioned person, this drug clearly has its attractions. It is not difficult to appreciate how it could be used to take sexual advantage of a defenceless woman, who could then have difficulty in recall and who could leave herself open to the suggestion that it was part of a sexual fantasy," he said.

Ms Annis, who worked at a hospital in Crawley, met Cobb when the pair attended a paediatric care course at the Royal Brompton hospital. They were given rooms opposite each other and in the evening shared a takeaway in his room. The court heard that the defendant claimed Ms Annis drank three cans of cider and fell asleep on his bed before returning to her room.

In fact, said Mr Temple, "[he] had secretly introduced Midazolam into Miss Annis's cider in anticipation of her being comatosed and a sexual assault in the shape of rape or indecent assault.

"But before he could carry out that intention she suffered an adverse reaction to the drug with fatal consequences."

The nurse in charge of the course, Julie Schernower, told the court that Ms Annis had been in good health when the pair had lunch earlier that day. "She was very happy, fit, a lovely girl and I would not have perceived any problem."

The trial continues.

webTitle: Young men seek 'safe' ways to let off steam

fields.headline: Young men seek 'safe' ways to let off steam
fields.standfirst: 'Alternative buzz' is the way to cope with pressure, say teenagers
fields.trailText: Young men increasingly suffering from low self-esteem and depression are desperate for "safe" ways to take risks and vent their frustration, according to government research published today.
fields.body:
Young men increasingly suffering from low self-esteem and depression are desperate for "safe" ways to take risks and vent their frustration, according to government research published today.

Amid signs that boys are coping less well than girls with peer pressure and are more likely to turn to crime as well as drugs and alcohol, teenagers begged for the chance of an "alternative buzz" offered by activities such as bungee jumping, go-karting or stock car racing.

The study, the government's largest consultation with young people, identified a generation of 5m teenagers struggling under increasing pressure to conform to idealised images in advertising and the media.

While girls were more likely to use close friendships to help manage stress, boys turned their anger outwards in aggressive or criminal behaviour, the survey of 500 teenagers in England found.

Where boys were unable to cope, they were three times more likely than girls to commit suicide, while girls were up to four times more likely to harm themselves deliberately, or fall victim to eating disorders including anorexia and bulimia. Boys and young men interviewed for the study made a plea for more opportunities to take part in dangerous activities in "safe settings".

"They want activities that give them a buzz but take place in a controlled environment, such as bungee jumping," said a Home Office source.

Young men also asked for round-the-clock access to a safe place to go to "be themselves, talk and get information", including help on drink and drugs, and for improved school lessons addressing their concerns about relationships.

Ministers will use the Listen Up report, published jointly by the Home Office and the government's Women's Unit, to highlight moves to do more to help teenage boys, including £500,000 funding for im proved health advice and guidance targeted specifically at young men and fathers.

"Boys felt they just weren't being catered for as girls were, particularly in sex and relationships education," a Home Office source said.

"They told us that in most areas they were not listened to, and they feel a lot of pressure in terms of stereotyping and bullying."

One young man in Manchester told researchers: "I used to bottle it all up until I couldn't stand it any more and then I'd batter somebody". Another said: "You can cry when you're little but not when you're big. You're expected to be a hard bastard."

As well as new Department of Health guidelines for young men and boys, particularly on sexual health, a new framework for personal and social education in schools is intended to help boys to learn to assert themselves, develop relationships and resist pressures to take drugs or turn to crime.

Eighty per cent of under-18s found guilty or cautioned for an offence in 1998 were male.

Though the report also outlined pressures facing girls, the findings relating to boys underlined government concern that a hard core of young men were slipping through a series of nets. Educationally, girls now out-performed boys, with a widening gap in performance at GCSE level, and boys were failing to acquire the kind of interpersonal skills increasingly demanded by the world of work.

According to the study, official recorded suicide rates in 1996 found that 547 young men took their lives compared with 154 young women. The report noted the high suicide rate among young men as a "major concern".

It said: "One explanation is that the methods boys use to attempt suicide - weapons and vehicles - are more likely to prove lethal. Boys are also less able to communicate their emotional distress, so that without help or support problems can become insurmountable."

Terri Apter, a social psychologist and senior tutor at Clare Hall at Cambridge University, yesterday welcomed the study, but urged more work to distinguish more closely between age groups.

Ministers are to hold a summit to examine ways to encourage women's magazines and the fashion industry to create more lifelike images of women and girls rather than using teenage waifs.

According to the study, official recorded suicide rates in 1996 found that 547 young men took their lives compared with 154 young women. The report noted the high suicide rate among young men as a "major concern". It said: "One explanation is that the methods boys use to attempt suicide - weapons and vehicles - are more likely to prove lethal. Boys are also less able to communicate their emotional distress, so that without help or support problems can become insurmountable." Terri Apter, a social psychologist and senior tutor at Clare Hall at Cambridge University, yesterday welcomed the study, but urged more work to distinguish more closely between age groups. Ministers are to hold a summit to examine ways to encourage women's magazines and the fashion industry to create more lifelike images of women and girls rather than using teenage waifs.

webTitle: Health warning on air inside homes

fields.headline: Health warning on air inside homes
fields.trailText: Air inside the home is up to 10 times more polluted than outside, according to Health Which?, with problems made worse by double glazing and central heating.
fields.body:
Air inside the home is up to 10 times more polluted than outside, according to Health Which?, with problems made worse by double glazing and central heating.

Carbon monoxide from cigarettes, gas cookers and heaters is singled out as causing drowsiness, headaches and heart strain, while nitrogen dioxide from unvented gas appliances has been blamed for respiratory problems.

The report quotes a recent Building Research Establishment survey which shows that one in 10 homes has carbon monoxide levels above World Health Organisation guidelines.

Less obvious sources of pollution include synthetic furnishings, cleaning products, and materials such as chipboard, varnish, glues, paints and vinyl flooring. These contain volatile organic compounds, which give off vapours in warm houses and may cause cancer.

The editor of Health Which?, Charlotte Gann, said: "While most people won't be sitting at home feeling ill, the old and the young, who are most likely to have existing health problems, are likely to be at risk.

"But it is possible to take a few simple steps to reduce that risk; people can open windows on opposite sides of the house to create a through draught. You should also try to cut down on the chemicals that are used around the home.

"Considering that most of us spend 80 to 90% of our time inside it may also be a good idea to get out and enjoy the fresh air."

webTitle: Portillo apologises in Commons for failing to declare oil firm interest

fields.headline: Portillo apologises in Commons for failing to declare oil firm interest
fields.standfirst: Tories in opposition: special report
fields.trailText: Michael Portillo was forced to make an embarrassing apology to MPs yesterday after he broke parliamentary rules by failing to declare his interest in a multi-million pound oil company during a Commons debate on petrol duty.
fields.body:
Michael Portillo was forced to make an embarrassing apology to MPs yesterday after he broke parliamentary rules by failing to declare his interest in a multi-million pound oil company during a Commons debate on petrol duty.

In a personal statement in the Commons, the shadow chancellor described his failure to declare his interest in the Kerr McGee Corporation as an "oversight". Mr Portillo said: "On Monday March 27 at the conclusion of the Budget debate I made some remarks regarding the taxation of petrol without reminding the house that I have a registered interest as an adviser to an oil producing company. It was an oversight for which I apologise to the house."

Mr Portillo delivered his apology at the earliest opportunity after he was reported to the parliamentary standards commissioner on Friday for failing to mention that he receives up to £10,000 a year from Kerr McGee, the world's third largest oil exploration company. In the Budget debate, Mr Portillo pointed out the level of inflation by which petrol duty was raised was higher than that used for other taxes. His swift move means that he will avoid a rebuke from the commissioner, Elizabeth Filkin, whose reports can lead to the expulsion of MPs.

His apology was rejected by the Labour MP Christopher Leslie, who reported Mr Portillo to the commissioner. "An apology is the very least of it," Mr Leslie said. "As a senior member of the shadow cabinet he should not be working for a company making large profits from petrol at the same time as discussing duty and taxation on fuel ... I would suggest he should resign from Kerr McGee. This is a case where he has a conflict of interests."

The row over Mr Portillo's links with the company highlighted the burgeoning business interests of members of the shadow cabinet, some of whose outside jobs relate to their Commons portfolio.

Last year Mr Portillo's predecessor, Francis Maude, was rebuked by Ms Filkin when he proposed a new clause on the retail industry for the government's finance bill. Mr Maude was a then director of Asda.

webTitle: Move to cut price of cars in UK

fields.headline: Move to cut price of cars in UK
fields.standfirst: Byers acts as report shows British buyers pay 10% extra
fields.trailText: Motor manufacturers are overcharging private motorists by about £1,100 on the average new car, according to Britain's top competition watchdog.
fields.body:
Motor manufacturers are overcharging private motorists by about £1,100 on the average new car, according to Britain's top competition watchdog.

In response, the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, has pledged a range of new measures designed to stimulate competition and bring down prices.

Both the report by the competition commission and Mr Byers's promised reforms were welcomed by the Consumers' Association. But the industry responded coolly, playing down the prospects for "significant price reductions".

The 730-page report found that while UK car prices had fallen by 6.5% in real terms over the past four years, UK car buyers were still paying 10% more than their counterparts in France, Germany and Italy, even though two-thirds of cars sold in the UK were imported.

John Bridgeman, the director general of fair trading, said the overall extra cost to UK buyers could be around £1bn a year.

Mr Byers said the report's findings represented "a clear and unambiguous call for change... For many private buyers, a car is the second most expensive purchase of their lives. This report confirms what many people have thought was the case - that in Britain we are paying over the odds for new cars."

The report blamed the "selective and exclusive distribution system", under which all new cars are sold through manufacturers' franchised dealers for high prices. It said the system gave manufacturers excessive power to influence the market and ideally should be abolished.

Mr Byers is adopting a "twin track" approach. In the short term, officials say he is planning to order suppliers to offer dealers who buy in bulk the same discounts as those offered to fleet buyers. The dealers will be able to pass on these fleet discounts - which can top 15% - to private buyers.

Dealers will also be permitted to set and advertise the price for individual models. Many manufacturers have penalised dealers who have not advertised the recommended retail price.

Manufacturers are also to be stopped from manipulating the monthly market share figures by offering dealers discounts, provided they preregister the vehicles.

In the longer term, Mr Byers intends to press the European commission to end the "block exemption". That would open the way for root and branch reform of the car distribution system.

Alan Pulham, director of the National Franchised Dealer Association, welcomed Mr Byers's action. "Car companies are going to have to take less profit in this country and increase prices in other countries," he said.

The Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders (SMMT) said it welcomed the report but said price differentials between Britain and Europe existed because the former "remains a high currency market, not a high price market."

It argued that the UK market was competitive and pointed to the problems at Rover as an indication of the tough times facing the industry.

"There is little scope for price reduction," according to the SMMT's chief executive, Christopher Macgowan, "but we will be seeking to work with the government to ensure UK customers continue to buy with confidence in the UK."

A spokeswoman for the Consumers' Association said the report was a vindication of the organisation's stance. "It is a disappointment that they [the manufacturers] can't just turn round straight away and reduce prices."

fields.headline: Getting personal with Richard Jobson
fields.trailText: Answer me
fields.body:
Have you ever adopted a pseudonym and, if so, why? Yes. It was Alex Splode. I was 16 years old, in a punk band, and you just had to have one.

Have you ever lied about your age and, if so, why? Yes. To get in to see A Clockwork Orange at the cinema. I must have been about 13, and you had to be 18, I think. I've always looked quite old for my years.

How would you describe yourself in a lonely hearts ad? Not tall. Not dark. Not handsome. But not a bad gardener.

What was the last illegal thing you did? "Redesigned" a Phil Collins poster.

What was the last kind-hearted thing you did? Bought a Rangers fan a drink after they beat my team, Celtic, 4 - 0.

Who's the nicest person you've ever worked with? It has to be the late Billy Mackenzie.

What are the initials of the most unpleasant person you've ever worked with? FB

Has a critic ever made you cry? No.

What would you advertise without a fee? Glasgow Celtic.

What would you never advertise? Glasgow Rangers.

What wakes you up screaming at 4 in the morning? My past.

What takes you to a "happy place"? The Lisbon Lions, Irvine Welsh, my garden, Terrence Malick films and my kids.

 Richard Jobson presents Movie Talk and the Face To Face interviews on Sky Premier

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
They are very good down at the local DIY shed store nowadays, slipping safety leaflets in with your new power tools and hammers, but every year the NHS gears up for the Easter Bank holiday flood of not so handy Andys. Right Said Fred (Radio 2, 9.0pm) looks at the history of DIY. Once it was Barry Bucknell putting up a shed, by the 1970s we got on to serious grouting, and since Laurence Llewelyn-Bowen appeared on the scene we all want homes that express our originality. Andy Kane adds comedy, music and readings to the social history of DIY.

When you get to the head of the queue in casualty with that pulverised thumb you might want to switch over to Case Notes (Radio 4, 9.0pm). Graham Easton asks if gut instinct or keeping abreast of the latest scientific evidence make for better doctoring. While GP Dr Keith Hopcroft ponders whether you should trust the eminent consultant or the hands-on houseman.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Satellite, cable and digital
fields.body:
The Fallen Idol (Carol Reed, 1948 ) 6pm, FilmFour
Neat little drama adapted from a Graham Greene short story, The Basement Room. It's about the affecting friendship between ambassador's son Bobby Henrey and the butler (Ralph Richardson), and how the boy mistakenly makes a murder suspect of him when his bullying wife dies in an accident.

That Obscure Object Of Desire (Luis Buñuel, 1977) 10pm, FilmFour
In which Fernando Rey undergoes ritual humiliation at the hands of a beautiful woman. His wealthy Mathieu is aroused by Spanish maid Conchita, a maddening mix of passion and untouchable virginity who turns him into love's buffoon. It's a fine Buñuelian conceit to have two actresses playing her, Angelina Molina hot, Carole Bouquet cool. Set against a backdrop of terrorism, through which the obsessed Mathieu wonders distractedly, there's a hard satirical centre to the hilarious sex games.

Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas (Terry Gilliam, 1998) 10pm, Sky Premier
Hunter S Thompson's drug-fuelled quest in a crimson convertible for the American Dream was labelled the novel that could never be filmed, but this is a defiantly faithful adaptation. Gilliam, creator of fantasies from Jabberwocky to Twelve Monkeys, conjures astounding pharmaceutical hallucinations, and there are exceptional performances from Johnny Depp (pictured) as the Thompson alter ego Raoul Duke and Benicio Del Toro as his pal, Dr Gonzo. But the serial trashing of hotels rooms, the awesome soundtrack and Depp's jaded voiceover combine to be more numbing than stimulating.

Sneakers (Phil Alden Robinson, 1992) 10pm, Sky Cinema
Slick and clever comedy thriller with Robert Redford as head of a hi-tech security team mixed up in hacking activities. Among those having fun in his gang are Sidney Poitier, River Phoenix, Mary McDonnell and Dan Aykroyd as Mother, who has his own line on the Kennedy assassination: "They shot him but he didn't die. He's still alive."

fields.headline: Life after marriage
fields.trailText: One can only admire the expertise and expedition with which Rodolphe removed Emma's riding habit, her top hat with six feet of blue veiling, laced stays, bloomers, camisole, chemise, stockings and, with a wrench like velcro, her stout riding boots. And, afterwards, the dexterity with which Emma dressed, put up her hair and removed the major part of the forest floor from her underwear so that the village noticed nothing but her attractively heightened colour.
fields.body:
One can only admire the expertise and expedition with which Rodolphe removed Emma's riding habit, her top hat with six feet of blue veiling, laced stays, bloomers, camisole, chemise, stockings and, with a wrench like velcro, her stout riding boots. And, afterwards, the dexterity with which Emma dressed, put up her hair and removed the major part of the forest floor from her underwear so that the village noticed nothing but her attractively heightened colour.

It was the sort of scene Mrs Patrick Campbell had in mind when she deplored people doing it in public and frightening the horses.

Spiced with explicit sex, Madame Bovary (BBC 2) will have given her compatriot, Monsignor Renard (ITV) a bloody nose. In the concluding part tonight she is, appropriately enough, in competition with Bad Girls (ITV) and When Celebrities Strip (ITV). The effectiveness of implicit sex could be seen in a minimal gesture by Emma's husband (Hugh Bonneville), who, as her lover sang lieder, wiped a wisp of milk from her mouth with his thumb and then sucked it.

Madame Bovary thought life should be like a novel. She did not realise, naturally, that she was in a novel. Unusually for a romantic heroine, her story starts after marriage.

It is a pretty production, though sunk at first in buried-alive shadows. This is certainly deliberate as, when Emma (Frances O'Connor) meets Rodolphe, (Greg Wise) there are, quite literally, fireworks.

The backing cast - Barbara Jefford, Eileen Atkins, Trevor Peacock, Joe McGann, Keith Barron - is the best butter but rather wasted. (Though, even with a live turkey under his arm, Trevor Peacock makes his presence felt).

I do believe I might have liked it more if the BBC's publicity material had not begun "The heavens have been torn open."

The Lost Ark Of The Covenant (Channel 4) is a Mecca , if I may put it that way, for the gently demented. The last theorist, as I remember, believed it contained radioactive material. Mike Sanders, described a little disturbingly as a self-taught biblical scholar, constructed a toppling tower of conjecture to show that the ark was seized by Ramses the Third. Ramses, it was fascinating to see, was in very good shape for a mummy. As a burglar fears creaking stairs, I am uneasy about a programme where every second sentence squeaks "Stunning... awe some... amazing... startling".

Mike's methods are intuitive ("It doesn't take much of a stretch of the imagination to see...") and can be illustrated by his method of finding Djahi, where Ramses may have built a temple. "I asked my wife to go to The Times Atlas Of The World, look into the index and see if there was any Djahi anywhere. She said 'There's a Dhahiriyah - will that do?' The hairs on the back of my head jumped up!"

In Dhahiriyah archaeology met bureaucracy. He needed permission from the Palestinian Ministry of Tourism and Antiquities (a first floor flat from the look of it) to excavate a promising ruin which might, he thought, have the tablets of the law in its foundations. The minister kept him waiting two hours, then two days, then remembered a pressing prior engagement. A less hell-bent man would have taken the hint. The minister hid himself in a cloud of red tape, deaf to Mike's argument that "this would be the most profound archaelogical, even political discovery, not only of the decade, of the century, but of the millenium!"

Mike has biblical whiskers. He returned from their meeting looking thunderous like Moses when, after a draining encounter with Jehovah, he found the Israelites worshipping a calf.

"Stupid buggers!" roared Mike.

I am disconcerted to see that DCI Mason, the portly Scot who appears in EastEnders whenever a body is found stiffening in the street, has suddenly turned up in Coronation Street (ITV) as a park keeper. Though Albert Square has more corpses to the square inch than Kensal Green, DCI Mason never had much success in pinning down the guilty parties. I deduce a mental breakdown, remedial retirement and a less stressful job among the daffodils. Unless, of course, he is working undercover on Tony's murder. In which case, we'll never know who did it.

I deduce a mental breakdown, remedial retirement and a less stressful job among the daffodils. Unless, of course, he is working undercover on Tony's murder. In which case, we'll never know who did it.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Holiday On A Shoestring 7pm, BBC1
If you've ever watched a holiday programme and discovered your dream destination may involve a second mortgage, this puports to be the answer. All the holidays, including a trip to Grenada for host Kate Humble, supposedly cost less than £500. It's also refreshing to see Toyah Wilcox's father confirming the universal truth that stolid parents say the oddest things on holiday. "It's 30 years since I've been through here and I got very wet then", he says on a canal trip with his daughter. "Fortunately I was drunk as well. Which helped."

Madame Bovary 9pm, BBC2
"There's nothing left to feel", screams Emma Bovary (Frances O'Connor) as despair and bankruptcy drive her to the edge, and events in this two-part adaptation of Flaubert's novel draw to a close. Despite the familiarity of the material, it's a shocking scene that encapsulates the way all our vanities eventually trip us up. Add in a dignified performance from Hugh Bonneville as Emma's ineffective husband Charles and Keith Barron's gloriously greasy turn as an unscrupulous money lender, and this is powerful drama far removed from the usual costume eye-candy.

Cutting Edge 9pm, C4
Mary, Jimmy, Luke, Kwok and Alain share a flat in Notting Hill. Nothing unusual there, especially when they bicker, except that all five have special needs, and care staff are on hand to help them live inde pendently. A quietly beautiful film that treats the five with respect and dignity as it follows their lives.

Film 2000 With Jonathan Ross 11.30pm, BBC1
As the long-running series returns, it's strangely difficult to imagine Barry Norman hosting the show. Sure, Bazza's a national institution and all, but interviews were never his forte, and the series benefits immensely from Jonathan Ross regularly rapping with film folk. On the subject of which, Kristin Scott Thomas is tonight's guest.

fields.headline: The road to nowhere
fields.standfirst: Holidays are like anything else - you get what you pay for. So just why is the BBC's newest TV travel show trying to pretend otherwise? Ex-Holiday presenter  John Carter  explains how travel television went off the rails
fields.trailText: Holidays are like anything else - you get what you pay for. So just why is the BBC's newest TV travel show trying to pretend otherwise? Ex-Holiday presenter John Carter explains how travel television went off the rails
fields.body:
If someone insisted he could sell you a Rolls-Royce for the price of a Vauxhall Astra, you would, sensibly, keep a tight hold on your money and try to attract the attention of a passing policeman.

Holiday On A Shoestring (tonight, 7pm, BBC1), however, is based on the premise - peddled by the travel trade and believed by suckers - that one can buy top-quality holidays for rock-bottom prices. Why consumers believe a holiday to be different from any other product is something I have never been able to understand, considering that "you get what you pay for" is one of the travel writer's most used clichés.

On that score - your average television travel programme providing enough verbal and visual clichés to fill a skip - Holiday On A Shoestring gets off to a flying start, with presenter Kate Humble describing the "...glittering blue sea, wide sandy beaches and tropical sunshine..." of the Caribbean before demolishing the premise of the entire series - that all holidays featured will cost less than £500 - with its very first item.

True, her one-week holiday to Grenada costs £479, but as it includes no meals, I don't see how anybody can do it for under £500 - unless they take provisions. And that doesn't allow for the side trip to the isle of Carriacou (return ferry fare £18).

Television travel shows demand "glamorous" locations, but this programme's dilemma is that those locations must be accessible on a self-imposed £500. Watch out for future examples of "creative pricing".

I like Kate Humble. She tells me nothing about Grenada that I don't already know, but, unlike other female presenters in this genre, she resists the temptation to get into a bathing suit until she is actually under water, and her cheerful enthusiasm rises above the verbal banalities. I look forward to seeing more of her.

I look forward, as keenly, to seeing less of Rowland Rivron, whose item on Salou consisted of lots of him and not much else. Though the vast filing- cabinet of a hotel (Salou's version of a multi-storeyed Benidormitory) and its crowded beach is something I would avoid, I'm sure it has its devotees. Mr Rivron's cheeky-chappy presence should have his fellow guests complaining to their travel agents in droves, with copies to Watchdog.

His contribution is an example (fortunately the only one in this particular programme) of television's belief that a holiday show's presenter is more important than the destination he or she is describing.

Having hacked my way around the world for both Holiday and Wish You Were Here...? I assure Mr Rivron and others of his ilk that the best compliment you can be paid is for somebody to say: "I know your face, but can't remember the name." It means the viewer paid more attention to where you were and what you had to say about it, than to your on-camera antics. Unfortunately, the tendency today is to take the opposite view, crediting viewers with the attention span of a Mayfly and feeding them short items, presented by "celebrities" or "personalities". The vocabulary of television being what it is, a "celebrity" is celebrated for nothing other than being on television and a "personality" usually has none.

Though mainstream travel shows present a wide range of holiday ideas, viewers regularly complain that most are beyond their financial reach. Such complaints - misguided though they are - have to be addressed, and, rather than tell a vocal minority of viewers that you have to have plenty of disposable income in order to enjoy the champagne lifestyle, a series like Holiday On A Shoestring is the dissembling result.

If it concentrates on low-price short-haul package deals abroad, of which Salou and camping in the Loire Valley are this week's examples, or on deals in the UK (a narrow boat on the canals of the Warwickshire Ring), this series would do a worthwhile job.

But would it attract viewers? Television producers believe they must give us the glamour of long-haul locations and, to justify this, will go along with the fiction that, as far as holidays are concerned, you can, magically, get more than you pay for.

Time was when Holiday paid in full for its air tickets, hotel rooms, hire cars and so on, and had to produce proof of those payments, on demand, to a ferocious female from "Accounts". It was the Corporation's way of defending editorial integrity and ensuring that those early programmes put the occasional boot into a complacent travel trade. That time has long gone and, though I would not question the integrity or the motives of today's producers, directors, presenters et al, it is a fact that journalism has given way to "infotainment" and the travel shows are now a part of the holiday industry's sales effort.

To present everything in a glowing light, with pretty pictures, bland words and the kind of saccharine music that tinkles away in a thousand hotel elevators, is bad enough. To go along with the fiction that you can buy a Rolls-Royce for the price of an Astra is compounding the felony.

webTitle: What the *** is going on, MPs ask defence officials

fields.headline: What the *** is going on, MPs ask defence officials
fields.trailText: MPs yesterday accused the ministry of defence of being excessively secretive after publishing a heavily censored report on intelligence cooperation between Britain and the US.
fields.body:
MPs yesterday accused the ministry of defence of being excessively secretive after publishing a heavily censored report on intelligence cooperation between Britain and the US.

The report, by the Commons defence committee, is so studded with asterisks that much of the evidence provided by the MoD is rendered meaningless. The ministry refuses even to disclose under what treaty US spy planes are allowed to fly from British bases.

At one point, Bruce George, Labour chairman of the committee, asks: "How dependent [are] you on material provided by the United States?" Group Captain Stephen Lloyd responds: "***".

"There are restrictions, obviously, on passing any information you get on to third parties with United States permission?" Answer: "***".

"Does the United States make available any of the material that it gives to you to any other Nato ally?" Answer: "***".

"We are talking about France?" Answer: "***".

The MoD witnesses were then asked: "Presumably there is a relationship also between the amount of information you are given by the US and the use of our sovereign bases by their intelligence-gathering vehicles like the U2? In fact what, under what treaty is the agreement for the use of sovereign bases agreed?" Answer: "***".

Mike Hancock, the Liberal Democrat MP, asks: "Were we, the United Kingdom, in any way responsible for the targeting errors that related to the bombing of the Chinese embassy in Belgrade?" Answer: "***".

The report continues with Air Vice Marshal Joe French saying : "In certain times of the [Kosovo] campaign we saw many tanks on the ground ... ***."

"We saw them but we did not tell anyone?" Air Vice Marshal French: "***".

"Were they targeted?" Group Captain Lloyd: "***".

Clearly frustrated by not being able to share the information with a wider public, the MPs conclude: "As ever, the MoD seems to be much more sensitive about [intelligence cooperation] than ... US authorities".

They recommend the MoD takes the opportunity to reassess its approach to what information might be made public.

They add, with no apparent hint of irony: "The MoD should be actively engaged in demonstrating its commitment to Whitehall's efforts to bring about more 'open government'."

fields.headline: Tony Cliff
fields.standfirst: Revolutionary political theorist and organiser who fired the Socialist Workers Party with his charisma, charm and vision
fields.trailText: The first I heard of Tony Cliff, who has died aged 82, was from Gus Macdonald, now Lord Macdonald, Minister of Transport. Forty years ago, Gus was a charismatic leader of the Govan and Gorbals Young Socialists and had an awesome reputation from a Clydeside apprentices' strike. In late 1961, he reckoned it was time the Young Socialists took some serious lessons in Marxist theory, and arranged a weekend school to be addressed by two leaders of an obscure Trotskyist sect called the International Socialists.
fields.body:
The first I heard of Tony Cliff, who has died aged 82, was from Gus Macdonald, now Lord Macdonald, Minister of Transport. Forty years ago, Gus was a charismatic leader of the Govan and Gorbals Young Socialists and had an awesome reputation from a Clydeside apprentices' strike. In late 1961, he reckoned it was time the Young Socialists took some serious lessons in Marxist theory, and arranged a weekend school to be addressed by two leaders of an obscure Trotskyist sect called the International Socialists.

Gus and I met the couple in an airport lounge. I can still see them coming in: Mikhael Kidron, smart, suave, urbane, and Tony Cliff, short and scruffy, looking and sounding like a rag doll. As we mumbled through the niceties of introductions, the rag doll looked irritated and shy. We climbed into a taxi.

As we did so, I saw a newspaper poster about events in the Congo, and remarked, partly to break the silence, that I'd never really understood the Congo. Quick as a flash, the rag doll came to life, and started jabbering with amazing speed and energy. I can't remember exactly what he said, but I do remember my clouds of doubt and misunderstanding suddenly disappearing and the role of the contestants in the Congo, including the United Nations, becoming brutally clear.

I met Cliff many hundreds of times subsequently, sometimes for private conversations, more often on shared platforms, from which we urged our audiences to join IS and its successor, the Socialist Workers Party, and to organise for socialism. Though he often made exactly the same speech and cracked the same jokes, I never failed to be astonished and enthused.

His death is shocking. Very few of us who knew him well believed that such an essentially youthful figure could ever pass away.

Tony Cliff was born Ygael Gluckstein, the son of a Zionist building contractor, in Palestine, in May 1917, in between the great Russian revolutions. He was speedily converted out of Zionism by observing the treatment of Arab children. Aged 13, he wrote in a school essay: "It is so sad that there are no Arab kids in the school." The teacher scrawled across the page the single word: "Communist".

She was right, and Cliff was always grateful for her perception. He fought vigorously against the exclusion of Arabs from the closed Zionist economy. When a speaker from the Haifa trades council spoke glowingly of the anti-fascist uprising in Vienna in 1934, and ended his speech with a tribute to the Paris Commune and workers' unity, Cliff, aged 17, heckling from the back of the hall, added the one word "international". In this context, "international" meant Arab, and the stewards responded by twisting his finger till it broke.

Cliff joined the Communist party, but was quickly disillusioned by the party's nationalism. He became a Trotskyist before he was 20 and devoted the rest of his life to building revolutionary socialist organisations. He came to Britain with his newly-married South African wife, Chanie, and was promptly expelled from the country on the advice of the Special Branch; he spent five years in poverty in Ireland until allowed to return.

In the 1950s, he formed the Socialist Review Group, which grew into IS in the early 1960s and the SWP in 1977. For a long time, these groups remained tiny. But when the Communist party, with its (comparatively) huge roots in the organised working class, collapsed in 1989, the SWP became by far the largest and most confident of the socialist organisations to the left of the Labour party.

This achievement was due largely to Cliff's most striking qualities; his immense intellectual power and his ability to explain his libertarian Marxism in simple language. His unique intellectual contribution was to describe, in the late 1940s, the Soviet Union as state capitalist, and therefore imperialist - a proposition as shocking to most socialists of the time as it was inspiring to those of us who were convinced by it.

With the theory of state capitalism came a number of associated ideas, all of them based on Marx's message that the emancipation of labour must be the work of labour itself; that capitalism is far too strong and sophisticated a system to be brought down or replaced from on high; and that the workers alone, through their union organisations and instinctive solidarity, have the power to bring about that vital change. This power, moreover, cannot be effectively mobilised without political organisation in the working class rank and file.

These themes emerged from Cliff's early books about Russia, China and eastern Europe, and his later four-volume biographies of Lenin (in the 1970s) and Trotsky (in the 1980s).

They emerged even more clearly from Cliff's tireless public speaking. His wild accent often startled his audiences, but they were soon giggling at his folksy jokes, like the parable in which a flea boasts to the ox on whose back he is riding: "Look how far we have ploughed today."

My favourite featured an Arabian sultan, who went to Manchester to buy a cooling system for his palace. As he was chatting to the managing director in his office, the sultan heard a blast on a hooter. Out of the window he saw, to his horror, thousands of workers walking out of the factory. In a hysterical panic, he shrieked at the managing director, who told him not to worry. Half an hour later the hooter went again, and the workers returned from their break. "Don't worry about the cooling system," concluded the sultan. "Just give me the hooter."

Cliff died without a penny in his pocket or any property to speak of. He was always bored stiff by property or talk of property. He left a far richer inheritance: thousands of us socialists, who, without him, would have degenerated into apathy, opportunism or careerism; a wife, who lived and fought by his side for 55 years, and two sons and two daughters, all of whom, in their different ways, are inspiring socialists and engaging companions.

"Don't mourn, organise!" was one of Cliff's most consistent slogans, and somehow we must try to live up to it.

fields.headline: Heinz Burt
fields.standfirst: Pop singer briefly propelled to stardom
fields.trailText: The career of the singer and bass player Heinz Burt, who has died aged 57 after a courageous battle against motor-neurone disease, is a cautionary tale rooted in the pre-Beatles 1960s. Heinz, as he was billed, was a protégé of the paranoid, and finally homicidal, record producer Joe Meek.
fields.body:
The career of the singer and bass player Heinz Burt, who has died aged 57 after a courageous battle against motor-neurone disease, is a cautionary tale rooted in the pre-Beatles 1960s. Heinz, as he was billed, was a protégé of the paranoid, and finally homicidal, record producer Joe Meek.

In 1962, the German-born 19-year-old, plucked from bacon slicing in a Southampton grocery, was credited as one of Meek's studio band, the Tornados, on Meek's five million-selling single, Telstar. A year later, Heinz entered the top 20 as a Meek-created solo artist with Just Like Eddie, a tribute disc to the dead American rock 'n' roller Eddie Cochran.

Meek was Britain's first independent pop producer. He recorded in a tiny flat in the Holloway Road, north London, and - in between obsessions with the dead Buddy Holly, death in general, seances and graveyards - had made a clutch of British hits, which displayed an occasionally spectacular talent for electronic sound.

But it was a time when the salesmen of British pop culture, of which Meek was one of the most driven, were almost entirely parasitic on the United States. Thus did they attempt to clone American-style teenage stars from wildly unsuitable domestic material. Meek dispatched a series of Elvises, Buddy Hollys and their ilk into the world, and the world remained largely indifferent.

Meek fell in love with Heinz, and dismissed suggestions that the teenager, who moved into the Holloway Road flat, might be an indifferent singer or, indeed, bassist. Inspired by the movie Village Of The Damned, in which the world is threatened by a brood of blond, staring-eyed children, the producer prevailed upon the youth to peroxide his hair. The theory may have been an image of the cold teuton, the reality was rather bemused Hampshire.

Soon Heinz was separated from the Tornados to pursue his Meek-directed solo career. Since his voice had displayed some inadequacies, the producer doctored the tape on his debut single by adding that of another singer. The record flopped.

Then Heinz was unwisely sent on tour with the American rock singers Gene Vincent and Jerry Lee Lewis. Meek envisaged Heinz's audience as teenage girls, but he was confronted with sceptical male youth and booed on and off stage. In Birmingham, Heinz told Meek's biographer John Repseh, the audience tried to attack him. The band and singer were showered with beans.

The next single, Just Like Eddie, was Heinz's only hit. He played a summer season at an end-of-the-pier show with the ancient comedian Arthur Askey. But a week after Just Like Eddie entered the top 20 came the Beatles' She Loves You. The era in which herds of tin-pan-alley-created pop singers could roam the lower reaches of the charts was over, at least for the time being.

In 1967, Meek shot his landlady, and himself, at the Holloway Road flat. In later years, after a succession of manual jobs, Heinz reappeared on stage at 1960s pop revival shows. These included a 1992 Meek tribute concert, where he concluded with Teenager In Love. No cans were hurled. The audience sang along.

fields.headline: Peter Jones
fields.standfirst: Actor famed for comic television roles and the ability to speak for 60 seconds on radio
fields.trailText: Though he was perhaps too unfocused a creative and public personality to make a major impact, Peter Jones, who has died aged 79, was an intelligent, inventive, versatile and witty part of British show business for more than 50 years.
fields.body:
Though he was perhaps too unfocused a creative and public personality to make a major impact, Peter Jones, who has died aged 79, was an intelligent, inventive, versatile and witty part of British show business for more than 50 years.

As actor, playwright, script- writer and gameshow personality he had solid virtues, but his versatility may have told against him, and his range was certainly wider than it was deep. He is likely to be best remembered as the fumbling dress manufacturer Harold Fenner, who wages ineffective war against shop steward Miriam Karlin in The Rag Trade, the BBC-TV series which began in 1961, was revived in 1977 and, at its peak, commanded nearly 15m viewers.

Jones tended to specialise in characters that PG Wodehouse would have called, if not disgruntled, at least not particularly gruntled. His lowly and usually skint executive, Gerald Garvey, in that other popular television series, Beggar Thy Neighbour, which began in 1967, was a masterpiece of jittery jealousy of his better-off - if working-class - neighbour, played by Reg Varney.

But though television consolidated his fame, it was radio that first brought Jones to prominence - and kept him there. To hear him on the long-running BBC game- show Just A Minute, in which contestants had to talk for 60 seconds without repetition, hesitation or deviation, was a bubbling joy. He was also the programme's champion interrupter at challenging other contestants, especially Kenneth Williams, with whom he virtually did a double act of personality opposites.

Earlier, Jones had featured in the BBC radio comedy show, In All Directions, which he co-wrote with Peter Ustinov. The Ustinov connection was seminal. Jones appeared with him on stage in Eric Linklater's Love In Albania and in Crime And Punishment, and their friendship resulted in them chatting together, apparently spontaneously, with a tape recorder running, often taking off on verbal flights of fancy. The result became In All Directions, which took over from the Goon Show of the 1950s in cult status.

Born at Wem, Shropshire, the son of an antiques dealer, Jones went to Wem grammar school and Ellesmere College, later referring moodily to his "tenth-rate public school" education. A rather delicate boy (to quote his own estimation of himself at that age), he nevertheless produced and acted in school plays.

He had seen only two professionally performed plays, but landed a job as an actor at the age of 16, at the Grand, Wolverhampton. There were two performances a night of The Composite Men, in which Jones was supposed to play a reporter. After his first performance, he found a note dispensing with his services and suggesting that he spent some of his resultant spare time watching actors who knew what they were doing.

Years later, he would drily call himself the actor with the shortest run on record. He consoled himself by landing a part in a BBC radio production of Arnold Bennett's The Card, broadcast from Birmingham, in which knowing where to put his feet and hands was not so crucial.

But he got other jobs in rep, or in summer shows on the east coast, and in 1942 gave his first West End performance, also as a reporter, in a revival of George Bernard Shaw's The Doctor's Dilemma at the Haymarket. Jones was especially congenial to Shaw. His strong, clear but unaffected voice admirably fitted the playwright's belief that his lines were so foolproof that all the actors had to do was say them intelligently and the back rows could hear. Jones went on to appear in Shaw's The Simpleton Of The Unexpected Isles and Misalliance.

By 1946 he was in Crime And Punishment at the Globe, and during the run, the actress Hermione Baddeley took an option on a play he had written called Marion. By then, Jones was working on another play and had written several scripts for BBC radio.

He made a respectable reputation as an actor in intelligent plays, often in classics like The Imaginary Invalid and The Rivals but, as a playwright, he did not enjoy much success. In 1952, he appeared in his own play, Sweet Madness, at the Vaudeville, and in 1966 he appeared in, and directed, his work, Angie and Ernie, at the Yvonne Arnaud Theatre, Guildford. Neither became part of the popular repertory.

Jones would admit that no one could call him a playwright of consequence, and he often felt that he fell between two or more stools. In the 1960s, he said of his career: "It seems to have been a series of disasters. No one quite knows precisely what to do with me . . . I appear in comedies, but do not rate the title of comedian; when I go on the stage, I still feel like someone from the audience helping out the conjuror."

His television successes and his reputation as a radio wit were to alter all that, helped by occasional films, like School For Scoundrels (1960), Carry On Doctor (1968) and The Return Of The Pink Panther (1974), in which his well-practised suggestion of crumbling and irate semi-competence was good for many laughs.

To help unravel the mysteries of Douglas Adams's surreal epic, The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy, Jones supplied reassuring explanations of the bizarre on radio in the 1970s, and in the 1981 television production. His tone of detached authority as "the Book" brought him much voiceover work. The radio anecdotes that he wrote and related as the spoof theatrical all-rounder "Jacko" Kingston Platt were permeated with his ironic view of his own career.

Jones's wife, the American actress Jeri Sauvinet, died last year; he is survived by their two sons and daughter.

Peter Jones, actor and writer, born June 12 1920; died April 10 2000
