webTitle: Two Koreas to meet after 55 years

fields.headline: Two Koreas to meet after 55 years
fields.standfirst:
Leaders of North and South begin long journey to reunification

Korea Web Weekly
Democratic People's Republic of Korea
fields.trailText: North and South Korea took a historic step towards resolving the world's last major cold war conflict yesterday with the announcement of their first bilateral summit since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945.
fields.body:
North and South Korea took a historic step towards resolving the world's last major cold war conflict yesterday with the announcement of their first bilateral summit since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945.

Washington, Beijing and Tokyo welcomed the move as the best chance for peace on the peninsula since the Korean war of 1950-53, but diplomatic experts said many obstacles lie ahead on the road towards unification.

In an unprecedented joint declaration, the two sides said that the president of South Korea, Kim Dae-jung, would meet his North Korea counterpart, Kim Jong-il, for talks in Pyongyang from June 10-12.

The main item on the agenda will be economic aid for the communist North, where the infrastructure is in ruins and millions are thought to be starving as a result of natural disasters and a failed government policy of economic self-sufficiency.

The two Kims will also discuss how to reunite families that were split during the Korean war - the cold war's most bloody conflict - during which more than 3m people were killed.

Since the 1953 armistice, the two sides have never signed a peace treaty. Forty-seven years later, they remain technically at war, divided at the 38th parallel by the most heavily fortified border in the world.

Timed just three days before a general election in South Korea, the summit announcement is a stunning political coup for Kim Dae-jung, who has gone further than any other previous leader in Seoul to try to coax the reclusive and aggressive north out of its shell.

Despite domestic political criticism and military provocation by Pyongyang, his "sunshine policy" of engagement has seen a four-fold increase in visits across the border in the past two years. Bilateral trade hit a record high last year of $333m (£211m) and passenger cruises to the Mt Kumgang resort in the North have attracted hundreds of thousands of tourists.

Kim Dae-jung said the June meeting would take relations to a new level. "The agreement is an opportunity for bringing development and prosperity to the nation and ensuring hope for peace on the Korean peninsula," a spokesman quoted him as saying.

It would also mark the debut on the world stage of Kim Jong-il; the North's mysterious "Dear Leader" has not held a summit meeting since taking power after his father's death six years ago. Although North Korean news agencies claim that flowers bloom when the 58-year-old "Renaissance Man" walks by, he has rarely been seen in public or on television.

The breakthrough comes amid the most concerted international effort in history to persuade the "hermit kingdom" to open up. Taking a lead from Kim Dae-jung, the US, Japan and Europe have increased diplomatic ties with Pyongyang, while offering increased economic aid in return for improved North-South ties in Korea.

China - the North's most important ally - has also played a key role by hosting unofficial talks between the two sides.

The Chinese foreign ministry said it welcomed and supported the summit plan. "We have always advocated the belief that both sides on the Korean peninsula should improve relations through dialogue aimed at reconciliation and ultimately reunification," the ministry said in a statement.

Given Pyongyang's provocative negotiating tactics in the past and the complex range of issues dividing the two sides - most notably the future of the 37,000 US troops in the south - a successful conclusion of the talks is far from certain.

Professor Kim Ki-jung of Yonsei University said sudden reunification was unlikely. "The summit meeting is the beginning of what will be a very long and time-consuming process," he said. "The most important first step will be to build confidence after all the years of mutual distrust."

In Seoul, the response was mixed. Optimism about prospects for trade helped to push the stock market up by almost 4%, but members of the opposition Grand National party accused the president of cynical electioneering.

The feeling among the city's population, however, was muted. "I cannot get excited about this announcement at all," said Ahn Soo-jeong, a film industry worker. "We've seen plans like this dashed before, so it is best not to have high expectations."

In contrast, supporters of the Pyongyang regime were jubilant. "This is an epochal step towards realising the peaceful unification of the Korean peninsula," said So Chung-on, spokesman for the 400,00 North Korean residents in Japan. "Now that the will on both sides is there, reunification is not so far away."

Decades of conflict

1945 Second world war ends 35 years of Japanese colonial rule. Cold war begins, US troops occupying area south of 38th parallel and Soviet Union moving into north.

1948 Republic of Korea (South Korea) established, backed by Washington, and the Democratic People's Republic of Korea (North Korea), supported by Moscow.

1950-53 3m killed in Korean war that also involved US and China.

1968 Thirty North Korean commandos killed in Seoul as they attempt to blow up the presidential office in January. Nine months later, 100 shot dead during coastal landing.

1974 South Korean first lady killed in failed attempt by Pyongyang agents to assassinate president Park Chung-hee.

1987 A North Korean bomb destroys a Korean Air jet, killing all 115 aboard.

1994 Planned bilateral summit cancelled due to death of the north's "Great Leader" Kim Il-sung, 82. He is succeeded by his son, the "Dear Leader" Kim Jong-il.

1996 Twenty-four northern commandos killed after their submarine runs aground on the east coast of South Korea.

1997 Two Koreas, China and the US begin four-party peace talks in Geneva amid reports that famine in the North claims 2m lives.

1998 South elects Kim Dae-jung as president promising a "sunshine policy" of engagement with Pyongyang.

April 10, 2000 Historic joint announcement of summit between two Kims in Pyongyang on June 12-14

fields.headline: Mulla Asgharali Jaffer
fields.trailText: When Uganda's Asian community was expelled by Idi Amin in 1972, 5000 Khoja Shia Muslims were among the arrivals in England. It was the beginning of the presence of the Khojas in the west.
fields.body:
When Uganda's Asian community was expelled by Idi Amin in 1972, 5000 Khoja Shia Muslims were among the arrivals in England. It was the beginning of the presence of the Khojas in the west.

Within four years, Mulla Asgharali Jaffer, who has died aged 62, had become the driving force in setting up the headquarters in London of the World Federation of Khoja Shia Muslim communities, of which he was the first president. The Khoja Shia exemplify the dynamic diversity of the Shia tradition, often seen in the west as simply Iranian. Largely self-taught, Mulla Asghar, as everyone knew him, was renowned in the Muslim world for his learning, piety and charitable work.

The Khoja are concentrated in Pakistan, India and East Africa, but there are now sizeable communities in Britain and the United States. Converts from Hinduism in medieval Gujerat, they first embraced the local Ismaeli Muslim tradition, then in the late 19th century acknowledged - with steadfast loyalty - the authority of the senior Shia cleric in the sacred city of Najaf, in Iraq.

As federation president, Mulla Asghar harnessed the community's entrepreneurial spirit, working particularly on charitable projects, including educational schemes in Africa, and medical and housing projects in Bombay. In Britain, a main centre was built at Stanmore, Middlesex, and there were many others. Money was raised for disaster relief.

Mulla Asghar was born and educated in Kenya, and ran his father's optician's shop in the old town of Mombasa. By the late 1960s he had set up a large and famous optics factory in Nairobi, meanwhile becoming head, first of the Mombasa Shia community, then of the African Federation of Khoja Muslims.

Plain-spoken, courageous and sincere, Mulla Asghar was formidably learned, and he was fluent in six languages - English, Arabic, Persian, Urdu, Kiswahili, and his native Gujerati. In 1983, he visited his friend and mentor, the spiritual head of the Shia, Grand Ayatollah Al-Khoei, in Iraq. Preparing to leave the country, he was arrested and spent three months in a Baghdad jail, where he was tortured before international pressure forced his release.

He is survived by his wife, Sakina, and four children.

Mulla Asgharali M M Jaffer, religious and community leader, born April 14 1937; died March 21 2000

webTitle: Bank protest heralds start of 'Seattle East'

fields.headline: Bank protest heralds start of 'Seattle East'
fields.trailText: Environmentalists gearing up for protests at summit meetings of world finance chiefs at the weekend blocked a street near the World Bank in Washington yesterday to demand that it stop funding oil, gas and mining projects.
fields.body:
Environmentalists gearing up for protests at summit meetings of world finance chiefs at the weekend blocked a street near the World Bank in Washington yesterday to demand that it stop funding oil, gas and mining projects.

Seven protesters were arrested, including several who chained themselves to a lorry blocking Pennsylvania Avenue, three blocks west of the White House, police said.

Another group of protesters met to launch a campaign to boycott the World Bank's bonds. They hope to convince institutional investors, members of the public and local governments to force changes in the institution's policies towards poor countries.

Many of the protesters who disrupted the Seattle meeting of the World Trade Organisation last December are gathering in Washington to protest over the role of the bank and its sister institution, the International Monetary Fund (IMF), in the globalisation of the world economy.

webTitle: British MPs find 'irregularities' in Peru poll

fields.headline: British MPs find 'irregularities' in Peru poll
fields.trailText: A British delegation sent to monitor Peruvian elections yesterday expressed concern about the way the poll was conducted.
fields.body:
A British delegation sent to monitor Peruvian elections yesterday expressed concern about the way the poll was conducted.

President Alberto Fujimori, who has ruled Peru for a decade, suspending parts of the constitution and overriding the judicial process, was yesterday accused by his main challenger, Alejandro Toledo, of rigging the poll.

Official results of the presidential election have not yet been released, but Mr Toledo's supporters fear that Mr Fujimori will be declared the outright winner rather than face a run-off.

The monitoring group, Transparencia, reported abuse of the election process by supporters of Mr Fujimori. Parliamentarians from various European countries sent as independent monitors backed its findings.

The delegation, which includes the British Labour MP Tom Clarke and the Ulster Unionist MP Willie Ross, spent polling day in Lima. Mr Clarke said: "We are profoundly disappointed about the irregularities on polling day itself and believe there should be a second round. We hope the authorities will respect the view of the Peruvian people."

Transparencia, basing its projection on counting slips at a small number of voting centres, put Mr Fujimori at 48.7% to Mr Toledo' s 41%. With only three hours to go, Mr Toledo believed he had won and his supporters were celebrating in the centre of Lima.

If Mr Fujimori secures less than 50%, there will be a second round in June. Forcing a second round would be a triumph for Mr Toledo, a US-educated economist, who weeks ago had poll ratings of only 4%.

Mr Toledo addressed thousands of supporters in Lima on Sunday night, saying: "They are dressing up the results without listening to the will of the people. I want them to know if they attempt to twist the will of the people that I will be the first to go to the streets, at the front of the line, to defend the rights of the nation. I am Indian and I am a rebel with a cause."

He then started a march to the presidential palace where demonstrators threw stones before police using teargas dispersed the crowd.

Mr Fujimori, whose appeal is based on curbing inflation and defeating Marxist guerrilla groups, is trying for a third five-year term. It is alleged that his helpers forged a million signatures to register his candidacy.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iranian editor loses appeal
fields.body:
Iranian editor loses appeal

An Iranian editor who challenged the Islamic law of retribution was jailed yesterday after losing an appeal against a 30-month sentence imposed for criticising capital punishment.

The leading reformer, Mashallah Shamsolvaezin, was jailed for offending religious values in an article that he wrote for the newspaper, Neshat, which was closed by the hardline press court which originally sentenced him. Reuters, Tehran

Stolen art listed on the internet

Germany launched an internet website yesterday listing thousands of works of art thought to have been plundered by the Nazis from museums and victims during the second world war.

The new website, www.lostart.de, includes unclaimed treasures amassed by the armies of Adolf Hitler for the lavish "Führer Museum" he dreamed of building in the Austrian town of Linz, near where he grew up. Reuters, Berlin

Circus lions kill Brazilian boy, 6

Five circus lions devoured a six-year-old Brazilian boy in the north-eastern town of Recife after one snatched him from his father's hand and dragged him into the cage in a tent full of spectators, according to news reports yesterday.

Police wounded two people with bullet fragments in the ensuing pandemonium as they machine-gunned the cage to scare the lions. "My daughter saw her little brother dragged away," the boy's father said. Reuters Sao Paulo

Russian recruit kills 8 soldiers

An investigation has begun into a 19-year-old private suspected of shooting dead eight soldiers in an army train in the central Volgograd region of Russia.

Oleg Dovzhenko allegedly broke into a wagon containing ammunition, took two automatic guns and shot dead a sergeant with whom he had an "unfriendly relationship". The others were killed because they were witnesses, the regional prosecutor's office said. Reuters, Moscow

Farmer kicked by ostrich

A Norwegian farmer had his lungs punctured yesterday after an ostrich kicked him in the ribs, apparently mistaking him for a feathered male rival. Reuters, Oslo

webTitle: Muslims choose moderates in Bosnian election

fields.headline: Muslims choose moderates in Bosnian election
fields.trailText: Bosnian Muslims appear to have rejected nationalist parties in weekend local elections, and voted for a multi-ethnic party favoured by the west, results showed yesterday.
fields.body:
Bosnian Muslims appear to have rejected nationalist parties in weekend local elections, and voted for a multi-ethnic party favoured by the west, results showed yesterday.

Results from 13 out of 145 municipalites showed big gains for the multi-ethnic Social Democratic Party, but Serb and Croat voters have stayed loyal to the nationalist parties which led them into war.

The results suggest that the Muslim community, particularly in larger towns such as Sarajevo, has been the first to turn its back on nationalists. The result will give a impetus to the holding of a general election in Bosnia in October. Western authorities in Bosnia welcomed the result. The US ambassador, Thomas Miller, called it 'the beginning of a new era'.

But that enthusiasm may be dampened by the victory of the Serbian Democratic Party, which was founded by the indicted war criminal Radovan Karadzic, in large parts of the Serbian Republic in Bosnia, and by the Croatian Democratic Union in Croatian areas of the federation.

The hope of the international community will be that, in the general election, Serbs and Croats will follow the Muslims' lead and choose more moderate parties which came second and third in many areas.

They hope that when Serbs and Croats see that the Muslims have rejected their own Party of Democratic Action, they will feel encouraged to choose social democratic and liberal parties in the regions of Bosnia where their communities are dominant.

The big vote for the Serbian Democratic Party was probably helped by the arrest last week of one of its wartime leaders, Momcilo Krajisnik, by Nato soldiers acting for the international war crimes tribunal in the Hague.

The nationalist wins may yet be tempered by the counting of the votes of 300,000 refugees and 800,000 internally displaced people, who were entitled to vote for candidates in the communities from which they were expelled during the war. The final results may take weeks.

The leader of the Social Democrats, Zlatko Lagumdzija, was upbeat about his party's gains in Muslim areas.

"This is the biggest political turn since Dayton," he said, referring to the 1995 peace agreement that ended the Bosnian war.

webTitle: New CDU chief takes Brussels by surprise

fields.headline: New CDU chief takes Brussels by surprise
fields.trailText: In a break with the past which will send tremors through much of the European Union, the new leader of Germany's conservatives last night outlined a vision for Europe radically at odds with the one to which the German right has been wedded for decades.
fields.body:
In a break with the past which will send tremors through much of the European Union, the new leader of Germany's conservatives last night outlined a vision for Europe radically at odds with the one to which the German right has been wedded for decades.

Angela Merkel, who was elected to head the Christian Democrats at a congress in Essen, used her keynote address to call for power to be wrested away from Brussels and given back to national, regional and, particularly, local politicians.

Her party's rank and file had demanded a radical break with the scandal-tainted era of Helmut Kohl, and yesterday they got it. Though not Eurosceptic as such - it did not question German membership of the EU - Ms Merkel's vision of a much looser union with more devolved powers, was light years away from the one foreseen by Mr Kohl.

In a much more rightwing speech than had been ex pected, Ms Merkel linked her cause to the profoundly German concept of the Heimat -beloved native town or village.

"Either we succeed in creating a Europe of the people or we shall have to put up with a centralised and over-bureaucratic entity," she said, using language which would not have been out of place at a Tory conference. The first woman and the first easterner to head a major German party, Ms Merkel was later voted into office unopposed, with 95% of the ballot.

Struggling to reunite a movement reeling from the recent funding scandal, Ms Merkel made repeated conciliatory gestures to the right. Most strikingly, she attacked the EU for its isolation of Austria where Jörg Haider's far-right Freedom party is a partner in government.

Her criticism was that the EU had only succeeded in promoting Mr Haider's cause, from which she disassociated her party, the Christian Democratic Union (CDU). But she made it clear that voters had the right to opt for such movements.

"If the nations of the EU and their heads of state and government behave as they have towards Austria in recent weeks and months, the Europe of the future will not be a Europe of the people," she said. "We are really not friends of the Freedom party ... but instead of judging Vienna by its deeds, [the governments of the rest of Europe] want to isolate almost two-thirds of the Austrian voters."

Ms Merkel was careful to stress her party's continuing commitment to the EU. "European consensus politics are peace politics," she declared. But she went on to deploy views not heard from a CDU leader since at least the 1950s.

"Centralisation is the same as egalitarianism and egalitarianism means standstill," warned Ms Merkel, who rose to prominence as a dissident in East Germany.

In a passage reminiscent of John Major's lyrical evocation of spinsters on bicycles, Ms Merkel sketched her vision.

Heimat was not "experiencing the community as an anonymous machine that distributes money but as a place where one is needed and where one can decide and take responsibility", she said.

Because Germany had strong regional characteristics, "it is only logical that we say no to centralism and over-regulation whether it comes from Brussels or Berlin, but that we say yes to a Europe of the regions and of the diversity of its citizens", she added.

Ms Merkel, 45, floated to the leadership on a tide of popular support after her predecessor, Wolfgang Schäuble stepped down. Mr Schäuble was caught up in the funding scandal which broke after Mr Kohl, known as the reunification chancellor, admitted running secret accounts.

Mr Kohl was notably absent from yesterday's proceedings - the first time he had failed to attend a CDU conference for more than 40 years.

webTitle: Historic church at heart of a modern row

fields.headline: Historic church at heart of a modern row
fields.trailText: Built in 1693 by a wealthy uncle of Peter the Great, the little red brick and stucco Church of the Intercession standing in generous parkland to the west of the city centre is the jewel of Moscow baroque.
fields.body:
Built in 1693 by a wealthy uncle of Peter the Great, the little red brick and stucco Church of the Intercession standing in generous parkland to the west of the city centre is the jewel of Moscow baroque.

Its upper chapel is the sole 17th century church interior in Russia to have survived intact the ravages wrought through the centuries by Napoleon, the Nazis and Stalin's atheistic demolition men. But having coped with the barbarities visited on it over 300 years, the church now faces a new threat.

According to some of Russia's architecture experts, incense and overcrowding could succeed where despots failed and destroy a precious national heirloom.

The church hierarchy wants to use the building as a normal parish church, open to the public 12 hours a day. The experts are horrified at the prospect. After serving as a carefully-tended museum for years, the church is to be handed over to the Moscow patriarchate on the orders of the president-elect, Vladimir Putin.

One morning last week Father Boris, an indefatigable art historian and campaigner for the restitution of Russia's orthodox churches, marched into the chapel waving the piece of paper just signed by Mr Putin. It was the climax to a 10-year battle for control of the church.

Since 1990 the Russian orthodox church has recovered 16,000 churches and monasteries. The Church of the Intercession is the latest to be restored. But the curators, backed by the ministry of culture, are determined to fight Mr Putin's ruling.

Officially the church is run by curators as part of the Rublev museum, but the Putin paper awarded use and control of the church to the Moscow patriarchate, bluntly rescinding a cul ture ministry ruling in January that the building should be allowed to remain in the care of its curators.

"This is our cultural heritage and that is paramount. That's what we should be thinking about," says Gennady Popov, director of the Rublev museum. "But Father Boris is determined to take total control. Putin should not have signed that document. He had no right."

Alexei Komech, an expert on old Russian architecture and director of the art research institute, is outraged at Mr Putin's decision and at the patriarchate's campaign.

"The church is too valuable. We need a solution here that suits both believers and non-believers in Russia. It's part of our common heritage. But the government is just trying to curry favour with the patriarchate because orthodoxy is very fashionable these days and increasingly powerful."

The Church of the Intercession comprises lower and upper chapels. The bottom part is currently used for exhibitions, art history seminars and other meetings. For years Father Boris, who will be the new parish priest, has been lobbying for it to be returned to its original function.

To defuse the row, the curators proposed building a new wooden church nearby for regular services and agreed to joint administration of the property with the patriarchate. The culture ministry endorsed this deal. But the orthodox clout with Mr Putin appears to be considerable.

"For these experts our churches are not churches," says Father Boris. "They're architectural monuments. What are we supposed to be?" he asks. "Vandals of our own churches? We'll be having services there. The church will be open every day for believers."

The curators refer to dampness charts and hydrological studies to argue that opening the church to normal services would imperil the delicate interior, although services would be held only in the lower part and not in the more precious upper chapel which is to be administered jointly by the museum and the patriarchate.

"So you can have conferences, film shows, debates, but not church services," Father Boris points out. "It's just resistance and obstruction. They're always the same, it's ideological."

But the priest, who says he can tell that Mr Putin is a genuine believer "from the way he walks into a church", is relishing his victory perhaps prematurely. "I went to the museum director the other day to discuss when I could take over. He said he hadn't seen the Putin paper yet, that no one had told him officially. So I left."

webTitle: Stasi tapped Kohl's phones round the clock for 14 years

fields.headline: Stasi tapped Kohl's phones round the clock for 14 years
fields.trailText: East Germany's infamous Stasi secret police tapped the private and official telephones of the former chancellor Helmut Kohl round the clock for 14 years of his political career, ex-officers of the now defunct communist intelligence service revealed in a series of interviews published yesterday.
fields.body:
East Germany's infamous Stasi secret police tapped the private and official telephones of the former chancellor Helmut Kohl round the clock for 14 years of his political career, ex-officers of the now defunct communist intelligence service revealed in a series of interviews published yesterday.

Former Stasi officers who carried out the bugging told Berlin's Tagesspiegel newspaper that East Germany used automatic radio listening devices to systematically tap Mr Kohl's phones from 1975, when he became prime minister of the state of Rhineland-Palatinate, until shortly after the fall of the Berlin wall in 1989.

The bugging was carried out 24 hours a day on Mr Kohl's official, private and car telephones and included 30 of the former chancellor's close aides. The recordings resulted in a weekly 25- to 30-page Stasi report that was delivered to the East German politburo.

"The chancellery was wide open as far as we were concerned," one of the officers was quoted as saying. "The only time we couldn't listen in was when Kohl was on the line to the American president."

The disclosures stepped up the already intense pressure on Mr Kohl to break his silence on the scandal surrounding his Christian Democrats by naming the donors to the slush funds he used to bankroll the party illegally.

Publication of the Kohl conversations tapped by the Stasi would almost certainly provide a detailed and damaging exposé of the ex-chancellor's illicit fundraising activities.

The Stasi officers, who were not named in the report, said it was "absolutely realistic" to conclude that a potentially explosive 9,000-page dossier covering Mr Kohl's years as chancellor between 1982 and 1989 still existed.

webTitle: Marry a foreigner and you'll pay the price, say Emirates

fields.headline: Marry a foreigner and you'll pay the price, say Emirates
fields.trailText: Officials in the United Arab Emirates are struggling to stop young people marrying foreigners, a trend blamed for soaring divorce rates across the Gulf states.
fields.body:
Officials in the United Arab Emirates are struggling to stop young people marrying foreigners, a trend blamed for soaring divorce rates across the Gulf states.

At present all children born to Emirati parents become UAE citizens, but new proposals will limit this right to children whose fathers are UAE nationals. The legislation would make it almost impossible for an Emirati woman divorcing a foreigner to win custody of her children because they could be technically stateless.

Child custody is a thorny issue in Islamic societies, where sharia law generally grants custody of children old enough to be weaned to the father in the event of divorce.

Studies indicate that divorce rates have risen sharply in the last decade in all Gulf states; around a quarter of marriages end in divorce in Qatar and Saudi Arabia, rising to 29% in Kuwait and 40% in the UAE. Officials in several states, including the UAE, have blamed marriages to foreigners for rising divorce rates.

This month senior officials in Abu Dhabi unveiled plans to introduce mandatory medical tests for Emirati brides whose husbands-to-be had applied to the government-run Marriage Fund for financial assistance.

Marriage Fund grants will be available only once the woman has been tested, but the ministry of justice, Islamic affairs and endowments said it would ban marriages where the woman tested positive for certain unspecified diseases.

The UAE's ruler, Sheikh Zayed, created the £42m marriage fund in 1992 to combat the soaring dowry prices blamed for rising numbers of marriages to foreigners.

The fund offers money to men marrying local women. It has threatened fines of up to £80,000 on families whose weddings defy the new austerity and has ordered parents to limit dowries to £6,000.

Officials are promoting mass weddings - common in poor Shi'a villages in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province - to cut costs.

Meanwhile, teachers and youth workers report that teenage Emirati girls are increasingly reluctant to marry, finding their male compatriots conservative and saying that foreign Arab men make more considerate husbands.

"It amazes me how cynical my female students are about marriage," said a teacher in Dubai. "They would rather never marry than marry a man who expects them to lead the same kind of life as their mothers.

"They often say that they want to marry a non-national. They do not want to be second wives; they want to be the first wife, full stop."

fields.headline: No: 1612  Hansie Cronje
fields.body:
Age: What's it worth?

What are you saying? Nothing, it's a joke.

Well how old is he then? 30.

Appearance: Stressed.

Position: Captain of the South African cricket team.

Status: Innocent until proven guilty.

Why's he in the dock? The Indian police have accused him of taking bribes from bookmakers during the recent one-day series against India.

Sounds serious: If it's true, cricket will never be quite the same again, and Cronje's career will be over.

And is it true? That is the 64-million rupee question. The New Delhi crime branch say they have an incriminating tape of Cronje and London-based bookmaker Sanjay Chawla discussing a forthcoming match.

Let's hear it then: At the moment, they are refusing to release it and until they do all bets are off.

Unfortunate phrase: Sorry. They have released a transcript of the alleged conversation, said to be taken from a bugged telephone call, but that proves nothing.

Where do we go from here? The Indians want Cronje arrested; the South Africans are protesting his innocence.

What's he like? Combative, tempestuous, God-fearing. He reads the Bible every day and proclaims a strict moral code: he won't let players' girlfriends stay at the team hotel because he thinks it's unseemly.

Sounds like a paragon: "I am not perfect. I will say and do the wrong things sometimes. People might point to me and say 'you're a Christian, you can't do that'."

Is that evidence? No it's a suggestive quote I've taken slightly out of context. Hang on a moment while I check it with the lawyer...

Ah, you're back. What did he say? It's OK.

Not to be confused with: Australians Shane Warne and Mark Waugh, who were fined for giving (very bland) information to bookmakers in 1995.

Do ask: Why the Indians don't stop smearing Cronje and his team-mates and just produce the tape.

Don't ask: Why no one ever bribes England to lose cricket matches.

webTitle: Japan strives to improve its debt relief image

fields.headline: Japan strives to improve its debt relief image
fields.standfirst:
Debt relief: special report
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: Japan sought to shake off its reputation as a laggard on debt relief yesterday by announcing plans to write off millions of dollars of outstanding loans and to make a twenty-fold increase in its contribution to a fund for the world's poorest nations.
fields.body:
Japan sought to shake off its reputation as a laggard on debt relief yesterday by announcing plans to write off millions of dollars of outstanding loans and to make a twenty-fold increase in its contribution to a fund for the world's poorest nations.

The declaration received only a muted welcome, however, from Jubilee 2000, the UK-based campaign which has threatened to send thousands of supporters to this summer's Group of Seven summit in Okinawa unless Japan takes a more active role on debt relief.

Under the new plan, Japan will write off up to 100% of loans owed by the world's 40 most impoverished nations.

Compared to the previous 90% maximum reduction, this represents an extra 14bn yen (£85m) in potential debt "forgiveness". Britain, the US, France, Italy and Canada have promised 100% debt relief.

The foreign ministry said Japan would also increase its contribution to the World Bank fund for poor nations to $200m (£129m) from $10m.

Jubilee 2000 said the announcement was still short of the commitments made by other countries because most of Japan's official development loans are provided through multilateral organisations not covered by the latest move.

webTitle: TV soccer and casual dress hurt retailers

fields.headline: TV soccer and casual dress hurt retailers
fields.trailText: Strong competitive pressures in Britain's high streets kept price rises at bay last month as shops and stores blamed a late Easter, dressing-down for the office and too much televised football for a drop-off in activity.
fields.body:
Strong competitive pressures in Britain's high streets kept price rises at bay last month as shops and stores blamed a late Easter, dressing-down for the office and too much televised football for a drop-off in activity.

Data to be released by the British Retail Consortium today shows how low unemployment and eight years of growth has failed to boost inflationary pressures, with discounting a vital ingredient for outlets trying to attract consumers.

Official government figures for manufacturing released yesterday also revealed that producers are absorbing the hefty rise in the cost of oil in their profit margins rather than risk passing on higher costs to customers.

City analysts said that the oil-inspired increase in manufacturers' fuel and raw material costs over the past year may now have peaked, and that fears of sharply higher interest rates over the coming months were misplaced.

According to the BRC's retail sales monitor, the value of business last month was 0.8% down on March 1999, largely due to the timing of Easter. The BRC said that both Good Friday and Easter Sunday fell in March last year and that this may have reduced sales growth by 5%.

Bridget Rosewell, chief economic adviser to the BRC, said: "The figures suggest that a fairly steady recovery is now underway in retail sales, even though inflation figures show that this is based on discounting as much as recovery in demand."

Among the various sectors of the high street, menswear sales were weak. The BRC said that this reflected the move to dress down at work, adding that some retailers had also suggested that "too much televised football was keeping men away from the shops".

Electrical and electronic retailers found that demand for mobile phones was strong, but prices were lower than last year. Sales of the new-generation phones - with internet access - were building as stocks arrived in the stores, but prices of "old" technology TVs, videos and hi-fi were being pushed down by the increased popularity of DVDs, minidisk and widescreen and digital televisions.

The figures for producer prices from the Office for National Statistics showed that industry's input costs rose by 0.8% last month in the wake of increases in excise duties in the budget and the spike in the oil price to over $30 a barrel. The annual rate of increase dipped slightly from 14.1% to 13.8%.

However, with output falling in manufacturing, firms are intent on keeping price rises to a minimum. The price of goods leaving factory gates rose by 0.5% in March - a smaller increase than in March 1999 - and by 2.3% over the past 12 months.

Excluding food, beverages, tobacco and petroleum - which strips out both oil prices and excise duty effects - industry's output prices rose by just 0.1% last month.

fields.headline: Property prices cool further
fields.trailText: The rate of house price growth in London and the south-east is slowing dramatically, providing fresh evidence that the property market is starting to cool, the Halifax announced yesterday.
fields.body:
The rate of house price growth in London and the south-east is slowing dramatically, providing fresh evidence that the property market is starting to cool, the Halifax announced yesterday.

It said new figures showed the price of a typical London house rose 4% in the first three months of this year - less than half the 8.5% growth notched up in the final quarter of 1999 - because growing numbers of would-be buyers are being priced out of the market.

The lender said the price of the average UK home rose 3.2% in the first three months of this year compared with a rise of 3.6% in the fourth quarter of last year and 4.4% in the third quarter.

But there were marked variations across the regions. Prices in the West Midlands and the south-west rose 5.1% and 5% respectively over the period, for example, while the figure for the north of England was just 1%.

Price rises in the south-east dropped from 7.9% at the end of last year to 1.4%.

The housing market remained "buoyant" but the four interest rate rises since September appeared to be having an impact on demand, the Halifax said.

London and the south-east have been leading the boom, but sharp rises over the past year have made it difficult for potential purchasers - particularly first-time buyers - to enter the market, curbing demand. Prices in London are forecast to moderate further over the rest of this year.

The figures were released on the day the government announced details of its new "fair charges, easy access and decent terms" (CAT) standards - the new voluntary rules for mortgages aimed at preventing unfair terms and hidden charges.

The planned minimum standards of fairness and simplicity have been extended to discounted rate and cashback mortgages, which were previously excluded.

The treasury said the scheme was designed to allow more borrowers to benefit from low charges and "no surprises". It includes a requirement that the interest rate on variable rate loans should be no higher than 2% above the Bank of England base rate, and that for fixed and capped rate loans, no "lock-in" early redemption penalties would be allowed after the end of the fixed/capped period.

While the move to include discounted rate and cashback mortgages was welcomed, a decision to ban mortgage brokers from charging borrowers a fee when they recommend CAT-marked mortgages was criticised by the Council of Mortgage Lenders (CML), which said this could restrict the take-up rate for the deals.

"In extreme circumstances the rules might give rise to borrowers not being recommended a CAT mortgage even if this was the most suitable product for them," the CML said.

The first CAT-standard mortgages are expected to go on sale in the next few days. The Woolwich welcomed the new rules, saying it would launch two deals within weeks, while Abbey National said it would unveil a range of products by early summer.

fields.headline: Phantom builders cost taxman £1m
fields.standfirst: Accountant claimed rebates on behalf of fictional clients
fields.trailText: An accountant whose dishonest advice to building workers cost the Inland Revenue more than £1m is likely to face a prison sentence after conviction on two counts of cheating the tax authorities. Seven people have pleaded guilty to connected offences.
fields.body:
An accountant whose dishonest advice to building workers cost the Inland Revenue more than £1m is likely to face a prison sentence after conviction on two counts of cheating the tax authorities. Seven people have pleaded guilty to connected offences.

Investigations into similar rackets are continuing under the auspices of the revenue's special compliance office in Nottingham.

Simon Rogers, aged 41, of Stevenage, bolstered his list of genuine clients with thousands of phantom building workers and made false claims for tax rebates on behalf of both the real and fictional tax payers. Rogers, who had denied the offences, was convicted at Blackfriars Crown Court, central London, after a 10-week trial. The revenue expects him to be sent to prison.

The seven self-employed building workers who admitted revenue offences were either clients or associates of Rogers. They are Neil Scott, of Letchworth, John Mitchell of London, Michael James and John McGinnity, both of Stevenage, Anthony Whaymand , of Baldock, Colin Chantler of Huntingdon and Robert Knights, of Watford.

Sentencing of all those convicted will take place on May 2. An eighth man was found not guilty and a ninth died before coming to trial.

Rogers misused revenue forms supplied to the construction industry allowing those who have overpaid tax to claim it back. His Stevenage-based practice boasted 4,600 clients, which if true, the revenue noted, would make it "the largest of its kind in the home counties".

In reality, a large chunk of the client list was fictional, and one headache for revenue investigators has been sifting real from invented clients.

Anonymous death threats were made to two witnesses in the case, according to the revenue, to prevent them from testifying. Although Rogers's practice has been closed down, the revenue believes similar tax fraud is being carried out elsewhere in the east Midlands and northern home counties and a major inquiry is continuing. Information supplied to the investigation, the revenue said, will be treated in strict confidence.

Halfway through the financial year, the number of people convicted of serious fiscal offences was about the same as for the whole of 1998/99.

Most prosecutions arise from "aggravating features" such as false invoicing or lying to revenue officers.

Simon Rogers, aged 41, of Stevenage, bolstered his list of genuine clients with thousands of phantom building workers and made false claims for tax rebates on behalf of both the real and fictional tax payers. Rogers, who had denied the offences, was convicted at Blackfriars Crown Court, central London, after a 10-week trial. The revenue expects him to be sent to prison. The seven self-employed building workers who admitted revenue offences were either clients or associates of Rogers. They are Neil Scott, of Letchworth, John Mitchell of London, Michael James and John McGinnity, both of Stevenage, Anthony Whaymand , of Baldock, Colin Chantler of Huntingdon and Robert Knights, of Watford. fields.headline: Keep the customer satisfied
fields.standfirst: Carmakers will give Byers a fight
fields.trailText: It's a little late, but Stephen Byers is getting the hang of this speaking-with-forked-tongue stuff. Just as he is encouraging a market-bucking alternative bid for Rover he says he is ready to stamp out anti-competitive behaviour in the market for new cars - just as every consumer body has been screaming at the government to do for years.
fields.body:
It's a little late, but Stephen Byers is getting the hang of this speaking-with-forked-tongue stuff. Just as he is encouraging a market-bucking alternative bid for Rover he says he is ready to stamp out anti-competitive behaviour in the market for new cars - just as every consumer body has been screaming at the government to do for years.

Potential car consumers have been boycotting the UK market in the hope that Mr Byers, armed with the competition commission report on new car sales, would force manufacturers to cut prices by thousands of pounds. And so it was not surprising to see the manufacturers welcoming the report yesterday. Believe it or not, they like clearer air too. But they also expect a pick-up in sales in response to modest, line-toeing cuts and all the while the manufacturers can be expected to fight Mr Byers' new package of measure every inch of the way.

It would be nice now to see a clear indication from the trade secretary that he is ready to fight hard and fast for abolition of the so-called block exception. This is the European Commission's device which enables car makers to continue the uncompetitive practice of selling new cars only through their own dealer networks.

More than anything else this keeps prices artificially high, and while it is due to end in September 2002, there seems no reason why it should not disappear rather sooner. The problem for Mr Byers is that Britain has no EU veto on this. If other Euro-states, some of which have a vested interest in high British car prices, decide to continue the arrangement, Mr Byers will be back to his old self - looking ineffectual.

Meanwhile, the Competition Commission has pointed out that while car makers claim low margins, transfer pricing makes it impossible to establish just how profitable their British operations really are.

We are simply left with a headline "rip-off" figure of £1bn, which sounds as though it has been plucked out of thin air, and there is bound to be lots of quibbling about this when the manufacturers turn up at Downing Street tomorrow. Rather than talking numbers, Mr Blair might respond with the word "service" and point out that it is time that new car sales are carried out in an even-handed way, that takes account of the consumer's interest.

Car giants pride themselves on the services they offer to customers, but yesterday's report shows that these are little more than a blind for a restrictive pricing policy. Ford says it is aiming to be the world's largest "service company," not just the world's second largest car maker. Other car firms harbour similar ambitions. Treating their UK customers fairly would be a good starting point.

Think again

On the subject of service, we've all done it - skulked into the shop, bearing right to avoid the sales desk, past the managers' soiled specials, only to be caught by a 17-year-old launching into the pros and cons of something called a graphics card. By the time he starts warning on the danger of running up against limitations on the motherboard in two to three months time the urge to buy what is directly on offer or get the hell out of there becomes irresistible.

Intentionally or otherwise, Sir Stanley Kalms, the boss of Dixons, has done more than most to ensure that the average shopper, trying to buy a simple piece of consumer electrical kit, feels mentally retarded. This approach to customer relations has helped the development first of mail-order and more recently web-based electrical suppliers to the point where the competition authorities decided last year that Dixons did not have a dominant market position - whatever the suspicious eyes of consumers suggested.

Yesterday, the office of fair trading appeared to have little time for the latest complaint about Dixons, this time concerning its exclusive supply agreements with Compaq and Packard Bell, casually declaring that such vertical deals between manufacturers and retailers were commonplace and rarely raised competitive concerns.

If this really is the OFT's view, then John Bridgeman might start by reading the competition commission's report into the car market. There's a bit in there about vertical agreements.

Then he might look again at some of Dixons' statements, such as the claim that it does not exert notable control over the market in consumers' first PCs - which rather jars with the success of its internet-offspring Freeserve, having snapped up a third of the British internet service provider market over the past 18 months.

Then Mr Bridgeman should look at the reputation and conservative commercial style of the company voicing the complaints against Dixons - the John Lewis Partnership. The fact that it has gone public at all suggests its arguments deserve a more considered response.

webTitle: Murdoch must find a modus Vivendi

fields.headline: Murdoch must find a modus Vivendi
fields.standfirst: Market forces  David Teather
fields.trailText: The cost of the government blocking Rupert Murdoch's bid for Manchester United last year was painfully clear for the media mogul when the football club's market value passed the £1bn mark earlier this year, against Mr Murdoch's bid of £623m.
fields.body:
The cost of the government blocking Rupert Murdoch's bid for Manchester United last year was painfully clear for the media mogul when the football club's market value passed the £1bn mark earlier this year, against Mr Murdoch's bid of £623m.

Given that few could find any reason for the bid being blocked other than voters' sentiment, it is not far-fetched to think Mr Murdoch might now want something in return. Nor is it unlikely that this government will be willing to play ball.

That was the contention on Sunday in the Observer, which suggested a deal had been brokered between Mr Murdoch and the prime minister which would force French conglomerate Vivendi to sell its 25% stake in BSkyB. The French firm's investment is being investigated by the competition commission.

Mr Murdoch, whose News Corporation has a 40% stake in BSkyB, is reportedly rattled by Vivendi's stake, which was built up last summer after merger talks between BSkyB and Vivendi's pay-television business, Canal Plus, broke down.

Mr Murdoch reportedly has been irked by calls from the French company's chief executive, Jean-Marie Messier, to renew the talks.

The prospect of another 25% of BSkyB equity flooding the market initially caused shares in the company to fall by 6%. They rallied and finished 2.2% lower at £17.17.

The reason for the rebound was that many analysts thought the scenario unlikely. Mr Murdoch hopes to merge his satellite assets into a single company that would offer a ready-made platform for alliances with internet firms. Galling as it may be for Mr Murdoch, Vivendi would be an ideal partner.

webTitle: Capital may ride to Border rescue

fields.headline: Capital may ride to Border rescue
fields.trailText: Capital Radio is mulling a white knight offer for Carlisle-based Border Television which would value the besieged company at up to £140m.
fields.body:
Capital Radio is mulling a white knight offer for Carlisle-based Border Television which would value the besieged company at up to £140m.

Chrysalis, which last week partnered Border in a failed bid for the second London digital multiplex licence, is also understood to be weighing a bid of about the same value.

The stock offer from Capital is thought to value Border at about £13 a share. A cash alternative of £12.25 is also expected to be put on the table.

Border directors met Capital yesterday and must now decide whether to accept an offer that would see off the hostile predator, Scottish Radio Holdings.

Buyers have already been lined up for some of Border's radio assets in a number of the putative bids because of potential regulatory difficulties - either because of the points system that restricts radio ownership or because of potential regional conflicts.

The Capital bid would significantly outstrip the approach made by Scottish Radio, which has dropped in value since the bid was made four weeks ago. Scottish Radio's offer of 10 shares for every 17 Border shares was yesterday worth just 911p. Shares in Border, which have risen steadily since the bid, climbed another 20p to £11.75p.

A cash alternative is on offer from Scottish Radio at £10.25 a share.

Border owns one of the few remaining independent ITV franchises, but it is the company's recent efforts to build a radio empire that have attracted suitors. Border has four stations - three which air under the Century brand, and Sun FM in Sunderland. They are regarded as some of the most potentially lucrative franchises in the country, with a reach of 9.2m adults.

Border last week argued that its Scottish predator's offer undervalued the company's potential worth.

Scottish Radio said yesterday that it had "the best fit, the best management and the most synergies to draw from the transaction. If anyone pays more than we are prepared to pay, then they are overpaying".

Scottish Radio shares yesterday fell 25p to £15.50, Chrysalis was unchanged at £14.50p and Capital was down 75p at £15.12. None of the other parties involved would comment.

fields.headline: MPs call banks to account
fields.standfirst: Barclays will be forced to explain closures and pay policies
fields.trailText: Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, will end his silence over the bank's controversial closure of 171 branches next week when he is questioned by an influential body of MPs.
fields.body:
Matt Barrett, chief executive of Barclays, will end his silence over the bank's controversial closure of 171 branches next week when he is questioned by an influential body of MPs.

Mr Barrett is expected to defend his bank's policy to the Treasury select committee just days before Barclays' annual general meeting at which shareholders will be asked to approve his new performance-related pay deal, estimated by some remuneration experts to be worth up to £30m.

He is expected to be joined before the committee by Peter Ellwood, chief executive of Lloyds TSB, and Bill Dalton, chief executive of HSBC's UK bank. NatWest is expected to be absent despite being asked by the committee to attend.

While the banks have been asked to discuss with the select committee on April 18 Don Cruickshank's recent review of the banking industry, they can also expect a tough time on issues such as branch closures and pay.

Lloyds TSB, which has the largest branch network in the country, yesterday pledged not to close any of its branches where it risks leaving a community without a bank at all, which was one of the strongest criticisms levelled at Barclays last week.

Lloyds TSB is already the last bank on 125 high streets but analysts estimate that despite this pledge it might be able to take the axe to its 2,300 branch network because of the overlap remaining from the merger between Lloyds and TSB.

Industry analysts calculate that as many as 400 town and villages around the country have a Lloyds and a TSB branch, although the bank insisted yesterday that it should not be taken for granted that it would close branches.

Giles Radice, chairman of the Treasury select committee, said yesterday that all three banks faced questions on the Cruickshank report, which among other things suggested a competition commission review of small-business banking.

Mr Cruickshank, a former telecoms regulator, published his report last month after an 18-month investigation instigated by the chancellor.

"We are taking Cruickshank as our text. We were waiting for Cruickshank [before calling the hearing] and we're going to follow him up," Mr Radice said.

But it was "100% certain" that the bank chief executives would face scrutiny about the more "populist" issues such as their branch closure programmes and salaries.

Confusion surrounded the reason for the absence of NatWest, the country's biggest supplier of banking services to small businesses. A spokesman for Royal Bank of Scotland, which took over NatWest last month, put it down to a "simple conflict of diaries".

Last week John Varley, Barclays' chief executive of retail financial services, defended the branch closures, which still leave the bank with the second largest network in the country.

The select committee hearing comes at time when banks are being called on to act in a more socially responsible way while also being forced to cut costs to offer the best possible return to their shareholders.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.body:
Shares closed off their session lows but sentiment was hit late in the day by an opening fall on the American Nasdaq market, awakening fears that the recent recovery in so-called tech stocks might prove to be short-lived.

The FTSE 100 index closed 36 points lower at 6533.4, while the FTSE 250 ended 1.3 adrift at 6459.8. The FTSE Techmark 100, on the other hand, suffered a 33.86 slide to 4361.30. Trading volume was relatively thin.

Shares in Pearson were in demand, closing 38p higher at £23.59 as Goldman Sachs made positive comments on the outlook for the media and publishing group in the wake of last week's ground-breaking European TV deal.

In the food retailing sector, J Sainsbury rebounded 16p to 324p as HSBC Securities - reportedly a long-time bear of the stock - turned positive. Analysts at the bank seem to like the new chief executive, Peter Davis.

But Unilever fell 15p to 410p after Deutsche Bank downgraded the stock to "neutral" from "buy". Analysts are said to be worried by the complexity of the restructuring faced by the group.

Emap shot 43p higher to £11.37 after Warburg Dillon Read reiterated its "buy" stance on the shares and set a £17 share price target.

In the banking sector, the rot at Barclays stopped for the moment, with the bank's share buyback programme helping to push the price 72p higher to £16.92 in the wake of the damaging comment over its bank closure programme.

Freeserve dropped 59p to 432p as its parent, Dixons, was savaged by retailing rival John Lewis over the its supply agreements with Compaq and Packard Bell.

Among the leaders, gases group BOC proved to be one of the worst performers, dropping from £12.26 to £10.89. The move reflected growing worries that its planned merger with Air Liquide of France and Air Products of the US could face forced divestments by US regulators.

US litigation worries continued to weigh on British American Tobacco after another adverse judgment in Florida on Friday. The shares closed 26p lower at 302p.

Tadpole Technology , the portable computer maker which became a laughing stock in the stock in the early 1990s, jumped from 59p to 79p after announcing that its Endeavors Technology division - bought recently for just £2m - would make a statement today concerning its web-based software. The software is said to help integrate desktop and laptop computers as well as mobile internet devices.

webTitle: Blue Circle bid signals time for change

fields.headline: Blue Circle bid signals time for change
fields.standfirst: Now it is the cement industry's turn to expect global consolidation
fields.trailText: Pick an industry - from aerospace to automotive, banking to oil - and globalisation is forcing the pace of change. Consolidation is the name of the game. Top players are looking for the most effective combinations, the best alliances, to exploit the new opportunities of scale in the worldwide market.
fields.body:
Pick an industry - from aerospace to automotive, banking to oil - and globalisation is forcing the pace of change. Consolidation is the name of the game. Top players are looking for the most effective combinations, the best alliances, to exploit the new opportunities of scale in the worldwide market.

But cement and aggregates? Hardly a line of work where markets are likely to be much more than regional. Cement makers looking to rationalise their networks might be expected to find any savings in production weighed down by rising transport costs. Their cousins in the concrete game need to mix their product even closer to the customer.

At the heavy end of the business, however, the globalisation bug seems belatedly to be biting hard. The last few months have seen a series of corporate moves: Anglo-American's agreed bid for Tarmac; RMC's successful offer for Rugby; Heidelberger's acquisition of Scancem and, most recently, the £3.4bn bid from France's Lafarge for Blue Circle.

The Anglo-French battle is now entering its final stages. Lafarge has until the middle of next week to decide if it wants to increase its offer, although it is, predictably, playing its cards close to its chest. This hostile offer is slightly unusual for an industry that tends towards agreed deals, although the French group used similarly aggressive tactics when it snapped up the brickmaker Redland just over two years ago.

Lafarge's approach is straightforward, almost brutally direct. It reckons Blue Circle took its eye off the ball in the 1980s, when it branched out into heating and bathrooms. Although Blue Circle has now reversed this strategy, it is still lagging behind and is, according to Lafarge's chairman Bertrand Collomb, "only a medium-sized cement producer, struggling to regain world class status."

This may seem a little harsh. Blue Circle is a respectable number six in the world league, and it is hard to blame its flirtation with Potterton boilers and the rest of its heating and bathroom ventures for its failure to top the tree.

Lafarge argues that Blue Circle is an excellent geographical fit with few areas of overlap - a view endorsed yesterday by the European Commission's competition directorate, which decided to nod the bid through provided Lafarge sells it Danish concrete roofing tile operation. As conditions go, this is hardly a deal breaker.

The French group claims it will be able to rattle up some €125m (£78m) worth of synergies from next year. It believes, for example, that it could use its own experiences of cost cutting on Blue Circle's UK operations. It says the combined group will have a better cash flow and stronger regional positions in emerging markets.

The key factor, is likely to be the price. The 420p a share offer offered a significant premium over the market price of Blue Circle shares ahead of speculation that an offer was on the way. But it is reckoned on the cheap side, with an offer of 450p, even £5 seen as more realistic.

Though any hopes the City may have held of a white knight have yet to be realised, Lafarge still has a tricky calcula tion to make - to stick to its present bid or sweeten the terms. Interestingly the Blue Circle share price is hovering just a fraction above the offer price.

But, whatever the immediate twists and turns, the bid may prove a milestone in the industry in more ways than one.

Firstly, it raises, again, the prospect of vertical integration in British construction companies which has so far been resisted, largely on the ground that the cost benefits are minimal. Lack of integration in the industry means that even RMC, the proud new owner of Rugby, still sources some cement for its concrete mix operations from its arch rival, Blue Circle. Nevertheless, this is the issue that won't go away. And it raises, in turn, a second question: how would a new breed of integrated building materials group behave in the marketplace?

To put it kindly, the cement and concrete industries have a chequered history when it comes to price fixing. In 1994, the European Commission hit 33 cement firms - including Blue Circle, Rugby and Castle - with fines totalling £193.5m for a carve-up of the European market dating back a decade. The record is, if anything, even worse in concrete (the material when mixed and ready for use). RMC has repeatedly been found guilty of market rigging over the years, most recently by Germany's federal cartel office.

Thirdly, the relatively gentle treatment of the Lafarge bid by the European authorities suggests cement and allied businesses may be taking advantage of their relative unpopularity with technology-obsessed stock markets to slip big mergers past competition watchdogs while the going is bad.

Lafarge-Blue Circle, were it to come into being, would be the world's biggest cement producer, turning out nearly 160m tonnes a year in Europe, Asia, Africa and north and south America. A group that size ought to come up with some definitive answers as to whether the off-white powder that holds the world together can ever be a truly global industry.
fields.bodyText: Pick an industry - from aerospace to automotive, banking to oil - and globalisation is forcing the pace of change. Consolidation is the name of the game. Top players are looking for the most effective combinations, the best alliances, to exploit the new opportunities of scale in the worldwide market. But cement and aggregates? Hardly a line of work where markets are likely to be much more than regional. Cement makers looking to rationalise their networks might be expected to find any savings in production weighed down by rising transport costs. Their cousins in the concrete game need to mix their product even closer to the customer. At the heavy end of the business, however, the globalisation bug seems belatedly to be biting hard. The last few months have seen a series of corporate moves: Anglo-American's agreed bid for Tarmac; RMC's successful offer for Rugby; Heidelberger's acquisition of Scancem and, most recently, the £3.4bn bid from France's Lafarge for Blue Circle. The Anglo-French battle is now entering its final stages. Lafarge has until the middle of next week to decide if it wants to increase its offer, although it is, predictably, playing its cards close to its chest. This hostile offer is slightly unusual for an industry that tends towards agreed deals, although the French group used similarly aggressive tactics when it snapped up the brickmaker Redland just over two years ago. But it is reckoned on the cheap side, with an offer of 450p, even £5 seen as more realistic. webTitle: New Tower of London  £600m landmark proposed

fields.headline: New Tower of London  £600m landmark proposed
fields.trailText: Europe's tallest office building will soar above London's south bank if a £600m project, unveiled yesterday , goes ahead, writes Dan Atkinson .
fields.body:
Europe's tallest office building will soar above London's south bank if a £600m project, unveiled yesterday , goes ahead, writes Dan Atkinson .

The London Bridge Tower is the latest in a line of controversial turn-of-the-century developments proposed for the City and its fringes.

This 1,200ft skyscraper would easily top Canary Wharf's 1 Canada Square, which dominates the east London skyline at 800ft, and outclass the Eiffel Tower in Paris, in height terms, which stands at 984ft. Worldwide, it would be the sixth tallest building.

But by the time planning permission is sought it will be the new London mayor and assembly who will have to give the project the green light. Ken Livingstone, is known to be in favour of more landmark buildings for the capital. But the precedent of the Millennium Tower - unveiled in 1996 by developer Kvaerner - is not encouraging; the scheme was withdrawn in the face of public opposition. Recently, the "erotic gherkin" - a novel office development suggested for St Mary Axe in the heart of the City - received a mixed reception.

Sellar Property, a privately owned developer, is leading the consortium to build London Bridge Tower on the site of a 1970s office block, Southwark Towers. Chief executive Irvine Sellar said: "From the point of view of meeting government criteria for development it fits in very well with that."

fields.headline: Bookham Technology
fields.trailText: The mettle of technology investors should be tested today when one of the more promising new issues, Bookham Technology, makes its debut on the London stock exchange and Nasdaq market.
fields.body:
The mettle of technology investors should be tested today when one of the more promising new issues, Bookham Technology, makes its debut on the London stock exchange and Nasdaq market.

The company, which makes fibre optic components, should give confidence to new shareholders and support the price at the top of the £8 to £10-a-share range.

First, Oxfordshire-based Bookham boasts a 10-year trading history, unlike many of its technology and dot.com cousins. It also has US technology group Cisco Systems, the networks group, and Intel, the chip maker, as shareholders.

Bookham is only offering 19.4m shares in its float but, at the top end of the pricing, the company could be valued at £1bn. The cash it raises will be used to expand its manufacturing operations and invest in new product development.

The excitement has centred on its technology which slashes the costs in manufacturing fibre optic components that sit on top of silicon chips. It has set itself apart from competitors which have relied on manually-assembled devices.

Yet even Bookham's solid shareholder base and market-leading product may not prevent it from suffering a fall given the volatile trading environment for technology stocks. In the past two weeks, shares in technology and internet related companies have tumbled following the Nasdaq's daily seesaw.

Lastminute.com and World Online have failed to stay above their issue prices, disappointing investors. Another hi-technology group Eyretel was force to cut the price of its share offering from an indicative range of 195p-240p back to 150p because of the turbulence.

Bookham's revenues are expected to grow at a compound annual rate of 260% between 1999 and 2001, from £3.5m to £161m, according to Goldman Sachs which is co-ordinating the float. However, like other technology companies it is loss-making with forecasts that Bookham will move into the black in 2001. A £19m loss is expected to be made this year on turnover of £25.1m.

Bookham takes its name from the Surrey village where chief executive Andre Rickman was born.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText: Virgin to bid for Great Western
fields.body:
Virgin to bid for Great Western

Britain's two largest train companies, Virgin and Stagecoach, are prepared to mount a bid for the Great Western franchise, the operator at the centre of the Southall and Paddington train crashes.

Their interest was revealed last night by Chris Green, Virgin Rail's chief executive, who said that as a provider of "high speed inter city trains, the companies were interested in all main inter-city rail franchises.

The franchise for Great Western, a part of First Group, which operates fast services between London, South Wales and the West Country, is not due to become available until 2006. However, there is a chance it might become available next year.

Great Western has an annual turnover of more than £200m

Renault and Volvo in swap

Renault and Volvo are reported to be in negotiations over a deal under which the French group would swap its truck business RVI for a stake of up to 20% in the Swedish company.

Earlier this year Volvo's bid for fellow truck maker Scandia was thwarted by the European Union's competition authorities.

A merger of the two truck businesses is seen as creating a group with sufficient critical mass to compete effectively while the cross shareholding would make Volvo - currently seen as vulnerable to a bid - a more difficult takeover target.

Greenpeace wins hearing

Environmental groups have won the right to ask BP Amoco shareholders to vote for abandonment of oil drilling plans in the Arctic. Resolution 12 on the agenda for Thursday's annual meeting (calls on the British oil firm to drop the Northstar project, BP's newest Alaskan oilfield, and channel the funds into its solar energy division. Greenpeace expects to lose the vote, but said yesterday that getting the issue on to BP's agenda for debate was a victory in itself.

Six of the best for co-op group

United Norwest, the country's second largest cooperative society, staked its case for continuing independence by delivering a sixth successive year of profits growth.

Pre-tax profits rose 65% to £38.6m, helped by exceptional gains on the sale of businesses. Trading profits were up 5% to £19.9m. Chief executive Martin Beaumont said the society had successfully shifted from superstores to corner shops, many branded as Late Shop.

Thomson family ups travel stake

The Thomson family has further raised its stake in Thomson Travel, which is facing a bid from Germany's C&N Touristic, to 22.7% from 21.3% through its Woodbridge holding company. Last week, the family increased its stake to 21.3% from 19.2% after C&N made a £1.3bn bid for Thomson, which rejected C&N's offer of 130p a share.

fields.headline: Paper politics
fields.standfirst: Sun-reading Tories are more likely to totally abstain from voting in the next general election than to switch to New Labour
fields.trailText: Press reports at the weekend suggested Labour is out awooing Rupert Murdoch with regulatory sweeteners for the sake of his newspapers' support (or at least non-opposition) at the next election. It is worth revisiting the "it was the Sun wot won it" assertion. Do newspapers significantly influence the voting behaviour of their readers?
fields.body:
Press reports at the weekend suggested Labour is out awooing Rupert Murdoch with regulatory sweeteners for the sake of his newspapers' support (or at least non-opposition) at the next election. It is worth revisiting the "it was the Sun wot won it" assertion. Do newspapers significantly influence the voting behaviour of their readers? Political scientists have done a lot of work in recent years but it is not merely an academic question. If newspapers do have political influence over their readers, then New Labour may have a problem at the next election, since its brief honeymoon with the Murdoch tabloids is over. There is also the question whether the referendum on Britain's membership of the European monetary union can be won.

A problem here is causality. Do Sun readers tend to support the Tories because of their paper's editorial line or because they were Tories to begin with and for that reason choose to read the Sun? This is a tricky question but the 1992 and 1997 general elections provide something of a handle on the problem.

Since the Sun's endorsement of Labour came only very late in the campaign in 1997 it is unlikely that this prompted many people to start buying it because they were already Labour voters. It is much more likely that any differences between the voting behaviour of Sun readers in 1992 and 1997 were explained, at least in part, by the change in the paper's alle giance. To be fair, the Sun's endorsement of New Labour was relatively lukewarm compared with its earlier ferocious opposition, but there should be a measurable effect if the newspaper was politically influential.

It is important to take into account the fact that even if the Sun's editorial stance had no effect at all on its readers' voting habits, we would still observe differences between Sun readers in 1992 and 1997, because other factors were at work in influencing their votes. Some of these other effects can be taken into account by comparing Sun readers with Mirror readers. If newspapers have a lot of influence, then differences in voting between Sun readers and Mirror readers should have narrowed in 1997 compared with 1992, since the Mirror remained loyal to Labour throughout. In other words the Sun's endorsement of New Labour should have made their readers behave rather more like Mirror readers. The two elections provide a natural experiment for examining this question.

The proposition can be examined by means of data extracted from the British election studies: large-scale surveys of the electorate undertaken immediately after polling day. The analysis in the table concentrates on the three major parties, and shows that 39% of Sun readers voted Conservative in 1992 compared with only 14% of Daily Mirror readers. In contrast, 30% of Sun readers voted Labour in that election compared with 63% of Mirror readers. Clearly there were large differences between the readerships of the two newspapers in the election. These differences cannot be attributed to factors such as social class either, which differ greatly between the Sun and the Guardian readerships, but which are very similar in the case of the Sun and the Mirror. Just over half these two tabloids' readers are in working class occupations, and only about 10% are in the professions or in management.

The table also shows that by 1997 political differences between the readerships of the two papers narrowed in relation to Conservative voting, but not for Labour voting. Thus support for the Conservatives among Sun readers fell by 16% between the two elections (from 39% to 23%) but by only 8% (from 14% to 6%) for Mirror readers. On the other hand support for New Labour increased by 8% for both papers, although it started from a much higher base in the case of the Mirror.

One noticeable change be tween the two elections involved readers who did not vote. About a fifth of Sun readers failed to turn out in 1992, but this increased to nearly a third by 1997. In contrast, the increase in non-voting among Mirror readers was a modest 4%.

So it appears that the Sun's switch from strong support for the Tories to lukewarm support for Labour had the effect of discouraging Sun readers either from voting Tory or from voting at all. It did not appear to encourage them to vote Labour or Liberal Democrat. This illustrates the point that newspapers are better at mobilising readers to vote (or abstain) than they are at changing their voting habits. Analysis by a team of researchers in 1997 confirms this result.

So what difference might this make to the next election? The answer is that it might be important and a thought experiment shows why. Imagine the Sun had not endorsed Labour in 1997 and this had the effect of producing changes in Conservative voting and abstention among their readers similar to those which occurred among Mirror readers. As a result Tory voting among Sun readers would have declined by 8% instead of 16% and non-voting would have increased by 4% instead of 11%. A quick calculation shows that in those circumstances the Tories would have got an extra half a million votes, assuming that the bulk of the non-voters were Tory supporters. Depending on where they lived these voters would have significantly changed the party composition of the House of Commons. The conclusion has to be that Labour does need a Sun or at least a Murdoch strategy for the next election.

Paul Whiteley is professor of politics at Sheffield University
