webTitle: Absinthe, morphine and the gates of hell

fields.headline: Absinthe, morphine and the gates of hell
fields.standfirst: Adrian Searle on the decadent world of art nouveau
fields.trailText: Adrian Searle on the decadent world of art nouveau
fields.body:
A few days ago I stood in a bar festooned with cardboard cut-out apples promoting a new designer cider, each apple framed by a century-old curlicue motif. A man stood beside me at the bar, his arms tattooed from wrist to armpit in snakes and roses, Viking dragons and angry eagles, all entwined in a writhing scroll of fanciful Celtic bands; a sinuous, hooked and seriffed trelliswork indelibly inked on to his 21st-century skin. I looked too hard and he looked back. This was not the moment to explain that, after visiting the Victoria & Albert Museum, where the exhibition Art Nouveau, 1890-1914 has just opened, one sees art nouveau everywhere: in the tendrils of ivy growing on a wall, in the poise of a girl smoking at a bus stop, on the bulging arms of an illustrated man.

The repressed always returns, and it was undoubtedly a kind of repression that gave birth to art nouveau. It was as sprawling, digressive and all-encompassing a movement as can be imagined, displaying itself in everything from a building to a brooch, in the gloomy, Nordic paintings of Edvard Munch and in the design of Tiffany table lamps. One might almost see art nouveau as a kind of pervasive, fin-de-siecle disease, which, indeed, it was. It infected and infested architecture, painting and sculpture; it found its form in furniture and in fabrics, in the flat, coloured planes of the popular lithographic poster, in jewellery, couture and hairstyles. It found its living embodiment in the dancer Loïe Fuller, who writhed and flounced and jittered about the stage in yards of flailing drapery.

The style was international, eclectic, easily identified, but almost impossible to define. Art nouveau crossed continents, media, wildly conflicting belief systems. It was decadent and utopian, pure and corrupt.

The V&A show gives us a glimpse of all this - from posters of morphine addicts injecting themselves to colour illustrations of sea anemones, from Viking-ship silverware to lampshades and chairs. We visit art- nouveau cities - Paris, Brussels, Helsinki, Glasgow, Munich, Vienna, New York and Budapest. The exhibition traces the roots of art nouveau in Japanese ceramics and woodcuts, and Moorish calligraphy, glassware, marquetry and joinery. The exhibition is as copious, marvellous and horrible as the style itself. I love it and hate it, all at once.

It was more than a style, more than a look. It was a mindset, a mentality, a style that had depth as well as an all-encompassing, self-multiplying and mutating breadth. How else to explain what it is that connects the complexity of forms, styles and materials that went into the design and building of Lluis Domenech i Montaner's Palau de la Musica in Barcelona and the four-square, Protestant sobriety of an art school in Amsterdam? Yet something connects them, both to one another and to a bookshop in Oporto, a hotel in Brussels, a Glasgow tea shop and the skylights of a pie-and-mash emporium in Hackney.

One of the attributes of the art-nouveau style was its contorted, deformed plasticity, its strange extrudedness and overwrought exoticism. The characteristic art-nouveau line coiled and climbed like smoke, sobbed and swooned like Arab violins. It fragmented into brittle little facets and tessellations. The style was excessive. Lively as art nouveau was - veritably writhing with life - it also, seen en masse in the V&A, strikes me as deathly, a style on the side of death. Little wonder H R Giger took art nouveau as a starting point for his designs for the movie Alien, and that the style was re-used in so many album covers and posters in the psychedelic, psychotic 60s.

A whiplash line, let's not forget, begins with a whip. Vitriol and morphine, absinthe and opium begat art nouveau's florid forms, as much as nature ever did (Antoni Gaudi, now en route to sainthood, was apparently a veritable walking pharmacy for much of the time). There's something morbid about so much here - Lalique's beetles and winged female figures, his dragonfly brooches which make you think of awful transmutations of the human and the insect worlds; Mucha's electroplated female heads, von Stuck's personifications of evil in female form, Munch's melancholy - haunted by fears of venereal disease - Guimard's Paris Metro entrances (beguiling gateways to Hell, in my view). How can one look at Belgian designer Phillipe Wolfers's Civilisation and Barbary - an ivory, silver and onyx confection, in which a good part of an elephant's tusk is wound about by a swan and a half-bat, half snake-like serpent - except as an extremely repulsive decoration, probably intended for some Belgian industrialist who had made a lot of money from the heart of darkness itself, the Belgian Congo? The exhibition's curator, Paul Greenhalgh, writes tellingly in the excellent, catalogue, "The Europeans occupied and to a considerable extent asset-stripped the globe. As they did so, they voraciously consumed the cultures of the world and made them their own."

This, in part, is what art nouveau came to represent, as the consummate art of conspicuous consumption. A view, in the catalogue, of Fyodor Shekhtel's main stairway from the dining room of the Riabushinsky mansion in Moscow is the stuff of nightmares. The curving staircase with its sea-swell balustrade is like a journey through the inner ear. The overall effect I can only describe as queasily decadent. Descending into the Paris Metro, through one of Guimard's station entrances, taking a coffee in a Brussels cafe, walking the streets of Barcelona, one is aware that art nouveau, the final efflorescence of the neo-gothic and the neo-rococo, the mannerist and the Moorish, needed to have its day, and needed to be replaced by something cleaner, straighter, something more rational.

Art nouveau, looked at, as it were, through the wrong end of the telescope of modernism, was a fascinating, fabulously excessive aberration. That we owe so much of our own, belated modernity to it, and to the reaction against it, that gave us clean lines and unadorned geometry, is not in doubt. It was a sort of devil's crucible, giving off poisonous fumes, just like a bowl of vitriol.

 Art Nouveau, 1890-1914, is at the Victoria and Albert Museum, London SW7 (0171-942 2000), till July 30.

I looked too hard and he looked back. One might almost see art nouveau as a kind of pervasive, fin-de-siecle disease, which, indeed, it was. It infected and infested architecture, painting and sculpture; it found its form in furniture and in fabrics, in the flat, coloured planes of the popular lithographic poster, in jewellery, couture and hairstyles. It found its living embodiment in the dancer Loïe Fuller, who writhed and flounced and jittered about the stage in yards of flailing drapery. The style was international, eclectic, easily identified, but almost impossible to define. Art nouveau crossed continents, media, wildly conflicting belief systems. It was decadent and utopian, pure and corrupt. The V&A show gives us a glimpse of all this - from posters of morphine addicts injecting themselves to colour illustrations of sea anemones, from Viking-ship silverware to lampshades and chairs. We visit art- nouveau cities - Paris, Brussels, Helsinki, Glasgow, Munich, Vienna, New York and Budapest. It was a mindset, a mentality, a style that had depth as well as an all-encompassing, self-multiplying and mutating breadth. fields.headline: Duet for an odd couple
fields.standfirst: Judith Mackrell sees modern dance and ballet leap into each other's arms
fields.trailText: Judith Mackrell sees modern dance and ballet leap into each other's arms
fields.body:
A gala at the Royal Opera House's Linbury Studio last week raised £25,000 for the rebuilding of the Place, London's prime centre for the teaching and performance of modern dance. It also made a small piece of history. This was the moment when the embattled students and workers of modern dance entered the stately home of ballet.

The classical world has tended to look down its exquisite nose at modern dance ever since its arrival in Britain in the mid-60s; the practitioners of modern dance were just as quick to dismiss ballet dancers as brain-dead throwbacks who were also shamefully overprivileged. While most members of the modern dance community worked for pennies in cramped and dirty rehearsal conditions, ballet companies appeared to luxuriate in a world of airy studios, permanent contracts and real money.

However, some of the early movers and shakers of modern dance were in fact ballet rebels - Michael Clark, one of the most high-profile, had been the most promising classical student of his generation until he opted for poverty and dissent. And over the years emissaries from both camps have begun to find more common ground. Royal Ballet choreographer Ashley Page says that the periods in which he has worked with fringe and mainstream modern groups have significantly influenced his art, while modern dance-makers like Siobhan Davies and Mark Baldwin have started to choreograph for classical companies. Individual dancers, too, have discovered value in each other's disciplines, to the point that some of the most bluntly modern companies now base their daily class in ballet, and the hit productions of Adventures in Motion Pictures star modern and classical dancers on the same stage.

And finally this year the Place has come to Covent Garden. For decades the grand, white stuccoed Opera House and the grimy red brick Place have symbolised the polarisation of the dance world. But since the ROH reopened with a new studio theatre and a new hip and friendly demeanour, it has welcomed outsiders. The Place has programmed a couple of its own dance events at the Linbury and, most importantly, leapt at the chance to hold the fundraising gala, Spring Fling, there.

Last Thursday's show produced moments of inspired concordance between the dance forms. Darshan Singh Bhuller (once the most famous male dancer on the modern stage) created a duet, Sita, for Irek Mukhamedov, one of the biggest names in ballet. With Mara Galeazzi, he showed how eloquently the refined curves of ballet could interact with the raw, physical mechanics of modern dance.

The programme also featured AMP's 1988 mini-classic Spitfire, in which choreographer Matthew Bourne notoriously crossed the harpy competitiveness of 19th- century ballerinas with the macho posing of male underwear models. There was also a revival of Harmonica Breakdown, a sinewy, passionate solo created in 1938 by Jane Dudley, who was once a performer with Martha Graham and came to teach at the Place back in the 60s. She is, at 87, still revered as the school's godmother.

The Place was also home to London Contemporary Dance Theatre, now down-scaled and retitled the Richard Alston Dance Company. The gala staged an extract from its 1977 repertoire, Robert Cohan's Forest. Even in excerpt, the choreography retains its enchantment, its feral sparks of activity mixed with drowsily sensuous body sculpture. This was one of the works by which Cohan and LCDT converted a mass public to dance, and someone should revive it for today's audience.

There was a feisty range of new talent, showing that the art form has lost none of its momentum: Akram Kahn, a serious, charismatic dancer, showed off the kathak/street-dance fusion he's made his own; Wayne McGregor, as long, lean and electric as the virtual bodies he incorporates into his live dances, defied the rules of physiology in a solo called Zero; Sean King and Susanne Thomas stood naked on the stage and executed a single hilariously timed pli. The dancers were well showcased on the Linbury's designer stage, but the Place itself is now some £675,000 and a few months short of its own inspiring new quarters. A kind of equality at last.

 Spring Loaded, the Place's season of new dance, continues till June 3. Box office: 0171-387 0031.

webTitle: A musical about rundown north London. In Leeds

fields.headline: A musical about rundown north London. In Leeds
fields.standfirst: Inner City Jam is a colourful portrait of King's Cross. So why couldn't it find a theatre in the capital, asks  Dave Simpson
fields.trailText: Inner City Jam is a colourful portrait of King's Cross. So why couldn't it find a theatre in the capital, asks Dave Simpson
fields.body:
What do you get when you put together one former EastEnder, a pulsating soul/R'n'B soundtrack and a cast representing the pimps, hookers, pushers, homeless people and struggling pop stars who permeate London's King's Cross? The answer is, an innovative piece of musical theatre.

The EastEnder is Paul J Medford, once known as Queen Vic tearaway Kelvin. Inner City Jam, his first production as director, is hard-hitting, at times grim, but always colourful. It seems tailor-made for large London audiences, so you might wonder, as I did, why the month-long run is in Leeds.

Last year, when Inner City Jam appeared as a fringe production at London's Cockpit Theatre, the critics loved it. Time Out praised its "show-stopping voices, spectacular dancing and great character acting". It is not uncommercial (it was once a smash on Broadway) but has been forced out of the capital because there is nowhere else for developing theatre to go. Like many productions, Inner City Jam is now too large for fringe but too small for the West End. So there might be a few red faces if Medford succeeds in his plan to ship Inner City Jam to the major theatres via Leeds.

The problem is less conservatism on the part of West End theatre than huge rents and the lack of subsidies. Bigger unsubsidised theatres won't take a risk on a relatively unproven project when a guaranteed blockbuster will pay the bills. Elsewhere, however, subsidies are more widespread and West Yorkshire Playhouse, where Inner City Jam appears, is forging a national reputation for innovative musical theatre. Last year's Deadmeat was set in a club and fused drum'n'bass and drama, while Carnival Messiah mixed reggae and Handel to rapturous reviews. And Spend Spend Spend, often touted as a "new" smash in London, was developed at the Playhouse almost two years ago.

"Thank God for regional theatres that are interested in development," says Inner City Jam's producer, Shezwae Powell, a New Yorker who has lived in England for 15 years but is still amazed at the gulf in theatrical opportunity in the capital. "It's ironic that you have to go out of town in order to get back into town. What London really needs is an 'off Broadway', where pieces can develop their way into the West End."

Inner City Jam aims to go beyond entertainment, providing a real insight into the reasons for the continued existence of an underclass. It is a risky production, not least because it involves no stars. There is little by way of plot, either. It fuses short stories and the experiences of its characters into a compelling portrait of how a society within a society perpetuates itself, with little chance of escape. When a drug addict "falls in love" with a pregnant teenager, it is because he fancies taking heroin in her cosy flat, rather than on the street. When a God- fearing mother devotes her life to protecting her son from the "wicked" local influences, he ends up getting hit by a stray bullet.

Inner City Jam is a personal crusade for Powell and Medford, who met while Powell was in Starlight Express. Both noticed that problems within theatre mirror society's lack of opportunity for black people. "It's better now, but the casting still tends to be a bit faddish, stereotypical," says Powell. "In the past the excuse was, 'There isn't enough good talent around' but how can good talent get better without practice and exposure?"

The project got under way when Powell gave Medford a tape of the original soundtrack - by Aretha Franklin songwriter Helen Miller - of the 1971 Broadway production of Inner City Jam. "I was on the Euston Road just passing King's Cross in a lot of traffic one rainy afternoon and one of the songs came on," says Medford, who was a member of Kid Creole & the Coconuts before joining EastEnders. "I just thought, 'Yes, this is really funky.' "

When the tape ended, Mary J Blige came on the radio doing a cover of Natural Woman by Aretha Franklin. "It all seemed like the same place. The 70s revival thing was happening and I just thought we could do the same with the musical. So we reworked the songs, orchestrated them, and left a couple of dodgy ones in for the comedy value. Voilà - musical theatre!"

They also relocated it to King's Cross, but as Medford explains, it could equally be any city with urban homelessness. "It could be Leeds. Most people here are familiar with King's Cross anyway, because if you travel to London by train that's the first thing you see. I grew up slightly fascinated by it, yes. The drug deals, the murders, but mainly the characters. These people knew how to scam innocent people coming in."

The pair financed the project themselves, partly thanks to a "dodgy" advert Medford did in Holland. "No nudity involved!" laughs Powell.

Some of Inner City Jam's content and dry black humour will be familiar to viewers of Granada TV's Band of Gold, and the films Mona Lisa and Trainspotting. The themes - homelessness, disenfranchisement, lack of real community - are sadly timeless but the production is hugely positive.

"It's a combination of MTV videos and soap opera," says Medford, a bundle of enthusiasm who still gets called Kelvin despite leaving EastEnders almost 10 years ago.

"I used to walk around London and see all these disused buildings that I thought could be used to help the homeless. Now I think the same thing about theatre. There are so many disused offices or warehouses that could easily be transformed into studios or middle ground theatres. Maybe that'll change."

A last infectious grin. "I hope so."

 Inner City Jam is at West Yorkshire Playhouse, Leeds (0113-213 7700), till April 29.

webTitle: A distinguished reign ends in ignominy

fields.headline: A distinguished reign ends in ignominy
fields.standfirst:
Tim de Lisle on the sacking of South African captain Hansie Cronje
Reaction in South Africa
Mike Selvey asks: Where now?
South Africa's captain sacked
How the scandal was exposed
Hansie Cronje profile
Matthew Engel
fields.trailText: Only yesterday, the cricket world was still rallying round Hansie Cronje. Justin Langer and Angus Fraser joined Bob Woolmer in protesting Cronje's innocence. Today, he has gone: sacked as South Africa's captain, out of the team to play Australia tomorrow, and perhaps out of cricket altogether. Of all the game's match-fixing scandals, this is the biggest. The longest-serving of the international captains, a devout Christian widely regarded as the most upright man in the game, Cronje is the last person you would ever have expected this to happen to. It is as if the Queen had been caught fiddling her expenses.
fields.body:
Only yesterday, the cricket world was still rallying round Hansie Cronje. Justin Langer and Angus Fraser joined Bob Woolmer in protesting Cronje's innocence. Today, he has gone: sacked as South Africa's captain, out of the team to play Australia tomorrow, and perhaps out of cricket altogether. Of all the game's match-fixing scandals, this is the biggest. The longest-serving of the international captains, a devout Christian widely regarded as the most upright man in the game, Cronje is the last person you would ever have expected this to happen to. It is as if the Queen had been caught fiddling her expenses.

Except that it's not quite that clear-cut. Cronje has not admitted to match-fixing. Overnight, he admitted to "being dishonest". Now, he has confessed to selling information to a bookmaker, for $10,000-15,000. That was during the triangular one-day series involving England and Zimbabwe, which South Africa won. So Cronje's claim that he never sold a game stands up - for the moment. Last week, it seemed inconceivable; this morning, it still seemed improbable. Now, well, you're not sure who to believe. It would help if Cronje had appeared at this afternoon's press conference himself, instead of leaving it to Dr Ali Bacher to speak for him.

It is an ignominious end to a long and distinguished reign. Cronje was not quite a great captain, but he was a very good one. He took over at the tender age of 25 - something that Mike Atherton, for one, found a daunting task - yet his authority was unquestioned. With Bacher and Bob Woolmer, he formed one of the great management teams. Bacher handled PR, politics and diplomacy, both internal and international; Woolmer supplied tactical imagination and innovation; Cronje was a rock, on and off the field, leading by example with his ungainly-but-effective front-footed batting, standing thunderously at mid-off and carefully nursing his two great new-ball bowlers, Donald and Pollock.

He argued with the UCBSA over quotas, but that didn't make him a racist. The two regular non-white players in the team both flourished under his wing. He helped turn Paul Adams from a novelty act into a proper Test wrist-spinner, and in New Zealand a year ago, he deliberately let a Test match die in order to give Herschelle Gibbs, newly promoted to open the innings, the chance to make a double-hundred. Gibbs never looked back, at least not until he dropped Steve Waugh on that fateful afternoon at Headingley last June.

Cronje could be inflexible and defensive, but captains are judged by results and his were excellent: he won exactly half his 54 Tests in charge, and lost only 11. He leaves South Africa in second place in the Wisden World Championship; briefly, when the table began late in 1996, they led it. His finest hour came in 1998-99, when West Indies played Tests in South Africa for the first time, and were hammered 5-0. Despite having to play a vast number of one-day internationals, he won nearly three-quarters of them. Cronje's team had everything except the ability to come through in the very tightest situations. In Australia in 1997-98 Steve Waugh called them "chokers" . It was harsh, and uncalled-for, but not exactly unfair. They lost that one-day series after dominating its early stages, a pattern that was to be repeated in England two summers running. First they allowed England, under Alkec Stewart, to come back from the dead and win a Test series 2-1, then, in the World Cup, South Africa were the best team early on, and the second-best one overall, yet did not reach the final, but went out, agonisingly, on a tie.

Cronje confessed to being haunted by that result - "I keep asking myself, where was that one run?" - yet he bounced back strongly. He lost Woolmer, and his own batting form, and was handled insensitively by a new chairman of selectors, yet he still won all four of South Africa's Test series in 1999-2000. Cronje lost the match, but won friends. Then he took his team to India, and, before the fatal one-day series, won a two-Test series 2-0 - India's first home defeat for 13 years.

That was an extraordinary result. But nothing like as extraordinary as this.

fields.bodyText: Only yesterday, the cricket world was still rallying round Hansie Cronje. Justin Langer and Angus Fraser joined Bob Woolmer in protesting Cronje's innocence. Today, he has gone: sacked as South Africa's captain, out of the team to play Australia tomorrow, and perhaps out of cricket altogether. Of all the game's match-fixing scandals, this is the biggest. The longest-serving of the international captains, a devout Christian widely regarded as the most upright man in the game, Cronje is the last person you would ever have expected this to happen to. It is as if the Queen had been caught fiddling her expenses. Except that it's not quite that clear-cut. Cronje has not admitted to match-fixing. Overnight, he admitted to "being dishonest". Now, he has confessed to selling information to a bookmaker, for $10,000-15,000. That was during the triangular one-day series involving England and Zimbabwe, which South Africa won. So Cronje's claim that he never sold a game stands up - for the moment. Last week, it seemed inconceivable; this morning, it still seemed improbable. Now, well, you're not sure who to believe. It would help if Cronje had appeared at this afternoon's press conference himself, instead of leaving it to Dr Ali Bacher to speak for him. It is an ignominious end to a long and distinguished reign. Cronje was not quite a great captain, but he was a very good one. He took over at the tender age of 25 - something that Mike Atherton, for one, found a daunting task - yet his authority was unquestioned. With Bacher and Bob Woolmer, he formed one of the great management teams. Bacher handled PR, politics and diplomacy, both internal and international; Woolmer supplied tactical imagination and innovation; Cronje was a rock, on and off the field, leading by example with his ungainly-but-effective front-footed batting, standing thunderously at mid-off and carefully nursing his two great new-ball bowlers, Donald and Pollock. He argued with the UCBSA over quotas, but that didn't make him a racist. The two regular non-white players in the team both flourished under his wing. He helped turn Paul Adams from a novelty act into a proper Test wrist-spinner, and in New Zealand a year ago, he deliberately let a Test match die in order to give Herschelle Gibbs, newly promoted to open the innings, the chance to make a double-hundred. Gibbs never looked back, at least not until he dropped Steve Waugh on that fateful afternoon at Headingley last June. Cronje could be inflexible and defensive, but captains are judged by results and his were excellent: he won exactly half his 54 Tests in charge, and lost only 11. He leaves South Africa in second place in the Wisden World Championship; briefly, when the table began late in 1996, they led it. His finest hour came in 1998-99, when West Indies played Tests in South Africa for the first time, and were hammered 5-0. Despite having to play a vast number of one-day internationals, he won nearly three-quarters of them. Cronje's team had everything except the ability to come through in the very tightest situations. In Australia in 1997-98 Steve Waugh called them "chokers" . It was harsh, and uncalled-for, but not exactly unfair. They lost that one-day series after dominating its early stages, a pattern that was to be repeated in England two summers running. First they allowed England, under Alkec Stewart, to come back from the dead and win a Test series 2-1, then, in the World Cup, South Africa were the best team early on, and the second-best one overall, yet did not reach the final, but went out, agonisingly, on a tie. fields.headline: Fortune finishes off battling Boro
fields.standfirst: Champions are stirred into four-goal riposte after Campbell's early strike
fields.trailText: Middlesbrough 3 - 4 Man Utd
fields.byline: David Hopps at the Riverside Stadium
fields.body:
Another Premiership title for United might look inevitable today but, if the rip-roaring encounter here last night is any guide, there will be plenty of fun and frolics along the way.

Eight points from their final six matches will suffice for United after this victory over Middlesbrough and their manager, Sir Alex Ferguson, said he intends "to get them as quickly as possible". He is a wise man. No heart could stand much more of this.

United began sloppily, like a team that believe their own publicity, but roused themselves like one that richly deserved it. Shaken by Boro's first-half challenge, they trailed to Andy Campbell's goal at the interval, scored three times as David Beckham galvanised them and then were shaken again in a madcap finale that brought three goals in the last four minutes.

"Middlesbrough just kept coming back at us," said Ferguson. "We did well to come out of that." Boro gambled on three strikers, a daring ploy considering United's gifted midfield quartet, but Bryan Robson's adventure was vindicated when Campbell, whose bite has just won a new four-year contract, gave them an 18th-minute lead.

Campbell fed Hamilton Ricard and tore through United's defence to volley Ricard's up-and-under past Mark Bosnich. Denis Irwin, who had played Campbell onside, was soon substituted as United sought to fortify the centre with the addition of Mikael Silvestre.

The goal infused Boro with a self-belief that had its origins in a seven-match unbeaten run. Paul Ince was so impassioned at the prospect of putting one over his former club that when Robbie Mustoe, lying injured, inadvertently prevented a quick free-kick being taken, Ince angrily shoved his startled team-mate out of the way.

It would have been 2-0 soon afterwards but for the referee. Paul Durkin's disallowing of Ricard's header from Christian Ziege's corner - presumably for Brian Deane's impeding of Jaap Stam - was so harsh that even United looked surprised.

United were below par, but even so Dwight Yorke and Andy Cole had spurned two of the countless good chances they created by half-time. Yorke, collecting Ryan Giggs's cross, failed to beat Mark Schwarzer from eight yards out when it was still 0-0, and Cole might have equalised just before the interval after Schwarzer had parried Paul Scholes's 20-yard shot.

That at least had the effect of fine-tuning Ferguson's half-time analysis. Sure enough, 59 seconds after the restart, United had equalised. Ince's clearing header from Gary Neville's long throw looked good enough, but Giggs fired in from the edge of the area.

United were reborn, with Beckham beyond compare for 20 minutes. When he stood over a free-kick 35 yards out, the question seemed to be whether he could bend the ball in from so far. A chip of the utmost delicacy over the wall, contested by Silvestre, finished with Giggs's shot scraping the far post.

The Brazilian Roberto Carlos, who remarked in Madrid last week that Beckham could not go past defenders, might have to reassess after the way he skipped between two Boro players in centre field to create United's second. Giggs supplied the decoy run, Cole the finish: an exquisite goal.

United were now rampant. Juninho headed off the line and Cole missed again but with 16 minutes to go Scholes, one of the few United players to exude sharpness all night, lashed in a third from 30 yards.

That should have been that. But Bosnich remains a liability under crosses. He failed to clear three successive corners and Ince finally bundled the ball over from a yard out.

Quinton Fortune restored United's two-goal lead - the linesman correctly, and perhaps uniquely, judging that Ziege had played him onside - but even then Boro would not lie down. Juninho drifted in from the left and beat Bosnich at his near post.
